text: Be advised that a particular seller (that claims to be the actual distributor for Baofeng) claims that their lower capacity 3600mAH generic battery will work with the UV-5RA radio - it DOES NOT.  It will work with the original UV-5R (of which I happen to own), but when I ordered more radios from this "distributor/seller" they switched my order from the original UV-5R to the UV-5RA unit (without any prior contact or approval) and then proceeded to ship generic lower capacity batteries (with that same order) that won't work with the new units that they (not me) chose to ship as (in his words) an "upgraded unit".  What good is an upgrade if the batteries shipped with them won't fit?In addition, when you (as an Amazon customer) point out their listing error (shipping a non-Baofeng battery, shipping a less than advertised 3600mAH model (vs. the actual Baofeng 3800mAH model that was advertised on the listing), and shipping an Extended Battery that won't work on the UV-5RA radios that they shipped with them in the same box), they claim that:a) Baofeng doesn't even make an Extended Battery (funny since I own several already with Baofeng Electronic's label on the inside of the case and Baofeng's name imprinted into the back of the plastic battery case), andb) if I'm not happy I should pay to ship my order back to them (this is how they treat a customer that ordered multiple radios, extended batteries, and programming cables all at once and paid over $117 in shipping fees?).I'll be out of town on business during the next few days, but when I get back rest assured that I plan on contacting Amazon and reporting their anti-customer and extremely RUDE behavior.  That's when I'll post their actual seller review, but I wanted folks out there considering what battery to buy to be aware of this seller's bait and switch tactics.The actual Baofeng OEM 3800mAH Extended Battery (offered by other sellers) works very well and in my opinion, is well worth the extra few pennies the "smaller" sellers charge vs. this "distributor in KY".The actual Baofeng battery also has a small DC jack in the case for what appears to be designed for a cigarette lighter charger/adapter, although I have not tried it yet.

Most folks that have a problem with these units simply don't understand how they are designed to work.They ARE NOT designed to work all over the FM dial on your radio, they are designed to work on only two frequencies on your FM radio - period.  Mine worked on either 88.9 MHZ or 106.7 MHZ.They WILL NOT work on AM or HD radio either, only FM.  The simple way to correctly (and easily) get them to work in your area is to sit in your car, truck, or van, turn on your FM radio and manually dial your radio to either of the two frequencies your Car Baby II unit supports (it usually 88.9 MHZ or 106.7 MHZ), but I have seen some that are different.This is the important part for all you non-technical folks, so pay attention.After you manually dial up both of the two frequencies that your particular Car Baby II unit supports, pick the one (of the two frequencies) that your FM radio has the least amount of interference with and program that frequency into one of your memory channel inputs in your car radio (my Jeep has 12 different memories, so it was easy to pick memory 12 as my "go to Car Baby" channel in the radio.Install the required AAA battery and turn on the unit.  Your FM radio should now magically have no interference as the signal from the Car Baby II unit will over-ride any local interference on that channel (assuming you've correctly followed directions so far).Now when I'm driving down the road listening to the radio and my phone rings I simply switch to memory 12 on the radio (by pushing one memory button) and like magic the Car Baby broadcasts the audio from my phone through my radio speakers.If you follow the instructions on the package (and read this review), you'll have no problem with this product, assuming of course you do follow the directions and use common sense (don't leave your phone in your purse in the back on the van or in the trunk and expect Car Baby to work for example).Don't laugh, I've had folks do both and then complain when the product didn't work how they "assumed" it would.  One previous buyer of the product thought that her car radio should constantly be scanning between AM, FM and her HD channels, find the Car Baby frequency automatically, and then switch her radio to the proper frequency when she had a phone call come in.  Sorry folks, but the current car radios don't have that magic technology (maybe someday), until then these sub-$20 devices work quite well if you learn how they are designed to work and then use them in that fashion.If all else fails, get a teenager in your neighborhood to install it for you and then show you how to correctly use the product.

You can pay more for a dual-band VHF/UHF antenna, but you'll be hard pressed to find a glass mount antenna that outperforms this one.  I've had one installed on my motorhome for two years and it still works great.  Plus it can be installed in about 5 minutes with no holes to drill.

Optimus has a winner with this extremely quiet unit.  Unlike many other brands that skip the more extensive cETLus approval rating (meaning the unit meets both Canadian and U.S. safety standards), Optimus has this approval rating, plus a three year factory warranty.The picture shown really doesn't do this unit justice.  The actual unit comes in a beautiful Cherry wood cabinet (suitable for any den, bedroom, or living room), plus the remote control allows you to completely control the unit's functions (not just "on or off" like some others).  Even the really large blue LCD display performs a dual function, since it not only is easy to see from a distance, it also acts as a night light (no more stepping on items left on the floor or the family pet) while getting into bed.The heater is instant on, which is probably helped by the actual copper coils used by Optimus (unlike some other units that merely coat their aluminum coils in copper).  My wife loves being able to stay under the covers on chilly mornings and turn on the unit from the comfort of our bed, wait just a minute, and get up into a much warmer room (this unit can kick out 1500 watts of heat in a hurry).I love the fact that it's cheap to run (around $1.00 a day) and I can easily roll it (when needed) into another area in our house.  You can even set the thermostat to have the unit kick on (or off) when room temperature reaches a certain pre-set temperature.One warning however.  This is not some cheap light-weight plastic unit that we've all seen before in various hardware stores.  Shipping weight is around 45 lbs. and the unit probably weighs around 40 lbs. sitting in your room, so if you're planning on getting one for your grand-mother you probably had better unbox it for her (or make arrangements for someone else to help her).  Of course once it's removed from the box, anyone can easily move it from room to room using the 4 built-in caster wheels in the base of the cabinet.Anyone that has a vacation home, an RV, or lives in an apartment without much insulation will love this unit.  I like it because my wife and I both get what we (she ??) wants.  She wants more heat, and I don't want to keep feeding money to the local utility company when she gets cold.

Many folks are quick to blame the Avery software or Avery templates for their printer problems, but most of the time it's not the software to blame but rather the old age of their laser printer's rubber rollers.  The older rubber roller's (that grab the paper or label sheet to feed the printer) have a much harder time getting proper contact with the clear sheet labels, which is why your laser printer can work perfectly with regular paper or white labels but go crazy when trying to print clear label sheets.The easiest fix to to check your printer's rubber feeder and if it's dirty or worn get it replaced.  9 times of of 10 that will fix your issues when printing on clear labels.

Far too often reviewers (that have very little expertise with a particular product or field) rant on about what they perceive is a failure of the product, when in reality it's not a failure of the product, it's a failure of the individual in not reading the manual, not following proper directions, or simply not checking for compatibility when purchasing the product.We see this all the time in the technical field, so often that we generally tell the customer (that's ranting on about how a product doesn't work when we know it does) that their hardware or software issue is called an ID-IO-T (pronounced I-D, I-O, T) error.  It makes them feel good, and they don't even realize that to the tech working on their issue ID IO T really means (idiot).That's not to say that some hardware or software doesn't work, but even then it's usually caused by somebody assuming that a 5 year old Windows XP version of software "should" work on his/her Windows 7 Pro 64 bit workstation.  Unless it states Windows 7 Pro compatible on the box, don't assume it works and most of your tech support issues will magically disappear.The same is true with hardware configurations as well.

First, let's clear up an issue with some folks writing negative reviews about this product (as it relates to the wet/dry claim).  The shaver works fine (in or out of the shower) so long as you are using it on DC power (batteries), which is why it's called a cordless shaver.  Only an idiot would stand in the shower and try to shave with ANY shaver plugged into 110V AC power, that includes this unit (which is why Emerson states their warnings about using it plugged in).  Honestly how some reviewers on Amazon downgrade their reviews on a product because the manufacturer is forced to remind idiots about safety is beyond me.Second, regarding the unit itself, as most folks (with an IQ of 100 or more) will tell you, this unit works as advertised.  For the money, it's hard to beat.  Will it outdo a unit from Braun or Norelco costing a hundred bucks more?  No, but do you really expect it to?  For the price, it's really hard to beat.  It's certainly a great backup unit (for work or travel), as I'd be mad as #$*^ if I left my expensive unit sitting in a hotel room, but if this one got accidentally left behind it wouldn't cause me to panic.

A small percentage of Amazon sellers continue to list non-Xerox Solid Ink Sticks under the actual Xerox OEM listings (instead of listing them under a compatible category).Perhaps they really think that it's Amazon's job to move their listings to the correct category (I've actually had one seller from TX tell me it's Amazon's fault that their cheap clone ink is listed under the Xerox part number and picture).More likely is that these questionable seller's think it's an easy way to trick buyer's into purchasing their clone ink and not wanting the hassle of sending it back when we discover the bait and switch upon opening the box.Several sellers also believe that simply listing the word "compatible" within their short description field is enough to avoid the problem, it isn't.  When a seller (by accident or on purpose), lists an item under the manufacturer's part number, uses the actual manufacturer's picture of the product, and the Amazon main page also lists within the main description field words like "actual, OEM, Xerox, genuine" etc.,etc., we buyers should be able to feel confident about what will arrive in the box within a few days.The latest trick a few sellers attempt is to simply claim they are now out of stock on the actual Xerox item (and they cancel the order through Amazon), but they would be happy to ship you "replacement" product that's "as good as" actual Xerox.What they don't seem to understand is that while they can cancel they order, if you wait around 10 days after the order is cancelled you can then leave feedback on your order (even when they cancelled the order).I encourage all buyers to take the time to leave feedback on seller cancelled orders (after waiting until Amazon finally allows feedback on those cancelled orders), since negative ratings are apparently the only way to get these questionable sellers to stop with their bait and switch sales tactics.I would also encourage Amazon to allow immediate buyer feedback when a seller cancels an order for any reason, instead of making us wait up to 2 weeks before the feedback option finally appears.  That's far too long (in my opinion) and simply allows most of the questionable sellers to continue to get away with bad business practices for an additional two weeks.

We are a small business that tends to do most of our marketing in-house in order to a) save money, and b) have greater control of our marketing.I've tried all different types of color printers (ink-jet's from Canon, HP, and Lexmark, colored power toner based printers from Brother, Canon, HP, Okidata, and Xerox, even a gell-based color printer from Ricoh).  They all have their individual pro's and con's, but most small business owners simply don't have the budget to have various pricey color printers on-hand to pick the one model perfect for each job, in other words, we have to understand that while it would be nice to have four or five different color printers available it simply isn't realistic for most of us.So what to pick?In our case, we wanted a color printer that could at least do legal size pages for some brochures, the Xerox 8560/DN model does that nicely.We also wanted a printer that didn't bend the pages much (if at all), again the Xerox 8560/DN model does that nicely.We also wanted the ability to automatically duplex print and be attached to our network (which helps share the cost among several users).  Again, the Xerox 8560/DN printer has those features built-in.We wanted a printer that has a great reputation for quality, which the Xerox 8560/DN has.  Now I know some folks that fill up their sport's car with cheap gas and oil and wonder why it doesn't perform to factory specs.  I'm guessing those same folks throw cheap clone wax cartridges into their Xerox printer and then whine constantly about color issues, color matching, print jams, etc.All I can tell you is that we've continue to use our Xerox Phaser 8550N, 8560/DN, and 8560MFP units virtually every day printing invoices, packing slips, quotes, marketing materials, etc., etc. Perhaps because we don't fill them with cheap clone ink products allows us to have virtually zero maintenance issues year after year, I don't know.What I do know is that the 8550/8560 color output looks fantastic for normal office work and smokes (speed wise) normal print output from powder toner products we'd tried (so far) and yes, that even includes Xerox powder toner based products.So if you are a graphic artist looking to print 11"x17" output for sale at a gallery, skip the Xerox Phaser 8560 line of printers.  Or if you are so tight with money that you'll shave crayons down in an attempt to refill your ink needs, skip the Phaser 8560 printer line, or if the noise from a business quality printer (that's built to last) is too much for you in your home library, then skip the Xerox Phaser 8560 printer line.The rest of us, however, appreciate how well these things are built, how fast they print, and how inexpensive they are to run year after year.  For the record, I don't work for Xerox and never have.
Very lightweight and flowy--great for super-hot summer weather.
Looks much longer/taller in the photo.  In reality, it's rather short and stubby and the design looks a bit squashed.  Will keep it for Halloween, but not everyday use.

This is my smaller (65lb) dog's favorite slow-feeder bowl.  The Dane prefers the round flower design, and neither dog really likes the spiral.In order to make this more dishwasher-friendly, we used a drill press to make drainage holes in the points where water collects when it's upside-down.  The holes are small enough to allow the water to drain, but not large enough to bother the dogs when they eat.  We've done this with all the slow-feeder bowls and it makes washing them much easier--and I know they're clean if I run them through the dishwasher with every use.  (Otherwise, there can be a little build-up from the dogs' jowls, and it doesn't come off as easily if I don't keep up with it every day.)

The version I purchased was not in English, but German.  (The publication language was not--and as of this writing, is not--listed anywhere on the page, but other versions had "German" right in the title as well as the item description and information sections.)  Not cool.

The setting is really quite pretty--intricate without being too busy, and the diamonds add some sparkle.  It's all exactly as it appears in the photo, including the opal, which is a shame because it's a very plastic-looking stone as compared to the more fiery opals I'm familiar with.  I'm giving the ring five stars because you do get exactly what is pictured, so I can't fault the seller for anything.  (It's my own fault for hoping that the photo didn't do it justice.) I'll replace the opal with another that has more fire, and I'll be perfectly happy since the setting really is just perfect.  Definitely a cocktail/going out ring, though--it's very high-and-wide, which makes it difficult to wear with rings on any adjacent fingers.  (For me, anyway.  As always, where fit is concerned, YMMV.)

Very nice assortment of patterns.  Doubly cool since they're reversible--even if you don't like one side, you might like the other.  The workmanship is pretty good.  A little thready here and there and a couple seams weren't quite finished, but considering the price, I'm not fazed by minor inconsistencies.Since one-size items can be tricky where fit is concerned, here's how they fit on two body types/heights:  I'm 5ft6, down to 155lbs, and wear average length jeans in anywhere from 8 to 12 depending on the manufacturer and style.  Hourglass figure--best fit is Curvy Skinny jeans by NY&Co.  Definite waist, but "baby got back," as well.  These are a great length if I tie them a bit below my natural waist.  If I tie them at my waist, they seem a little short as they just skim my ankles.  If I had less "junk in the trunk" the length might not be an issue if I tied them at my natural waist.  As far as coverage is concerned, I am happy to wear them around the house because they are *super-* comfy, but they're a little revealing if a stiff breeze opens the slit up the side of the leg.  To feel comfortable wearing these outside the house, I'd have to add leggings or bike shorts, and that kind of defeats the purpose of the comfy fit.  So:  I love love love these for lounging around the house or porch, but I won't wear them out anywhere.  Still a great deal on a very comfy product.The other tester is 5ft2 and just shy of 120lbs.  No booty or thighs, but a bit of a tummy.  These pants were just dragging the floor when tied at the natural waist.  Rolling the waist up a bit helped, but created a bulky waistline.
Gave as a gift to go with a little fold-up knitting/crochet accessory kit.  It was very well received.

This was given as a gift to someone who can crochet like a champ but who is only just learning to knit.  It went over very well, as many of the items are suitable for both crafts.  (I also added a yarn cutting pendant.)  Plans to take it to knitting classes.

Shipped Priority Mail in black velveteen gift box.  The posts are a *lot* longer than my other screw back earrings.  Probably won't be able to sleep in these as they are--will likely need to have the posts shortened and swap out the backs for the screw-on cap-style.  (They're less pokey.  I have five studs in each ear--1 cartilage, four lobe per ear--and I have always slept in them with no problems.). This pair is for the second-highest non-cartilage piercing in each ear.  The piercing above them is a pair of 1/4 carat (tw) studs, below them is 3/4 carat (tw), and the lowest (and largest) pair is 1 carat (tw).  In my opinion, this is the perfect size progression for quads.  (The cartilage piercings are usually captive rings, so they're not part of the equation.)As far as looks go, they're really beautiful stones.  Perfect everyday earrings.  Very pretty in the sunlight.

Very pretty in the sunlight.

I bought two of these bowls in the Henna pattern and couldn't be happier with them.  The size is perfect for anything from soup to noodles to tuna salad.  The chopsticks that came with them are twist-style (not the plain, traditional chopsticks that are currently pictured), and they're also very nice, but black lacquer chopsticks look good with the Henna print since it has a black rim.  One nice detail is the raised white dots that accent the designs; it gives depth to the pattern while adding texture to the bowls.  Oh, and they do just fine in the dishwasher.Great purchase--already looking forward to using these at breakfast (scrambled eggs work fine with chopsticks!) while sitting out on the porch now that the weather is warming up.Update:  I've had these for nearly 6 months now and they've held up really well.  I put them in the top rack of the dishwasher and they come out fine.  We've had everything from buldak noodles to scrambled eggs in these bowls, and the finish was not discolored by the sauce on the buldak.  (That stuff is evil.  Delicious evil.)  There is no crazing of the glaze, and no stress cracks.  We remain pleased with these and look forward to using them through the winter.

The good:  Unless you're right on top of this stuff, it looks super real.  Everyone who's seen it has been impressed with the image quality and the dramatic transformation (given that the walls were white, before).  The vinyl is textured, which makes the woodgrain effect even more realistic.  (I included a photo so you can see how it looks on a white wall, in both light and shadow.)This stuff is really pretty easy to work with, too--just don't peel off all the backing paper at once.  Only peel off a few inches at the top of the piece you're hanging.  Once you get the top aligned, you can peel away more of the backing and work your way down.  It is very forgiving, and I managed to cover my curved metal switch plate and outlet covers without even having to overlap it anywhere on the front of the plates.  It was easy to match up the pattern around the plates to make them blend in better.The roll arrived safely packed in bubble wrap, and the seller very thoughtfully included some useful little plastic smoothing tools for pushing out bubbles and getting the paper into corners.The less-good:  While this stuff is definitely durable, it is *somewhat* transparent.  I put it up on a painted, white wall, but there was a spot where the drywall paper and paint had peeled off which was much darker than the rest, and I ended up removing this wall-covering, painting over the dark spot and re-hanging the paper because the dark spot showed through so much.  I'd say that if your walls are not one solid color, you'll probably have the same issue.  While the print is "busy", dramatically darker or lighter areas (like, say, a big, dark waterstain or a white area of drywall patch) will show through to some degree.Overall:  I really love the look of this paper.  I was able to put it up by myself with nothing but the included smoothing tools, scissors, and an Xacto knife.  (And a screwdriver for the outlet/switch plate covers.)  Despite some uninspiring reviews of the seller's brick pattern paper (primarily involving the print not lining up over extended run), I had a positive enough experience with the pattern I chose that I decided to order some of the brick print and a couple others to brighten up the kitchen backsplash and do a couple accent walls in the diningroom.  I'm very pleased with how the room turned out, and I'm optimistic about trying the other patterns.

Nice variety--2 each of 5 flavors.  We've had 3 of these before, but I can't find the other two of their own.  Pricey for instant soup, but we don't eat them every day so it's okay for an occasional lunch or snack break.

While these are very pretty, at least two of the four cups in the set have a hairline crack that allows tea to seep slowly down the side of the cup to pool around the base.  The cups appeared to be in perfect condition when I unpacked them, but the cracks are visible once tea gets in them, as it stains the inner porcelain brown and makes the crack(s) easily visible.  Since I have used these cups I can't very well return them, so I ordered a second set and am hoping for the best.  If the next set is also unusable, I'll take this down to 1 star and there won't be a third try.Update:  Received the second set of teacups yesterday and they are all in perfect condition.  Ran them through the dishwasher (top rack) and tried them again, and they are still water-tight and unblemished.In order to make something good out of the two cups with hairline cracks, I decided to repurpose them by lining them with blue sticky-back felt and using them to hold my glasses on my desk and on the bedside table.  They're very pretty, and the felt keeps my glasses from getting scratched.  Not ideal, but perfectly useful--and I won't be terribly upset if they break since they're already on borrowed time.Overall, a decent purchase if you're okay with the risk.

These are great go-withs for blue-and white dishes.  I have a sushi set with a similar pattern and these look very nice with it.  They also look good with the various Japanese blue-and-white patterned bowl and teacup sets that are around here on Amazon, and/or populating import stores.  Don't let the size put you off--you really can do a lot with these dishes.  They can hold sauce (of course), but they can also function as a salt dish, hold wasabi or pickled ginger, or even a few pats of butter.  They make a nice little teabag caddy, too, if you have similarly decorated teacups.  I'm sure I'll find even more uses for them over time.(Since people have asked about it: they seem to do just fine in the dishwasher--top rack only, in the small-items caddy.)

So glad I tried this!  This flavor is not included in the Flavor Lovers assortment so I was curious about it, but not sure if I wanted to risk buying a whole box.  It kept taunting me (because the Bananas Foster is soooo good!), so I just went for it.  It's really lovely.  Not as intensely apple-y in the way that the Bananas Foster is banana-y, but that's probably the "a la mode" coming through.  Definitely a keeper.  (Still wish the Crazy Cups folks would get on the Decaff bandwagon.  They make some awesome dessert favors, but the caffeine makes them inappropriate for a late night treat.)UPDATE:  They got on the bandwagon!  Best selection of decaf dessert flavors *ever*.  Love these guys.

Phone-wise:  This is a pretty decent little wristlet for the price.  It easily holds an iPhone 6 in the Apple-endorsed Tech21 Evo Mesh impact-proof case.  (I can't say whether it holds the 6 Plus or not--I bought it so I would have room for the 6 in its impact-proof case.)Pros/cons:  The snap is tight (requires a bit of aligning sometimes, but it does stay closed), the materials are not shabby (it's not leather, but it's not plastic-y like some other low-end wristlets), and the chain is not plastic, either.  The zipper isn't the greatest, but it's easy to use and doesn't open by itself.  The cards-and-cash pocket area that zips is WAY roomier than I thought it would be.  I had a ton of cards, a slim credit-card sized emergency phone charger, a super-short charging cable for the iPhone, and a small pen in there.  So yeah--it won't fit the contents of a purse, but it holds more than my Vera Bradley All-in-one wristlet.Bottom line:  I would totally buy another of these in a different color or print, but the black/pink is the only one I liked.  Would give as a gift, would recommend to a friend looking for an inexpensive cell phone wristlet.

I *love* this case.  It is a great alternative to the origami cases which are certainly durable and flexible, but don't offer a lot of variety in terms of looks.  I ordered an iPad Mini case in the same pattern from a different vendor, but it was defective.  Twice.  So when I ordered this case I really had my fingers crossed and hoped for the best.  And I got it!  So, so cute for Spring.

I admit I was really surprised that my iPhone 6 fit in this wristlet--let alone the 6 in its Tech21 impact-proof case.  This wristlet/wallet is very slim-and-trim.  I can fit my ID, insurance card, four credit/debit cards, 3 punch-cards (business card sized coupons that are stamped or punched out every time you go to a shop, and redeem when all the slots are filled) and a bit of cash.  Any more than two credit cards to a slot, or too much cash/receipts and I can't always get the flap to snap shut.It's a shame that it arrived damaged.  The only good part is that the scrape is under the flap, so it's hidden most of the time.  I just keep reminding myself that you get what you pay for.Bottom line:  cute, cheap, holds my iPhone 6 in the impact-mesh case without struggling to get it in and out of the phone pocket, and holds enough of my essentials that I can grab it and go, or change to a different wristlet pretty quickly.  I don't regret the purchase at all, and would probably try my luck with a different color if I liked any of them well enough.  Perfectly nice little wristlet/wallet for the cost.

These are seriously cute shoes--just right for Spring and Summer.  That said, I have to acknowledge that they're pretty pricey for what comes in the carton.  (They come in a milk-carton style shoebox, which is also very cute.)  Without being judgey, it seems like what you're paying for when you buy these is the cute, chic fabric designs.  And really, that's it.  Because these shoes have no leather uppers, super-cushiony linings, or molded, impact-reducing heel cups;  no waterproof this, suede that, or ergonomic the other thing.  They're flat Mary Janes with a roomy, squarish toe box, a silvertone buckle, and silky fabric uppers stitched to a thin rubber sole.  And, of course, they're completely adorable.When I got my first pair, it took me a couple days before I realized that they're freakishly similar to the embroidered silk Mary Jane flats I used to buy at a Chinese import store near my workplace when I was in college.  They were just like these except that the toebox was round.  They came in silk or cotton, and they cost about $10.  The silk was really gorgeous for the price--perfect for a poor college student--and the embroidery made them look like a million bucks.  But sadly, like all cheap things, they never lasted very long.  If it rained, the silk showed every drop, and the color bled if your feet got sweaty.  And now, whenever I look at my feet, I am reminded that my super-cute Hot Chocolate shoes are so very, very like those cheap, Chinese import store shoes in almost every respect but price.Pros/Cons:  The soles are very thin, but flexible.  The footbeds have -0- arch support, but since they are roomy and the strap is adjustable, I wear arch support insoles with them and that makes a huge difference in comfort.  If you use orthotics with a highly cushioned heel cup that raises your heel up too much, you might have issues with the way these shoes rub your Achilles tendon.  The prints and patterns are, of course, super cute, to which there is no down side.  The toe box is very roomy, the stitching seems tight, and they seem to hold up well in a purely mechanical sense.  Aesthetically, however, you need to baby these shoes a bit to keep them looking good--especially the paler designs.  (They really seem to show dirt/scuffs, and the silky fabric doesn't wipe clean as easily as leather or fake leathers do.)So, with all that considered, why did I give them 5 stars?  Because they're just that freakin' cute.  Bottom line, I guess, is that if you go in knowing what you're getting for your money, you'll probably give these shoes 5 stars, too.

Hikari soups are great!  Convenient and tasty.  If you've wondered whether the Miyasaka soups are just as good (or better), here's a brief comparison.Hikari and Miyasaka soups consist of the same ingredient set:  one packet of miso paste and one of dehydrated/freeze-dried veg/seaweed/etc.  (The Kikkoman soups are simply one small packet of powdered miso that includes what seems to be a lesser quantity of additional ingredients.) Both Miyasaka and Hikari have 8 servings per bag, but the rest of the numbers is where they start to differ.  If you care about this stuff, here's how the Hikari wakame soup measures up to Miyasaka's wakame:Hikari: 17.4g miso paste and 2.1g garnishMiyasaka: 20g soup base (miso) and 2g garnishBoth recommend around 2/3 cup of water.  Hikari--5-6oz, Miyasaka 2/3 cup.Calories/fat calories:  Hikari--35/10.  Miyasaka--30/5.Both brands show 1g of fat:  both brands show saturated and trans fats at -0-.Cholesterol:  both -0-.Sodium:  Hikari--770, Miyasaka--840.Total Carbs:  Hikari--6g (>1g fiber, 2g sugar).  Miyasaka--4g (>1g fiber, 4g sugar).Protein: Hikari--2g, Miyasaka--3g.The vague takeaway there seems to be that Hikari goes heavier on the fat and lower on the sodium while Miyasaka does the opposite.  Which probably explains why I have a slight preference for the Hikari over the Miyasaka--particularly the green onion.  (While I use the Kikkoman soups, too, it's generally only for convenience as a take-along.)

The DH has some serious allergies; you name it, he reacts to it.  Animal dander, every pollen you can think of, mold spores and mildew--the lot.  He's not a great sleeper to start with, and (this is totally my fault) to make things worse, I have always let my dog sleep on the bed.  And the cats.  And since they were here first, I needed to make everybody as comfortable as possible.  This involves a LOT of regular laundering of bedding and throws, as well as having an air filter/cleaner/purifier of some kind in every room of the house (including an ozone-producing unit specifically for the Cat Genie litter boxes).I put this unit in the corner farthest from his side of the bed and generally run it on the highest setting when we're not in the room.  At night, I turn it down to about the third-lowest setting to make it quiet enough for us to sleep.  And let me say this:  when you first fire this thing up, is sounds like a jet engine preparing for takeoff.  It is *super* loud on the highest setting, and it moves a LOT of air.  When you stand next to it while it's going full-blast, you know how a pigeon might feel if it gets too close to a Boeing 737.  When you turn it down to the lowest setting, it's proportionately very, very quiet and (of course) doesn't move very much air.Within the first couple days of use, the DH was sleeping better and wasn't going through a half a box of tissues and Benadryl while reading before bed.  (And that's with random cats and the dog on the bed, too.)The proof is in the sneezing, really, and in this case, it's a significant improvement.  An added bonus over the last unit I had:  I guess this one moves a LOT more air, because I find that the temperature in the room is more even as opposed to warmer near the radiator and chilly on the opposite side.  This unit is moving the air so thoroughly that it's actually evening out the warm/cold spots.  Sweeeeeet.Pros:  Effectively relieves allergy symptoms for better sleep (presumably related to animal dander and pollen/mildew), you can clean the pre-filter, it moves a *lot* of air on high, very quiet on lower settings, the light is not bright enough to bother us while we're sleeping, long cord, unobtrusive design.Cons:  The base feels incredibly cheap given what it's supporting.  I find the unit to be a bit unstable, and it wobbles a bit when we walk by (historic house, old floors have a lot of give) which is alarming.  I'm always worrying that one of the cats will knock it over and it will come partially unplugged, so I have left generous slack in the (thankfully long) cord.  When it's on the highest settings, it is *incredibly* loud.  Not that you have to be in the room with it the whole time, but just be prepared--if you have one of these, you know that the jet engine comparison isn't really a joke.At the time I was first considering buying this, the reviews were largely not by verified purchasers.  I don't know about you, but this tends to say "buyer beware."  Still, I looked around and figured it was worth a shot.  It's only been a matter of weeks, but so far, Cons aside, I have few complaints.

Bought these to match the case on my Kindle Fire HD 7" after the first retractable charger I bought met a bad end.  When I went looking for a new one, I saw this set and decided to go for it.  I use the longest one for reading-while-charging, the middle one by the sofa for reading/overnight charging, and the retractable for travel.  No complaints so far--everything seems tight and well-made, and the price for all three ($12.95 + $2.98 s&h when I bought them) is more than decent.

Excellent snack for chocolate cravings without the sugar hit of candy.  Yes, they're sweetened, but the sugar/fiber ratio is a decent offset:  9g sugar per serving, and 5g fiber plus 3g protein.  9/5/3's really not that bad a profile.Regarding the taste, I think that liking dark chocolate with a high cocoa content helps.  I love barely-sweet chocolate, and I think these are great, but the DH likes milk chocolate best and it took him a while to fall in love with these.  Now he keeps them in his desk and divides the 1oz serving up throughout the day for a quick buzz.  I've bought them in a larger bag elsewhere, but they don't last forever.  These little bags are still the most convenient form.

It's as comfortable as a hoodie, but the collar and the fitted/princess cut class it right up.  The zippers are metal, not plastic, and the sleeves (as on all the Patty items I own) are a generous length.  To be fair, I'm kinda short at just under 5'6", but I still like the length.  There's no band around the bottom, so it moves well even though it is longer on me than it is on the model.  Looks good zipped partway or unzipped, but given the high collar you probably won't want to zip it all the way up unless you find yourself in the middle of a sandstorm.Washed on cold, gentle cycle, inside out and zipped, dried on Extra Low.  No shrinking that I could detect and the shape stayed true.

This is SO sheer it's not even funny.  If the model was wearing it layered over a tank or something I could see it being an honest representation, but there is no way anyone could wear that without a bra or something under it--it's a *very* loose knit.  However: the band around the lower 1/3  of the arms and the bottom is super tight.  The bottom band has a row of buttons that run the length of it, and they are not for show--you can actually unbutton them, and that is the only way I could wear this sweater because it was so constricting when walking.  (I'm a little under 5'6", and this sweater is tunic-length on me, coming down about five inches onto my upper thighs.  This isn't going to be an issue for the model or taller folks, but between that and the sheerness of it, it's not a keeper.)Pros:  Kind of soft; really nice, unique grey-green color; can hand wash as opposed to having to dry-clean (although it's an option).Cons:  See-through, not flattering, tight band around the bottom that might not be very comfortable for shorter folks--even if they like the length.  It just... It just feels pretty cheap for $40.  I don't know what else to say.

Bought this because it's the closing track in Princess Jellyfish. It wasn't available last time I looked for it, so I was super happy to see it when I was trolling Amazon for anime themes last night.There's another version available, too (an anime compilation listing the artist as "Anison Project"). That version is 3:41, while this one is 1:54. (I bought both.) This one seems to be the the cut version that runs into and during the Princess Jellyfish closing credits while the other seems to be the uncut version. (At least, I'm pretty sure that's the difference. According to YouTube, the runtime on the closing credits is around 1:30, and that's *without* about 25-30 seconds of the "Love is coming back" bit and the musical lead-in to the primary lyrics, which would account for the difference.  Both versions include the intro.)Such a cute song! (And a cute show, too.)

Bought this because it's the closing track in Princess Jellyfish.  It wasn't available last time I looked for it, so I was super happy to see it when I was trolling Amazon for anime themes last night.There's another version available, too (listing the artist as "Team Akihabara").  That version is 1:54, while this one is just over 3:40.  (I bought both.)  This one seems to be the full-length track while the other seems to be the cut version that runs into and during the Princess Jellyfish closing credits.  (At least, I'm pretty sure that's the difference.  According to YouTube, the runtime on the closing credits is around 1:30, and that's *without* about 25-30 seconds of the "Love is coming back" bit and the musical lead-in to the primary lyrics. And btw, both versions include the intro.)  While this particular compilation credits the composer/arranger (Yamaguchi Takashi), it doesn't credit the artist, which Google tells me is Sambomaster.Such a cute song!  (And a cute show, too.)

Wore this coat for the first time this morning, and it's a total keeper.  When it arrived a couple days ago, it was somewhat loosely folded in a plastic bag.  I took it out ASAP and hung it in the closet to let the wrinkles hang out.  This morning, it appeared to be de-wrinkled.  (Maybe the black fabric hides wrinkles better than the grey?  I don't know, but it looked fine to me.  If it arrives packed in with other things and it's super-wrinkly, you might want to hang it in the bathroom through a few showers and see if the steam helps--it always worked with my old peacoat.)It was 25 degrees this morning, so I wore it over a light sweater with a scarf and gloves.  I was definitely warm enough, but if I'd been standing around or if it had been windy, it would have been too light.  (There is no insulating liner--just the usual shiny, synthetic fabric lining to make it look finished.)  This is not a coat for the coldest, windiest New England weather, but the cut is easy and it's great for layering.  Goes nicely with jeans, slacks, or a longer skirt--very versatile.  The material is soft and moves very well--not stiff or scratchy at all.  It was also comfortable when driving--it didn't bunch up behind me and make the drive miserable.It closes with two large concealed snaps, and they seemed very tight when I pulled them open the first time.  The belt (which is super long, IMO) is made of the same fabric and two side loops to keep it in place.  It's a tie-style belt, and I had trouble getting it tight enough to look good without the knot looking ugly, so I gave up and just looped it over itself once and let the snaps do the work.  I'm told it looked fine, and it stayed in place throughout the walk and the drive.Overall, it was very comfortable.  I felt good wearing it, and everyone had to touch it (to see if it was scratchy wool, or not), and then wanted to know where it came from when they felt that it was more like soft, strong fleece than itchy wool.And for size reference, I'm 5'6"/165, and the XL fit very easily with room for layering.  (I could probably get the Large and it would look perfectly fine, but it definitely wouldn't be as comfortable and I wouldn't be able to wear it over anything but eveningwear or single-layer tops.)

Pros:  There's no two ways about it--these sheets are super soft.  Even the ever-stoic DH had to admit they're comfy.  I washed them after they arrived, and true to the description, there was very little lint in the lint trap of the dryer when they were done.  Also, they lost none of their softness after washing.  The King size sheet set fit the pillowtop mattress perfectly, and the top sheet was large enough to turn over a bit at the top, tuck in at the bottom, and hung down the sides far enough to reach the top of the box spring.  Also holds heat nicely--paired well with heated mattress pad, thermal fleece blanket and bedspread.Cons:  I wish there was an option to buy additional pillowcases.

This dress is everything I have come to expect from Patty products.  The cabling is gorgeous and tight, the fabric is heavy enough to be warm but light enough to move, and the fit is very flattering (and I'm a bit under 5ft6 and 165).  The first thing the DH said when he saw me in it was, "Oh!  That looks really good!  Is it new?  Because I think I'd remember if I'd seen it before."  (So cute.)This dress does loosen up a bit with wear.  When I first put it on, it fit like a glove and I thought it was just a bit too tight to be flattering.  After cooking doing some morning chores, making breakfast and startng some laundry, I noticed it had already loosened up a bit (particularly the bottom hem) and lower sleeves, (which I had pushed up to cook).  I think that if you find it a liiiiiiitttlllle tight at first, you just need to break it in a bit and it will be your new best friend.  I'm going to order it in black, too.  (And maybe one more of each so I'll have a couple for slouching around the house and a couple for going out.)

While the plot is a classic trope of the romance genre (rich aristocrat falls for working woman struggling to stay afloat) the art and choice to have the FMC as a chef and restaurant owner are novel enough to make it interesting.  It's also set in France, so the backgrounds and architecture are very charming.  Nice, sweet, quick read.

Lacklustre dialogue, mediocre art, uninspired plot.  Nothing about this sticks out except Sally's stutter, and even that was a throwaway "flaw" to keep her from becoming too Mary Sue.  I realize that the genre is not exactly high art, but judging this piece against a body of its peers, it remains just another manga-style romance.

A lot harder than I thought it would be, but surprisingly comfortable.  The cutouts are definitely in the right places, but you might have to shift around a bit to find the best way to sit, depending on your needs.  This cushion has been a real boon after these last couple surgeries (Bartholyn cyst marsupialization and excision).  I wouldn't be able to sit at my desk without it.  I still can't sit up for extended periods, but it makes the experience a LOT more comfortable, and allows me to do a bit of work and keep my desk tidy instead of watching bills pile up and trying to pay them on the lap desk on the sofa.  (it just feels wrong.)You might want to treat the washable cover with some care.  The fabric is a stretchy synthetic blend, so I wash it in a lingerie bag with similar items on the Delicate cycle and dry it on Extra Low.

Nice, cheap wireless BT headphones with easily learned controls, good battery life, decent sound, and comfortable ear surrounds.  I bought a case for them, as well, so they'd have a safe place on my headboard.  (I generally use them for listening to music or media in bed without disturbing the DH.)

I also have Bose in-ear noise canceling headphones.  They are more comfortable, but wired, and I wanted a wireless set and these fit the bill.  Sound quality is quite nice, which one expects from Bose products, and the microphone is handy for taking phone calls.  So far, there have been no complaints about how I sound to the people I've talked to that way.  Also bought an after-market case and a retractable charger.  Overall, I was pleased enough to buy the same set (headphones, case, and retractable charger) for the DH as a Christmas gift.

Holy heck this one is long!  I love Patty products, but this one was just waaaaaay too long for me at just shy of 5ft6.  (I gave it to an even shorter friend to wear as a sweater dress, and she loves it.)  Everything else was excellent, including upper body fit, construction, and fabric quality.

Quick tip:  you can buy the three-pack of these (one pack of three boxes) and *easily* fit all the packets of cider mix into just one box.  I do it all the time to save cabinet space.  So don't be afraid to buy the three pack!  :)
Bought these to stir and add flavor to hot chocolate, apple cider, and coffee.  Both quality and quantity are excellent.  Will definitely buy these again.

I bought this because it includes the theme from the Parasyte: The Maxim anime.  Haven't listened to the rest yet, but the disk itself arrived intact, seems undamaged, and the track I was interested in is now a part of my iTunes library.  No complaints.

I first read Ian Fleming as a teenager well before James Bond had become a cultural icon associated more with film than Fleming's books. I recall that my friends and I read these books and felt a self satisfied sense of being grown up and sophisticated when reading the Bond novels. So here I am 50 years later deciding to pick up Fleming again and I must say I was immediately struck by the quality of this very first James Bond book Casino Royale. It is still a page turner and suspenseful action novel. Here Bond emerges as a more introspective and complex character than I perceive the film versions to have ever captured. Although the cold war setting of the plot risks being dated, for me it felt vaguely familiar like a good historical novel should. Fleming was a master of pace and his story moves quickly from suspense to action and back. Another aspect I found fascinating after so many years is that many of the features that must have seemed so exotic to readers in the 50s and 60s ( The food, the French Riviera setting, cars, wine, even the casino itself) are now elements that are much more commonly experienced and understood by a broader public I devoured this and thoroughly enjoyed it. I expect to start working my way through the series and even revisiting some of the older films.

In a style that combines the right amnount of detail within the grand scope of the age of Portuguese exploration and expansion, Mr Cliff has produced a fine enthralling account of Vasco da Gama's role in the exploration of East Africa and India by Europeans.It is rare to read a work of history and be caught up and absorbed in it as if it were a novel, almost disappoinnted to have finished it. That's how well written and exciting The Last Crusade was for me.Cliff's theme is that the Portuguese explorations were intrinsically tied to the struggle between Christianity and the Islamic world with long reaching historical ramifications that extend to the present day. He makes his case effectively and enlightens and entertains while doing so. I absolutely loved this book and highly recommend it.

David Mitchell's thoughts and musings on just about everthing in modern life is entertaining. I read it in bits and pieces over time and it works as a series of humourous reflective essays so its not necessarily required to read it cover to cover at a single go. Mitchell's rants make me laugh and he has a knack for turning a phrase that makes reading him always worthwhile. Far from a masterpiece but this is an entertaining read.

In Scoop Evelyn Waugh combined his own journalistic experience covering a foreign war with an hysterical case of mistaken identity to great comic effect. William Boot is a country wildlife writer who is unwittingly mistaken for his namesake who has tried to use his influential Aunt to get a post on the newspaper The Beast. William is dispatched to Ishmalia to cover the revolution there and while the professional reporters are off on wild goose chases he stumbles on the big scoop. Waugh is always funny but in Scoop there are so many sub plots that add to the humor. This is a great novel and the theme is as relevant today as it was then.

Lanchester's novel is grand in scope and he has a wonderful ability to get inside the heads of an incredibly diverse number of characters. In Capital he is pursuing numerous story threads involving a cast of unrelated people who's only common thread is their connection to a specific residential street in South London. Rich and poor, established or recent immigrant , Lanchester's gift is to tell their individual stories in such compelling and believable terms that each short chapter reads like a vignette or short story on it's own while still contributing to the whole mosaic feel of the novel.There is much to recommend this book as a snapshot of life in modern urban London. In some ways it is like a modern version of a Dickens novel. While exploring the plight of the various waves of humanity that have made London their home ,whether by choice or not it maintains a sense of humor and entertains the reader on several levels. Great book.

A remarkable film set in post war Rome with a cast of non-professional actors. Centering on a pensioner struggling to get by with his dog , as his mean spirited landlady threatens him with eviction ,the film is a classic of Italian cinema from this period. It is relentless in it's depiction of a man losing his dignity and identity as he sinks into desperation. Not the most uplifting of stories but so humanly compelling and unforgettable. In one scene where he considers begging on the street you see a man struggling with his sense of loss in such intimacy that you are pulled by the heart into the story.Tragic, sad and unforgettable fim making.

Written toward the end of his long exile from his native Austria during the war years, Zweig's portrait of Erasmus while fascinating on it's own merits clearly has a touch of autobiographical reference from Zweig as well.His story of Erasmus' life and work focuses on his essential humanism and his dream of a united and peaceful Europe on the eve of the reformation much as Zweig dreamed of the same before the rise of fascism 400 years later. The comparisons continue with both men being exiled from their native countries and being confronted with growing violence precipitated by a new ideology.Apart from those self references that can be read into this work, Zweig gives us the conflict between Erasmus and Luther in clear terms and the relative importance of these two men with very different approaches to reform is portrayed as central to the drama of the unfolding reformation and the violent upheavals that grew from it.Stefan Zweig is a masterful biographer and this book is no exception. Not easy to find but an incredibly rewarding read.

Following Stefan Zweig through the years in which the Nazis were gaining power forcing him to leave his beloved Vienna and seek asylum abroad allows the author to examine not only Zweig's personal circumstances but also his place in a network of Exiles in both Europe and the Americas during this tumultuous time. Zweig's inner struggles with living in Exile are related through reference to his own excellent autobiography The World Of Yesterday as well as correspondence and interviews. I've rarely read anything about these years from the perspective of those who escaped the Holocaust with such a depth of feeling and understanding of the combination of restlessness, grief for what was lost and guilt for having left others behind. The author is the descendent of Austrian Jews as well and his common heritage with his subject Zweig gives this book a particular poignancy when discussing the seemingly lost world of pre-Anchluss Vienna.Zweig was a renowned author, a celebrity who quite suddenly finds the rug pulled out from under him in such a devastating way that his story is the perfect example of what those exiled from their homelands during the Nazi era experienced both externally and internally. As an avid reader of Zweig , I found this book incredibly interesting and valuable and recommend it to anyone with an interest not only in Zweig but in this story of those fortunate to escape the death camps but who struggled to find themselves after being cast adrift. Fabulous book.

In this remarkable book, Rose Macaulay combines a beautiful story of travel and adventure in Turkey and the middle east with ruminations on organized religion, human nature and love in such a seamless and entertaining way that the pages fly by. Set in the post war period, traveling with her Aunt and an Anglican priest, the narrator guides the reader through the incredible landscapes and introduces numerous fascinating characters along the way. I had purchased this edition quite some time ago and set it aside but I am so glad to have finally picked it up and read it . A truly entertaining novel.

I ordered this while traveling to Vienna and after viewing many of Klimt's masterpieces at the Belvedere Gallery.  When it arrived I was very pleased with the layout of the book. It puts his work in context of his overall artistic development and his major influencers. With text about the life and work of the artist supplementing the reproductions and photos of Klimt and his models this is a wonderful overview of the life and work of this important artist.

All of these films stand as master adaptations of Shakespeare to the Screen. Olivier's Hamlet is the standard for any screen version. Staged traditionally and filmed in black and white it is the Hamlet performance that can be viewed again and again. Olivier's direction and acting are superb as are the rest of the cast and the lines of the most famous scenes are so beautifully delivered as to make them seem fresh again with every viewing. Much the same can be said of the other two plays that are in this collection. Henry V uses the device of showing the play being staged but then the viewer is drawn into the action in a way to make the experience as immediate as if in the theater. For Shakespeare lovers this is a must own collection as Sir Olivier does the bard justice as no other film maker can.

These stories set in the former British colonies of the far east invoke the atmosphere of Englishmen far from home clinging together in clubs sipping G&Ts in the dark corners of the waning empire. No one captures that setting better than Maugham did in his short stories and novels set in Asia. These atmospheric stories introduce the reader to a fascinating collection of characters who have found their way to these British outposts for reasons both mundane and shady. Written by a man whose life spanned the turn of the 20th century it may be said that the Native characters serve as background fodder for these British centric stories and are never or rarely fully fleshed out characters in themselves but consider the time. If reading about expatriate Brits playing bridge on a veranda in Burma is your cup of tea you will love these stories written by an absolute master of short fiction. Maugham's writing never disappoints me and I return to these stories time and again.

This book is certainly targeted towards fans of the The Stanley Brothers but it has enough background on the early recording industry and the evolutiion of Bluegrass as a seperate genre to satisfy the curiosity of a gnereal readership as well. Well written and researched, Lonsome Melodies depicts the intersection of both the art and business side of The Stanley Brothers' careers illuminating rivalries and friendships that were both the natural outgrowth of a small but growing market for traditional music.  There is much here for the those that love their music as well. The origins and creation of songs, the detailed view into life on the road and their recording sessions outlining various band members who come and go over the years.  The personal side of their story is detailed as well including the tragic demise of Carter Stanley and his premature death after struggling with alchoholism.  Overall I thoroughly enjoyed this and have been listening to The Stanley Brothers almost non-stop while reading this. This book is a slice of Americana - a look into an era that is gone when regional isolation allowed for development of traditional music as represented here by the Stanleys. A great read.

There's really nothing in here but ramblings and testimonies from his kids about what a great guy he is. I know the ramblings are mentioned right in the title but the organization of this book suggests it was just thrown together without any editing and the average reader will gain almost nothing from reading this. A bathroom shelf book if anything.

Thomas Hardy's writing is always evocative of atmosphere and filled with meaningful symbolism. This tragic novel is no exception and once again fictional rural Wessex and the ecclesiastical center of Melchester provide the setting for two individuals who fall in love with all the circumstances of social position and differences in wealth arrayed against them. In the case of Viviette Constantine and the Astronomer St. Cleve age difference is added to the volatile mix of factors that doom their love for each other. Hardy provides several twists of fate that irrevocably challenge this pair who through an overly developed respect  for social convention leave their feelings for each other hidden from everyone else in their lives with tragic consequences. For those who love Hardy's work and enjoyed Jude The Obscure or The Mayor of Casterbridge , Two On A Tower will satisfy the desire for another wonderfully written story with similar themes and settings. I personally can never get enough of Hardy and highly recommend this book to anyone who has enjoyed his better known works.

This is a very tightly scripted film noir crime drama. All the elements are here- great acting, crisp screenplay and a plot that moves along quickly and holds the viewer's attention for the entire length of the film. A race track heist being planned and executed by a diverse group of characters organized by Sterling Hayden's character , The Killing packs a punch and the ending is incredible. Great old film and a must for Noir fans.

In Shakespeare's hands this tale as old as time itself becomes a perfect representation of the ends that people will go to follow passion and neglect duty. Anthony as one of the triumvirate could rule one third of the known world but his obsession with Cleopatra is the weakness he cannot overcome. Cleopatra as the Queen of an important country herself is also victimized by the mutual passion these two share. Whether this is historically accurate or not is immaterial as the world has witnessed this type of tale play out again and again in both art and in real life. Shakespeare again held the mirror up to the world and used historical figures to demonstrate universal truths about human nature. Brilliant !

Andrew Garcia's first hand account of his experiences in the Montana area as a trapper and trader living among the tribes native to that area are both harrowing and remarkable for the level of detail that he recorded in his memoir. Referring to himself as the squaw kid he becomes comfortable trading and even becoming romantically involved with a survivor of the Nez Perce debacle who is living among the other tribes as a refuge. This is a fascinating book on many levels. First Garcia is a white man living with the Indians and his perspective is unique in that much of his trouble results from encounters with other whites or Indians who are drunk on the whiskey that is used to trade for anything the Indians had of value. There is a sense of the inevitable change that is fast approaching these people as these two cultures increasingly clash over land. At one point he diverges to allow his Nez Perce woman tell the story of her people's struggle in her own voice as told to Garcia. These chapters are a bit difficult not because the content is inaccurate but because the style of writing changes dramatically before Garcia reverts back to his own tale in his own voice.Overall this is an indispensable read for anyone interested in the history of the West. It was recommended to me by a friend and I immediately ordered and read it. Truly unmissable to anyone with an interest in that topic.

Shorter than his other major works, Joseph Roth's Weights and Measures is a novelette that is almost fable like in the portrayal of the downfall of a man who has followed a code all of his life and upon abandoning that code falls deeply and irrevocably into a world dominated by those very people upon whom he had imposed some semblance of order. As an inspector of weights and measures in an area of the former Austo-Hungarian empire bordering on Russia the protagonist is a symbol of government authority in an area given over to smuggling , cheating and theft. Roth's nostalgia for the order of the old ways in personified in the character Eibenschutz who becomes increasingly unmoored from what has sutained him as the story progresses.Roth was an extremely talented writer and his longer works, The Radesky March and the Emperors Tomb take place in similar circumstances ( in fact several of the characters overlap in this story) but here he has honed his observations into a masterful work of short fiction that has poetic descriptive passages of incredible beauty.

Ricky Gevrais is great as a misanthropic Manhattan dentist who is caught up in a bizarre plot involving Ghosts who wander the city seeking resolution of one conflict before they can find eternal peace. Tia Leoni is fabulous in this and her performance gives the movie it's heart and soul. Overall even though the story seems implausible the screenplay is intelligent and funny and all the main characters are  well conceived and well acted. Gregg Kinear as the deceased husband and the primary ghost character is also excellent. THis is a lighted hearted comedy with in the end an uplifting redemption angle that is well worth spending a couple of hours with.

Robert Larson tried hard in this biography to give a layered and balanced perspective on a man who's leadership and prominence lasted for over two generations. In the end I believe he succeeded. Red Cloud was a figure who played a significant role in the history of his people during the most volatile  and dynamic years of change and struggle that the Lakota experienced. His early days as a warrior are outlined here as are his skills at reading the intent of his adversaries and using negotiation, stall tactics and long deliberations to prolong the Sioux traditional way of life in the face of what Larson suggests was his view that the forces arrayed against his people would in the end be irresistible.Red Cloud is presented here as a man with faults and shortcomings. He did not take part with the Northern Sioux led by Crazy Horse and Sitting Bull in the Great Sioux war that included the Battle of Little Big Horn. His role in the episode that resulted in Crazy Horse's murder at Camp Robinson is clouded in mystery and frankly Larson's book does very little to shed any additional light here. These factors may have diminished his stature among his own people to a large degree. But the record of his continued resistance to white encroachment on Sioux lands is clear.His numerous visits to Washington and meetings with several US Presidents  are described in great detail and attest to the importance of the man and his reputation at the time. It also seems that those trips gave Red Cloud insights into the way white people thought and the overwhelming numbers he was dealing with contributed to his legacy as a treaty Sioux.Overall I learned a great deal from reading this book and highly recommend it to anyone interested in Native American history.

The Moonstone by Wilkie Collins has been referred to as the first modern English detective novel. It is unique in form , being narrated by no less than 7 characters. In this way Collins enabled the reader to see events from varying points of view. The effect of this is not disunity of form as you might suspect but instead a gradual buildup of suspense that grips the reader and provides numerous thrilling plot twists. This is a Victorian era novel ( Wilkie Collins was a close friend and associate of Charles Dickens) and must be read in that light as a work of historical importance and a classic even if it may not be as well known as the works of his famous friend.The plot revolves around a theft at a Yorkshire state and the story moves between Yorkshire and London as a variety of characters come under suspicion and an equal variety of people either attempt or think they have identified the guilty party. There is enough intrigue in this novel to satisfy any fan of mystery writing and enough quality of writing and depth to satisfy any lover of great literature.Wilkie Collins may now be best remembered as the author of THE WOMAN In WHITE but The Moonstone is reputed to be his masterpiece so I chose to start with this and truly enjoyed reading it.

Alan Stilltoe was a fine writer who really exposed the grimness of life in postwar industrial England through characters who either endure lives of quiet desperation or inner rebellion. The title story in this collection is well known since it was made into a film in the 60s and it falls into the later category. The prime character is a youth living in a grim rainy gritty city in England who is caught after a robbery and sent to a Borstal where he discovers his talent for running. He then uses this to set up a rebellious tale that sets the individual against the establishment, a theme that is repeated in much of Stilltoe's work. The other stories are very good and as a collection this short book is excellent for the quality of the writing and consistency of theme.Stilltoe's full length novel  Saturday Night and Sunday morning is equally well done and worth exploring if you enjoy these stories.

This is the 6th installment of the Flashman Papers that I've read and while not my favorite it is still a tremendous adventure following our man from the cricket grounds of London to Borneo, Singapore and finally Madagascar  to rescue his wife Elspeth from the clutches of a Pirate. Like all Flashman stories the hair raising close calls alternate with ribald humor and the combination of adventure tale with well researched history brings this story to life. All the Flashman books I have read so far have been hugely entertaining and informative. I continue to work my way through the remainder. George Macdonald Fraser was brilliant in the way he was able to continually find new and interesting circumstances in which to place his hero for our amusement. Well done again.

Having just read Van Gogh The Life ,an outstanding 900 page biography, of Vincent Van Gogh I was curious to see this film again after many years to see how it lined up against the book. I was very impressed with the film for a number of reasons. It is obviously condensed compared to the book and begins with Vincent already a grown man trying to enter the ministry. The time he spent in Arles with Gaugin takes up a significant part of the film even though their time living and working together was really only three months out of his 37 years. That aside the performances by Kirk Douglas and Anthony Quinn are both excellent. Douglas particularly does well in conveying the artists manic depressive states and his essential feeling of isolation. The scenery and and the way the film incorporates the actual paintings of Van Gogh and sets them in context is truly remarkable.A film by necessity must have a buildup ,a climax and a conclusion and the choices that were made by Vincente Minelli to achieve that without compromising the essence of Van Gogh's life story result in a wonderful concise view into a very complex artist and troubled man.Overall I thought after reading the book that I might find the film trite but I was happily surprised to find it completely engaging from beginning to end. It is an excellent movie that has held up quite well after almost 60 years.

I came away from watching this film with very mixed feelings. The film is stunning in period imagery and many of the performances are really outstanding. The plot is intriguing enough and there are several surprises along the way. The historical aspect of seeing Spain in the late inquisition followed by the French invasion and then the British marching up from Portugal to drive out Napoleon's troops is very well captured in a compressed timeline. Excellent costuming and atmospherics contribute to a highly entertaining period piece. The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is that for me the involvement and chance encounters of the main characters during these tumultuous events strained believability to the breaking point. While that distracted me while watching I still recognized the beauty of the film and admire the attempt to tell a truly fascinating historical tale through the eyes of a handful of people including of course Goya. Bardem is convincingly evil and self- interested. Portman in a dual role is very good. Overall I'd recommend it.

The eighteen stories in this volume range from early New York fiction as represented by Edith Wharton and O'Henry to more modern selections represented by Junot Diaz and Jay McInerney. For a compact sampler of short fiction set in New York City over the last 150 years this is an outstanding choice. The list of writers is impressive and nothing is more guaranteed to put one in a New York state of mind than picking this up and reading a few of these excellent tales before a visit. Compliments to the editors on their fine selections.

I am a big fan of Steve Coogan and that is what prompted me to watch this film. I knew little of Paul Raymond's story beforehand. There are some fine and highly watchable moments in this and Coogan does admirably in the lead role. The background and scenes in London from the 60's through the 80s are very entertaining in their own right. Given the subject matter there are a host of beautiful women in supporting roles. So far so good, right ? But overall there was something missing. The story of a man building a business empire based on soft porn and strip clubs , the inevitable use of drugs in the 80s, the tragic family relationships with his ex wife and children all may be based in fact but it seemed like a check the box exercise in a typical the higher they fly the further they fall cliche".It was worth a rental but in the end it's a fairly forgettable film.

Captain Phillips provides a seriously tension filled movie experience. Tom Hanks is terrific in the title role. The actors who play the Somali pirates are equally strong. The movie has a very short buildup that allows the viewers to understand the  major players but the action sequences commence very early on and once they do the action is relentless making the entire rest of the film edge of your seat stuff.  I have read that there is some criticism that the film distorts the actual story  but even if true that doesn't detract from the quality of this as an action movie. I haven't been that tense watching a film in a long time.

Stunning in the amount of detail and yet never dry or boring this is as an extensive and insightful biography as any I've read. The authors collaborated and yet the style of the writing is so engaging and consistent throughout that it seems the work of a single author. Van Gogh is traced from childhood through his troubled young adulthood and emerges here as a tortured soul striving for understanding and a place in the world who intimately translated those longings into his art. Beautifully written, massive in scope , detail and informative while entertaining ,this is a model for what good biography should and can be. You leave this book feeling like you know Van Gogh the way you know members of your own family. Using the letters Vincent wrote to his brother as a primary source in a narrative that very effectively merges the circumstances of his life with his inner torment and struggles results in a dissection of the man's evolution as an artist and his emotional neediness that is at once disturbing and powerful. This is a long read but for me the pages flew and I loved being immersed in this  man's life and world for a time. If you have an interest in Van Gogh or this period of art history you simply cannot miss this book. It will enrich your appreciation and stay with you for a very long time. An investment in time that is well worth it. Bravo !

I first read this book many years ago and recently picked it up again before visiting Little Big Horn Battlefield. Connell's meandering style takes some getting used to even in a second reading. Nevertheless, this is a fascinating portrayal of one of the seminal episodes in the history of the American west, with the personalities of many of the major as well as the lesser known players explored as tangents to the events leading up to the Custer battle. Connell's practice of going off on countless tangential details may be distracting at first but in the end he weaves a quilt that allows the main thread of the story to emerge while entertaining and informing his readers of an astounding array of characters who influenced or participated in these events from both the white and Indian perspective. This is a book that often left me shaking my head in awe at the almost unbelievable characters involved. As the saying goes truth is often stranger than fiction. In Connell's hands history takes on the dramatic tension and has the ability to amaze as if it were a great work of art which I suppose in the end it is even though well documented and true.

W. Somerset Maugham is one of my favorite authors and I find his writing to be always insightful and interesting. The Hero is far from being one of his masterworks and yet there are passages in it that are just so stunning in the way he is able to capture a person's essence and reflect their inner life that forshadow how some of his later more complex novels are structured. As a playwright first and a novelist second Maugham has a unique feel for the dramatic confrontation and that quality is reflected throughout this book.A decorated veteran of the Boer War returns to his small town in England to his family and his fiance only to find he has changed in his attitude toward them through his experiences overseas. He struggles to reconcile his feelings and actions with tragic results. The plot is excellent, the tension is palpable and the characterizations are typical Maugham. For those who like me can't get enough of his writing this is a fine selection. If you are new to his writing I wouldn't start here but read one of his better known works first.Overall I found this relatively short work by an author I revere to be exactly what I would expect from him.

I count myself a true fan of The Flashman Series by George MacDonald Fraser and so could not resist picking up his own memoirs of the Burma campaign in WWII when I saw it in a London bookstore. I was not disappointed. Fraser writes so warmly of his experiences with his Unit of Cumberland soldiers as they fought their way toward Rangoon. There is the hardness of battle worn veterans in mortal combat with a deadly enemy levied by a camaraderie and slowly gained respect for men in the far end of the world isolated except for each other's company. Fraser spares nothing relative to the cruelty and also to the role of luck in who makes it and who doesn't and his battle and combat writing is superb. What sets this war memoir apart is his willingness to record dialogue between military comrades , much of it written in a Cumbrian dialect that brings his former comrades to life and makes this such an engaging read.
