Vitamin D will accumulate, so I think these could be taken safely every other day or so, but I am not a doctor. Experts recommend having your vitamin D levels tested before supplementing anyway.

This is a great product--the best "instant" coffee machine on the market. It uses Nespresso capsules to make a rich, satisfying cup of coffee in a minute or less. The capsules are expensive for home-made coffee, but the quality of the drink is coffee-shop, and the price is reasonable on that basis. I have not found a single generic brand capsule that comes close to the Nespresso brand capsules, and the Nespresso help-line person said the off-brands can actually break the machine--the pressure involved in making such a good cup requires a precise calibration so that the capsule yields appropriately (which makes sense to me).and which brings me to my issue: the machine I got was a "factory-recondition"-- that did not draw water out of the reservoir. The Nespresso help line person said Amazon sellers often sell malfunctioning machines, which are not covered by the Nespresso warranty--and since I was a previous owner of a Nespresso machine, I got a discount that made a brand new, under-warranty model the same price as the defective one I sent back.

I love this, but please be aware that the color is not a hazel brown as it appears on my MacBook Air---it is a lovely rich leafy, ferny green. This fits nicely and is the lovely silky material that make Three Dots worth paying more for. The armholes are, on me, bra friendly, as long as I wear my ones with the straps that set on the back closer together. It's flatteringly low-cut, but does not show the top of a full coverage bra.

In the perhaps misguided push to eliminate parabens from products, problematic substitutes have been introduced. Methylisothiazolinone is known to have sensitizing properties---which means even if you don't have sensitive skin now, it can help you get it. I have sensitive skin, especially n my neck and I don't want this preservative to stream down my neck after I use the conditioner in the shower. Sorry, Nexxus--you ruined an otherwise excellent product!

These are causal pants, not dressy twills. The fabric is fairly lightweight, and prone to looking a bit wrinkly. There is obvious topstitching in matching thread and rivets, so these are more like dressy jeans or casual pants. The fabric is evenly dyed--it is solid, not like a lot of black denims--more of a poplin, but with a very fine twill weave. They fit, as all pants nowadays seem to, one size up--the waist measures 38 inches on a 36. They are flatteringly cut for a middle-aged man with more gut than butt. The stretch makes them very comfortable and not prone to bagging.

They say these are slim, and they are! Not dad pants, for sure. They fit my husband's muscular thighs snugly, but not too snugly. No diaper butt bagginess! The waist actually measures 40 inches, not 38, but I have found that vanity sizing has struck men's clothes now, too, so that is to be expected. The fabric is not non-iron, and the tonal topstitching and rivets makes these casual pants, more lightweight jeans substitutes, not the "dress khakis" suitable for all occasions down here in the south. The fabric is a nice crisp, thinner poplin, not warm--which is a plus down here.They do stretch quite a bit, but do not look at all like "stretch pants"-- they are just nice fitting, comfortable casual pants!

This is better than the Braun cordless it replaced. It holds a charge for at least 30 minutes and did not need to be recharged for a whole two week vacation! It cuts a lot closer than my Braun.It isn't quite as close as a Gillette Mach how ever many, but it also doesn't require shaving cream---a big plus when traveling. It also doesn't require ridiculously over-priced blades! You have to be extra careful not to miss whiskers, because once they get a bit longer, it is even less likely that you will cut them. It works very quickly in dry environments, not so much so in extra humid ones like here in SC this summer.It took just a bit of doing to figure out how get the pop-up trimmer to work, but it is excellent for trimming all those longer hairs on places other than your cheeks--ahem! It also can catch any of those chronically missed spots.Also, because you don't have all the mess of shaving cream and washing it off, you can use it with your shirt on without getting your shirt all messy!

This tends to stretch out larger as I wear it, so that the waistband gaps by midday. I can wear a belt, but who wants to wear a belt in the summer? A bit of elastic would help.The polyester tends to pick up smells, but dries quickly, so for travel, it's a wash.Also, there is tiny tonal "bling" on the back pockets--it doesn't stand out much, but it does detract from the dressiness.

This is perfect to line over a pencil to make my hazel eyes--olive green with dark green ring around the iris and a rusty star in the middle--really sparkle. Since any color eye besides brown depends on Rayleigh scattering, I figure adding a bluer tone near the eye can't hurt, and certainly helps whiten my whites---while navy can look a bit harsh, this is a super green--nice and rich--not garish.I don't think I'd wear it other than as a liner, but then I am fairly conservative in makeup.

This is a lovely color, and the zinc oxide may be why it has a very slight white heathering--very slight. I wish the shoulders were just a bit wider so it was more of a ballet neck--my shoulders are admittedly fairly wide, and my bra straps show unless I wear a racer back type. I had hoped it was more of a sleeveless top, as photographed, than a tank. Oh well.It is very cool, and not clingy or billowy, and washes up well and dries quickly for a cotton knit.

It's a bit scratchy, but I have a very sensitive neck--which is why I bought a sunscreen scarf. It doesn't cling, unlike silk and some very fine cottons, which is nice and cooler. The print looks kind of cheaply, but then I am a collector of vintage scarves, so maybe my standards are too high. I have no information on the bug repelling qualities, but it doesn't smell of anything, so if it does repel bugs, yay!

I returned these. While the footbed was plenty large enough for my foot, the straps over my instep, which is very high, were short---the Velcro did not catch very securely because of the lack of overlap. If you have a lower volume foot, these would probably be great.Also I wasn't wild about the color--it isn't exactly tan and it isn't exactly beige and it isn't exactly "nude."

The styles in the photos are dated, and the photos don't always illustrate the concept as well as one would like, but as a consumer of this sort of book for decades, I learned SO much I never knew. Raes doesn't just slice women into four shapes--she dissects each part of one's figure, and advises what to do to highlight or minimize its appearance. Of especial note are the parts about choosing textures and prints based on your appearance--way more refined than any other analysis I've read.Check out her blog for more updated fashion advice!

These are super nice, heavyweight and sealing well enough so bugs can't fly in and lay eggs that hatch and eat your clothes. They are breathable to defeat mildew.  They hold a couple of blazers or a tux plus trimmings nicely, and you use your own hangers.

I like this, but oddly the buttonholes are stretched out from the get go. It's a nice silky cotton, and the color looks right on my laptop. The collar wanted pressing and starching, though, to look neat. Oh well.

This was a piece of crap. It tore while I was trying to assemble it. The frame is so flimsy, you might be able to hang a few peignoirs from it, but anything more will not hold. It also did not want to hold open. Massive fail!

I have the starter set, with five bands, door hanger and ankle cuff already, and thought this would be a nice addition. It is the next toughest up in level (35-40lbs). Oddly, the instructions included only list the resistances for the first five I already had, and I only knew what this resistance was from enlarging the photo on the Amazon product page. I dinged it one star, because unlike the rest of my set, the cables on these are not clipped, but run through the grips, so in order to double up resistance, I will have to hold two grips in each hand, and can't use this strength with the cuff The door hanger strap is included, though.

This is supposedly cotton, but it sure feels like modal---whatever--it isn't overly hot. It's a super flattering cut, and it didn't stretch out and start to show my bra like some other wraps do. I am not overly busty--36D, but spread over a broad chest. I would imagine, though, that it would still be decent on a much fuller bust. It is wicked flattering, with the thin vee neck and the gentle wrap, whittling your waist, while the gathers conceal rolls and bumps underneath. The sleeves are more cap than sleeveless, as you can see, but also create a nice hourglass line.It takes a while to come, so plan ahead. It also is sized generously.

This is book 1.5 in the series but really does stand completely alone as a novella, and is centered around Christmas time so is a good novella for reading right now.Andrew is on the Aces hockey team.  I can't actually recall him at all in book 1, but that one was full of a ton of nicknames, more than one per player, so I likely missed him.  His family had a tragedy, and from age 16 onward he lived with his best friend's family.  That family also had a younger daughter, Jenna (2 years younger than Andrew and his best friend).  Both felt drawn to the other, but the dynamics of him living with the family meant they could not be together.  Andrew had already lost one family, and he was not doing anything that might mess up the new family he had.  That was the theme of the entire novella, fighting against the fear that if he dated Jenna he could lose his new family.The writing was good but the plot got a bit old, even given the short length.  There was nothing really other than Andrew's fear/insecurity.  There were a few humorous moments, and I liked those, the family banter.  It had some steam.  It wasn't very memorable overall though so 3 stars, and I'll still continue the series, hoping for a full-length and more memorable one next!My thanks to the publisher via Netgalley for an advanced copy to read and provide an honest review.

This is a new adult book, hero in law school (early 20s) and heroine 21ish.  The heroine's brother has been in prison just over 5 years now, convicted of killing his girlfriend in a particularly brutal manner.  His sister, Cora, has spent the entire time attempting to free him, convinced of his innocence.  She is, in fact, correct.  She uses every bit of her time on that as everyone else has abandoned him, and she feels she is the only person he has left.Leo, the hero, is working in his father's PI agency for the summer.  Cora arrives with her case on the hopes the agency will take it as they do one case a year to assist in possibly freeing innocents in prison.  Leo's father has already done his case for the year, but Leo surprisingly jumps to volunteer to help Cora.  At first, honestly, his reasons are far from altruistic.  He is attracted to her.  Thankfully, he finds some depth to his personality as the story goes on and changes for the better, at the same time persuading her to open herself to having a bit of a life outside of freeing her brother.This is a romantic suspense at the new adult level in a realistic (pretty much) way.  They followed leads and had some excitement while getting to know each other.  I really enjoyed both the mystery and the romance of this one, finding it pretty balanced.  The characters were both both mature in an age-appropriate manner if that makes sense.  For a new writer, that is quite an accomplishment.  I was able to buy into the story here easily.  The side commentary of a family falling apart of tragedy and others judging Cora based on her family struck hard and were a great addition.This was a new author to me, but I will definitely be looking for more of her work in the future.My thanks to the publisher via Netgalley for an advanced copy of this book to review and provide an honest review.

Trevor is just under 30 and the last remaining Moonshine clan Coleman single. He is not exactly searching for a partner but finds one nonetheless when Becky moves into "the rental" next door to his piece of land. She moves into the rundown house on the land, and he sees her out on the roof attempting to fix a leak herself. He then goes into "good neighbor" mode and uses that to attempt to get to know her as she is decidedly wary of him. We find out slowly her story (heartbreaking), how she ended up in Rocky Mountain and why she is indeed so wary of Trevor and people in general.I give this one a solid 5 stars. I have read the entire series (note this stands alone pretty well), and some stories have really stuck in my mind while others were forgotten pretty quickly. This is a strong one for sure for me. What I love about this series is the writer shows a pretty wide range in ability to write heroes. She writes some strong alphas and some more beta types. The range of their issues/problems varies as well. Trevor is more towards the beta but no wimp. He is hilarious at times with some memorable comments include being a "sparkly unicorn." Who can resist a hero who calls himself a sparkly unicorn to make his heroine smile? He shows himself over and over to do whatever it takes to help her heal and find happiness, even if it makes him a little uncomfortable to do it (thinking of a funny discussion with his cousin Travis here!).This book gives a HEA for the couple, but I enjoyed that it wasn't everything wrapped up with a bow and tied with nothing left hanging. They still had some issues to work out as a couple, but the romance part was solid and they were committed to fixing them and found a workaround rather than letting that sink them as a couple. That is true romance - working it out. Also, their familial issues saw little forward progress at all, but both of these characters did not just throw up their hands and shut the door on the relationship but rather showed compassion, insight and true caring. They left the door open to reconciliation down the line. Most of this series involves the entire family, and that makes this book and series special.Again, I just loved this one and I know this particular couple will stick in my mind like a few of the others. I do highly recommend this series. Some books were better than others but all were solid reads for me.My thanks to the author for a complimentary advanced copy of the book to read and provide an honest review.

Rating 3.5 to 4 starsThis is a quick (less than 200 pages) story from the Entangled Brazen line, meaning steamy. Chloe is a restaurant/bar owner who is allergic to commitment (good change as usually it is the hero), and her hero is a Search and Rescue member, Gage, who happens through her town a few times a year for the Search and Rescue there. Each time through for two years running now they hook up for a weekend, then he is gone again. And they both are happy with that arrangement, until Gage isn't. Now, he is out for more from Chloe, but in the process he has to overcome her fears and face his own issues. The story is quite decent, and the steam factor is good. It is a good light read, and I enjoyed it a lot. It is not some epic work of fiction or something with a ton of hairpin twists and curves, but it is a solid light romance. I would definitely read more from this author.My thanks to the publisher via Netgalley for the advanced copy of this book to read and provide an honest review.

2 stars because it was so darn short. There just wasn't hardly anything to review (Amazon says 45 pages). I'm glad this was a library Overdrive read because that was just too short. You basically got to see them meet, have insta-lust and mate. It was like the cliff's notes version of a regular shifter story with no external or internal conflict to drive the plot.I'm just stumped at this one as I have read and liked the author before, but there it is.

Wicked Ride (prior book) was good, I thought, but suffered from the plague if being the first book in a paranormal series.  Nearly every single paranormal series I have read has shown the first book to be the one I like the least.  It just seems the author has to work so hard to set up the world for the series, including the rules since it is paranormal, that it suffers either in the characterization or the reader is just lost.Here we get a book 2.  The world is set up already in book 1, and we have met all the characters in book 1 or the prior vampire series.  (Note here I would highly recommend you do indeed read book 1 of this series before 2, but the vamp series is just connected not required.)  As the setup is complete, this book and the action just exploded right from the very first chapter and never lets up.  Our heroine, Cee Cee, is far from a wimp despite her challenges.  Those who live strong females should like her.  She had brains, beauty and a solid plan.  Our hero, Coven 9 Enforcer, Daire, sometimes is left steps behind and racing to catch his fast-moving heroine.  Good for her as he needed his orderly life shaken up some.That drug-themed plot from book 1 unfolds some here but still is nowhere near resolved.  A couple evil guys are exposed and/or defeated but again the plot thickens and continues.  This is the main reason I say read book 1 first.  And of course I can't wait for the next book.  Love, love this author and series.  She writes complex, richly detailed plots and doesn't skimp on the romance while doing so.  Each secondary character of course is interesting enough to deserve his/her own novel so I'm sure I'll be tuning in for a while to come.My thanks to the publisher via Netgalley for an advanced copy of this book to read and provide an honest review.

Rating: 3 to 3.5 starsThis is a spin-off from one of this author's other series, but you absolutely don't need to have read the other series. In book 3 of the other series, Once Pure, we had the story of Sofie and Killian. Killian there had 5 brothers and a sister. Here, we have the story of one of Killian's brothers, a cop named Curran. We incidentally meet most of the rest of his family too, and all look like great stories!Anyway, here Curran has had a bad break professionally that is messing with his mind. In his recovery, he has light duty basically and is assigned to guard Tess, currently a law student assigned to his brother. Tess and his brother (Declan) are preparing for a very high profile case against a crime boss and hence have police protection. The first time Curran and Tess meet they realize they had a one-night stand in college. Whoops! The plot though made for a pretty good story.Where I had a problem was the relationship between Tess and her father. She was abused, and she is still very much under his thumb at the age of 24. Given she is in her last months of law school and apparently otherwise a strong person, I just plain had trouble believing it to the degree that was presented in the book. I would hope anyone strong enough to graduate at the top of her law class and protect the rights of others would be able to avoid being a victim herself, at least to the degree here. Her father came very close to being a cartoon villain, and that lost some of my enjoyment of reading this book. The plot involving the case they were trying and Curran's situation at work though was very well crafted and believable, so it redeemed the plot some. I'll definitely look into the next books in this series as I have enjoyed this author a lot in prior series.My thanks to the publisher via Netgalley for an advanced copy of this book to read and provide an honest review.

Rating 3 to 3.5This is a book 3 of the series but can stand alone. The first two books are a duo, but this one is a friend of the hero of the first. Jake Tanner is the owner of Tanner Security. He is hired to provide protection to Natalie, a writer of books and a popular game. She is suffering from very severe agoraphobia, unable to leave her apartment, but still is being tormented by notes and gifts meant to scare her. Her cousin, Oliver, comes to Jake to find out who is doing this. Jake himself is a veteran, having amputations of his left arm and leg, but does not let that hamper his abilities.An extremely unlikely romance developed between Jake and Natalie, in fact so unlikely I had trouble buying into it, but this is a romance so there we go. They did in fact begin it by texts and such given her phobia, but that was the most believable part in fact. Even more unbelievable was the final result of why she was being tormented and why, and that was the reason for the low star score. That was just ridiculous in my mind honestly, but I can't tell you why and ruin it for you. Suffice to stay I'm disappointed in that and hoped I was wrong throughout and there was a twist I didn't see coming. There wasn't.I like Jen Frederick's writing though despite this disappointing turn in the plot. I'll continue to read her works, though this is far from my favorite. I eagerly await the next.My thanks to the publisher via Netgalley for an advanced copy to read and provide an honest review.

This author and series is really a favorite of mine, so I was very happy to receive an ARC of this book via Netgalley to read and provide an honest review.Here we have Lilliana and Alec. Lilliana inherited the family home, and she is working on turning it into a bed and breakfast. We got to see her and her house briefly in a prior book. Recall the hair incident? LOL Anyway, Alec is a contractor, inspector and the quarterback coach for the high school football team with the prior two heroes. Here I have to divert and say that while the three books so far in the series all involve the three football coaches, they can indeed be read as standalone without issues. There is not really a strong plot line that runs through all three books, though there are indeed a few small threads in the secondary (younger) characters.Alec and Liliana had a one-night stand in college, but the kicker is that he doesn't remember it at all, having been drunk and a manwhore at the time. He has changed, and can't really figure out why she hates him so much. Well, he treated her badly but can't recall it. In this installment, they obviously get past the past and see if they can have something in the present, letting go of the past in many aspects.So, what did I like so much about this book (and series)? It is low-key and the writing is just plain good. There is little to no angst, but I don't find the books boring at all. They are in a small town, with small town issues, people, gossip and caring. Real people in a real setting in other words. This could reasonably happen. We have some catty and flawed family, some good friends and some that aren't so good, some flaws in our hero and heroine, maybe one or both behaved badly in the past and now is better. I found this an engaging yet relaxed and low-key read. Loved it and eagerly await the next book by this wonderful

My overall rating is a 4 but that is an average of the two included in there.The first part, the story of Ronin and Lorraine, was only really a 3 for me.  That was the biggest part, and I just didn't honestly feel that one.  Despite the climax of the whole SoCal storyline, it felt really flat and bland to me.  Ronin and Lorraine are back together after 25 years, and they too just felt bland.  I don't know why and may very well have a very different opinion than the majority on this one.The last part though, pertaining to Bart and his family, I would give 5 stars for sure.  It was a "side trip" type of tale and I loved it though it was very sad in parts.So this book as an entirety, about two different couples, averaged 4.

Here we have Jack and Isabelle, werewolves. Isabelle is a painter. Her first art she believes created a divide between her and her father. In one last effort to cross it before he passes on, she is buying up all her paintings to show him, hopefully to gain his blessing on her art. Jack holds a piece she wants for her collection. Jack is over 300 years old, past the age a werewolf can live without his Luminary, his fated mate. It turns out, Isabelle is his mate, but she refuses to mate with him, not believing at first, and then not willing without her father's permission, something he will never give because of the family Jack was born into. That sets up the conflict in this story.I just can't give it more than 3 stars despite the fact it was indeed written decently. What are the morals of this story? You let your fated mate, one you have come to love, die to preserve a relationship with your father, who has no direct knowledge of Jack at all, but rather a prejudice against him just because his family is bad. True love in fact doesn't win out, and that is just that. I had little respect for Isabelle, to let someone die because of prejudice. She had zero spine or integrity, and her entire clan or family, the people she was giving up everything for, appeared to treat others horribly. Just not the book for me in other words.My thanks to the publisher for providing an advanced copy of this book via Netgalley for an honest review.

Lucy and Pietro are both from mafia families. Pietro's parents are killed in a gripping first few pages of the book, and he goes to live with Lucy's father and Lucy, Pietro age 15 and Lucy 13ish. The book then picks up 8 years later. He loves her, and she him, but both feel it is impossible. Lucy is a dancer, and gets a chance to go to New York for a shot at ballet, and Pietro is tasked by her father to protect her. It is a great setup for a book but falls far short.This book is over 200 pages long and nothing really happens. We learn a little bit about a mystery of the death of Pietro's parents, but nothing really significant. Their relationship in the book feels shallow. There is nothing but mystery really, and then we find out it is a cliffhanger. So, from my point of view as a reader, this is basically being dragged out in multiple books instead of tightening up the plot and giving us an entire story in one book. This is a huge pet peeve for me given the explosion of this style of writing, and I'm just burned out on it. This could have been one interesting story and instead is a rather slow-moving and dull introduction part of a story.The writing? Not bad at all. I would read another by this author provided it was not a cliffhanger. I'm just plain done with that setup.For those interested, it is mafia but the gory and the crazy is really at a minimum for the setup, definitely nothing to freak out a reader of this genre at all. The characters are pretty typical new adult characters aside from the mafia component (age 21 and 23 through the majority of the story).My thanks to the publisher for providing me a copy of this book to read and formulate an honest review.

This is the first of a new series, new adult age characters, 20 and about 23 or 24. Sean is a mechanic and racecar driver on the weekends. He is the ex-boyfriend of Hannah's older sister. Hannah comes back to town after her parents are in a fatal accident to take care of final things. He has been away at college, having not come home for the past 5 years after the death of her sister. Sean and Hannah run into each other, but there are a whole lot of secrets and issues standing between them.I loved how this author duo didn't sugarcoat the issues without making them melodramatic. Everything that happened was 100% believable and tragic. There was no over the top craziness that made a reader roll eyes, but the aftermath was long-reaching nonetheless. The author portrayed that, and the resulting healing wasn't wrapped up with a tidy little bow either. Questions were left never to be answered. That is life when someone dies. There are often questions left behind, pains, things never said or understood. I love that the authors accepted that truth in life. So, as a reader, I got the HEA I have to have in my romances with enough realism to get immersed in the story and think some deeper thoughts. This was truly a 5-star read for me, and I will definitely be looking for the rest of the series. This was definitely new adult done right.My thanks to the publisher via Netgalley for the advanced copy to read and review.

Rating:  3.5 stars, rounded up to 4This is the first of a new paranormal series, wolf shifters.  Bailey is a white wolf, and the story opens with her being pressured to mate with someone she detests.  She flees, and in doing so finds herself with Ryker, who happens to be her true mate, something she was not even aware of existing.  This opens the entire new world this author has created of wolves, royal bloodlines, witches, protectors and many conspiracies to power and twists in the plot.  Among all this, Bailey and Ryker have to try to have a romance going on aside from the true mates thing.My rating of 3.5 may seem a bit low, but that is honestly because it read a little bit stilted at times, not flowing all that well.  To give this author/series credit though, first books in a paranormal series are often the worst of the series.  The author not only has to set up a romance between the main characters and introduce all the secondary characters like a typical romance would, but in addition has to create an entire world where the laws of physics are a bit different.  That is quite a feat to perform without boring the reader, taking too much away from the main romance or getting so darned complicated that again the reader is lost.  Often after the first book the world exists and the reader is familiar with it, so the flow evens out.  Hence, 3.5 stars, and a great story and interesting new world with many similarities to other shifter stories but enough of a unique spin from this author's imagination that I would definitely read more of the series.My thanks to the publisher for an advanced copy of this book to read and formulate an honest review.

This reads like most of Lora Leigh's books in terms of language, the alpha hero (heroes in this case) and the virginal female.  We have Alyssa, who honestly I felt was a rather lackluster female in this case, seemingly pretty naive and useless the majority of the book.  I'm not even sure what she did for a job she eventually started, social director for her parents?  In any case, she is 18 at the opening of the book.  A little unusual in this, there are some time lapses and eight years pass before the end of the book.The heroes, again like typical Leigh heroes, are Sebastian and Shane, cousins, age 24 at the start of the book.  They share women.  They are also CIA, wealthy, etc., etc.  There is a slight paranormal-ish element in this one (the entire series?) wherein they "soul bond" to their one true love, who happens to be Alyssa.  They all fall for each other in Spain during a romantic summer, but things go bad due to villains apparently after money.  This part was not as clear at all, with several players involved and twists.  I do grant Lora Leigh does twists and turns quite well, a little over the top, but complex nonetheless.  As also per usual, we see characters from several of the other books, and there are some past hookups and affairs making it seem almost like each character has slept with every other secondary character and the lead males.  That can get a bit confusing, but Leigh sprung a little bit of a twist with the heroine and her past relationships also, which I liked.  Again Leigh typical, characters sometimes appear to hate each other and others love each other with cynical and cryptic banter at various times.  I usually do like this about her books, but I have to be in the mood for one of her selections.  For those wondering, the BDSM-ish elements are very low in this one, and it is a permanent menage.I did enjoy this book, and probably would have enjoyed it even slightly more had I not missed several of this series in the middle.  A bit plus for series of course is seeing past couples in other books, and that wasn't there as much for me on this one.  It also had a very very large secondary cast that left me a bit confused at times, something that would not happen to a reader of each book in the series, so enjoyment would be higher for that person.  For those who love Lora Leigh, this book is consistently written per her other works, but really lost the stars for me on the extremely weak female lead.  I'm going back to some of those in the series I missed though and catching up though I think.  I had forgotten about this series and am glad to go back to those as well as look ahead to what is apparently the next book given the glimpse we see in this one for Summer, who will apparently be a much much stronger heroine.  I like that so look forward to that one.My thanks to the publisher via Netgalley for an advanced copy of this book to read and formulate an honest review.

I started reading Carrie Ann Ryan's paranormal romances back with the Redwood Pack, and I read them all. They were good, but honestly the Talon Pack series in my opinion is so far much better than even those. Perhaps just experience of the writer or the elaborate world she already created, but the Talon Pack series is much richer in dynamics, emotion, ties.Here we have Finn, the Heir to the Redwoods (son of Kade and Melanie from the Redwood series), now grown and taking on some Heir to the Pack duties, including interacting with the Talon pack, allies to the Redwoods. In this world, the wolves have been outed to society at large, and it is not smooth at all. Bryan, daughter of the leading family of the Talon pack, is partnered with Finn to be the face of the packs to the humans. They go out into society and show them wolves are not the monsters they are portrayed at times. However, this is not easy for Brynn at all. Her wolf knows Finn is her mate, but he seems to either not realize it or just have it not be reciprocally true for him, a mistake of Fate. Brynn is unable to bear telling him and facing that rejection, so she hides her pain. Finn cannot figure out why she dislikes him so much.This book centers around the ongoing storyline of the outing of the packs and the danger that brings to them. There are some frightening encounters in this book along those lines. The romantic struggle centers around why Fate has seemingly brought only half of the couple to the mating, what that means and if it is possible to rectify that and how. We get to see lots of secondary characters from both packs in this one, always fun. Some future storylines are hinted at. I loved the balance of romance and action/suspense in this one, finding it quite well done. I can't wait for more of the Talons series. This was definitely a 4 star read.My thanks to the author for an advanced copy of this book to read and formulate an honest review.

Brad, Todd and Scarlett were friends from freshman year of high school. Brad always felt drawn to Scarlett, but Todd claimed "dibs" and went on to date her all through school and marry her. A decade later, Todd has died while an active duty SEAL. Before his last mission, he tasked Brad with taking care of Scarlett and their young daughter should anything happen to him. Brad agrees, and thus begins this book. We seem them briefly at the funeral, and then 2 years later, when Brad convinces her to move to their home town. By then, she is tentatively ready for a relationship, though they start as friends. This is a friends to lovers and a second chance romance kind of rolled into one. Brad was also a SEAL in the past and now works for the fire department. He has always cared for Scarlett, and now is his chance if he can get past his survivor's guilt.This romance is very sweet, the hero very ready for marriage and family. He is cautious and makes sure at every point that he is building something he hopes will last. I loved their friendship to relationship story. I didn't enjoy this one quite as much as the last one in the series for whatever reason, but I definitely did like it. This series is loosely grouped together by all the men being part of a public servants calendar, but the separate couples are not close friends so you definitely don't need to have read earlier books to enjoy this one. There is just a cameo from the prior two couples. A 4-star sweet and happy read.My thanks to the publisher for providing an advance copy of this book to read and formulate an honest review via Netgalley.

First off, I love this series.  I missed book 2, but books 1 and 3 I loved.  Unfortunately, this one didn't quite reach that level of like for me.  What the author always does though is provide a professionally written tale with lots of depth and issues.Violet and Cain grew up together with their military families, along with Jeremy.  It turns out both boys fell for Violet, but she eventually became engaged to Jeremy, who died on active duty.  Cain and Jeremy were best friends.  Because of the situation, Cain feels he can never be with Violet as she was his best friend's fiance.  This is the huge conflict throughout the entire story, and here is where it lost stars.  I really do get that he felt that way, but the book was this drawn out saga of him drawing her closer and then hurting her by leaving her again and again and again.  It was just crazy and got a bit dull after a while.  That is not to say I didn't like both characters a lot.  Also awesome was getting to see all the secondary characters, couples from prior books, supporting and friends with this couple.  There were also some truly funny moments and some incredibly sweet ones.  This author is very talented.The last portion of the book we got a good grovel from our hero, and he really put in some serious work to resolve his issues in a reasonable way.  I liked to see that, and it gave credibility to a lasting happily ever after.  The epilogue was sweet, and we got a taste of the next book in the series.  I will definitely continue with this series, but this just wasn't my favorite.My thanks to the publisher for an advanced copy of this book via Netgalley to read and provide an honest review.

This is the second in a series, but I read it as a standalone, and my first book by this author. It appears to read just fine as a standalone. The background seems to be given adequately. The first book was centered around friends of this couple.Here, we have Ben and Devin. Both are new college graduates on their way to New York, Ben for a job opportunity afforded to him in the prior book, and Devin to live with her best friend and find work. At the opening, they met and have known each other for roughly 6 months, but Devin during this time has resisted Ben's attempts to start a relationship other than simply friendship. She comes from a bad background and is fearful. Both of them have some issues to work out regarding family, on both sides interfering with their ability to relate to each other. They just begin to settle into a tentative relationship when something very big happens to throw another wrench into the plan.While I admire the author for the plot she constructed, something I need to leave out basically to avoid spoilers, I just found this book too crazy in the drama category for my tastes. It was nonstop drama, drama and more drama of the teenage/new adult variety, and some really really crazy stuff. The writing was good, but it just wasn't for me despite Ben being an awesomely mature hero here. I would consider a different book by this author because she comes into this genre with a fresher plot line and writing for sure. So, 3 stars for writing and interesting perspectives, and a new writer on my watch list.My thanks to the publisher for providing me an advance copy of this book to read and formulate an honest review.

Estelle comes to New York to apartment sit while her brother goes to a conference. Unfortunately, she hates the city, missing her quiet home in the suburbs with greenery around her. She is in the store getting some groceries as her brother left her with an empty fridge when disaster strikes in the way of raining down pickles. Oops! Crosby feels bad about the disaster but intrigued by Estelle. They meet again and decide to enjoy her two weeks in New York together, but of course they don't want it to end and are left with the issue of living on separate coasts, each tied by business and life to their own coast.The beauty of this novel isn't the plot. The story itself is very simple and typical for a romance. What I loved about it was the humor, the bantering between the couple as well as with their siblings/family. It was a light novel that made my smile, very enjoyable. It was my first book by this author but won't be my last as I loved the style. Highly recommend!My thanks to the publisher for providing me an advanced copy of this book to read and formulate an honest review.

This was a DNF for me. I have read and enjoyed books by this author before, but I just couldn't make it through this one. It read as completely unbelievable, and the writing in this one was tell rather than show, low on dialog and simplistic. I would probably read another by this author, but not this series.My thanks to the publisher and Netgalley for providing me a copy of this book to evaluate and formulate an honest review.

Rowan and Seth fell in love as teens. Then one night a tragedy occurred, and Seth is sent to prison for something he didn't do. He pushes her away, and blames her for 7 years for what happened to him.Seth comes home to their town when his grandmother dies. He also indicates he wants Rowan back, realizing that she is not at fault for what happened. This is there I had a problem with the story. Rowen during the 7 years has cared for his grandmother, managed his grandmother's auto shop, stayed in her home and generally made sure everything was running smoothly as he stayed away. He comes in and states it is his house and shop (true), and threatens to fire her, etc. This is a guy who wants her back? Huh? She makes mistakes too, but is so afraid of opening up and getting left behind again. So what does he do? He threatens to leave her and does multiple times, knowing that is her fear. This book was just crazy for me to attempt to read. The writing was really not bad, the characters more than one sided, and the secondary characters great. However, this guy just couldn't seem to make up his mind at all and the wild yanking back and forth just didn't do it for me at all. It is my very personal pet peeve but I don't want the tension/conflict in a book to be a hero who can't make up his mind how he is going to treat his heroine. Therefore, this gets 3 stars from me because of plot and plot only despite good writing and characters.There will be further books. I think the next is Piper and Jase. Based on this book, it should be good, but will watch and see how that plays out. She is a shy little thing, Rowan's best friend, and he is Rowan's brother, fresh out of prison, and now a tattoo artist.My thanks to the publisher/Netgalley for a complimentary copy of this book to read and offer an honest review.

This is the third in a series, but can stand alone if you haven't read the prior ones. Each book is a separate couple, and there is limited series-wide story arc going on. The entire series centers around a group of friends who happen to make up a couple different crime families in New York. This story is Maksim, who came from Russia with his Pakhan (the father of the heroine from book 1). He works for his Pakhan and owns a nightclub. The heroine is the owner of a nearby nightclub, Sydney. We met her briefly in book 2, when she was able to assist that couple. In book 2, Maksim was interested in her but she was resistant to his charms. In this book, we get to see why she as so resistant, what happened in her past and what now is risking her future. She is in trouble, and Maksim and his friends are in the perfect position to assist her. Maks has the most tortured past of the heroes so far, truly awful, but in this book he is actually a toned down version of what we saw in prior books funny enough. I kind of miss how outrageous he was in those first two, but he makes a good hero in this one.I liked book 1, book 2 not so much, and I really loved this one. Books 1 and 2 were remarkably similar to each other, but this one breaks out of the mold with different tone. I love that. It feels as though the author's voice is strengthening with experience. Her characters are more unique and rounded. There is still action in this one, some gruesome as fitting of a crime family book. She doesn't take it overboard or out of the scope of what would be expected in this genre.Maks and Sydney are a good fit for each other. We also get to see some progression of a series wide plot involving Gabriel and his brother (missing after book 1), Aleks and his lost love (I think they are the next book?), Lore and another in their group, a cameo of Nika's brother and his motorcycle club, etc. So, while books 1 and 2 aren't critical, it makes this one even more fun. I can't wait for the next in the series!My thanks to the publisher/Netgalley for an advanced copy of this book to read and provide an honest review.

This was 3.5 to 4 stars for me.I loved the first one, and enjoyed this one as well, though I had a hard time getting into the story at first. I picked it up and put it down a few times before it really grabbed me. Logan is Darcy's cousin from book one, and he is a chef with his own restaurant in Falcon, the small town featured in this series. Logan also helps coach the town's high school football team. Jessica is sent by a corporation owned by her father to entice Logan again from Falcon to come to one of their own restaurants. Logan turned them down before, so now Jessica is sent by her domineering father to Falcon to confront him in person and get him to sign on with their company in whatever way she can. Well, when they meet there is confusion, some funny moments and attraction. Eventually, their getting to know each other will change the course of both their futures. Jessica especially undergoes a change, both through her relationship with Logan but also with the other characters of the small town. This is a story of her really thinking about what it is she wants out of life. As with the first book, all the secondary characters, and the town itself are funny, enjoyable and relaxing. This is a laid-back read suitable to the small town setting of the story. Once I finally got past the first bit it kept me reading for sure. I will definitely be continuing with this series and this author. She writes small towns very very well.My thanks to the publisher/Netgalley for an advance copy of this book to read and provide an honest review.

Rating:  4 fluffy, happy starsThis is a novella, available alone and in the Alphas After Dark anthology.  Jim and Lillie meet in Vegas and decide to have a fling.  Both are bear shifters, and they don't talk much about themselves, pasts, etc.  There is a bit of mystery, especially surrounding Lillie.  It all works out happy as can be in the end.  And that is it.  Yep.  The writing is good, and it is a happy feel good story for an afternoon with some laughing and sexy moments.  A good read.

Rating:  4.5 stars rounded up to 5!This is my first book by this author, but definitely won't be my last.  The book opens 12 years in the past, and we see a little vignette that is very important to Xander, the hero, then again years later with another very pivotal moment in his life.  The book then picks up 3 years after that.  Xander is a gym owner in Australia.  He fought pro for a while and then, after a traumatic event, went back to his hometown to open a gym and train other fighters and students.  Eden was on the cusp of a modeling career when she suffered burn scars that wiped out her career, and her self-confidence.  Years later, she is still struggling with coping with the transformation of her image.This book is about the relationship between Xander and Eden, their ability to bring out the best in each other as well as challenge each other to fight personal demons and insecurities.  The series title actually comes from that, oni apparently being demons ... thus "demon fighters."  Their romance is sweet and hot, but there is a lot more to this book that gave it extra stars.  Both fought hard with trauma in their pasts and displayed remarkable maturity and strength.  The secondary characters were interesting.  There were some "bad guys" that gave us some drama, but nothing over the top.  I loved the whole story.  It was long, and dragged the tiniest bit in a couple places as the exposition got long and drawn out, but the story was too awesome to let that slow it down too much.  The whole thing was emotional and inspirational, something that sticks in the memory.We are given hints of what is going on with a secondary character, Dane, but apparently the next in the series in his book.  That too sounds like it will be a great story.My thanks to the publisher and Netgalley for the complimentary copy of this book to read and formulate an honest review.

We got this tie for my 13yo son.  He needs to wear it 3 evenings per month.  We bought it in January, and at this point I have had to hand sew most of the stitching that keeps the folds of the tie closed on the back, and had to reattach the tag on the back that also serves to tuck in the back part of the tie when knotted.  We don't wash this thankfully, so the stitching coming out appears to come from just typical wear, albeit with a teenage boy (let's face it that they are hard on clothing in general).  My husband's more expensive ties have not had these problems at all over years and years of wear.  So my recommendation is that this tie looks fine and is very suitable for occasional use, or more heavy use if you are willing to hand stitch things in place as needed.  It is not the more durable menswear item I have found, but the price was right for our needs.  If you are considering this for very heavy use (uniform for work or such), you might want to pick a different brand/tie.  If you need it once or very occasionally, the black one looks and functions fine.

This was a hard one to rate.  I debated hard between 3 and 4 stars, but it's uniqueness pushed it to four.Dylan is from book 1 of the series, from the love triangle sort of there.  He is back from the mental facility after treating his bipolar disorder and working.  Along comes Emma, a new hire at the furniture factory.  And he falls for her but is terrified given his past situation with Jess, his illness, and the slew of problems surrounding Emma in addition to her being a coworker.This book suffered from a meandering storyline with some crazy inclusions of mobsters and exes and whatever thrown on in.  It differed a lot from book 1 in that sense.  But I liked the story of Dylan and Emma, and I liked how his mental illness was handled, factually and honestly, with admission that it was going to frankly be a life-long management process with no cure.  I love that in this book, and that Emma was realistic and accepting of his strengths and his weaknesses.  Good for them for creating a strong base for their relationship.I could have done without that weird mobster plot.  I do believe though that Cooper from this book is the next hero, so that sounds like a lot of fun to read.  I like this author with her unique voice.

Rating: 3 to 3.5 starsThis is the second Serena Bell novel I have read, I think. She has a very straightforward writing style that is interesting and engrossing. Here, we have Kincaid, who is just out of prison for a violent crime, but which occurred while he was attempting to protect another. I personally as a reader have serious doubts what was described would have given him a sentence that harsh, but I'm not a lawyer so who knows. In any case, we have him just out of prison. Lily is a chef, currently working as a waitress and living with her sister after undergoing not only a breakup with her boyfriend but losing him as a mentor and thus losing her job prospects. They meet as he comes into the diner to eat.The story is actually pretty simple, them overcoming past insecurities and issues to find their way forward together. There is light BDSM in the story, attempting to be integrated but it felt a bit forced despite being a big part of the storyline funny enough, with Lily and her ex and now with Kincaid. There was a light element of mystery/suspense that flowed well in the story, though the resolution was pretty obvious.Overall, a good but not outstanding book in my opinion. It was a good light read with some serious elements but not overly heavy or taxing to read. I would definitely read more by this author.My thanks to the publisher for providing a complimentary early copy of this book via Netgalley for review purposes.

I loved this - 5 stars for me - but it was SAD.Here we have Cam and Trix, children of the heroes/heroines of the prior round of characters in this series.  They have known each other since they were children, but that doesn't make their romance easy.  In fact, it makes it harder as there is an age gap (6 years I think).  That means Cam matures faster, and is a prospect and then a member/brother before Trix is out of her teens ... with her dad (Dragon) being Cam's MC brother, as well her grandfather (Poet).  That is a hard setup, on top of the emotions of the couple.  This book doesn't span the years of Poet's book or anything, but we do see them over some years.  I liked them as a couple despite some immature and cruel moments on the parts of both of them.  Nicole Jacquelyn writes very human and rounded characters, complete with crummy decisions, immaturity and personality characteristics that aren't terribly desirable.The outside influences in this one are very mild and really kind of weak in terms of the threat to the club.  I never quite got the full story there, but maybe the details went flying past my head or something.  It was a little bit bizarre honestly but whatever.  There was some outside danger/threat to the club as a whole.  It was not part of the prior story arcs.The minor spoiler-ish part of this is that there is tragedy, in that there is death aside from the bad guys.  I'll leave it there.  As a reader, I hate when it happens, especially in romance.  But then again I find myself admiring those authors for daring to completely anger their readers by including it.  If the writer feels it is necessary for some reason, I usually sniffle my way through it.  Not my favorite plot though, I'll admit, and this one was especially sad.  I still was very engrossed in the book and loved the storytelling.At the end, there is a preview of the next book - Will's book!

The Fisher-Price Bright Beats 3-in-1 Bright Pod comes with two pods in a set.  The age range of 3 months to 36 months seems pretty true, since this toy was a hit in our house, both with the 5 month old and the 2 1/2 year old.Mode 1: Tummy time made fun! My 5 month old grandson loved these for his tummy time sessions.  He held his head up and kicked like crazy to try and reach them the entire time.  The beat pods light up and play music: one plays music and the other plays a drum beat, the colors change and the music is fun for the baby and not annoying for the parent.  He was cooing and interacting the entire time.Mode 2:  This is for babies/toddlers that are sitting up. When you hit/touch one pod, the drum beat goes off and the other goes on; it was fun to play with them with our 2 1/2 year old.  The lights go on and off on both pods during this mode.  The pods also have little rattles on them; one more thing to get the child's attention.Mode 3: This is for crawling/walking toddlers.  I set the pods across the room and my granddaughter would run back and forth touching them.  Once you touch the pod playing music, it stops and the other one starts.  She loved this game.  Again the music was upbeat and fun.  We also tried turning off the lights in her room and had a little light and dance party, tapping the pods and watching the lights go off and dancing to the music.  It was really very fun.  She could easily carry them around; although the bottom of the pod is large and round, the neck is thin enough for little hands to grasp/carry comfortably.These pods are fun, interactive toys for baby and toddler.  I can see getting a lot of use out of them and definitely recommend them.Note: Each pod requires 3 AA batteries which were not included.

The Serta Perfect Balance Organic Crib Mattress provides good quality protection.  The top is a quilted, soft material and the underside is totally waterproof (even for a two year old who had an accident when she napped, there was no leaking through to the mattress); there is elastic to keep it safely around the mattress.  I tried this on both a standard crib mattress and a foam crib mattress.  On the standard mattress it is a good, snug fit.  I like that the sides of it are very fine material, which does not impede the airflow from the crib mattress vents. Because the foam mattress is a little thinner than a standard crib mattress, this cover wrapped all the way around to the bottom of the mattress.  It washed and dried well, on a normal drying cycle.I am very happy with this mattress cover and would buy it.

If you want to see some happy kids, get the Power Wheels Harley-Davidson Cruiser! This has Fisher Price quality and attention to detail, and the look of a real miniature Harley-Davidson motorcycle.  It's a definite five star purchase.It took about 45 minutes to put the bike together. The pieces were easy to find and instructions were easy to follow. We built ours with our 6 and 4 year olds and it was actually not frustrating to have them helping out.  Most of the construction involved screwing the plastic pieces together, so it was fairly easy. The hardest part was assembling the front wheel. It was easiest doing this with one adult holding the bike off the ground and the other adult pushing the rod through the bike and wheel. The stickers took about 10 minutes; there are a lot of them, but again the instructions are easy to follow. The stickers provide a lot of detail on the bike that give it a more realistic appearance. Very nice! Our 6 year old did our stickers and I was able to carefully peel them off when he accidentally misaligned them. The only thing I don't like,  is that some of the stickers go on curved parts of the bike but they are flat stickers so it was nearly impossible to get them on the bike with out wrinkles. From far away you would never see that, so its not a big deal at all. It just bothered me that I could not get them on without wrinkles. The battery is held in with a bar over it, so that the little ones can't take it in or out; this is a great new feature. We have another battery powered ride on vehicle that does not have this safety feature and the boys take the battery out and try to charge it by themselves. Having it screwed down eliminates this stress - major plus.  Another unexpected plus was that the battery comes charge, so we could use it right after it was assembled. No waiting to ride! It is not a full charged battery but it was enough for them to ride it for about 90 minutes before we had to charge it again.The power wheel has 4 wheels so its very sturdy and not an actual 2 wheel power wheel. The foot rest is large and makes for getting on and off very easy. Our 6 year old felt very comfortable on it and he is tall.  The bike has two speeds. You have to connect the wire for the little one to be able to put the bike at it fastest speed. This is a great feature for families that have multiple aged children using it.  Our 3 year old was able to drive it on the slow speed and i could easily walk by her and help her steer. We connected the wire for the 4 year old and the 6 year old; they were able to easily drive it at the fastest speed (5 mph). The car is easy to steer and handled the sidewalk very well. It was slower in the grass and spun out a little but for the most part it kept moving. It has a horn and engine rev noise button which the kids loved.It is very sleek looking and a great ride on toy. All the kids love it. Huge hit!

I'm not a fan of the Belkin Sport-Fit Universal Armband for iPhone/ Galaxy etc.  The material seems ok; it was easy to adjust.  I used it when walking so I wouldn't have to carry my phone. It is a very tight fit for the IPhone 6  - I don't think it's as universal as they claim. You can operate the screen on the phone through the plastic but since you're outside, if it's sunny, you can't see it for the glare. It's ok for playing music while I walk.  I don't run or do strenuous workouts, so I can't speak to how it would hold up for that.  It's just not that comfortable and I've stopped using it.

What a perfect way to celebrate a new baby's first Christmas  with the Lenox 2015 Baby's First Christmas Carriage Ornament! This is a lovely keepsake, traditional Lenox quality, with cream colored china and gold decoration.  The baby carriage is simple and very cute.  I am probably going to write the baby's name on the reverse side, since this is going to baby #4 in a big family.  It makes a very nice and thoughtful gift; it does come safely packaged in an attractive red box.

The Bubula Stainless Steel Diaper Pail is truly the perfect diaper pail.  There is so much to like about this product.  I know, you're thinking "who would get excited about a diaper pail?" This is the product parents have been waiting for.  The design is sleek, good looking and made of stainless steel.  It's easy to wipe clean.  You can use ordinary tall kitchen bags in it, so no expensive specialty bags/containers to buy. The best part is no diaper odor - at all.  You load the bag into the lower part, then shut it.  When you want to put a diaper in - you just raise the thin top lid, drop in diaper, shut lid and THEN push the button that drops the diaper down into the bag.  Why didn't someone think of this sooner?  Granted, it is a little pricey at approx $77 but trust me, it is worth every penny.  I recommend this without reservation - gave it to my daughter and she loves it.

The Serta Nightstar Extra Firm Crib and Toddler Mattress is a winner on all counts!  This is certified Green Guard Gold, which means it is certified for low chemical emissions.  It is ready to use right out of the box.  It comes wrapped in a thick plastic bag; no dust and no chemical odor whatsoever.  It has a nice waterproof vinyl cover which was easy to wipe down and has small air vents on the side.  This is a nice firm mattress; it looks and feels well constructed, yet it is light enough to take out and change the bedding when necessary.  My four month old grandson, who is a big boy, has slept soundly on it from day one.  I feel this is an excellent quality mattress for a reasonable price ($100) and delivered to your door in three days.  I definitely recommend this.

The Four Paws Wood Portable Decorative Gate is good looking with its' dark wooden finish and modern design.  It opens from 24-68 inches and is 17 inches tall.  It is made of three wooden panels that can be extended almost full for wider areas, zig-zag style for medium areas or you could close two panels for smaller areas. It is pretty sturdy and not easily knocked down.  When it is closed, it is a good 4 inches or so thick, so it takes up some space when you are not using it.  This is more for small dogs who are not jumpers, as it is only 17 inches high.Cons:  There is a very strong paint odor that has yet to go away after four days; perhaps this needs to be outside for a while to air out before bringing it into the house, or maybe ours was a fluke.  I thought this would be useful for blocking off the kitchen for our dog, but the way the hinges are set to let the gate be free-standing, you can't make a "U" shape; it needs to be a zig-zag shape to stand up and this did not work out well for our space constraints.

These Tovolo Jelly Roll Baking Mats are a must for every kitchen! I had previously purchased an expensive ($18 for one)Silpat mat, which I loved but two of these, that are the exact same size are 2/$18.  They are slightly thinner than the Silpat mat and a bit longer - they extend the whole length of a standard jelly roll pan.  They perform exactly the same as the Silpat mat.  They are a must for cooking baking; no need to keep buying parchment paper - just get yourself a set of these mats.  They clean up easily  with soap and water. I highly recommend them.

This Simple Stories Claus & Co Collection Kit is cute and unlike other things they advertise as a "kit"...this actually is one.  You get 6 sheets of 12  x 12 double sided nice weight card stock paper, 6 sheets of element pieces (also double-sided), and 2 different sheets of stickers.  Nice colors, well made, they coordinate well with each other and priced at approx $18; you could definitely get a few projects from this kit.

"My First Toolbox: A Lift-the-Flap Activity Book" by Anne-Sophie Baumann has a cute premise.  There are several  different tools in the book with moving parts that enable little fingers to see how they work.  I feel that the age 2-4 year old range is very accurate.  My  4 year old grandson was interested at first but after about a minute he put it down and hasn't touched it since.  My 3 year old granddaughter seems to be the perfect age for this book.  The illustrations are cute and not gender specific so it is good for both boys and girls. The pieces that do move are kind of flimsy and do not move very easily. My granddaughter ripped two of the pieces already trying to get them to move. it is also a little hard to grab the action pieces , so they are bent at the end from trying to grasp it with her little fingers. The handle is a cute idea but when you open it, you have to turn the book  upside down to use it, so it is awkward to hold (sideways might have been a better idea). If the pieces were sturdier and easier to move I could see using this book more, but considering the flimsy pieces and how they easily they get stuck,  I imagine this will be ripped and in the garbage in a short while.

This Woods 6-Outlet Television Surge Protector for Multimedia is a steal at $11.49 on Amazon and a must-have electronics protector.  It is all about ease of use and attention to detail with a low profile that fits well in a tight space, a 4 foot cord, 6 outlets with sliding safety covers, cable protection, a surge indicator, a ground indicator and even a right angle plug.  When I received this, I also noted that in contrast to the surge protector I was using, this one has extra protection up to 1000 joules; with the cost of replacement of the equipment that I have plugged into it, I am definitely glad of the extra protection.  There is a lot of protection provided in this slim package.Note:  An interesting fact from the instruction leaflet - it said all surge protectors have a finite life of approximately 2-3 years, which I did not know (beyond that, they pass electricity but do not surge protect).  More than ever, I'm glad I replaced my old surge protector with this one.

I love Eminence skin care products.  Of the moisurizers I have tried, the VitaSkin Bright Skin Moisturizer with SPF 30 is my favorite.  I cannot honestly say that I noticed my skin is brighter, but it is definitely smoother.  This is a very creamy moisturizer that applies easily and blends in well, leaving my skin smooth but not greasy.  Another thing I like is that there is no overwhelming scent; very mild and fresh smelling.  This product is noncomedogenic in my experience.  The price is great at Amazon too.

My review of the Fisher-Price Roller Blocks Tumblin' Zebra is based on my 11 1/2 month granddaughter's use of it.  It is sturdy and cheerful; typical Fisher-Price Quality. My granddaughter liked playing with the blocks; they have shapes that turn inside them.  She did drop them through the hole at the top and was underwhelmed.  This did not hold her interest for very long. She played with the blocks themselves more than with the zebra.  I would say for the size and price (approx $15) this would be a good toy for grandparents to keep at their house, not one that would entertain a child for very long.

I bought this Summary & Analysis of Paula Hawkins "The Girl on the Train" because we were reading the book for book club and I thought it would help with our discussion.  It was of no benefit and I would not recommend it.  On the other hand "The Girl on the Train" itself was very well written and I recommend it.

For a reasonable $35, this Conair Infiniti Pro Dual Voltage Styling Tool delivers!  I usually use a travel hair dryer because the full size dryers are too heavy for me to hold for any length of time.  While not as light as my travel dryer, this dryer is lighter than my other full size dryers and smaller in size, fitting nicely in my hand.  A plus over my usual dryer is that the warmest setting does not feel hot on my head, due to the ceramic technology providing infrared heat, yet with its 3 heat settings and 2 heat speeds, this dryer delivers professional quality results.  There is a separate cold button to finish up and set curls.  It also comes with a diffuser and an attachment to concentrate the heat.I've liked using this - it gives me good results and right now there is a $5 off coupon on Amazon!

What's not to love about the Graco Premium Foam Crib and Toddler Bed Mattress?  The mattress came rolled up in a box that was lightweight and easy to pick up.  As per the instructions, it does take approximately two days  to get to full size. I was concerned because it had a faint odor to it at first but that went away. The mattress fits in both the crib and the toddler bed perfectly. It seems to be just as firm as the coil mattress that we had in the crib previously. Both the toddler and the baby  have gotten good night/nap sleeps on it. I laid on it and thought it was comfy. It is actually more comfy to me then the coil mattress. I also really like that we can roll it up and store it if necessary. I think it would even be a good idea to purchase a second one for sleep-over guests, since it would be so easy to store until needed, or to take with you if you go visiting family.Overall, this is a good quality, firm, comfortable mattress for a great price.  I  would definitely recommend to anyone looking for a  mattress for a crib or toddler bed; it is a lot cheaper than the coil mattress but just as firm and comfy.

I've been using the Viva Labs Magnesium Bisglycinate Chelate 200mg for several weeks now.  The bottle has 240 tabs which equals a 60 day supply (2 tabs twice a day with meals).  I have noticed no gastric upset of any kind and have not had any leg cramps at night (an occasional problem for me).  The Amazon price is $16.99 for a two month supply.  I would buy this product again.

Twins mean twice the fun at a reasonable cost when you are talking about the Berenguer Boutique Twins.  These 15" soft body baby dolls are adorable and they come with plenty of accessories.  One boy and one girl doll, each with their own bottle, pacifier, shoes, "lovey" blanket, a cute outfit, matching hat and a pair of shoes.  The 15" size is good for the 2+ age group. Their eyes open and shut.  The head, arms and legs are vinyl but not stiff; the body is soft, so all and all these are good dolls for cuddling.  The pacifier fits in the mouth opening but strangely, the nipple on the bottle does not and I even tried squeezing the dolls' cheeks together.  My 2 1/2 year old granddaughter loves these babies (especially the pacifiers)! Considering all the accessories, I think they will work well for a long time.  The box doesn't mention washability but I have wiped the vinyl down; haven't had to clean the body yet.Really, for the $39 price on Amazon, you can't go wrong and the twin factor really doubles the fun.

I found that the Thrive BodyShave Oil works as promised; it leaves your skin smooth and soft,  not red/rough after shaving. There is a lot to like in this vegan-acceptable product.  It is cruelty-free and has not been tested on animals.  It's botanical scent is suitable for men or women but I found that the scent lingered more than I would like,  even after rinsing.  It is made of natural, unique oils found in Costa Rica and the purchase helps local farmers, so you feel like you are making a good choice on all counts when you use it.Basically you wet your skin, apply the oil and work it up into a lather.  I started with a dime size amount of oil and had to reapply twice to get it to lather up; it will be a flat, see-through type of white lather (nothing like shaving cream, more like soap).  The razor glides nicely and after rinsing, the skin feels smooth.  The bottle is small enough to take with you for travel or put into an even smaller container since you can just pour it; no pressurized metal cans etc.I'm just not sure about the fragrance but it performs as advertised and lives the skin very smooth and soft after shaving.

Bounty with Dawn Giant Rolls is an incredible product that I recently had the ability to test.  Like the name says, these are oversize rolls of Bounty paper towels that have been infused with Dawn.  These are full size paper towels; I personally prefer the smaller tear off format, so I ripped one of these new towels in half.  I wet it and the bubbles of Dawn were immediately evident.  I cleaned my butcher block island; it did a great job on coffee and fruit stains.  I rinsed it and then used it to clean my counter tops.  I rinsed it again and cleaned both my sinks - after all this rinsing and cleaning, there was still some soap and the paper towel itself was still strong and rinsed clean.  I went on to clean my bathroom sink.I was truly amazed at how strong this paper towel was (after rinsing and using 8 times I threw it out and it still was as strong as when I started).  The Dawn lasted through several rinsings.Cons:  I used a plain paper towel to wipe up after cleaning the first few times when it still had a fair amount of Dawn left.  You wouldn't use this for windows. Some people may not want to buy two kinds of paper towels.Pros:  This product has the strength of Bounty and the cleaning power of Dawn; it does the job and then some!  I expect these rolls to last a very long time - in truth it is almost like using an actual cloth that you can rinse out over and over.  Even with scrubbing the sink, they held up very well.  For me, this is a great product and I will buy it again.

Readers of cosy mysteries, especially those who are quilters, will be interested in " A Stitch in Crime: Quilts of Love Series" by Cathy Elliott.  The plot revolves around a big quilt show, the first ever  that is being held by the Quilt-Without-Guilt-Guild.  Thea James, a young woman who is running her family's Antique Emporium in the small town of Larkindale, and a novice quilter, has been talked into co-chairing the event.  It is safe to say that nothing goes as planned; her friend and quilt mentor Mary-Alice Wentworth is injured at the opening soiree and a valuable family broach goes missing.  That's not all that goes missing...the esteemed judge Dr. Cottle is a no show for several early events.  Thea's co-chair Prudy is no help whatsoever and Thea's best friend Renee suddenly seems like her worst enemy.  There is a possible love interest for Thea in the form of a local newspaper reporter/photographer, Cole Mason.  The closer it gets to the opening of the show, the more headaches for Thea, ultimately resulting in the theft of the heirloom Larkin's Treasure Quilt - owned by Mary-Alice's family.This is a Christian-style cosy mystery; no swearing, no sex and a simple story that revolves around events in a small town.  Neither the characters or the mystery is very complex but it is an easy read for those who enjoy this genre.

I am very happy with the Avery Shipping Tags in Manila with Reinforced Holes.  Not only is the card stock a nice heavy weight but even when I tried, I could not rip the reinforced holes.  Also, instead of string, these tags are attached with wire; you are going to have to work pretty hard to get these off.  This is the kind of good quality I've come to expect from Avery and they don't disappoint.

"She Has Your Eyes" by Elisa Lorello is the continuation of the story of Andi and David that was begun in the author's prior books "Faking It" and "Ordinary World".  You do not need to have read the earlier books in the series as Ms. Lorello gives enough back story throughout the book.  Andi is a widow and a professor at a small liberal arts college.  She lives with and is in love with David, who is an artist and art dealer.  She met him before her marriage when he called himself Devin and ran an escort service (yes, really).  After her beloved husband Sam's death on their fourth wedding anniversary, she met David again, fell in love and they are enjoying a pretty picture-perfect life together.  He is talking to her about marriage (she is reluctant to commit) when the doorbell rings and they find a 15 year old girl named Wylie on their doorstep.  She has tracked David down because she recently found out that her Dad is not her biological father and she thinks that David might be...David responds with shock and denial, but to Andi, it is obviously a possibility as she tells David "she has your eyes".  The story that follows is about the changes that Wylie brings to David's life, their life as a couple, how Wylie fits in with her family and David and Wylie, issues with Andi's relationship with her mother, letting go of her deceased husband and an ex-fiance of Andi's that resurfaces in the midst of her unsettled emotional state.  A lot happens at once but the issues themselves are interesting.I think this could easily have been a more serious work of fiction , along the lines of Anita Shreve's "The Pilot's Wife", but  I think it's a good example of  chick-lit (not that there's anything wrong with that). This was an okay, "beach read" type of book for me.  It was entertaining, if predictable but I did not like it enough to want to read the two prior books in the series.  If you are looking for a light read, this might fit the bill.

I have long been a fan of Karin Fossum's writing, so I was excited to preview an advanced copy of "The Drowned Boy", the latest in the excellent Inspector Sejer mystery series.  This is an author who never disappoints.  As I finished this book, my heart was pounding.  She is a master at the psychology of crime and her deliberate style lets the horror creep up on the reader page by page.The story begins with a tragedy, the accidental drowning of  16 month old Tommy, a toddler with Down Syndrome, in a pond behind his home.  His very young parents, Carmen and Nicolai are naturally distraught, and yet, there is something...something that seems off to Inspector Skarre when he is called to the scene; something that has him calling Inspector Sejer to voice his concerns.  Amidst some troubling health concerns of his own, Inspector Sejer begins the routine investigation into an accidental death and what he finds produces a sense of unease in both the Inspector and the reader.
