It's still a zoom lens, and a zoom lens that's pushing limits as well. Optical design is difficult, and some things like variable focal length pose serious challenges with the elements that correct stuff like the spherical distortion enemy of sharp focus. Imaging having to vary all of the spherical and chromatic distortion, astigmatism, and other correcting elements as the focal length changes. Changing distance between all lens elements might not be enough to correct everything perfectly at all focal lengths; likely the actual *shape* of elements would need to change as focal lengths vary. Assuming the technology even exists, you could expect to pay astronomical $$$ for it.Regarding sharp focus: I'm not convinced that this lens has any problems beyond the usual, but I do plan to use the autofocus fine-tune on my D7000 to calibrate the autofocus as well as possible for the focal range I usually use. I've had some lenses, especially wide-aperture lenses like f/1.8, that seriously benefited from some autofocus fine-tuning. Unfortunately you'll need at least a D7000 to get the fine-tune feature, and if a lens is seriously off then it probably needs to go back to Nikon for adjustment as part of the warranty.VR II performance: I think it's actually better than my other VR lenses but haven't compared carefully. I'm impressed.Focus range: The specs say 20", but I seem to be able to get a sharp image at 8" away, at any focal length. I think they must mean 20cm NOT 20". At 200mm the frame on my D7000 is about 3 3/4". Supposedly that's a 1:4.5 reproduction ratio which is good enough that some manufacturers would make the exaggerated claim that such is a "macro" lens.In summary: this lens won't replace all lenses in this focal range, but it does a respectable job of getting 18-200mm on your camera at one time. You're still going to need prime lenses and/or (expensive) continuous-aperture zoom lenses with wider apertures and less focal length variability.I'm happy enough with this lens that I'll probably sell my 18-105mm and 70-300mm lenses. (Arguably I should keep the latter in case I get a full-frame camera, but if I get one of those then hopefully I'll be able to just get the 28-300mm full-frame lens.) This 18-200mm lens almost delivers on Ken Rockwell's slightly exaggerated "replaces a whole bag of lenses" claim, but if I carry a camera bag it's certainly going to have at least one other lens in it depending on what I'm doing.

I've been keeping ink jet prints (Epson R3000, UltraChrome K3 ink, epson paper) in the larger version of these that I bought 8 months ago or so and  no signs of ink transfer or sticking. Prints slide out just as easily now as they did months ago, glossy paper included. At least with the media I'm using, these things just won't stick.How will the prints look in 50 years compared to unprotected prints? That's obviously rather difficult to say, but if the archival quality of the sleeves matches what I've seen so far then it won't be the sleeves at fault. I'm more suspicious of the paper. (I don't think that even the "Ultra Premium" epson paper is considered archival quality.)I only subtract one star because the price is kind of high, and for the price I feel like they should have come with hard (box type) sleeves.

According to lenstip.com, this filter along with the Hoya HMC Haze UV(0) - 72 mm, is the #1 performing model of filter out of the 20 or so that they tested, including ones from expensive manufacturers like B+W.Tests included spectral transmission using a photospectrometer, lens flare testing, and vignetting. Personally I think they should have put a little more weight on the flare tests which might have upped the ranking of one of the B+Ws, but it likely wouldn't have made much difference in the cost/benefit ranking.The Hoya HMC Haze UV(0) - Filter - UV - 72 mm is just as good as this one, performance wise, but supposedly the Pro1 Digital is just more solidly constructed. I don't have one of the HMCs so I can't really compare. Anyway, if you want to save some money you might go for the HMC version.I'm using these on 2 $1000 lenses.

This stuff saves a tremendous amout of trouble when it comes to hanging little bits of equipment (like flash triggers) onto other equipment (like strobes/speedlights). I also made my own "speedstrap" (gel holder) simply by taking 1 1/2' of the tape and sticking the loop half of the tape onto the back of the hooks half (resulting in a strip with hooks on one side and loops on the other). If you need lots of these then you might try velcro cable ties, but I'm not sure how suitable they'd be for holding gels onto the front of a flash or other applications that don't involve cable management. Anyway, the sticky velcro can be used to make cable ties as well as faten other objects together.Serious photographers with lighting equipment will probably want to get 15' of this stuff. It'll probably get used up faster than you think.The only things I wouldn't use these for are certain applications that need a very tight hold. For applications where you need something to practually be glued down to something else, but still need to be able to remove it *sometimes*, Velcro Industrial Strength is much much better. I've used the industrial strength stuff to install some gadgets in my car and the things might as well be glued down, except for the fact that I can remove them (which takes some real force) for maintenance etc and put them back with the same glue-like level of hold.

NOTE: For the geeky  extreme technical stuff like power consumption, see "TECHNICAL DETAIL" toward the bottom.I regularly do "tethered capture" with my DSLR. (In other words, I connect my camera to my computer while I'm actually taking photos so I can see the processed images as I take them.) Since it's practically impossible to have your camera connected to a computer with a 5' cable and still use it to take photos, I ordered the AmazonBasics USB 2.0 A-Male to A-Female Extension Cable (9.8 Feet/3.0 Meters) (which is a very good quality product for the price). Combined with the 5' cable my now 15' total length cable was really quite sufficient for most photography in the small studio bay I was using... well, most of the time.So I decided that I needed even more freedom to move around, and ordered this extension cable. I haven't used it much yet, but I ran some tests with my camera + 5' cable +10' extension + this 32' cable and had no connection problems over 3 hours or so of constantly staying connected and visible to the software. Note that I didn't use the cable with "live view" (same as having the computer use the camera as a remote video camera, basically) so there weren't data constantly being transmitted, but I did take lots of photos at various times (filling up the camera's RAM buffer so it's transmitting as fast as possible) and no issues there.The repeater on this cable is all the way on the far-side (away from the computer, etc) rather than in the middle of the cable. This is good because the repeater is a hub, and this lets you get another 5m of cable length with a regular cable. My guess is that you should also be able to connect at least one more active cable to this one as well.Note that the USB limit on cable length (5m or about 15') still applies to the repeater. So my 15' normal cable with no repeater is the longest normal cable that you can plug into an active extension cable. Longer than that and it may not work so well depending on whether or not the repeater exceeds USB specs or something.Another thing to be aware of is that the repeater uses up USB bus power. A normal "high power" USB port supplies 500mA, and the repeater claims that it needs 100mA to power itself. Since the repeater has no other power source, it can't "pass through" more than 400mA. (These values are approximate since, in reality, the amount of power is going to differ from what the hardware and specs say it should be.) Therefore if you use the cable to connect up a bus powered USB device (one that doesn't normally need to be plugged into the wall because it gets all of its power via USB), it can't be one that uses more than around 400mA. If it does, then the device will exhibit erratic behavior or fail to work at all because the repeater will incorrectly tell the device that it has 500mA on its 400mA port. (See TECHNICAL DETAIL below for the excruciating detail.)The female connector on the cable has a tight fit which is good since it would otherwise be too easy for the next cable to fall out.Lastly, I like this product overall and figure that it's similar to other such cables, but for what I do I wish the cabling were more flexible like the previously mentioned Amazon Basics 10' cable (which lays on the floor like a piece of nylon rope). This is no doubt a trade-off with the fact that the thing has thick shielding and thick outer insulation which has the benefit of making it more durable. The amount of flexibility is only going to matter to you if you're using the cable with a handheld device though, since it's perfectly fine for fixed placement behind desks and such. So for most people this extra durability tradeoff is all gain.I'd give this 5 stars, but I'm subtracting a star for the fact that the repeater falsely claims an output of 500mA when "asked" by a device via the USB protocol. Normally this will NOT be an issue for people as long as they realize that they can't use the cable with a "full power" USB device like the USB-Powered Portable LED Monitor I have. Since the cable flexibility won't be an issue for most people, and arguably it's worth the extra durability, I wouldn't lower the rating for that.TECHNICAL DETAILNon-engineers can ignore this section.The repeater is actually a full USB hub and is detected as such by the USB drivers.I decided that I wanted to figure out exactly what was going on with the repeater power-wise (after all, the thing must be consuming some power and can't pass all 500mA through it), so I did a bit of USB logging/probing to see what it was telling the USB driver on my mac. I used the standard OS X utility "USB Prober" along with the USB kernel extension for logging USB events and querying devices for their descriptors. The cable was plugged directly into a port on the MacBook.First off, the repeater is using a generic 4 port USB hub chip(set) which says it's made by Terminus Technology Inc. Even though it  says it has 4 ports, obviously only one of them has a connector, resulting in a "1 port hub" as odd as that sounds. The repeater is telling the USB controller (root hub) in the computer that it needs 100mA (out of the 500mA) fom the port. Essentially that's how much power it "asks" for and how much it claims the hub/repeater hardware needs. Assuming that it's not lying and actually using significantly less or more than 100mA, that leaves 400mA that it can use to power it's own port.So the repeater is basically telling the computer that it's a self-powered hub (such as the type you plug into a wall), but "self powering" itself off of the bus power from the port on the computer instead of a wall wart. This isn't toally unreasonable, but the repeater is *claiming* to downstream devices that it's single powered port will supply 500mA. Obviously that's not going to happen unless the thing contains a free energy machine or something.So if you plug a device that uses 400mA (or however much is available on the port in reality) or less then you should be OK; the bus power "passes through" the repeater with (what it claims is) 100mA drained off of it. So your device gets power.Unfortunately, if you plug in a device that "asks" for and needs 500mA of power (or more than 400 anyway), the repeater will falsely claim that it can supply 500mA on the port. As a result, the attached device won't get the power it needs and will exibit some sort of dysfunctional behavior depending on what it is. Sometimes this may be immediately obvious, but some devices may fail at random during usage when they suddenly try to use full power. Normally the hub wouldn't "lie" about the power and so this wouldn't happen. (I beileve the chipset that they're using isn't capable of "believing" it has less than 500mA on one of it's powered ports. This in fact may be true of all USB hub chipsets for all I know. But this chipset, unlike more sophisticated ones, does say that it isn't capable of tracking different amounts of power usage on different ports, so it may simply assume 500mA on all ports and have no ability to track total power available.)This probably isn't terribly bad as you can't expect an active repeater to consume no power, thus there's no way you can get 500mA through such a cable no matter what. And as long as your aware of the issue (essentially some bus-powered devices will work and some won't) then you'll have some idea what you can use it for.I don't know how many of these cables you are supposed to be able to connect in series, but in theory you should be able to connect more, using up another 100mA for each one. The repeater on each cable is going to claim it can output 500mA, making the current mismatch issue worse as you go. The signal delay caused by so many hubs in series might make this impractical before you ran out of current though. I'm pretty sure you should be able to connect 2 of these in series, but I'm not sure I'd try more than that. It's also going to depend on whether the cable is plugged into a hub that's plugged into a hub, etc, because USB has a maximum "depth" (number of hubs that can be connected in series) and will just refuse to work beyond that.

Normally I use Adobe Photoshop Lightroom 3 for everything, but it's extremely weak in some areas such as tethering where you can't change camera settings and the connection tends to go down if you take photos too quickly. Some of its RAW processing is just "ok" and not spectacular, but it's generally a good deal for the money. It's true that you can use Sofortbuild for Nikon tethering, but it doesn't allow changing camera settings either.Anyway, I bought Capture One primarily because I've been doing mostly tethered capture in the studio with a Nikon D7000 and some medium format backs and I managed to get it for about $100 due to an educational discount. Unlike Canon which gives Canon owners the EOS Utility capture software for free, Nikon wants you to buy their silly Capture NX2 in order to get a tethered capture utility. Since I could get Capture One Pro 6 at a rather substantial discount that actually made it cheaper than NX2, and I can use Capture One with a bunch of medium format backs and Canons, I said to heck with NX2 and bought this. A rather sad statement about Nilkon, but tethered capture alone makes Capture One worthwhile for Nikon users if you can get it at a massive educational discount.And oh yea, you also get some very impressive raw and other image processing capabilities. In fact this is the real reason why most people who use it would be willing to spend $400 on it.A tip for those who haven't used this before who are planning to: The UI in Capture One doesn't work in an immediately obvious fashion, but it's actually pretty good once you understand the design strategy for the thing. Workspace customization is extremely important especially if (for some simple stuff) you want the help of assistants who don't really know the software. Customize your workspace for what you do!  Use extremely simplified workspaces for particular purposes especially when less familiar people need to do something with it. Basically figure out the whole organization of the UI before doing anything else or you'll end up wasting lots of time wondering where things disappeared to.My ONLY complaint about Capture One Pro so far is that, unbelievably, it doesn't support live view for Nikon or Canon cameras! I just don't understand this since I thought these vendors pretty much provided all the code for this in their SDKs, so it seems like supporting live view would be easy. I'd give it five stars if only it supported live view for Nikon at least.UPDATE: I kept having problems with my camera randomly disconnecting during tethering at times (C1 stopped "seeing" it as being connected). It didn't happen too often, just enough to be annoying. When the last C1 update came out I actually read the release notes and noticed that they mention that certain older versions of Logitech Control Center can cause this problem. When I looked, I found that an old version of Logitech Control Center was installed on my laptop. (Not sure why... might have been automatically copied from my desktop.) Though a Logitech update should fix the problem too, I didn't need it so I just deleted it. After that I did a little stress test where I connected up the camera, shot in continuous mode for a while (constantly keeping the camera's RAM buffer full), and everything worked flawlessly. No images lost and no disconnections. I also just left the camera sitting there turned on for a few hours and still connected (until the batteries were almost dead), and it was still shown as connected in C1 and working when I came back. So the moral of the story is, read the release notes.

I'm using this with an iPad3. I read through the reviews of almost 10 different versions of these aftermarket camera connection kit type devices on Amazon and this one seemed like the one with the most encouraging reviews, so I bought this one.Here are the tests that I've counducted with this product:- My iPad3 is in a Zagg ZAGGfolio for Apple iPad 2 Carbon with Silver Keyboard (LEACSIPAD2) right now and the card reader thing fit into the dock port quite tightly without the case getting in the way at all. This could have been a problem if the reader didn't have as much space between the connector and the rest of the box, so I was quite happy to see this.- Inserted a SanDisk Extreme HD Video 16 GB SDHC Class 10 Memory Card (SDSDRX3-016G-A21) with a little over 1,200 JPEG files, and a few short videos, about 3.3GB total. Thumbnails all appeared almost immediately with no problem. I imported a few (didn't want to trash my photo stream with all of them) photos with no problem. Never got an "accessory incompatible" warning during this test.- Inserted an Eye-Fi Pro X2 8 GB Class 6 SDHC Wireless Flash Memory Card EYE-FI-8PC with several iPad screens worth of JPEG files. The Photos app immediately displayed a bunch of empty box thumbnails, but it took forever (more than a minute, at least) to display actual thumbnail images and I got the "This accessory is incompatible.." notice at some point. I just dismissed the notice and it continued doing it's thing. Thumbnails appeared in spurts but eventually all of the thumbnails appeared and I imported a few photos. I tried it another time and the thumbnails never completely appeared, so it seems rather unreliable with this particular card. Not sure I'll use this card with the thing anyway, but it seemed like a good card to use to test with an atypical SDHC card.- Switched the switch to "USB" and plugged in my Nikon D7000 with both the (now mostly empty) SanDisk card and the eye-fi card inserted in the camera. Thumbnails appeared almost immediately and I was able to download some images with no problem. I think the "accessory incompatible" notice might have appeared but I just dismissed it and continued on with no problem. Very quick response and no functional failures even though the images were on the eye-fi card that the card reader previously had trouble with. So using a camera that works to read SDHC cards seems to be a good way to workaround any SD card compatibility problems.I did not try plugging in a keyboard (I have no use for that as I'm using a bluetooth keyboard to type this) or any sort of card other than these two SDHC cards.So this thing seems to mostly work. The only problems are that it doesn't seem to like certain SD cards (this can be a problem with cameras as well) and the "accessory incompatible" warning appears in some situations sometimes but doesn't seem to really mean anything as everything continues to work (except with my eye-fi which was having problems, warning box or not).My guess is that most major brands of SDHC cards like SanDisk will probably work fine (Nikon really only certifies some of these mostly major brands of cards for use in their cameras, so I think device compatibility problems may just be typical with certain cards in many devices anyway.)The official Apple accessory is probably more solid, but for the $5 I paid for this thing it seems to work well enough that I can't complain. I don't intend to use this very often anyway. (I just figured that it would be worth having one around if I could get a working one for only $5.) If it cost any more than $5 I'd give it fewer stars, but for $5 I'd say it works well enough to warrant 4 stars. If it didn't have card compatibility quirks and never caused the compatibility warning to display then I'd give it 5 stars, but it loses a star due to these issues.

Neewer products are great when you just need a cheap version of whatever item that, while not so high quality, is at least good enough for whatever you need it for. Basically you get what you pay for, but at least you are getting what you pay for and not less than you pay for or something worthless. So while you get low quality at a proportionally low price, you still get sufficient value for the money and you have a low cost option for things that only need to be sufficient and not top notch.This reflector/gobo is pretty much the same sort of decent value as other Neewer products. It's not the absolute most solid construction but it shows no signs of coming apart right out of the box and seems to be more than sufficient for occasional use. I'm sure that if you're a pro who uses these things all day every single day then this thing will probably wear out too quickly, but I'm an amateur who only needs this sort of thing occasionally. Essentially this is like a consumer version of a blender or other appliance rather than a commercial version of an appliance. If you're a restaurant then you'll be using a blender all day every day and need one that won't die under such heavy use, but at home where you only use the thing a few times a week at most, if even that, buying a commercial version of something would be totally pointless.I haven't used this too much yet, but so far it seems to be sufficient for the frequency that I'll end up using it.

The design of this thing is such that it has a bulging area that keeps it from even coming close to fitting in any grip other than the specific knockoff grip that ATC sells. Some people have reported successfully filing off this bulge, but in order to do so you have to file all the way through the outer shell, exposing the insides. Some people have solved this problem by just duct taping over the resulting opening. Some people have cut out parts of the inside of their grips to get it to fit. Do some searching around and you'll find discussions about this on one or more forums.

Not only is the shell of this thing too soft, more like vinyl than hard plastic, but there is practically NO padding in the thing to provide reasonable protection. It's so bad that I'd rather just use no case since this thing is likely to do little more than provide a false sense of security. The little carabeaner type hook on the thing is the worst construction I've ever seen for this type of hook, and that's no exaggeration. I didn't know these things could even be constructed so poorly. The spring on the thing broke instantly and, even if it hadn't broken the first time I tried to open the hook, it would have broken pretty quickly anyway. In other words, this appears to be a design defect and very poor quality materials/construction, not an individual unfortunate one-off manufacturing defect in one unlucky unit.Unfortunately I failed to send this thing back in time so I'm stuck with it. I'll probably try to use it for storing something but certainly not something as delicate and critical as a hard drive.Don't buy this!!!  Just get the official hard case that Western Digital makes.

I wasnt going to buy this thing because it used to cost something like $120 and I normally use cheap Cactus triggers instead of the comparitively super expensive Pocket Wizards, but I started using the studio facilities at school and all of their stuff is Pocket Wizard based. I found that trying to carry around both a full PW transmitter along with the light meter is a real pain whether or not they're connected with a sync cable or not.  Either both hands are full or one hand is fumbling with two unwieldy devices.Still, I was not willing to spend over $100 for this. However this cumbersome situation was getting really annoying and I started looking around to see if I could find a better price. When I noticed that I could get the thing for $65 I was like "heck yea". I was pretty sure I was going to be using other people's Pocket Wizards enough that this would end up being worth it, even if I don't own any PWs myself.So far I haven't done much more than test it a few times, but on the L-358 I'm using configuration is quick and easy, and it works. I wasn't able to tell from the documentation alone, but once installed it was immediately obvious that the channel configuration was essentially just another "mode" just like corded or uncorded flash are modes. So basically when you're flipping through modes with the dial and mode button, the channel configuration mode comes up one click before the actual transmit/meter mode. This means that there's no funky stuff with holding down multiple buttons and turning the dial, etc, so setting the channel is very quick, easy, and it's obvious how to do it. If you hand the meter to an assistant who's never seen it before and tell them how to switch the modes, it will be immediately obvious to them how to set the channel with little or no additional explanation.While the transmitter is "only" supposed to have a 30m range as opposed to the 500m or whatever ridiculous range that the actual PW transmitters have, this is several times what I need for the tiny studio bays I'm normally limited to and it's probably enough for the majority of situations (but hey, I'm new to this so I don't really know how big sets might get). If you occasionally need more than a 30m range then you can always go back to using a regular transmitter at times, as annoying as it is. If you always need more range then perhaps this thing isn't so great. Note that the studio I'm using isn't large enough to test the range on this thing, and I'm not yet allowed to check out location kits that I can use outside, so I haven't been able to test the actual range of my unit. For all I know maybe it works from further away but just fails to trigger half the time when too far away or something.If I had to pay $120 for this then I'd probably give it 3 stars just due to expense (though compared to the cost of PWs I guess it isn't that horrible), but for $65 the price no longer annoys me so much and it's an easy 5 stars.Now if only they'd make some module like this for the Cactus or some other cheaper brand of trigger then I'd be thrilled. At least my Cactus transmitter is rather tiny and not as annoying to carry around cabled to the meter.

I have an iPad3. I bought both the Kensington KeyFolio Pro 2 Removable Keyboard, Case and Stand for iPad 2 and New iPad (K39512US), and the Zagg ZAGGfolio with Keyboard for The New iPad 3G (FOLCARSLV101). The Kensington I bought from Amazon and the Zagg I bought from Best Buy. So this is a comparitive review of both products used with the iPad 3.First the ZAGGfolio since thats the product I'm posting this reviw on. I'm typing this part with it now.Here are its advantages over the KeyFolio:The overall design of the case is not that good, but it seems to be more durable and capable of better protecting the iPad. The keyboard is also a little larger and seems more solidly constructed.- The hard plastic of the case is thicker, harder, and would seem to offer more protection. The KeyFolio isn't that bad but the Zagg is just more durable. Overall the ZAGGfolio construction is bit more solid.- The keys on the keyboard are larger than the ones on the KeyFolio keyboard. The Space bar and modifier keys on the bottom row are also maybe 30% taller than the other keys. Overall the keyboard is larger but neither is a full-size keyboard.- The Zagg keyboard can be used as a stand for the iPad with the iPad removed from the case.- Because you can use the keyboard as a stand, you can stand the iPad up in portrait orientation though you can only do this if you remove the iPad from the case.- Overall the Zagg keyboard is more solidly constructed though both keyboards are made of plastic. The Zagg keyboard is also a little larger but I don't know if this is for a larger battery or just to accomodate the built-in iPad stand.- The Zagg keyboard has a "Globe" key in the lower left that can be used to switch the keyboard language. If there's any way to do this with the KeyFolio keyboard then I don't know what it is.- While lacking brightness controls, the Zagg keyboard has dedicated Cut/Copy/Paste keys. Personally I think this is pointless because the standard Command-X/C/V key combos work on both keyboards and I'm much more used to those anyway.- The Zagg has the auto on/off magnet that sleeps or wakes the iPad when you open/close the case.ZAGGfolio problems:- The outside of the thing is covered with this fake carbon fiber "skin" sticker that looks cheap-o and some have reported that it's prone to peeling off.- The case doesn't feel like it clips securely closed if you try to close it with the keyboard removed. So I would not try to carry it around without the keyboard inserted.As for the Kensington KeyFolio:This one seems to have a better overall design than the ZAGGfolio and is capable of being set up in a larger number of positions. KeyFolio design advantages:- Significantly less expensive than the ZAGGfolio.- Easier to open.- Seems to stay closed more securely with the keyboard removed.- Easier to insert the iPad in the case.- The iPad3 seems to be held more securely in this case.- There's a stylus holder! This is very important if you ever use a stylus.- The keyboard is held in securely by strong magnets, but is much easier to remove from the case.- The USB port for charging the keyboard is exposed while inserted in the case so you don't have to partially remove the keyboard to charge it.- The iPad panel of the case has velcro on the bottom so, with the keyboard removed, you can stand the iPad up at any angle from vertical to a very low angle that's suitable for typing on the on-screen keyboard if you want. Unlike the Zagg, there are no fixed notches that limit you to 2 or so different stand angles. This continuous range of possible angles is VERY useful.- While neither case is very good for typing when placed on your lap, the KeyFolio is better for this  than the Zagg.- With the keyboard still inserted, the KeyFolio is more comfortable to hold when you fold the cover over to use the iPad like a tablet. It's not that much better but is it easier to avoid pressing the keys with the back resting on your hand. Since its also easier to remove the keyboard, it's easier to switch to using the tablet like this without the keyboard.- The KeyFolio keyboard has display brightness control keys while the Zagg doesn't. It also has a caps lock light,  will allow you to type F1-F12, and has a couple of extra keys like Pause/Break. This may not matter for the iPad but makes the keyboard more useful if you ever pair it with a Windows machine device or something. This keyboard also has a separate Delete and Backspace as well as an Insert key.KeyFolio Problems:- Unlike some photos show, there doesn't seem to be any proper way to rotate the iPad into the portrait orientation while using the keyboard. You can take the iPad out and sort of stand it up being held by the bottom flap of the holder, but this doesnt hold it very securely.- Currently I seem to be having some sort of problem where the left Shift key is interfering with the Z key. If I try to type ZAGG then I get Zagg because for some reason, Shift-Z essentially deactivates the Shift key even if you continue to hold down the shift key. (Releasing the shift and holding it down again, after typing Shift-Z, fixes the problem as does using the right Shift key.) The right Shift key doesn't seem to have this problem with neighboring keys. I'm unsure if this Shift-Z thing is a design problem or just a random manufacturing defect  in my particular keyboard.- This is minor, but the Command key is lacking the little curly corner command key symbol.- As people have mentioned, the "new car smell" from the outgassing on the KeyFolio, right after you remove it from the box, is rather strong. I would expect this to go away once all the residue has evaporated and I plan to place it near an open window, with the keyboard removed and all surfaces exposed to air, to speed this up.Both cases have:- Cutouts for all of the standard ports, buttons, speaker, camera, etc- Enough space around the dock connector to support my larger-than-normal 3rd party cable.- Bluetooth keyboards that have a "connect" button for easy obvious pairing.- Once paired, both keyboards connect instantly after being powered on. You will not be able to get your hands on the keys before they connect.- Both have special keys for the home key, slide show, mute/volume, audio player control, on-screen keyboard show/hide, search, and lock.- Both have Ctrl/Option/Command and arrow keys.- Some way to stand the ipad up for typing or viewing video/etc, and a way to fold the keyboard side of the cover behind the tablet for tablet-only use.- Use a standard micro USB port for charging.- A certain look. The Kensington looks more "white collar" and the Zagg looks more "blue collar". I don't consider either of these styles to be better than the other so I've noted it here to point it out.- Both seem about as bulky. Maybe the KeyFolio seems a little thinner just because it's softer.Verdict:Aside from the weird Shift-Z problem that might just be a defect in my particular unit, I like the Kensington KeyFolio better. The smaller keys don't really bother me, I REALLY want that stylus holder, I like the ease of removing the keyboard, the usb charging port is exposed without removing the keyboard, the velcro angle stand with infinite positions is very useful. I don't care if I can stand the iPad up on the keyboard alone with no case. The iPad seems to be held more securely (not as loose). If I need to type on my lap, this one is easier to do that with. The Kensington is also less expensive and overall seems to be a better value. Lastly, the keyboard seems to be more suitable for use with other devices if needed.So if that stuff is what's important to you then I'd get the Kensington KeyFolio.If you need larger keys, more solid (but not quite milspec) protection for tougher environments, better support for portrait orientation, never use a stylus, really want that auto sleep/wake magnet, and/or like the tough-looking style (vs the office management organizer style), then get the ZAGGfolio.UPDATE: See my comments on this review for a wear-and-tear update after a month of daily use.

I have an iPad3. I bought both this, the Kensington KeyFolio Pro 2 Removable Keyboard, Case and Stand for iPad 2 and New iPad (K39512US), and the Zagg ZAGGfolio with Keyboard for The New iPad 3G (FOLCARSLV101). The Kensington I bought from Amazon and the Zagg I bought from Best Buy. So this is a comparitive review of both products used with the iPad 3.First the Kensington KeyFolio Pro 2 since thats the product I'm posting this reviw on. I'm typing this part with it now.This one seems to have a better overall design than the ZAGGfolio and is capable of being set up in a larger number of positions. KeyFolio design advantages:- Significantly less expensive than the ZAGGfolio.- Easier to open.- Seems to stay closed more securely with the keyboard removed.- Easier to insert the iPad in the case.- The iPad3 seems to be held more securely in this case.- There's a stylus holder! This is very important if you ever use a stylus.- The keyboard is held in securely by strong magnets, but is much easier to remove from the case.- The USB port for charging the keyboard is exposed while inserted in the case so you don't have to partially remove the keyboard to charge it.- The iPad panel of the case has velcro on the bottom so, with the keyboard removed, you can stand the iPad up at any angle from vertical to a very low angle that's suitable for typing on the on-screen keyboard if you want. Unlike the Zagg, there are no fixed notches that limit you to 2 or so different stand angles. This continuous range of possible angles is VERY useful.- While neither case is very good for typing when placed on your lap, the KeyFolio is better for this  than the Zagg.- With the keyboard still inserted, the KeyFolio is more comfortable to hold when you fold the cover over to use the iPad like a tablet. It's not that much better but is it easier to avoid pressing the keys with the back resting on your hand. Since its also easier to remove the keyboard, it's easier to switch to using the tablet like this without the keyboard.- The KeyFolio keyboard has display brightness control keys while the Zagg doesn't. It also has a caps lock light,  will allow you to type F1-F12, and has a couple of extra keys like Pause/Break. This may not matter for the iPad but makes the keyboard more useful if you ever pair it with a Windows machine device or something. This keyboard also has a separate Delete and Backspace as well as an Insert key.KeyFolio Problems:- Unlike some photos show, there doesn't seem to be any proper way to rotate the iPad into the portrait orientation while using the keyboard. You can take the iPad out and sort of stand it up being held by the bottom flap of the holder, but this doesnt hold it very securely.- Currently I seem to be having some sort of problem where the left Shift key is interfering with the Z key. If I try to type ZAGG then I get Zagg because for some reason, Shift-Z essentially deactivates the Shift key even if you continue to hold down the shift key. (Releasing the shift and holding it down again, after typing Shift-Z, fixes the problem as does using the right Shift key.) The right Shift key doesn't seem to have this problem with neighboring keys. I'm unsure if this Shift-Z thing is a design problem or just a random manufacturing defect  in my particular keyboard.- This is minor, but the Command key is lacking the little curly corner command key symbol.- As people have mentioned, the "new car smell" from the outgassing on the KeyFolio, right after you remove it from the box, is rather strong. I would expect this to go away once all the residue has evaporated and I plan to place it near an open window, with the keyboard removed and all surfaces exposed to air, to speed this up.Now the ZAGGfolio. I'm typing this part using it. Here are its advantages over the KeyFolio:The overall design of the case is not that good, but it seems to be more durable and capable of better protecting the iPad. The keyboard is also a little larger and seems more solidly constructed.- The hard plastic of the case is thicker, harder, and would seem to offer more protection. The KeyFolio isn't that bad but the Zagg is just more durable. Overall the ZAGGfolio construction is bit more solid.- The keys on the keyboard are larger than the ones on the KeyFolio keyboard. The Space bar and modifier keys on the bottom row are also maybe 30% taller than the other keys. Overall the keyboard is larger but neither is a full-size keyboard.- The Zagg keyboard can be used as a stand for the iPad with the iPad removed from the case.- Because you can use the keyboard as a stand, you can stand the iPad up in portrait orientation though you can only do this if you remove the iPad from the case.- Overall the Zagg keyboard is more solidly constructed though both keyboards are made of plastic. The Zagg keyboard is also a little larger but I don't know if this is for a larger battery or just to accomodate the built-in iPad stand.- The Zagg keyboard has a "Globe" key in the lower left that can be used to switch the keyboard language. If there's any way to do this with the KeyFolio keyboard then I don't know what it is.- While lacking brightness controls, the Zagg keyboard has dedicated Cut/Copy/Paste keys. Personally I think this is pointless because the standard Command-X/C/V key combos work on both keyboards and I'm much more used to those anyway.- The Zagg has the auto on/off magnet that sleeps or wakes the iPad when you open/close the case.ZAGGfolio problems:- The outside of the thing is covered with this fake carbon fiber "skin" sticker that looks cheap-o and some have reported that it's prone to peeling off.- The case doesn't feel like it clips securely closed if you try to close it with the keyboard removed. So I would not try to carry it around without the keyboard inserted.- See "KeyFolio" advantages above for other shortcomings that I wouldn't necessarily consider outright problems.Both cases have:- Cutouts for all of the standard ports, buttons, speaker, camera, etc- Enough space around the dock connector to support my larger-than-normal 3rd party cable.- Bluetooth keyboards that have a "connect" button for easy obvious pairing.- Once paired, both keyboards connect instantly after being powered on. You will not be able to get your hands on the keys before they connect.- Both have special keys for the home key, slide show, mute/volume, audio player control, on-screen keyboard show/hide, search, and lock.- Both have Ctrl/Option/Command and arrow keys.- Some way to stand the ipad up for typing or viewing video/etc, and a way to fold the keyboard side of the cover behind the tablet for tablet-only use.- Use a standard micro USB port for charging.- A certain look. The Kensington looks more "white collar" and the Zagg looks more "blue collar". I don't consider either of these styles to be better than the other so I've noted it here to point it out.- Both seem about as bulky. Maybe the KeyFolio seems a little thinner just because it's softer.Verdict:Aside from the weird Shift-Z problem that might just be a defect in my particular unit, I like the Kensington KeyFolio better. The smaller keys don't really bother me, I REALLY want that stylus holder, I like the ease of removing the keyboard, the usb charging port is exposed without removing the keyboard, the velcro angle stand with infinite positions is very useful. I don't care if I can stand the iPad up on the keyboard alone with no case. The iPad seems to be held more securely (not as loose). If I need to type on my lap, this one is easier to do that with. The Kensington is also less expensive and overall seems to be a better value. Lastly, the keyboard seems to be more suitable for use with other devices if needed.So if that stuff is what's important to you then I'd get the Kensington KeyFolio.If you need larger keys, more solid (but not quite milspec) protection for tougher environments, better support for portrait orientation, never use a stylus, really want that auto sleep/wake magnet, and/or like the tough-looking style (vs the office management organizer style), then get the ZAGGfolio.UPDATE: See comments section for a report on wear-and-tear after a month of daily use.

Ordinarily this thing would just be a horrible quality monitor. I'm not sure if I'd even give it two stars if it were just a normal monitor, but this thing not only has a built in DisplayLink chipset for USB video connection bit its also USB powered! This means that it will also run off of laptop battery power. For $100 that's not bad. The built in stand also handles portrait and landscape orientations.The thing is very very light and portable. The case might be a little bulkier than it needs to be since it feels hollow, but its not that thick and it fits in my backpack. I wish it had come with a sleeve or something, but I suspect a cheap minimalistic large laptop sleeve would work just fine.So that's the good stuff. Here's the bad: image quality. Compared to laptop displays in general, this one is more comparable to the lower quality displays on cheap laptops.-The viewing angle is horrible. You pretty much have to be looking at the thing dead on or it won't look right, making it very difficult for more than one person to view it at a time. I suppose you could consider this a security feature, but the screen isn't totally unreadable at an off angle, just really bad looking.-The color gamut is horrible. I used a ColorMunki Photo spectrophotometer to calibrate the thing and the resulting gamut plot doesn't come close to covering the standard sRGB color space. Then again, my built in MacBook display doesn't cover sRGB that well either, so it's not that much worse than the typically bad laptop display. My guess is that the image quality is probably comparable to the average screen on an inexpensive laptop.-As others have noted theres no brightness control. There are no controls of any kind on the thing, just a micro USB port and nothing else. The brightness I measured on mine was about 200 cd/m2 which is not bad for a laptop display.-While the built in DisplayLink USB graphics adapter is great in that it only needs a USB port, it lacks a lot of the processing power that a real graphics card with a real GPU would have. So the CPU ends up doing work that would normally be done on a graphics chipset GPU. This means it will use up some CPU power depending on what you're doing, and it's no good for video or games. So this thing is mostly for displaying documents and animated graphics which is good enough for many people.-There's no built in USB hub or anything. Perhaps there's just not enough power for one, but with only 2 USB ports on my MacBook I wish I could get at least one unpowered port out of it.Verdict:-Superior convenience and portability.-"good enough" image quality for basic productivity stuff like documents and web pages.-It's a second monitor!-Inexpensive and decent value.-Very poor viewing angle that's not very suitable for across the room viewing.-Generally poor image quality that's unsuitable for photo editing or anything color sensitive.-Some performance limitations due to USB (no good for games/video).-No screen controls at all.At some point better competing products will probably be available at which point I might consider this more of a 3 star product depending on how much newer versions cost, but at the current time I give it a solid 4 stars.

This thing is more solidly constructed than the cheapo last one that I bought at an auto parts store, and seems like it could tolerate being banged around a bit in your trunk. The auto shutoff feature seems to basically work and is useful, but after a few tire inflations it seems that its pressure gauge is probably too inaccurate to just blindly trust the auto shutoff feature. I'm not really surprised since most non-dedicated gauges seem to be a little deficient, and I wasn't planning to trust this one anyway.Basically what happened to me is that I set it to inflate all four of my tires back to 32psi using the auto-shutoff thing, and according to my TPMS (which is generally within +/- 1psi of my dedicated tire gauge, so not too bad) the tire pressures were initially OK, but after driving 10 min, parking, waiting at least 4 hours, and walking back to the car, the TPMS was reading something like 33,33,34,35. I got out my Accutire MS-4350B Tire Gauge and sure enough the tires were within +/- 1psi of what the TPMS said. So I just let air out of them until they all read 32psi. (It's possible that the temperature went up 10F while I was doing stuff, resulting in an increase of 1psi per tire, but that doesn't explain the the 35.)With the one that was at 35, I was already suspicious because the thing sat there pumping for 10-20 seconds AFTER it was already reading 32 (as if the gauge stuck at 32 then finally hit whatever fraction of a psi above 32 that triggers the shutoff). I actually shut the thing off on the first tire manually, then went back and tried it again after the shutoff worked on other tires. So I went back to the first tire to see what it would do and it continued to run at 32 for a bit and finally shut off, resulting in the 35psi pressure. Odd.Now, it was only 10-20F outside when I inflated the tires and it's possible that the tires had deformed or something due to the cold, then hardened such that they had slightly different internal volumes, possibly explaining why the pressures seemed OK originally but then read too high after a 10 minute drive and a 4+ hour wait. The one that was overinflated was also the one that was very low compared to the others before I inflated them, so it wouldn't be surprising if cooled and hardened into a different shape than the others. (I inflated them all when I got up in the morning and the car was dead cold.)So anyway, I'm still reasonably happy with this as it seems to be durable, it does have the auto shutoff feature which is still kind of useful, the power cord is long enough for my small car (as long as you run it out of the door on the same side as the tires you're inflating), and I didn't really plan to trust the pump's pressure gauge anyway.My advice is that if you use this, use the auto shutoff but then get out a real tire gauge (like the previously mentioned Accutire), check the pressure, and then let some air out until the proper pressure is reached. If the auto shutoff is routinely underinflating, just set the shutoff threshold a little higher so you can then let air out with your real gauge to get to the proper pressure. Watch the number on the pump's display the whole time it's running, and if the pressure gauge on the thing seems to stick at the same value while the pump runs, play it safe, shut the thing off manually, and take a reading with a real gauge. I doubt the thing is so inaccurate as to explode a typical car tire before shutting off, but certainly it's work needs to be verified with a known accurate gauge.

Epson's UltraChrome K3 inks have to be some of the best out there. It's what my visual arts school uses for all of their ink jet printers (3880s and up), and it's what all but one or two of Epson's huge high-end professional ink jet printers use.My only problem with the R3000 cartridges are that they're kind of expensive per ml compared to the 3880's larger cartridges, and of course more expensive than 3rd party ink, but I can't complain about the ink or container quality at all. I'd give them 5 stars instead of 4 if only they were less expensive. Still, the price isn't too bad for the price point of printer involved, just not particularly inexpensive or anything.

At first I thought thing thing seemed too expensive. Though I don't need portability, I was originally going to get one of the less expensive portable sized models like the ScanSnap S1300, not only because they're less expensive but because they take up less space. However, when I looked up the technical specs I found that the S1500 is still quite small when folded up, and I really don't need to carry it around with me. Considering that the somewhat suspect NeatDesk costs about the same, I decided that the price for the S1500 wasn't that unreasonable and I'd rather have the extra capacity over the S1300. (When in doubt, and something matters, I tend to avoid going the cheaper route on things if I don't have to.)Well, I'm glad that I did because the S1500 is FAST. I'm still rather in awe of how fast it is. I scanned in this whole double sided 100 sheet course pack (some pages in color) in 300dpi faster than I knew what to do with it. This thing will scan stuff much faster than Adobe Acrobat's ClearScan OCR will run on the results. Even if you scan at "Excellent" (600/1200dpi which is generally totally unnecessary for regular documents) the thing seems ridiculously fast to me. I rescanned my course pack with "Excellent" just so I could run the ClearScan OCR on the thing with better font quality and the scanner outpaced the software easily even with the slowness of the highest quality dpi mode. Most of my time was spent creating PDF bookmarks for chapters in the course pack and otherwise just organizing the PDF file the way I wanted.I haven't tried scanning too many wrinkled up pages with this yet, but I did scan a small stack of papers from a class last semester that had been stuffed in a book for quite a while. The scanner had absolutely no problem even though papers were wrinkled a bit and also different sizes (some note paper, some office paper, some paper ripped out of a sketchbook with a torn edge, etc.) I just fed the whole stack in with no regard for page size, thickness, or condition (smaller pages between larger ones etc).For stuff that's really messed up (like old wadded up receipts) I've just used the clear plastic document carrier. Simple and very little trouble. For all I know the extremely wrinkled receipts might have gone through just fine without the carrier, but I didn't feel like pushing the thing's abilities to the limit at the time.As for the included software: I personally think it's good enough. I'm using a Mac. The UI is a little unusual compared to Apple standard UI guidelines, but that's just typical of software provided by hardware vendors and doesn't really impact usability in this case. I was initially concerned about the lack of TWAIN support, but after using the software I find that I really don't care about TWAIN because you can configure the software to scan to standard file formats and automatically launch them in any application you want which is essentially all you get with TWAIN drivers anyway. And unlike some TWAIN drivers I've seen, I've had no problem with the ScanSnap software crashing or otherwise failing to operate.Tip: For stuff where quality isn't a big deal, the ScanSnap software by itself is fine just scanning directly to image PDFs (bitmap pages) in one of the faster low quality modes and doing its own OCR for text search. For anything large where I care about print quality, I scan to Adobe Acrobat in 600dpi and then run Acrobat's ClearScan OCR on it. ClearScan basically traces character bitmaps, converting them into more space efficient vectors, then generates its own embedded fonts for the resulting document. As a result, quality is maintained but the size of the resulting PDF is much much smaller. For example, my course pack was 450MB as an image PDF and was reduced to 60MB as a PDF after OCR with ClearScan. This is after scanning it in maximum resolution (600/1200dpi) mode and running ClearScan. With a 300dpi scan the resulting ClearScan PDF was about 40MB but the quality was noticeably worse. (Not bad enough that most people would care, but with 600/1200dpi+ClearScan the 60MB file is almost indistinguishable from the original whereas the 300dpi file is obviously degraded a bit.) Without ClearScan, the 300dpi file (image PDF) was something like 80-120MB. So for large documents ClearScan is worth the extra step. For lots of small documents (like less than 10 pages) it's probably not worth the extra step; just scan those in 300dpi or less and leave them as the image PDFs that ScanSnap generates.The ScanSnap software lets you set up custom scanning "profiles" in addition to the ones that it comes with (like "scan to email" etc), so for example I added "Scan to Acrobat, Basic Quality", "Scan to Acrobat, High Quality", and "Scan to Lightroom" (for photos). The profiles are basically just dpi/format/etc settings plus which application to launch, if any, and you can pick any application that will load a PDF or JPEG. Once you have a profile selected, all you have to do is load papers, hit the button on the scanner, and the document will appear in your application once its done.... no extra shuffling of files around.I haven't tried the "Scan to Word", "Scan to Excel", or CardIris stuff as I don't have any real use for them right now, so I can't comment on how well those work yet.Anyway, I'm quite happy with this. The thing is crazy fast and the workflow is very simple and refined, basically just press a button to get a document into an application. It will probably take you 10 times as long to organize all the PDF files than it will to get the pages scanned.

Great paper, significantly better than the "non-ultra" version if you ask me. The only things you might want to do with any large paper like this:1) Don't tighten the sheet feed guides too close to the paper (like I did once). I'd leave 1/8th of an inch between the left side feeder guide and the edge of the paper. If the paper gets bent inward because the width between the guides is too narrow (easier to happen with large paper), it can cause it to misfeed in such a way that the print head can scrape the paper, potentially causing costly print head damage.2) In addition to setting the paper type (in the print settings) to this exact brand/type of paper, you may want to set "platen gap" to "wide" just to be sure. You shouldn't really need the "wide" setting if you set the paper type properly (as the printer/driver should set the proper gap for the paper you set) but it might not be a bad idea anyway just to be safe.And to avoid waste, it's never a bad idea to do a nozzle check on the blank side of some clean and unwrinkled scrap office paper (if not new office paper) before you print on anything large or otherwise expensive.

This is worth having because 1) it's padded and seems to (after a few weeks in my backpack) protect the equipment nicely, and 2) it keeps the cable and pen with the actual tablet instead of mixed up in my backpack with a bunch of regular pens and cables where they can get misplaced.My small INTUOS4 tablet fits perfectly, there's a pocket inside for the cable, and another one that's big enough for more than one standard pen or art pen. I can't say how well the pockets fit stuff like the airbrush or mouse, but it looks like you should be able to at least fit the airbrush by itself if not with a pen, or a pen and the mouse. You could probably stuff the pen holder in there too without the mouse, but it doesn't seem to be designed for carrying the pen (desk) holder around. I personally have no desire to anyway.It's padded almost as much as a laptop sleeve. I put the tablet and it's stuff in the thing and throw it in my backpack which works nicely. It's better than sliding the tablet in between the laptop sleeve and the backpack's laptop pocket like I used to. The case is rather solidly constructed with no sign of stitches or fabric threads coming unraveled, tearing easily, etc.It's not surprising that the tablet/etc fits well since it's the manufacturer's "official" case, but considering that it's Wacom I'm just happy that the case doesn't cost $50 or something. (I'm still annoyed with the $100 art pen that by itself is half the combined cost of the small tablet, pen, pen holder, tips/etc, and mouse.)Overall I'd say that this case is just as good if not better than what a 3rd party manufacturer could provide for the same price.

I've had this for almost three years and have mostly used it with the mouse as I don't have a constant need for the pen. When I have used the pen though, it's been excellent. I'm personally not bothered by the small size of the drawing area, but if you think you might be then I'd go for a "medium sized" tablet of some sort. The small size is good for portability though, and it fits nicely in my backpack in the same pocket with my MacBook. (It's about the same width and height as the macbook though obviously much thinner.) Unlike the small tablet, the medium and larger tablets have little digital display labels next to the function buttons, but I'm not convinced that this is terribly useful.The only problem that I've had with it is that the right mouse button on the mouse accessory started failing after daily use for a couple of years. These things have a 2 year warranty, and I wasn't exactly on top of things enough to realize that and get the mouse replaced when it started having problems. (I'm actually not sure exactly when it started having problems relative to the warranty expiration.) Basically one of the buttons started "clicking" almost by itself and this became really annoying. I still use the tablet with the pen, which all still work perfectly fine, and just use a normal mouse for everything else. Really I think a normal mouse is better anyway, and the fact that they even include a mouse with this tablet seems like a minor bonus.The main issue with the Wacom tables is that they're expensive. They're high quality, but you pay for it. They're probably well worth it if you use them to a commercial degree, such as on a daily basis, but if you only use a pen tablet occasionally and don't need the tilt sensor, you can get some rather inexpensive pen tablets with pressure sensing, such as the VT PenPad 7.7-Inch Graphic Pen Tablet, for much less money these days. The cheaper tablets are probably sufficient for people who do photo retouching every week or two since the tilt sensing doesn't help that much with that (though the pressure sensitivity does) and the durability on many of them is probably good enough for a consumer level of usage.I like the eraser tip on the regular pen that comes with the tablet, but I hate the fact that the rotation-sensing Art Pen is NOT included and is nearly $100. If the art pen cost more like $50 I'd have probably bought it by now, but for what I normally do I don't feel like I can justify $100 for it.The tablet does come with different textured tips for the pen which is nice, and it's good that you can replace the tips. Replacement is quite easy, and you can also replace the drawing surface on the tablet.The little touch control wheel is OK, but it seems like it doesn't move very smoothly. Instead it kind of jumps in increments, for most things, that can be kind of annoying unless you lower the sensitivity. This might usually be more the fault of the software application though.Overall I'd say the people who should buy this are the people who will use it heavily and need the tilt sensitivity (or tilt and rotating sensing for the art pen option). For more occasional usage you can get much less expensive tablets with pressure sensing ability.

I just installed one of these in my 2001 Audi TT and everything went pretty smoothly. I bought a specific kit including everything needed for my specific model though, so if I were you I'd communicate with whoever you order this from before ordering to make sure you're ordering the right adapter and all of the parts you're going to need. Make sure you order from someone willing to help you get the right parts and who will help answer installation questions.The main thing to ask before buying one of these adapters is whether you should just buy a new head unit instead. If you buy a GROM-IPD3 with the iPod cable, Bluetooth audio/handsfree interface, and the RCA/phono aux cable, the total price will probably be about the same as the price for a whole new head unit that does all of these things and maybe others as well.So consider whether there is some reason why you might not just want a new head unit before buying this. If you don't want to change the "OEM look" or there's some other reason for not replacing the OEM head unit, an adapter like this one is a pretty good option.

This stuff holds very strongly and takes a lot of force to separate. In most situations where you frequently need to separate the hook and loop sides, this might not be the best thing to use, but for things where you need something to stay solidly in place while still being removable if the need arises, this stuff is perfect!I used a whole 2" x 4" patch of this to attach a Wagan 4-Way 12V Automotive Socket Extender under the dashboard in my car, and that thing does not come loose even with four heavy cigar socket connectors in the thing. I just recently had to remove the extender so that I could get to the area behind it to install some electronics, and while it took quite a bit of force and effort to separate the velcro, it did come off and go back on just fine. The extender might as well be glued down with industrial adhesive except that it can actually be removed when required, which is exactly what I wanted.I also used a couple of 1/2" by 2" strips to attach a wireless bluetooth diagnostic interface under the dash and that was more than enough to very securely attach it. That thing isn't going anywhere unless I want it to.The adhesive back on these patches is also very thick and strong. The plastic that I attached it to under my dash has kind of a matte smooth surface, and all I did was clean it with alcohol before sticking the velcro on. Even with all the force used to remove that socket extender, there's no sign of the adhesive coming loose.So this stuff is perfect for heavy objects and things that you might be tempted to glue down with strong double-stick tape or adhesive. If you need something glued down but you think you might need to remove it at some point, don't just use glue.... Use this stuff.As with any adhesive though, you can't expect one adhesive to stick to all possible material surfces. Some things might require the use of alternate means such as some other adhesive, staples, heavy stitches, screws/bolts/etc. When using adhesive strips like this, always clean the area thoroughly with some sort of solvent that will remove greasy oily stuff!

This is a secure well made case that you'll be happy with. It has a belt attachment on the side and a strap on the top allowing you to attach it to other things in a couple of ways. The Velcro holds the top shut very tightly (no danger of the thing coming open accidentally).This thing is BIG. As it says, this holds 82mm filters which is more than I actually need. However this extra capacity does seem to allow me to get more filters of a smaller size into the case. For example, I have four super-cheapo 72mm IR filters. I don't care too much about these so I just screw them all together and place the whole stack in the backmost slot in the case. I can do this easily (it's not a tight fit) and it works out just fine.Unless you just need something more compact, a large size like this will come in handy even if you don't have 82m filters, and you'll be prepared should you end up with any 82mm's.I can't find anything wrong with this product, or any drawbacks to it.

I think a number of people are being a little too hard on this product right now (Dec 2011), so I'm going to be a little more generous with the stars.I'm using the Escort RedLine with Escort Live which gives me the the Defender Database GPS feature of the 9500ix and the extra range of the RedLine at the same time. So with the RedLine, Live gives you significantly more value at little extra cost than it does with the 9500ix which it is somewhat redundant with.Yes, the complexity of dealing with it is less than ideal at the current time, but if you're the "early adopter" gadget nut type then you'll have no problem with it especially if you dock your iPhone to a power connector in the car all the time anyway for use as an audio player.The Escort Live app UI is more suitable for automotive use than I expected for the first version of the software. The most common 4 or 5 functions have large buttons, large text, and swipe gestures. Some functions have buttons/text that are too small, but that seems very likely to get addressed in later app updates.The things that Live gives you:- A fancy touch screen interface for the radar detector. You can change the detector configuration/mode with touch screen controls, and you can display more alert information on the screen than the detector can display on it's LED display alone. The configuration UI just uses standard controls for the most part and isn't suitable for in-motion use, but it could be very useful if you want to completely hide and silence the detector or something.- You get the Defender Database and *most* (not all) GPS-based functions (warnings for red light, radar cameras, etc) of the 9500ix. Obviously this is most beneficial when combined with something like the RedLine that's lacking location based features. With the 9500ix it's mostly redundant.- Over-the-Internet location based alert reports from other drivers. This is the feature that's most lacking right now (Dec 2011) simply because not enough people are using Live and thus very few alerts get reported. Keep in mind though that of the time of this writing, the Android cable has only been shipping for a few days. So we're still in the first days of the service and whether it will catch on enough over time to be useful still remains to be seen. This is just the type of stuff that's unavoidable when you're an early adopter. Feature wise, you can report radar alerts (some like Ka alerts get reported automatically, others like X band alerts require the user to decide) and a couple of things like "cop sighted".So if you're the early adopter type who likes to have the latest thing and isn't bothered as much by the issues with new technology then this product/service is pretty good and seems likely to get better. You're likely to rate it about the same as I have.If you're the later adopter sort that needs this to "just work" by itself so you can forget it's there, you will probably want to hold off on buying it for now especially if you're using the partially feature-redundant 9500ix. While the more users Live has the more useful the reporting will be, buying it won't be any help to anyone (except maybe Escort) if you end up leaving it in the closet. So if it sounds like you might neglect it in its current state then it's probably better to hold off for now. This should also give Escort more reason to improve the product when they have to make improvements to get more sales.So in summary, as of Dec 2011, depending on who you are:4 stars for early adopters with the RedLine3-4 stars for early adopters with the 9500ix3 stars for not-so-early adopters with the RedLine2 stars for not-so-early adopters with the 9500ix, those who don't want to deal with anything not solidly established yet, and those who don't normally use and don't want to use their phone in the car for anything.

I set out to buy the best windshield detector I could find, and after much research I settled on this one. After 800 miles cross country I'm not the least bit disappointed. This thing always manages to warn me of radar usage at least a mile before I get close to the source, and that's the worst its done. Given that most radar guns probably can't acquire my small car from more than 1,000ft away, this is way more than enough warning. Usually you pick up actual police radar strength sources from more than a mile away on typical slightly rolling terrain.I'm mostly interested in this for highway use and I use it with the SmartCord Live - iPhone Version, so I don't need the GPS features built in to other detectors like the 9500ix. The main thing I care about is getting the longest range detection possible, and filtering out false alerts is secondary. As a result I've spent most of my time running mine in highway mode and don't have a very good sense of how well it does at filtering out automatic door motion detectors and such in "automatic" (city) mode. I'm going to have to drive around my town and find some sources of false alerts so I can compare the two modes.But I don't care too much about false alert suppression because the "expert meter" option seems to make these things pretty obvious. If you buy a RedLine I recommend enabling that in the configuration as soon as you plug it in. As far as I can tell there's just no disadvantage to using it.How the "expert meter" works: Say you're driving along and you see X.,| on the expert meter. The ".," are vertical bar graph bars that show two different radar sources that are very weak, and the "|" is a bar showing another source that's very strong. You see a couple of grocery stores around you so you can guess that the two weaker signals are probably just building motion detectors, but that extremely strong X band signal is very suspect. Without the expert meter you'd be more likely to just see the stores around you, an X alert, and think it was a false alarm, but seeing that there are three sources with one way too strong to be a civilian source across a big parking lot, you know there's going to be at least a safety speed sign nearby if not a patrol car with an X band radar. If you didn't take this seriously then the detector might be more harm than good if you get more careless because you assumed it was nothing.Later you drive by a huge strip mall and office complex and see K.,X... indicating that you're probably just picking up automatic door and security system motion detectors. If any of those signals are police radar then they're probably still at least a mile away, if not more, given how sensitive this thing is. (Though the distance could be less depending on terrain and obstructions.)So even if you just run this thing in highway mode all the time, it can give you enough information with the expert meter to do your own brain filtering. If you're sure nothing important in your area uses X band, you can also just put the thing in AutoNoX mode or disable X band detection in the configuration.With Escort Live and the iPhone app you can also lock out alerts by location and frequency. So if you get a bunch of weak alerts when you drive by this mega strip mall every day, you can simply lock those out. The Escort Live app will remember the frequencies of the unimportant sources and not tell you about them in that location again, regardless of what the noise filtering on the detector thinks and regardless if you have the thing in highway mode (which essentially disables automatic false alert filtering).Escort Live gives you the Defender Database (red light and speed camera) location based warning feature of the 9500ix that the RedLine is missing. So the Redline + Escort Live is a great combination that's almost like having the RedLine and ix at the same time. If you have an iPhone or Android phone and you regularly use it in the car anyway, get the RedLine with Escort Live package and skip the ix. Escort Live is very inexpensive in relative terms. The ix by itself will supposedly do a little more to filter false alerts compared to the RedLine + Escort Live combo, but not that much. Personally I wouldn't get the ix unless I just never found myself on the highway at all or if I wasn't going to use Escort Live at all. RedLine + Escort Live also gets you "social alerts" from other Live users which the ix alone won't, and you won't have to periodically take your detector out of the car to update a database with your desktop computer or something.So if you have the budget for this and you're ever on the highway, get the RedLine! If you're thinking of getting the Escort Passport 9500ix Radar/Laser Detector (Black), you probably want to get the RedLine + Escort Live instead unless you don't have a compatible smartphone.Avoiding just one ticket will probably make this thing pay for itself when you consider both the cost of fines and increased insurance costs. Unless you always drive like grandma on Sunday, this thing is worth the price.

Lenspens seem to work pretty well in most situatons, but until now I've only had the standard sized one. I always wished that I had a smaller one that I could use to clean small lenses like the ones on point and shoot cameras and such, and the normal lenspen never seemed to be flat enough to do a very good job of contacting the surface of a flat filter.Well, the micro lenspen and the filter lenspen solve these problems. Really the one for filters isn't all that special, though it does do a better job of cleaning filters, but the micro sized lenspen is a huge help when it comes to cleaning some things like the tiny iPhone camera Photojojo add-on lenses that I have, and other little things that are difficult to clean with anything.If you're thinking of buying a lenspen, I say buy this set instead of an individual standard one unless you're sure you'll never want the others. Almost certainly you'll be glad you bought the specialized ones when something comes up.

This thing is perfect. Not only can you charge an iPad at full power with the thing, but the secondary port outputs 1A which will charge your phone faster than usual. In some cases the typical 0.5A charger (which might not even be outputting a full 0.5A) can't even supply enough power to my phone to both satisfy its power consumption and charge the battery if the phone is running the GPS, playing music, doing bluetooth, keeping the screen on, and other stuff that causes it to consume lots of energy.While this thing is more expensive than the cheapo adapters out there, it's well worth the cost. Having your devices too low on power when you get out of the car is really not fun, especially when they're drained before you can even make it back to the car. Two high power USB ports in one cigar outlet is a major advantage because most people don't have more than one or maybe two cigar outlets in their car. Even if you don't normally need two USB power ports, trust me... you will be happy you have the extra one day when you do need to plug something else in. And eventually you will.Buy a cheap adapter for $5 or something and one day the extra $15 you should have spent will feel like nothing when your battery is dead in some critical situation.

This thing is actually not bad. It fits on very securely. The only real drawback with it is that it doesn't do anything to protect the screen, but otherwise it protects from scratches and nobody can even tell that you have a case on the phone. At least for scratch protection, you can always just place a screen protector film over the screen.For me there's also the problem that the metal adhesive ring that I have around the camera lens that I use to attach magnetic accessory lenses won't fit over the camera lens opening in the case since it's too large. This won't be a problem for most people as most people aren't using the Photojojo iPhone lenses, but if you are then this is not really a good case to use. (Normally with a case that isn't too thick, attaching the lenses to the outside of the case works fine if the case is flat enough to adhere the metal attachment ring.)I'm probably going to give this to my mother as it should be pretty close to perfect for her. Anyway, for most people wanting a relatively light-duty case that protects all but the screen from scratches and doesn't stand out, this is a good choice.

For only slightly more than this thing costs you can find something like a GROM Adapter/Interface that's totally hidden with much better audio quality and no awkward junk sticking out of your cigar lighter socket.Here are the problems with this GOgroove thing:- Audio quality over FM is still too poor. A cassette deck audio adapter I have is much better even.- For some reason the control knob controls the broadcast frequency during normal operation, and it's too easy to accidentally hit the thing, changing the frequency by 0.1MHz, breaking the audio connection. This is dumb; they should have given you some way to hide or lock this so hitting the knob while trying to push one of the buttons won't change the frequency.
