Replacing 6 for a crib took 12 due to weak nail heads embedded in these plastic mounts.  The felt is so minimal, it should be measured in microns.  Be sure to pre-drill the holes and tap in using a mallet, otherwise the nail head will protrude to ruin the floor.At least these are somewhat better than the OEM ones that came with the $500 Baby Cache crib that cracked.I doubt these will last long, so will be giving Waxman 4718795N a shot instead.6 of the 24 are brown, and the rest are white.

The carbon fiber look actually gives it a nice quality look that doesn't betray its low cost.  The problem is the silver-colored rod assembly which snapped off on first day.  I've requested the seller to just send me another rod assembly, but using a black zip-tie for now.[update]The vendor sent me 2 sets of the rod & screw (good thinking), which has been fine, so I'm raising this to 4 stars.1 star still off for being 1/2" too short for my German key fob, which is listed as compatible.  This pouch is 3 1/4" long, but you need to account for the silver rod and key ring that'll reduce room by ~1/2" (so, 2.75" usable length).

I had bought this about 2.5 years ago in case I needed it.  Tonight 11pm, I needed it.My upstairs central air suddenly smelled of plastic, so--with the A/C turned off, and my wife on standby at the thermostat--I headed up the attic with a fire extinguisher.  I didn't smell any burnt plastic in the attic even after she turned the A/C back on, but the upstairs bedrooms still did, so I figured the problem was with the A/C or the ducts.I found that the attic A/C air intake and various housing components' tape covers were flapping about.  I removed the original foil insulation tapes, wiped down the surfaces with paper towel dabbed in rubbing alcohol, then applied this foil tape to cover the openings.  I also took the opportunity to tape up various holes and rips in the foil ducts, which ended up taking almost an hour.Afterwards, I had my wife turn on the A/C, and voila, no more funky smell.  I've hopefully also improved the A/C efficiency ever so slightly with the hole patches.

This tall board book (roughly twice the height of typical board books) is beautifully illustrated fully on both sides of the pages; the left and right sides form one scenary, with a sentence on a light background.  Unlike many recent board books which copy/paste simple drawings, and only 1 side of the page at that, this book is a work of art.It's among the favorite books of my daughter and son since birth.  We can easily spend several minutes between page turns, and the scenes are enjoyable even to the tired parent.Their eyes linger edge to edge, consuming all the colorful flora and fauna, and experience the progression of the seasons from Spring to Winter.  My 3-year old now likes to count and discuss various details of the book.The sentences are brief, yet cute and descriptive of the scene.  The final page of the book has Nicholas the Bunny going to sleep, which I is our kids' cue to also go to sleep.This and Goodnight Moon are popular classics for excellent reason.

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B006M9F50S/ref=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_0Inner OCD demon compelled me to somehow keep my wife's assorted boots and Uggs from being strewn and flopped over other shoes.She already had 1 pair of spring-loaded boot shaper that was gifted, but was reluctant to use it from fear of it stretching the leather or fabric.  They were also cumbersome to insert or remove one-handed, tended to be too short for her taller boots, and expensive (relatively speaking).I tried plastic boot clips from the store that sells "containers", but they twist, causing indentations and still flop to one side (at least together...).These Household Essentials Boot Shapers are a godsend!  Priced very reasonably (~$6.50 for 2 pairs), and can be trimmed to fit either tall, medium, or short boots.  The size guides have perforations and guide lines to help cut properly.  When not in use, they fold perfectly flat to be unobtrusive.The hanger holder feature is a bit dubious, since the friction required depends on the boots' inner material.  However, the "hanger" hole is great for pulling the boot shaper out when using the boots.The force of the boot shaper spreading doesn't stretch the boot material, so it's definitely suitable for leather, Ugg, etc.

There are many golf nets available on Amazon, but Haack's was a clear winner for me.PROS:+ Easy setup after first time (see CONS below)+ Minimal parts+ Detachable side nets (great for the "occasional" shanks)+ Includes 4 U-spikes (only 2 needed if not using side nets)+ Includes carry bag and spike pouch+ Lightweight, yet stableCONS:- Confusing first setup:  The printed instruction wasn't clear with base corner orientation, but a quick search on YouTube helped.  The 3-way angled corners should at least have "L up" and "R up" labels; I've printed them with a label maker.My wife and friends also love the net.I've paired it with Exclusive Pro Hitting Golf Mat 4' x 5' - 2 Inches Thick, which I think may be a bit too thick to use over grass, although I planned to use the combo in the garage in winter.

Fits Note 4 in OEM rubber case perfectly, even with the removable tray insert in place.  Due to its design, it should work with future Note models or  most other current phones.  I even use it to charge my Blackberry Bold, which has its microUSB port on the left side.  With my previous model-specific cradles, they became totally useless after I sold my old phone, so I usually gave it away or bundled it with my sold phone.The microUSB male plug is on a fore/aft hinge, so it's easy to remove the phone in a hurry, without worrying about bending or snapping off the plug.It comes with a square 2.1A wall wart plug (power plugs do not fold) and 2 USB cables (one for data, one for faster power-only).I wish it had a slot for extra battery charger, but otherwise it's perfect.

It does not fit Note 4 with a case (I have Samsung OEM rubber case), but fits perfectly without the case.  It's a shame it doesn't have a removable tray insert for case use, since this cradle is perfect for charging my phone and extra battery with minimal desk space wasted.  The seller "buyinsoon" was great about no hassle return though.I ended up buying 2 of below, which fits Note 4 in a case even with the removable tray insert still in place.  Alas, no battery charging slot, even though this cradle is about the size of the 2in1.RND Dock for Samsung Galaxy Note 2, Note 4 or Note Edge with Dock mode cable and 2.1A Charger (compatible with most cases)(black)

I've been holding off on purchasing this until the 4Ah battery bundle became available, but the monkeys swinging across my lawn jungle forced my hand.  I decided to just use the 2Ah battery that I already had for my GreenWorks 80V leaf blower.The shipping weight is 72 pounds (mower-only package), but the box was light enough to carry by myself.  Packaging is minimal, yet sturdy, with cardboard spacers.  The box contained the mower, handle bar extension, manual booklet, and quick-start sheet.The only assembly required were 1) attaching the handle bar extension using 2 bolt/knob combos and 2) snapping on the right-side mulch discharge chute.  Alternatively, you can leave off the side chute, pull off the rear mulching block, and attach the clippings collection fabric bag.  The entire handle assembly is adjustable to 3 heights using the pair of built-in 90-degree twist knobs.  Theres also a lever to adjust to 7 different cutting heights.To prepare to mow, simply lift the battery cover flap on raised protrusion on the center-top of the mower, push in the battery until it clicks into place (release button is used when removing the battery), then lower the flap.No messy, smelly gas or oil needed.  No nauseating exhaust!  The electric motor is far quieter than a gas engine; my toddlers fell asleep fine during my mowing.  Theres none of the headaches of maintaining a gasoline engine:  buy/store/pour jugs of gasoline, buy and keep engine oil topped off, buy fuel stabilizers, deal with spills, clean/replace spark plugs, burn off excess gasoline for off-season storage, etc.To turn on, you push and hold the green button on the upper-right of the handle, then grasp the green lever arm together with the handle bar, then let go of the button.  When you release lever, the mower turns off completely; there is no idle.  To restart, youll need to repeat the hold-button and grasp-lever routine.  There is no cord-yanking involved.The mower is very easy to push (note its not self-powered), so I speed-walked most of the time.  Its easy to turn 180-degrees for parallel mowing.  The blades cut very near to the outer edge of the wheels (see attached picture), so theres minimal need for overlap.  Theres a rubber rear skirt to protect you from any rock or debris projectiles, which is a godsend for my yard, full of landscape stones and sweet gum tree spike-balls.The 2.0Ah battery from my leaf blower had plenty of power to mow the  acre of greatly-overgrown grass and weeds (yesterday 5/17 was my first mow of the season), then power the blower to clean the mower.  Itll probably still have enough power for the string trimmer (on backorder), but I plan on buying either the 4.0Ah battery once its available or another 2.0Ah.For storage, the handle bars easily fold over at the base for fast, compact storage.  I actually have my mower resting vertically in the garage for maximum space savings (see my first picture).  I feel its also light enough for most people to carry it to the basement for winter storage.Im very happy with the 80V mower and leaf blower so far.  This Fall, I plan on selling my 24 gas snow thrower to replace with a GreenWorks 80V model as well.

I was INITIALLY very pleased with this device enabling me to watch DVR from my phone or PC anywhere, anytime.  Video quality is excellent, and the M1, which I now own, saves me money as well versus monthly FiOS STB rentals.  I can now watch DVR from my home office PC or in bed via phone (especially handy with Bluetooth headphones) without disturbing the wife.  The only time the actual TVs in the house get turned on is for guests.Cons:- Android app costs $15 per account.  My phone: $15.  Wife's phone: $15.  Tablet version, another $15.  $45 on top of this device...- Short lag between "button" changes- Only one device can be connected to the same Sling device at a time (if a second device/user connects to the same Slingbox, it'll ask whether to disconnect the previous)- M1 requires a PC app to be installed.  You canNOT use the web player with M1.- Recently has HUGE AD BANNER at the bottom and the right side of the app!  Sling decided to shove a huge banner at the bottom of the desktop app without user approval or notification.  The right-side banner can be hidden, but the bottom banner will persist unless in full-screen mode.

The GreenWorks GBL80300 is a bit heavier than my corded Toro 51609 (~14 lbs vs ~11 lbs, respectively) due to the included large battery, but well balanced.  The power on/off button and 3 speed settings button on top of the handle are easily reached, even while gloved.  With the Toro, I'd often inadvertently change the speed setting because of the poorly placed dial.The battery has a 3-level power indicator, which is activated by pressing a button on the battery itself, even when detached.  The battery is easily detached by pushing the release button and pulling out the pack.  To attach, just push it in.  When charging, the included charger runs an internal fan, which makes a soft but noticeable whirling noise.This blower easily clears several inches of powder snow off my front porch, driveway, and sidewalk.  The highest setting is surprisingly strong for a battery unit, requiring two hands for extended use.I'm planning to purchase a Greenworks 80V mower as well (battery & charger not included), but will opt to also purchase a 4AH battery, rather than solely rely on the blower's 2AH battery.  Note that this new generation of 80V battery and matching equipment are much more expensive than Greenworks' previous generation of 40V battery and equipment.I'll update in a few weeks, after the ultimate test of clearing the evil sweetgum tree "fruits" (hard, brown spherical spikes that fall down by the thousands, clinging mercilessly to the lawn in wait of twisting a victim's ankle).Versus a corded blower:I got fed up with my Toro blower's power cord always snagging, having to walk back around obstacles, and unwinding/rewinding/repositioning/unwinding/etc. around the house.  The hassle made me second guess the decision to forgo the $300/season landscaper cleanup of my tiny ~0.2 acre lot, or perhaps even revert to using a rake.  Although this unit costs double that of the Toro--which can additionally vacuum/mulch leaves--the wireless convenience makes it definitely worth it (like a laptop vs desktop PC).

The set comes as shown with a purple frame / red gate and a yellow regular panel (so, 2 panels total). The latch, hinge, etc are all plastic, so the gate feels a flimsy and needs a little wiggling to properly.To open, you toggle down the vertical switch near the top middle, then while holding the thumb slide at the top, lift and swing open the gate (see my pictures). You also have to hold the thumb slide when closing. The vertical lock can be left always unlocked if preferred, since the gate is too difficult for a child to operate.At $110, a regular non-gate set of 8 panels come out to $14 per. At $43, this gate set works out to $29 gate door + 1 panel ($14) which you may not even want. Gate door being double the price of a regular panel is not unreasonable, but forcing the purchase of an extra panel is unsavory.I use it with an existing panel set for a makeshift ball pit.

After about 13 months of use with my NON-iSpring 6-stage RO system installed last year by a local vendor, the water taste had noticeably changed.  By then, I'd been trying to schedule for weeks a date/time with the same vendor for filter replacement.  When the tech finally came, he didn't have the alkaline filter with him...  I said goodbye to him, and onto Amazon I went.These filters fit perfectly with my RO system.  This is by far the best bargain for RO filters, and even includes a replacement membrane (replaced every 3 years).  The local RO shop charges ~$150 to replace the 6-stage filters annually (not the membrane), and that's with the "6 months" filters being used for 12 months, and since iSpring's includes 6 of the "6 months" filters, its an even better value.  And you can replace the filters at your own convenience.Only caveat was I had to call iSpring to request 4 free quick-fit adapters to thread onto the stage 5 & 6 filters (my previous ones had quick-fit built into the filter cases), with several wraps of Mr. Gasket 2842G Teflon Tape.  Phone support was very prompt and helpful.Check YouTube for simple "RO filter replacement" videos.  You'll want to clean the Stage 1-3 filter canisters (the big vertical ones), since they get grimy after a year.If you don't already have a horizontal mount for the stage 5 or 6 filters, I'd recommend S5-TO-S6 RO Kit for 2.5" diameter Inline Filter (buy 2 if you need a pair for both filters), which will keep the stage 5 & 6 filters stable and less prone to hose leakage.

Perfect to retrofit my RO Stage 6 Alkaline filter from ISPRING F28K75 6-Stage 75GPD Alkaline RO 3-Year Supply Filter Pack onto the bladder canister (the thick, horizontal tube).  The included 2 elbow quick-fit adapters and short 3/8" tube were bonuses.  The Alkaline filter now no longer just lies precariously over the bladder canister, straining the water tube fittings.

A key benefit of this mount is the articulating "ball" mount behind the mounting plate, which allows pivot in all directions, including turning 90 degrees to portrait mode and back, all without any tools.  Together with the extension arm, you can easily find the perfect viewing position and easily plug/unplug cables.PROS:+ Very versatile viewing angles, screen rotation, and extension without any tools.+ No sagging so far during the week I've had Samsung 226BW monitor (10 lbs, 22") mounted.+ Lots of useful extras, like mounting level, HDMI cable, mounting extension plates, and various sizes of screws, washers, & nuts.CONS:- The ball and articulating arm together create a 2" gap between the wall and the back of the monitor.  If you want a flush wall mount, get a simple wall mount without ball and/or articulating arm.- All the screws, washers, and nuts were bundled in one bag, so you have to manually sort all of them, then reference the manual to figure out which is which.  Also, there was no suitable washer included for the smallest monitor mounting screw (all washers' inner diameter were too big).TIP:Finding the ideal monitor and wall screw positions are difficult to do alone.  To simplify, trace and cut a template of your monitor face-down on a box (like the Amazon box that the wall mount shipped in), then measure and mark the mounting plate's holes on that box.  Tape the template onto the mounting plate.  Once you find the ideal wall position with the template/mount combo, mark the wall mount holes using a pencil or thumbtack.

The tablets do not dissolve in the dish washer (2012 KitchenAid SS, run on normal wash setting).  Ran twice with the same tablet, but it does not dissolve at all (yes, wrapper was off).  The tablet just ends up sitting whole on the bottom of the dish washer each time.  Tried 3 different tablets with same issue.This has never happened with Seventh Generation nor Cascade dishwasher packs.  Apparently, some others have the same issue.

Has straight plug.  If you're looking for right-angle (flat) plug, try V7 SA0404B-8N6 (almost exactly the same as this, but has right-angle plug) or Monster MP OTG400 BK Outlets To Go Power Strip - 4 AC (compact/portable and has plenty of room 4 fat brick adapters, but has no power switch and short cord).

Below is a comparison of 5 various Note 4 cases, with notes on Verizon bottom mic hole compatibility.------Samsung Galaxy Note 4 Protective CoverSamsung original case, which I've settled on after trying at least 5 cases.  Note that if you register your phone on samsung.com, you'll receive a 50% off accessories code good for 30 days, so you may want to check samsung.com's price prior to purchasing on Amazon.Pros:+ Sleek, functional, very attractive, and doesn't even look like a case.+ Back has bump texture to prevent slippage+ Back blue color is very vibrant and shimmery like a blue morpho butterfly (also comes in black or red)+ side and front edges are black rubber (rather than cheaper TPU), with extra protrusions at the corners for enhanced drop protection+ Power and volume buttons are encased under well-defined protrusions, rather than cutouts.  You can easily find and press the buttons by feel.+ Cutouts for jacks and mics are perfect, with the bottom mic cutout being oval to fit any model Note 4 (Verizon's, which I have, has the bottom mic hole 2mm further from the USB jack than AT&T/T-Mobile/Sprint.  Verizon always likes being difficult).  This simple oval cutout avoids the mic-blocking issue on the majority of third-party case models.+ Rather than a typical bulky plastic/gel case, this case is flush everywhere and perfectly contoured to the phone, an obvious benefit of being the OEM.  In fact, the case and phone look to be one, rather than a phone inside a case+ The headphone jack cutout is large enough to accomodate thick moulding wire+ Google Wallet for NFC Tap-and-Pay worked fine at Duane ReadeCons:- At $25-$30, almost double the price of third-party cases, although Samsung offers 50% off direct accessories discount after registrationWishes:* A built-in kickstand------* Ringke FUSION CaseMy favorite case (prior to Samsung's), but the issue was the Verizon bottom mic blockage.  HOWEVER, it seems from the 4th product image and recent reviewers that the manufacturer has recently updated the hole placement to be oval to accomodate Verizon models.Pros:+ Nice looking soft clear case looks like your phone is encased in glass, rather than an ugly plastic slab+ Tethered dust/water caps for headphone and USB jacks, great frome blocking dust and lint from pocketing all day, every day+ Offered in many color options (just the sides or entire)+ Fits well all around, and volume/power buttons operated fine under the raised nubs+ Half the price of Samsung's OEM caseCons:- $4 shipping and seller doesn't offer via Amazon Prime, so you don't have Amazon's no hassle return policy- You may need to contact seller to replace yours with updated case if you have Verizon Note 4------* Encased Shell Holster Combo Case with Kickstand & Belt ClipIf you want a holster, this may be a good choice.Pros:+ Kickstand+ Case snaps onto included belt holster+ Sturdy kickstand that works in both vertical and horizontal mode, although horizontal is a bit wobbly+ Case alone is slimmer than expected+ Fits Verizon bottom mic hole+ Low priceCons:- Slick plastic surface, although it does have a slight bump texture- Front of top & bottom portions are exposed due to need for use with the snap holster- Available in "any color so long as it is black"------* JOTO Armor CaseProbably the best KICKSTAND case for Note 4.Pros:+ Oval cutout for bottom mic to accomodate both Verizon and "normal" Note 4+ Layer of soft rubber-like TPU + hard outer shell+ Flush kickstand works for horizontal, but is flimsy.  I'd only use it for viewing, not tapping the screen+ Low priceCons:- IMHO, back looks like cheap painted plastic prone to scuffs------* Evecase S-LINE Slim Fit TPU Case with Kick-StandNice looking clear case with sturdy kickstand, although I personally didn't like the "S" pattern in the back that much.Cons:- Bottom mic hole doesn't line up with Verizon model, but it was soft enough to cut with a knife- The bottom lip just under the home button rises a little, so it's not a perfect fit- The kickstand hinge juts out, so the phone doesn't lie flat, causing it to annoyingly wobble when tapping on the screen.  This became a deal breaker after a few days, relegating it to the junk drawer, since I had cut the mic hole.

The usual Spot flip-pieces book, but not nearly as interesting as "Where's Spot?", with tiny flip pieces.  The flip pieces are tiny (ex:  a ball the size of a quarter, with just a speech bubble beneath) and rip off with only a tiny tug (clear packing tape to the rescue).

I've been using Brother P-Touch label maker to tag assorted power and network cables, but needed something quicker to tag in assorted colors for the unfinished basement tubes, wires, and cables.Along with Sharpie Retractable Ultra Fine Point Permanent Markers, 3 Colored Markers(1735794), I was able to quickly tag cold (blue marker) & hot (red marker) water pipes and where they lead.  Same for reverse osmosis water system inlet and outlets to sink and fridge.  Water bypass tubes to backup sump pumps and sprinkler.  The uses are endless.Pros:+ Tag portion is above the loop enclosure (easier to differentiate among crowded cables).  Other similar products' tags are below the loop, which some may prefer.+ Loop enclosures had no defectsCons:+ Tag portion is a bit small, requiring a fine point marker to write.  You can use a taped-over Scotch tape or P-Touch label for a bigger writing surface.

Since my babies run, roll, & crawl on the lawn, I wanted a toxin-free solution to the weeds and crabgrass.  Whether you think pesticide/herbicide concerns are overblown, you can't argue with immediate results from weeds being physically removed versus waiting days/weeks with repeated chemical use (which cost money).Some folk remedies sounded dubious at best:* Vinegar:  costs money (albeit cheap) & also kills healthy grass* Boiling water:  boil multiple pots of water, then lug it around while trying not to scold myself??  No thanks.* Pull by hand:  not only tedious and painful, it's almost impossible to pull the entire root by hand.This Fiskars tool is pure genius:  the tried and true method of pulling weeds by the root via an ergonomic, lightweight tool.I bring along a small cart with a paper grocery bag to eject the weeds into and a container of grass seed mixture to fill up any soil gap.  After I'm done, the paper bag of weeds is left on the curb for weekly pickup.  Going green with a green thumb:  2 green thumbs up.Pros:+ Very easy and comfortable to operate.+ Instant results, and can be seeded immediately.+ No toxic chemicals.  Lawn can be used immediately.+ No $ spent after one-time purchase.+ Lightweight.  No heavy container of herbicide to lug.+ Eject mechanism further simplifies and speeds up weeding.  And fun!+ Super-herbicide resistent weeds?  No problem.+ Green.  0 chemicals.  No pollution.Cons:- This model doesn't have a handle hole for hanging, although the other 2 do.  You could hang it upside down at the base if you have a long hook, but dirt will fall and the handle will be tilted.Wishes:* A plastic cap for the claw-end would be nice.

I had the Chase Amazon Visa 3% back credit card, which I was happy with.  I had set my Chase checking account to auto full pay the card each month, so the only thing to remember was to periodically use the saved credit points on a purchase (can be an odd value like $3.21; doesn't have to be $20 increments like most point cards).  And free extended warranty!With that great experience, the new Amazon Store Card with 5% sounded even better.  But what's the catch??  For purchases over $149, Amazon Store Card automatically switches the benefit option from 5% credit to 0% credit with 6+ months extended financing.  Sneaky sneaky, but I figured I'd just be vigilant to manually change the reward option back to 5% credit.Not so fast.  Amazon Store Card becomes your default payment, so my subscribe and save purchase (costing over $149) automatically got the extended financing.  Since I pay in full each month (especially with its ridiculous 25% APR, I hope everyone does), this amounts to LOSING a 5% discount:  a $200 invoice should've been $190 after 5% credit, but now I've lost out on that $10.I've reverted my default payment to Amazon Visa, but then miss out on the extra 2% discount for subscribe and save.  For regular purchases, I now have to manually change regular payment option to the Store Card, confirm it's 5% credit instead of extended financing, and manually pay the monthly statement while adding on the previously forced extended financing amount.And the Store Card does NOT have free extended warranty, which Chase Amazon Visa has, so I use the Visa for more expensive purchases.  But then it kind of defeats the purpose of the Store Card.Now, if I close out the Amazon Store Card, it'll mess up my credit length (already -23 points from Store Card's hard credit inquiry).  I'll close it out regardless in a few months for my sheer spite for it.By the way, regardless of your credit score, your starting limit is amazingly low.  That itself is not a big deal; GE / Synchrony Bank (which manages the Amazon Store Card) automatically raises your limit after several months of full payment.I'd highly recommend applying for or staying with Chase Amazon Visa instead (I'm not affiliated with Chase).

I've been using the 18" x 36" for my kids' bathtub for almost 9 months now, and love it.Pros:1.  Non-slip:  My 2-year old has never slipped while using this mat.  The full-size tub (2008) already has a textured surface, but my toddler often slipped on it before the mat.2.  Sitting & standing comfort:  The thick rubber and big suction cupped bottom provide plenty of cushion.3.  Good grip:  Large and copious suction cups provide excellent stability even on textured tub surface.4.  Easy to clean:  After each bath, I just splash the top and bottom a few times with a small bucket of clean water, then hang top-down to dry over KidCo Bath Toy Organizer Storage Basket5.  Perfect coverage from back of tub to the drain.Cons / Wishes:- Some cute pattern options or brighter colors would be nice for kids' use.  However, better boring white (it's actually more like ivory, with cross-hatch pattern) than leaching colors or chemicals.Tips:* Be sure to measure the dimension of your tub bottom from the back to the drain.* It may have smelled initially of rubber, but scrubbing it with soap and sponge, then hang dry for a few days got rid of any smell.  You'll obviously want to clean it before first use anyway.Other great kid bath accessories:KidCo Bath Toy Organizer Storage Basket:  to organize scoops, toys, and hang dry the bath matSkip Hop Bath Spout Cover, Moby:  keep the kid from banging head or touching hot faucetBRICA Bath Kneeler:  your knees will thank youSkip Hop Moby Bathtub Elbow Rest, Blue:  your elbows will thank you, and it'll absorb water from your wet arms (rather than dripping to bathroom floor)Munchkin Lazy Buoys Bathtub Toys:  we've purchased multiple bath toys, but this is by far the most interactively fun toy set.  Great for keeping kids occupied during the bath, and they're a snap to rinse clean (no crevices for mold).

I had previously purchased Custom Leathercraft 125M Handyman Flex Grip Work Gloves, which at ~$12 for 1 pair, is almost the same price as this set of 12 pairs.  Although Leathercraft is certainly sturdier and preferred for handling very sharp objects, I just keep the G&F gloves all around house for 99% of the housework:  garage, mudroom, toolbox, paint supplies, basement, backyard shed, gardening basket, & 2 car trunks.  I still have 3 pairs left over.  Honestly, I don't even know where the expensive Leathercraft gloves are anymore.+ comfortable+ thick fabric+ full rubbery grip on bottom half of hand (prick protection & grip)+ washable (washed & hung dry after paint/dirt, and they're like new)+ low price (only ~$1/pair)- doesn't come in pink (I kid)

My wife and I happily used NorthShore Premium Blue Disposable Underpads (Chux), 17 x 24, Case/100 (4/25s) at ~$0.28/pad for our first child's diaper changing needs, but switched to this one (~$0.10) for almost a third of the cost for the second child.  Big mistake.  We don't care too much about the thickness or absorbency (just catch the occasional accidents and leaks!), but these underpads pill and strip way too much.  Whenever we scoop up our infant, cotton strands are stuck to our fingers and baby, resulting in much gnashing of teeth and non-PG exclamations.  Whereas the previous sets were good until leaks or smears, these are only good for a few changes, even if still clean.  I'm ordering NorthShore Economy Disposable Underpads, Small, 17x24 in., Pack/70 now to test (~$0.20/pad), but if they're also bad, I'm definitely reverting to the NorthShore Premium.

My wife and I had purchased this book shortly after our daughter's first birthday, but hadn't actually read it to her until she had turned 21 months, due to the fragile paper pages (vs a board book) and the sheer number of books we had already purchased.The first time I read this book to our daughter, I thought upon the first page that the calligraphy-style font choice and wasted page spacing were poor, but the story still endearing.  The book progresses with a story of the mother recounting her experience with her daughter through childhood, then imagining her future.  Around the middle of the story is the passage, "Someday I will stand on this porch and watch you waving your arms until I no longer see you."I cried.While I am already a daddy's girl's daddy, the story made me realize even more just how fleeting parenthood can be.The illustrations are also light, yet profound, in water color style.I rate this book 4 out of 5 stars because it's not really a kid's book, but rather more of a mother's, yet seems overpriced for a short, sentimentality book.  And where's the father in the story?!  So sexist... (only sort of kidding).  Regardless, it's a good companion of Dr Seuss's "Oh, The Places You'll Go!"

This is used as a liner for HANDy 2500-CT HANDy Paint Pail to easily switch between multiple paint colors (different color walls, trims, or rooms) and simplify cleanup:  even easier to wash since there aren't any nooks, or just toss it.For even easier trim painting and quick touch ups, I store extra paint in Ziploc Twist 'N Loc , Medium Round, Containers, which fit perfectly in the HANDy Paint Pail.  No need to pry open gallon or quart cans each time or wash the liners.

Instead of awkwardly holding a quart or gallon can by the metal handle (or precariously holding the Ziploc), you just slide your hand through the grip.  It feels very natural and comfortable, and brush dipping isn't obstructed by your other hand and handle.  Since you're holding the paint with your arm naturally bent and close, you aren't constantly doing bicep curls or bending down as with a paint can.For easy trim painting and quick touch ups, I store extra paint in Ziploc Twist 'N Loc , Medium Round, Containers, which fit perfectly in this pail.  No need to pry open gallon or quart cans each time or even cleanup.  Alternatively, use HANDy 2520-CT Paint Pail Liners, 6-Count to swap between multiple color paint (handy for accent walls or chair-mouldings), and makes cleanup a snap (quick wash with soap or just toss the liners).If you need your painting hand free or a break, the magnet in the pail at the inner top edge of the handle enables a metal-rim paint brush to rest vertically without sinking into the paint or dripping over the side.Definitely a great investment that makes life so much easier, again and again.

Everyone in the "Asian" family set has slanty line eyes (without eyeballs) and bowl haircuts, dad wears 70's drapery pattern shirt, and mom wears an apron.  While at it, why not just put chopsticks and bowls of rice in their hands?In comparison, the "Caucasian" and "Ethnic Family #7416" all have unique haircuts and non-stereotypical outfits (hmm, no cornrow braids and tie-dye shirts?).  Oh, and eyeballs.We won't be buying anything from this racist company.

My walk-in closet, which has the pull-down attic stairs, has been noticeably cold in NJ winter, even though it has its own central-air vent.  Makes sense, since the attic stair access is not insulated, while the rest of the attic flooring is.Using Black & Decker TLD100 Thermal Leak Detector over a couple of days, I've confirmed the attic access vs ceiling just a foot or two away consistently had a 10 degrees F temperature difference.  A few hours after installing this attic stairway cover, the temperature difference became only 3 degrees F, confirmed again a few days later.This unit was very easy to assemble (like a mini tent), and probably took less than a minute.  There's about 2 inches of extra fabric along the perimeter frame, which helps seal the draft.  The entire frame sits stable over the attic entrance, with about 1-2" per side of extra clearance.

Great for guests to keep track of own glass when hosting, although I've augmented it with the 12 set of True Fabrications Colorful Silicone Wine Charms.  If you don't host a big group, this alone is a perfect set, especially with the handy wine stopper.  Although natural corks usually store open bottles fine sideways (synthetics rarely do in my experience), the bundled bottle stopper ensures minimal drippage.The downside of this set is that it only contains 6 markets and it's TOO cute:  kids also found the little marker buddies cute, and run off with them (lost 2 in 1 night this way).  Now down to only 4 markers, I needed a new set, which is why I also got the True Fab 12-set.  Also, the black and the purple are a bit hard to tell apart (especially inebriated), but it's a minor quibble.

Great for guests to keep track of own glass when hosting.I had previously been using Umbra Drinking Buddy Wine Bottle Stopper and Wine Glass Markers, 7-Piece Set, which was great (especially the cute, yet useful, rubber bottle cork), but comprised of only 6 markers.  In addition, kids would also find the little marker buddies cute, and run off with them (lost 2 in 1 night this way).  Now down to only 4 markers, I needed a new set.This set contains 12 (although a color-blind friend couldn't tell the difference with a few colors), but aren't TOO cute for kids to run off with, although all adults loved them.  Champagne flutes, white wine glasses, and various red wine glasses all fit fine with these markers, although not quite as wide as the Umbra.  Some other reviewers had issues with fit, but these stretch and grip well.  With Amazon's generous free return policy, definitely give these a shot.The set comes with a handy clear stick to attach all of them for compact storage.  With the Umbra set, I had to just plop them loose in the wine glass cabinet.  If you don't have too many wino friends, go with Umbra.  Otherwise, this is perfect (companion or solo).

Previously with a standard car snow brush, I'd open a side door, stand on the ledge (I'm 5'10"), then swipe back and forth to clear one corner of the SUV roof, then repeat from the other 3 doors, inevitably resulting in some snow inside the car.  Similarly, I'd clear half the snow from the windshield, hood, and the back from one side, then repeat from the other side.  Now you're cold, covered in snow from hand to torso, and lamenting the wasted minutes of spiked hot chocolate time.With this ingenious device, you can clear the entire SUV all from one side in seconds.  You detach the handle from the head, twist it on, then extend the handle (twist locks secure); whole process takes 3 seconds.  The side of the foam head curved away from you is used to push the snow off to the other side, then you spin it halfway to the side curved toward you to pull the snow off.  Repeat this a few times (or just stick to the push technique), and the car's ready to go.  No discourteous and illegal "snow missiles" anywhere on your car.PROS:+ Easy to push/pull snow off the roof & hood very quickly and easily+ Head (orange portion) is solid foam to avoid scratching the car paint; bright color makes it easy to locate in the trunk/backseat+ Compact:  handle bar collapses, detaches, and clips lengthwise to the head+ Base of handle has an ice scraper+ Sturdy:  I've been using my first one for 3 NJ wintersCONS:- A brush attachment would be great for wiper well clearing (I just dig it out with the scraper portion or by hand)I've purchased another for the second car, and gifted 3 more to relatives.

Whether snowboarding or commuting to work, this is the scarf to have.  It's attached/adjusted via velcro in the back, so it's easy to put on and take off, without messing your hair or glasses.  This is especially handy when you're wearing a helmet/goggles or earphones.  I usually keep the nose/face portion down, but it's great to use on windy days.  The vented nose and mouth openings help breathe easily and minimize goggle/glasses fogging.  Since it's compact, you can keep it in your jacket/coat pocket.

I've had Zwilling Pro S line of kitchen & steak knives for years and love them.  These shears, on the other hand, are going back after a week of use.Pros:- Looks good- Cuts wellCons:- It's VERY stiff to open and close.  Each cut is sheer frustration- The finger hole fits only 2 fingers (I have small hands)- Blades are very short- Wife hates it because it's too uncomfortable (she's the home executive chef; I'm the bus boy)The no name kitchen shears we've been using is much more usable, but rusting at the screw.  I'll give the cheaper Zwilling J.A. Henckels Twin L Kitchen Shears a shot.

This is a great collection of classic Christmas songs, sung by the original artists of yesteryear (Bing Crosby, Nat King Cole, etc.).  This is not a choir of children singing, which can get annoying very quickly.The only thing "children's" about this collection is that they're all PG songs, but perfectly suitable for an adult gathering.  The collection doesn't include the salacious "Baby, It's Cold Outside", for instance.By the way, now when you purchase any music CD from Amazon, you can download the MP3 versions for free!

The microwave guide roller was missing in our recently purchased house, causing the tray to routinely rattle while revolving.  I purchased it on Amazon from PartsAway (third-party seller) for $28.24 (obviously too expensive for such a simple part, but it was still cheaper than directly from GE).

This was my wife and my favorite toothpaste for over 4 years until the latest research info on its #2 ingredient.  Look at the back of the box or tube for the ingredients (Amazon has a picture):  #2 is triclosan, the active ingredient in "Total" anti-gingivitis."Triclosan is a bacteria-killing chemical used in Colgate Total toothpastes...  It has been shown to interfere with thyroid signaling and male and female sex hormone signaling."www.ewg<dot>org/enviroblog/2014/01/chemicals-should-disappear-cosmetics"Research has shown that triclosan:- Alters hormone regulation in animals- Might contribute to the development of antibiotic-resistant germs- Might be harmful to the immune system"www.mayoclinic<dot>org/triclosan/expert-answers/FAQ-20057861"Animal studies have shown that triclosan alters hormone regulation."www.fda<dot>gov/forconsumers/consumerupdates/ucm205999.htm"Studies have increasingly linked triclosan (and its chemical cousin triclocarban), to a range of adverse health and environmental effects from skin irritation, endocrine disruption, bacterial and compounded antibiotic resistance, to the contamination of water and its negative impact on fragile aquatic ecosystems."www.beyondpesticides<dot>org/antibacterial/triclosan.php*EDIT*We switched to a non-"Total" version of Colgate (Crest is fine too, but wife still prefers Colgate) from PERSONAL choice of selecting a toothpaste that has no potential side effects from Triclosan, but clean teeth just as well.

Perfect to keep bugs out of your food for outdoor BBQs, picnics, etc., especially when dishes are laid out buffet style.  Comes with 2 large, 4 medium, and 1 storage pouch with drawstring.The net canopies are stored folded like an umbrella.  To open, pull on the little handle at the top to pop it open.  To fold, push the handle down.  Very effortless.I like the square shape, which allows flush edges with the table top to deter any crawlers, and the covers fit nicely over my rectangular dishes.  Be sure to confirm the canopies' dimensions will fit your dishes, but even the medium should be large enough for most.

I wasn't sure whether the water pressure from the 2 outside faucets were weak because of my Gardena hose attachments or the recently plumber-installed pressure reducer (from 80 to 45 psi) in the basement.  I had recently purchased the house, so there was no basis for comparison, other than that the outside water pressure was pitiful compared to other houses.  So I purchased this gauge to determine the source of the water flow issue and to use in adjusting the pressure reducer to 60 psi.I placed this gauge directly on the backyard faucet:  67 psi.  Surprisingly high for the low water pressure.  I shut off the water:  0 psi.  I then placed it at the end of the 1/2" Gardena hose with accessory adapter:  67 psi.  Hmm, I guess the hose and attachment are ok...  Front yard, both scenarios, again 67 psi.  I set the water flow to almost a trickle:  67 psi.  I check the basement's post-pressure reducer section of piping:  67 psi.  OK...This specific item has a no return policy.

We got a hand-me-down of this from a nephew, but noticed that the sounds it made for the animals were one spin behind.  For example, the spinner lands on chicken but goes "moo", spinner then lands on pig but goes "cluck cluck", spinner then lands on sheep but goes "oink".  1 out of 4 spins make no sounds at all.  I assumed the toy had just broken, so I ordered a new one directly from Amazon.  Surprise surprise, same exact problem with a new one.  Back to Amazon it went.

I had a NETGEAR GS108NA ProSafe 8-Port Gigabit Ethernet Desktop Switch (Ver 3) in my home office and an old Netgear FS105 ProSafe 5-Port Fast Ethernet Desktop Switch in the living room working fine for about a year, and I'd decided to upgrade to a second 1GE 8-port switch.After extensive research on Amazon & Newegg, I'd decided on TP-LINK TL-SG1008D 10/100/1000Mbps 8-Port Gigabit Desktop Switch, 10Gbps Switching Capacity.  While I could've just gotten another NETGEAR GS108NA ProSafe 8-Port Gigabit Ethernet Desktop Switch, I wanted a front-LED / rear-jack style for the home office for aesthetic reasons.  So, I moved my existing Netgear 1GE switch to the living room, and installed the new TP-Link switch in the home office.  I received from Amazon (direct; not a third-party) TL-SG1008D Ver 5.1, S/N 133A7904XXX (last 3 digits redacted for security).Since these are "dumb" switches, there's no configuration involved; just plug in the power and the cat 5e/6 cables and you're done (category 5 and lower are only for 100Mbps max).  However, in the 2 weeks I had the TP-Link switch, I'd noticed that the always-on Synology NAS consistently alerted me ~2-4 times a day that it had lost WAN connectivity.  My desktop also couldn't reach the router until I power-cycled the TP-Link switch.After I had swapped out the TP-Link switch for a second NETGEAR GS108NA ProSafe 8-Port Gigabit Ethernet Desktop Switch (another Ver 3) a week ago, I have not had any network issues.  The router has been consistently fine as of 7/20/2013.Before you suggest I should've done "ipconfig /renew" or something, my B.Sc. and professional background are heavily in networking.Home Office:270Mbps Actiontec Ethernet to Coax Adapter Kit for Homes with Cable TV Service (ECB2500CK01) (#1, uplink to MBR FiOS 1GE router)1Gbps  Tower1Gbps  Synology DiskStation 1-Bay (Diskless) Network Attached Storage DS112 (White)100Mbps Brother Printer DCP7065DN Monochrome Laser Multi-Function Copier100Mbps IBM Laptop (when not on WiFi)100Mbps Xbox 360 (when not in living room)Living Room:270Mbps Actiontec Ethernet to Coax Adapter Kit for Homes with Cable TV Service (ECB2500CK01) (#2, uplink to MBR FiOS 1GE router)100Mbps Sony STR-DN1030 AV Receiver100Mbps Samsung BD-P2500100Mbps Xbox 360100Mbps Samsung WI-FI All-Share Cast Hub, Wireless HDMI Display Adapter (Black)1Gbps  Sony Laptop (when not on WiFi, for 1080p video streaming)

This also comes in a smaller size Boon Grass Countertop Drying Rack, Green, which is roughly 2/3 in size of this Boon Lawn, but other parents who have the smaller one all said they'd prefer this bigger one.  I actually wish Boon offered an even bigger one, since this one just about holds my 1 child's items (since ~6mo - now 1yr old) with daily organizing.  However, as impressive as some of the Tetris-master parents' customer pics are, Boon Lawn in reality holds far less, unless you want wet counters from your meticulously stacking hands or drips from edge-hanging bottles.The green "grass" blades hold upside-down bottles well, although sometimes plastic bottles tend to pop off if not stuck properly.  Since there are so many blades, you can rest or stack various size parts without them falling into a crevice (they'll gently rest on the grass tips).  You can even vertically stick baby utensils, handle-down.Downside is that since the blades are so densely packed, they're hard to thoroughly clean by hand.  However, the grass (the entire grass portion is a single solid piece with holes at the bottom) and the white tray are both dishwasher safe.  You'll want to clean the grass and the tray at least once a week (whether by hand or dishwasher), since the old drip water pools in the tray and gets dirty.Boon Stem Grass and Lawn Drying Rack Accessory, Blue/Orange is a must-have addition, not only utilizing vertical space to hang nipples/seals/vales/etc., but also to minimize surface contact (faster drying & less germs).  OXO Tot Bottle Brush & OXO Tot Straw and Sippy Cup Top Cleaning Set are also great cleaning companions.OXO Tot Bottle Drying Rack, Green is a similar baby drying rack, but with much-wider spaced blades.  Downside of that is it won't stack small items.  Upside is you can vertically place thicker baby plates (like the excellent Oxo dish), which Boon can't.  Bowls are fair game, so I personally prefer Boon's versatility (I just use the adult dish rack for baby plates & bowls).

Upon my home inspector's recommendation, I researched and bought various types of water detectors.  Aside from Honeywell RWD41 Water Defense Water Sensing Alarm, which I also have and is prefect for perimeter water detection (e.g., around a water boiler, laundry, etc.), this is the perfect water alarm.I have 10 of Glentronics GWD-HWA--for various bathroom/kitchen sinks, sump pumps, a/c units, etc.  These take 9V batteries like Energizer LA522SBP 9V Lithium Battery for Smoke Detectors, which last much longer and are more convenient to test & replace (slide vs screw cover) than "Froggie" 3x AAA types.  This also has a detachable sensor that can be dangled over a deep sump pump pit or into dubious crevices.  There have been no false alarms for the 10 alarms in 1 year, other than one had water splashed so vehemently into a sump pit that it had splashed onto the sensor (which was really legitimate).  As you can see from the picture, the 2 metal contacts on the detachable plate must come in contact to sound the alarm (putting a finger on each electrode will also "test" it, since your body conducts the electricity).Seriously, this is less than $10 and will alert you of a potential liquified doom of your home.  How much would a plumber cost to fix it instead?

I have a high water table that caused the Liberty Pumps 287 1/2-Horse Power 1-1/2-Inch Discharge 280-Series Automatic Submersible Sump Pump with VMF Switch to run every few minutes, even during dry weather (2008 house has 9' ceiling basement & is very close to a reservoir).  Since the basement had flooded by several inches during 2011's Hurricane Irene during a blackout (prior to my purchase of the home), I was paranoid about ground water.Additionally, the previous owner had to replace the sump pump after only 3 years, so I wanted to minimize the on/off cycle, which not only is bad for the sump pump, but is annoying (constant on/off whirl heard from the main floor) and a waste of electricity.  I first bought Glentronics, Inc. BWC1 Basement Watchdog Dual Float Sump Pump Switch with Controller to "raise" the water level switch.Installation for this piggyback switch was easy:1.  Plug the sump pump power plug into the back of the this device's power plug, then plug it into the wall power outlet.  Note that the power plug is quite large in all dimensions, but it stayed put and didn't lean out at all.2.  Using the supplied metal ring and flat-head screw, tie the float along the sump pipe at the appropriate height, determined by your water table during a dry week.  Note that ground water can still persist for days after a rain had stopped.3.  Test by lifting the bottom of the float with your finger or screw driver (or dump water into the sump pit).Using the Watchdog to "raise" the pump activation trigger--to about 2" below the basement surface--cut the sump pump activation to occur only every few hours, which was indeed an improvement.The switch reliably activated the pump.  However, the switch was supposed to continue to electrify the plug's outlet for at least 10 seconds upon activation to ensure sufficient water has been pumped out, but mine only went on for a few seconds after water level receded below its float (often for a begin-end cycle of only ~5 seconds).  The pump itself would have turned off upon its own float switch hitting bottom, but there was plenty of water still left during these early shutoffs.  Manually lifting the Watchdog's float switch with a screwdriver would indeed activate the pump until the entire pit was empty.I later had installed a second pit and (Zoeller 98-0001 115-Volt 1/2 Horse Power Model M98 Flow-Mate Automatic Cast Iron Single Phase Submersible Sump/Effluent Pump) with another Watchdog (on separate, dedicated 15A outlet/circuit/fuse), but it had the same issue of turning off too early.After several months of looking for a better solution and much gnashing of teeth, I bought 2 of Little Giant RVMS-10 1/2 HP Piggyback Vertical Mechanical Float Switch, which are basically the same idea and installed the same way.  The RVMS goes deeper into the pit since it's basically a long stick with a purely mechanical on/off float switch, but you can trim the stick's depth as needed.  It also reliably pumps the desired depth of water for the expected duration (the depth of the float's stick:  ~6.5").  We now go days without any water pumping.---FYI,I additionally had installed Liberty Pumps SJ10 1-1/2-Inch Discharge SumpJet Water Powered Back-Up Pump for each of the 2 sump pits in case of pump failure or blackouts.  No batteries to maintain or replace, and no time limit during extended blackouts.  Only requirement is sufficient water pressure (I believe ~30 PSI; I actually needed the plumber to lower mine from "dangerous" 65 PSI).Also, You may want to consider also purchasing water alarms like BWD-HWA (takes a 9V battery), which will alert you if there's contact with water (e.g., sump pump failed).  I also have these alarms around the house (under the sinks, behind the laundry, by a/c handlers, etc.), and they've proven very worthy (sump pump didn't run during a night blackout and water reached a threshold just under the water-powered pumps; laundry unknowingly had leaked when using jumbo load size).  They'll pay for themselves in minutes vs water damage repairs.

I liked French Bathroom Door Toillette Sign / Plaque for the downstairs and the upstairs bathrooms (especially since upstairs bathroom was a mystery door among 3), but I couldn't find a silver/zinc one.However, with a small dab (size of a pea) and rubbing of this polish/finish/whatever, the sign transformed from dark bronze to silver/zinc that matched perfectly with the house's decor.  I used Scotch Exterior Mounting Tape, 1-Inch by 60-Inch to mount it to the bathroom doors (no screw holes and perfectly level).  This was one of the rare occasions when my wife approved of my house "improvements".I recommend you use a disposable glove like GLOVES NITRILE P/F MEDIUM ***G Size: 100 while rubbing/polishing.See the customer image for the after-polish-shot.

I liked French Bathroom Door Toillette Sign / Plaque for the downstairs (guests kept opening the closet door next to it) and the upstairs bathrooms (upstairs one was indistinguishable from 2 bedroom doors next to it), but I couldn't find a silver/zinc one.However, with a small dab (size of a pea) and rubbing of this polish/finish/whatever, the sign transformed from dark bronze to silver/zinc that matched perfectly with the house's decor.  I used Scotch Exterior Mounting Tape, 1-Inch by 60-Inch to mount them to the bathroom doors.  This was one of the rare occasions when my wife approved of my house "improvements".I recommend you use a disposable glove like GLOVES NITRILE P/F MEDIUM ***G Size: 100 while rubbing/polishing.0The finished result is in the "customer image".

I needed a very large magnet board (I bought the 60cm x 90cm, roughly 24" x 36") to hold novelty (fridge) magnets I've collected around the world.  Since the largest magnet/dry-erase board I could find top out at only 14" x 30", this was a great find.  A large magnet sheet I had previously purchased turned out to not be magnetic enough to hold a fridge magnet.Pros:+ HUGE+ Magnets stick very strongly (doesn't slide)+ No borders/frames+ Can be mounted horizontally or verticallyCons:- Not dry-erase (not meant to be, but most magnet boards are also dry-erase)- Magnetic bond is a bit too strong, so magnets can't be glided to a new position (pry magnet with your fingernails, then reposition it)- Surface is prone to smudge (it's stainless steel, so it's typical)- Over $100?!I bought it "like new" via Amazon Warehouse for only ~$44, which was less than half price.  1 short edge was very slightly bent (barely noticeable), but was easily bent back by hand.I also bought STEELMASTER Soho Collection Magnetic Board with Dry-Erase Pad, Pen and Magnets, 14 x 24 Inches, Silver (270162450) for dry-erase use, which I've mounted vertically next to this Blomus board for a paired look.

I'd used this upon ewg_dot_org's recommendation on safe laundry detergents, but will try alternatives.Pros:1.  Rated very highly on ewg_dot_org and goodguide_dot_com.Cons:1.  Doesn't fully dissolve, leaving clumps of detergent on some clothes.  Ironically, the package recommends using cold water, which is likely a big factor in the problem.2.  The box--with pull-off tie at the upper 1/4 of the box with no securing--results in potential spills and airborne powder.3.  Requires you to make a paste with the powder and water for pre-treatment.  Have an old liquid detergent cap or plastic cup handy.4.  Cleaning ability is just ok (many bibs and shirts need to be washed twice).  Followed instruction on the box, which states to use 1 scoop for a small or medium load, 2 scoops for a large load.Personally, I've found powder form to be quite a hassle.  Method free & clear laundry that I had used previously sufficed, but I'll now try Seventh Generation Liquid Laundry 4x, Free and Clear, 40 Fl Oz. 2 Count.[update]I've been using a long, empty water bottle to stir the powder to properly dissolve before loading clothes, which prevents the clumping & residue problem.  The efficient (lazy) side in me still prefers liquid.

This drawer sits under my Latissima+, taking up only minimal footprint UNDER it (extra 4" width & 4" depth), while saving much more space than the OEM Discovery Box accessory, which sits with nothing over it (needs to flip up).  The drawer tray glides smoothly, and the entire drawer is made of metal with black coating.  The drawer is very sturdy.The drawer is designed to be 6 capsules wide and 10 capsules deep.  Each slot is separated from the other with a slight lip, while the deepest 2 reside on a single, long slot:  likely to allow for the 10th to easily slide to the 9th position.  I cut the coffee sleeve's capsule label to sit on the front-most slot for easy reference (what do color-blind people do??).HOWEVER (the reason for -1 star), the last 2 slots (total of 12 capsules) frequently get caught and crumpled under the upper lip of the front frame because the entire drawer is not tall enough.  If you have the drawer sitting at the very front edge of your counter for maximum drawer-pulled-tilt, you can get away with 9 capsules-deep.  BUT if you have the drawer sitting further back (kitchen counter space is precious!), you'll need to pry off the ball glides on the bottom of the drawer tray.  I used a monkey wrench to rip off the 2 ball glides (back bottom of the drawer tray; very easy, no physical effort), and now all 60 capsules sit fine while I glide the drawer all the way in and out.While the manual "hack" was annoying, I highly recommend this drawer tray, and even consider getting a second one to stack.

Such a simple, yet brilliant idea!  Yet, in real life usage, practicality falls a bit short.PROS:+ Looks elegant.+ Adjustable courseness.  Both salt and pepper have respective adjustable knobs on the bottom.+ Salt and pepper are always in one spot together.  If you need one, you probably need the other anyway!+ Pepper grinders are plenty, but matching salt grinders are usually hard to find.  While the necessity of freshly ground salt is dubious, the idea is appealing.CONS:- Refill is a pain:  A.  Hold the base on a tabletop and yank the top off.  If you don't hold it steady on a tabletop, you'll end up spilling the contents everywhere.  B.  The contents are under a flimsy O-shaped plastic sheet cover that barely stays in place because the once-sticky rim has become clung with salt and pepper residue.  Lift the sheet from the side that needs refill.  C.  Origami one hand with the flimsy plastic sheet lifted one side to fill the tiny U-shaped crevice of salt or pepper side with your other hand.  Try your best not to spill salt/pepper chunks into the other section or bounce off the stem onto the table.- Does not hold much salt or pepper compared to typical tall salt/pepper grinders.- Depending on the coarseness adjustment, both salt and pepper may inadvertently grind at the same time (ex: if salt adjustment is not tight/fine enough, turning top activates both pepper AND salt).- Remnants of salt and pepper tend to cling to the bottom of the grinder (like any grinder), so if you want purely just salt OR pepper, it won't happen.  It probably won't make a difference by taste, but may aesthetically (bits of inadvertent pepper).Once the novelty of a combo salt/pepper grinder wears off, you have a gimmicky grinder that doesn't hold much AND is a pain to refill.  My wife doesn't care much for this, but if the salt/pepper refill sections were better divided with hinged lids instead of a plastic sheet, I'd still give it 5 stars.

I wanted to put up 3-digit individual number signs, but could barely get the hammer drill to make a dent in the brick walls.  I also figured a nail/screw hole outside may cause water to seep in and cause faster deterioration, so I tried these.I cut up and molded some pieces around the exposed back edges of the metallic numbers, cleaned the brick sections with a little rubbing alcohol, then pressed the numbers against the brick and held for a few seconds each.  Since the numbers were black on red brick, the tape wasn't visible at all.I also used a bit on 4 corners of a large metal "beware of dog" sign on the PVC fence.After 10 months of direct sun, wind, and rain (including Superstorm Sandy), the numbers and the dog sign are amazingly still holding fine.I'll next try adding a bit to the back corners of the mailbox that's not quite secure on the faux stucco.

That's obviously a stretch, but now the bottle opener is always next to the fridge, and bottles open easily one-handed in a quick, smooth motion.  Your other hand free to carry other precious items, such as popcorn or another bottle.  The bottle cap falls into the catcher, which has 4 little holes at the bottom to drain rainwater if mounted outdoors.  The catcher's also easily removed for dumping when full.The stainless steel looks good, the bottle opener is very solid, and we've gotten a lot of compliments from friends on the handy contraption set.The set was simple to install with 2 screws for the bottle opener and another 2 for the catcher with included wall anchors.  I used my own screws instead of the bundled ones, but used the bundled cheap, blue wall anchors since they're flush against the wall, unlike the toggler anchors, which are sturdier but stick out a bit.

This is a great undershirt that not only keeps you toasty warm, but also isn't so ugly that it can't be worn in public (well at least amongst friends!) The shirt fits snugly, and you can then put any type of shirt over it - a sweater, button down or even a t-shirt. It isn't yet freezing cold in my neck of the woods so I tested this by wearing just the undershirt outdoors in 30 degree weather and it kept me much warmer then I would expect. It also doesn't look bad...you could wear this to a casual place and not look ridiculous.

I'll admit I'm not a fan of pod detergents.  I don't think they are a good value, but I understand their purposes. Compared to others I've tried, this gets the job done at a nice price.Unlike others pod brands, this comes in a ziplock-style bag.  That caused the smell to leak out.  I was also very concerned about safety with children around.  You can't childproof the container.If I purchased this again, I'd use a child-proof container.

I love parchment paper.  I use it wherever I can.  It keeps stuff from sticking to a baking tray without using oil.This quality paper doesn't fall apart or burn in the oven.  I haven't gotten fancy with "en papillote" for fish or chicken.  That doesn't mean I won't try.Once you use parchment paper, you become addicted.  It also makes clean-up a snap!

I've never tried this supplement from other brands.  I had hopes that it would change my appetite or hunger.  It did not. The good news is a had no side effects.This product has a large quantity of the pills, so I suggest trying a smaller bottle and see if it works for you.  The capsules for me were hard to swallow.For me, this was no better than a placebo.

We put this Scotts seed down this fall and it sprouted quickly and came up really well, in a clay soil in a partially shaded area. While promising, I will have to wait until next year to see how the seed thrives long term, but it has a good start and germinated as advertised.

This is a simple "book" that is part of the Baby Genius line for toddlers who are beginning to learn things like numbers and vocabulary. Similar to the other baby book, this one features soft fabrics, crinkly paper, and numerous interactive elements to entice a baby or toddler. What makes this book unique is the focus on vocabulary with numbers, fruits, vegetables, and animals. There's an interactive element with voices that speak the terms, and the construction is fairly durable.

I have fond vague memories of "books" like this as a toddler and this Baby Genius activity book is an excellent choice for the newest generation, combining the fold-out interactive physical fun (pleasing touch, interactive elements like crinkles) with some electronics to make music when various areas are touched. Some of the music triggers are somewhat hard to get to, and it might be challenging for a baby or toddler; overall though this is one of the better "baby books" out there and should be fun for any infant or toddler.
This is a colorful basic teething toy that is fun for a baby to play with and safe to chew and nibble on. The toy is very durable, cute, and you can mix and match each of the characters.

Without the electronic aspect, this is a decent colorful toy but nothing special. Once you activate the electronics, the toy becomes maddeningly annoying. The various characters do not activate as expected; it appears they are set off by motion and not the actual contact, but it was so inconsistent that it is hard to tell. I guess it is fine for making random noises, but this isn't a great learning toy, and even worse, it seems flimsy and not well-made. Altogether, probably not really worth it.

We tried this cleaner on a few spots where our dog peed on the carpet and where there was a slight but noticeable stain. The cleaner worked fairly decently - all the stains were definitely made lighter and less noticeable, and a couple were almost invisible. Even better, the odor of the cleaner was pleasant, and not the usual harsh "chemical" smell that other cleaners have. Time will tell if the scent deters any repeat peeing, but so far so good.

Range extenders are often difficult to configure, this one was easy.  Once you connect to it, a wizard finds the local networks to extend and adds a password.  That's it.  No software to install.What I like about this unit is it extends most major network types:  2.4 Ghz and 5. Ghz.  The three antennas cover huge distances.  In addition to extending a network, it bridges wired to wireless connections.  You can plug an ethernet cord directly into it and it will let a wired device connect to the wired network.  That's great for older printers.The two-year warranty is nice compared to most competitors with a year warranty.

This 64 GB card is a decent upgrade from the older version. Read speeds are significantly improved, and write speeds are bumped up a bit - not a massive amount but there's noticeable improvement. I haven't done any scientific tests, but using this card in my high-end Sony point and shoot camera I had no problem taking several shots in quick succession, and even shooting in RAW mode the speeds were decent. Shooting video is where the continuous 10 MB/sec really shines as it allows for higher quality video; I had no issues with this card.

I primarily use coconut oil in cooking, but it's good for occasional moisturizing or throwing in a smoothie.  I've even used it to butter my toast.  For regular home use I can't imagine anyone buying this, but it's perfect for travel.  Although I haven't tried this, I have a friend that swears by putting it in her coffee, so I gave her a few of these.

Our 22 pound beagle is a chewer, but I expected this treat to last more than 4 minutes and 26 seconds.  I timed it.  She bit off the head immediately (Easter Bunny anyone?) and then the rest she was able to break off into a few chunks.  We love Nylabone in general but this one misses the mark.

These are your standard disposable plastic drink cups, and they will easily hold the contents of a normal can or bottle of beer or soft drink. And can be re-used as well as recycled (although they won't stand up to any time of dishwashing). The team logos are a nice touch that will add a nice touch to your tailgate.

This Weed Easter hedge trimmer is a real champ. It is lightweight and easy to control, and the battery last a surprisingly long amount of time (although you may want to invest in an extra battery if you have a really large job to do). Construction quality is solid; this hedge trimmer feels very well made. I had no issue doing ordinary hedge-trimming as well as cutting away unruly vines and tall weeds. Do keep in mind this is not a chain saw - it is not designed for (and won't cut through) woody branches. However for normal green stemmed weeds and hedges, it works great.

This is a great little short cable, which works perfectly in situations where the standard longer cables are just overkill. Was well-constructed without any weak spots or kink areas, and charges iDevices just fine.

Bleach is powerful, but a pain to use.  It splashes everywhere damaging stuff.  It requires a huge container.  This product solves all those problems.The crystals don't have that heavy bleach smell.  I always get overwhelmed opening a bottle.  If the crystals spill, you don't have bleach staining everything.A full bottle of bleach fits into this tiny bottle.  Use as little as you need.

I love mushrooms, so I was expecting at least a somewhat earthy taste.  This flavor reminded me of every other orange drink:  citric acid and steviaI drank it both straight up and mixed in a smoothie. I wasn't expecting many health benefits.  The recommended dosage is 8 grams and it has 5 grams of fiber along with a full daily dose of vitamin C.  The ingredients don't explain how much of a dose of mushrooms you are getting nor the percentages of each.  The label describes an "immune blend" that includes a mushroom blend, cherry extract, green tea leaf extract, and ginger root.The net cost is about a dollar a glass.  I'm sure it's not harmful, but it's unclear how helpful it is.

Sometimes your child gets hungry and you don't have food handy.  Jars break or go bad, but powdered food lasts almost forever.  These small packets can go anywhere like a purse or a diaper bag.I tried it as an adult and it tasted pretty much like every baby food.  Not bad, but not gourmet.  What I did like is throwing it in with a smoothie to add some green power vegetables.  Tasty!We're keeping a few of the packets in the glove compartment for adult and baby food emergencies.

I'm a big fan of using gloves, especially in the kitchen.  It keeps things clean and prevents cross contamination.  These gloves are thinner than what I usually use.  The hold up well and didn't tear.My only complaint is they don't have a matte finish that makes it hard to grasp slick things.

If you have an older PC (desktop or laptop) that either doesn't support wireless or only support old, slower wifi standard, this Trendnet USB wifi adapter is a nice way to update the computer to connect at high speeds to modern, secure wifi networks. The device is a small USB dongle that attaches to any spare USB port. Once connected, it allows the PC to join 5ghz AC wifi network - reducing interference and adding a lot of speed. Additionally as a modern wifi connector, the Trendnet supports better security modes then what an older PC may have built in.  This device works on a laptop or desktop without opening it up.  That makes it great for non-techincal users.  I also like the 3 year warranty.The only downside is inherent in the device - it is an external dongle and can get in the way especially on a laptop, but this is a small complaint; this is a great inexpensive way to add life to an old computer.

I'm not a gym rat, but I know the importance of protein after a workout.  I typically bring a bar with me.  The problem is that bars don't always travel well.  They freeze or melt.  This is a good compromise.When I can't bring a bar, I bring a blender jar along with protein in it.  That means I have a mess to clean up afterwards. This solution solves the problem with a disposable pouch that you add liquid to.  It won't freeze or melt and is great to carry anywhere.  I'm keeping a few in the workout bag and I'll probably travel with these.The ingredients are standard for low-cost protein shakes.  Lots of chemicals and artificial stuff.  I prefer more natural products.  The taste is completely acceptable for the type of product it is. Nobody drinks this stuff for the test, but it's not horrible.  I'm sure using milk instead of water would improve the flavor, but that's not the point.  Like most shakes, use cold water.  That improves the flavor.

These headphones are a decent cheap pair of bluetooth headphones. I use them at the gym, and they work well, lasting about 3 hours per charge. Unlike many other headphones, the mic on these works decent too, making it easy to talk on the phone. However, the Mpow headphones have two major flaws. The first is somewhat inherent in the design, but you will get no - and I mean no - bass from the speakers. Everything will sound as tinny as an old AM radio. This is no huge deal when exercising and no one would mistake these for anything resembling audiophile headphones, but till, the sound quality is among the worst I have heard. The second flaw is that it is difficult to properly untwist the headphones for wearing - they curl up into a coil when no on your head and when you uncoil them, they tend to get kinked into weird shapes that make it hard to properly seat into your ears.These flaws aside, the price is good and they work, so as a fairly durable pair of cheap workout 'phones, these are OK.

If you have one of the newer Macbooks with the USB C connector, this is a super convenient cable for charging anything that uses a mini B connector. It is nice having a straight cable like this without needing to use a converter; this cable also works with many USB hard drives. The cable is well-made, and doesn't feel cheap or like it will start to fray and come apart.

This set of bartender tools is like a basic set of pots and pans - great if you don't have anything at all, and definitely better then nothing, but none of these are high-end pieces, and the set overall is fairly limited. That said, if you are just beginning to get into mixing your own drinks, you could do a lot worse. All the basic pieces are here to get you started, and while none are super durable, they will be plenty decent for the occasional home bartender who might want to make drinks for a few friends at a party.One downside - there is no documentation included with the set. These tools are designed for beginners, and a business-card sized pieces of paper with a URL on it is not a proper substitute for even a simple couple pages of instructions on what the tools are and how to use them, with perhaps a pointed to the web site for videos and more advanced instruction including recipes.

I use these gloves for two main purposes - cleaning and kitchen work. In both cases, the gloves work great. They are quick and easy to put on, fit nicely, and are durable and reliable. I have had no problem with any type of breakage or tearing, and the gloves have no residue or scent.

There's not much to say about this cable - it works as advertised, the snagless design operates properly, and the cable transmits data no problem at cat5E speeds. If you need a simple and reliable patch cable, this will fit the bill.

Fisher Price has done a really great job here. This set was easy to put together, and more importantly, it stayed together across many play sessions without falling apart. The materials are somewhat cheap but the playability was great and the cars performed as advertised. The play mechanism is fairly simple - the cars launch down the track and go around the loop. This is pretty neat and should entertain your child, but there's not too much variety in the play and its possible some kids may grow bored quickly. Luckily the cars can be re-used in other types of play and overall this is a solid, fun set.

I love Annie Chun's seaweed products and these snacks are excellent overall, just not my type of taste profile.Seaweed has that umami taste many of us crave, but it's delicate and greasy.  Annie combined seaweed with rice crackers into a portable snack.  The go-chu-jang was too sweet for me.  It tasted more like a savory cookie rather than a rice crisp or seaweed.  Annie makes seaweed snacks in a brown sugar variety.  If you like those, you'll love these crisps.  I didn't like the brown sugar seaweed :(  I think I'd really like this in another flavor

This is a a lightning cable, useful for charging any of your Apple iDevices, and it works as you would expect. However, unlike many other cables, there is a 90-degree angle right before the portion that plugs into your iDevice. This is a nice feature which helps prevent the cable from snagging, and also makes it easier to stand your device up (say to lean against something, bottom down). The connection where the cable meets the plug is also strong, which should prevent the frays and bulging that most of the Apple branded cables fall victim to over time.

There isn't too much exciting about a wiper blade, but this is an area you don't want excitement - you want something easy to install that works. This Bosch blade installs quickly and performs as advertised, handling everything from light rain to a thunderstorm, effectively removing the water from the windshield. I haven't tried it in any winter conditions but for an inexpensive blade that works, this Bosch is a solid choice.

The Braven speaker is a really great accessory - it is a quality speaker, speakerphone and charger all in one, and it is waterproof to boot. As a bluetooth speaker, this device performs admirably. It was quick and easy to pair, but most importantly, the music sounds great. It will not replace a real stereo system, but the sound is great for such a small device, and is loud enough for the pool or a deck or a part on the boat. The Braven also doubles as a good bluetooth speakerphone. In addition to the speaker function, the device also provides USB charging capabilities for phones or tablets. Battery life is good, it lasted for over 5 hours playing music and still had about a third of a charge remaining. Finally, the device is advertised as water resistant. I didn't drop it in a poll, but with the rubber cover over the charging ports installed, I would fell totally comfortable with this in a driving rainstorm (or next to the pool).

I don't think anyone likes ironing, but I don't think anyone likes wrinkled clothes. I don't iron that much and the iron I have is from my college years.
