Technology has come a long way.This iron has the right amount of weight so you don't have to put heavy pressure on your clothes.  It's light enough for anyone to use.  The iron surface isn't non-stick, but glides easily over fabric.  The water reservoir  has a little funnel so you're less likely to spill while filling.  I like the manual that explains the different steam settings for various fabrics.One of the features I really liked was the auto-clean system.  Irons get dirty over time, and this is an obvious feature that's missing from older irons.  My old iron had residue on the vents and plate and it was a pain to clean.The most attractive feature is the auto-shutoff.  Yes, I'm one of those people that worries about leaving the iron on when I leave the house.  That's enough for me to get rid of that old iron.

These wine glasses are unique and look great - the aeration grooves down the sides of the glasses stand out and add a bit of style. However, I detected no difference in the quality of the wain, and these glasses do not appear to provide any special aeration; if you are serious about wine, you'll still probably want to use a decanter.  That said, the real negative for these glasses are some of the ridiculous health-related assertions claimed by the manufacturer in the included informational sheet. Apparently these glasses magically reduce the calories in the wine and even make it so you can drink more without getting as drunk - all the while causing less "damage" to your bodily organs then drinking wine from a normal glass! Pseudo-scientific mumbo-jumbo aside, the glasses themselves work fine for the job of conveying wine to your mouth and looking good while doing so.Note that the way these were shipped resulted in a broken glass - the packaging isn't the greatest.

I have used a Hario hand grinder for a couple years now, but this Tanors unit may give it a run for the money. The Tanors is more compact, feels better in the hand, and takes less time to grind the coffee. I also found the Tanors gives me a bit more control over the grind, and it is easier to clean. It appears to use ceramic rather then metal in the burrs - it worked well, but I would be slightly concerned about the long-term durability. My only negative (and it is nit-picking) is that there is no way to easily see how much coffee remains to be ground; a small window int he side of the bean section would have been a nice addition.

I use my label maker constantly, so I was excited about this product. Printing small labels from my standard printer?  Yes, please.  However, that's not fully what this is.These are more like address labels that anything you'd expect to come from a label maker.  The online templates make design easy -- a key advantage over label makers.The first laser printer I used didn't like the plastic and got stuck.  This "feature" is a design flaw of the product.  The label sheet includes one side with the label and the second with a plastic cover.  There's no need for the plastic cover to go through the printer.  Why not put all the plastic covers on a separate sheet?These plastic covers are a nuisance. They're a just plastic tape you put over the labels you print.  People have been doing that with packing tape for years.  Why pay extra for Avery to include plastic tape that gets stuck in the printer?

This FIsher-Price Batcave is a big, fun toy that will delight most kids. It is filled with several features to increase the variety and of the play experience, including several moving (transforming) parts - like the wings on the top, a missile launcher, lights (in the eyes), and a hidden cave. Size-wise this toys is over two feet tall - and is made of durable plastic. The moving parts seem to handle the initial wear and tear of play well, although I am not sure what the long-term durability will be. I really like toys like this because although there is a common theme, there are enough parts for a child to use their imagination to create fun adventures of their own with it. It also look really cool!

This really looks more like a stylish table than a shoe rack.  The wood finish and metallic accents fit most rooms.When I first got the box, I was concerned I wouldn't be able to put it together.  It took me less than five minutes.  All you do is stack the shelves and twist the cylinders.  No tools or skill required.My one complaint is this is a long shelf and wouldn't fit in some closets.  I'm concerned long term if debris on the shoes would scratch the wood finish.  We decided to use this shelf as a coffee table and store magazines on the shelves rather than put this in a closet for shoes.  It's just too nice for that!

Jurassic World is a PG-13 movie, so parents may want not find the connection acceptable for young children.  The toy depicts a man getting eaten by a dinosaur--which is scary for some children.Fortunately, the dinosaur grabs something with its mouth and then makes a chomping sound with the lights in the eyes glowing.  There's no reason the T-Rex couldn't be chomping down on some tasty trees. Sure, experts believe these dinosaurs were carnivores, but we can all pretend they eat cars!The only motion on the toy is the arms and legs twist and the neck That's about all it does (besides the rather gruesome theme).  It's cute for sure, but I don't want to explain to a child what the dinosaur is doing.  IMay Not Be Age Appropriate

And I say "beware of the version published by General Books LLC " because this particular publisher specializes in taking copyright-free books (such as this) and recreating them using OCR technology, then selling them at a highly inflated price.Within Amazon, books are generally grouped by the same title regardless of whether there are multiple publishers - which there are for this book, as it's now copyright free. Consequently, when one of these books with multiple publishers is reviewed, you will see the reviews of other publishers versions associated with it. And as a result you need to be very careful to make sure you've bought a decent version. The version available from General Books LLC is NOT what I would call a decent version. To be quite frank, it's awful. Full of mistakes (OCR does that, when there's no actual editing to catch the software-generated mistakes), tiny font (verging on the unreadable), no table of contents, no index. By now you should get the idea.General Books LLC puts together books using an OCR automated scanning device which can miss complete pages. There are many many Typos and no table of contents. There books receive NO EDITING of any kind, also, the OCR scanning is done by a robot (which the publishers website outright says can miss pages and which does not scan in images). This is all stated on the publishers web site (google them and read for yourself to get all the details). And with this particular book, you can't do the "Look Inside" thing for the General Books LLC version to see what you're getting. (And when General Books LLC does let you do this, you'll see something like the following - "Just so you know...This view is of the Paperback edition (2009) from WLC. The Paperback edition (2010) from General Books LLC that you originally viewed is the one you'll receive if you click the Add to Cart button at left.."They do this because if you saw the actual reproduction of their version, you'd NEVER buy the thing..... Enough said! General Books LLC are flooding Amazon with these low quality publications (450,000+ listed so far) and, unfortunately, many of them have the reviews associated with the original or with better quality imprints associated with them. For the buyer that's not aware of this publisher this can result in a rather unfortunate purchasing decision.A good rule of thumb for these Print on Demand publishers is to take a look at the cover - if it's a good quality illustration that reflects the content, there's a table of contents, and when you do the Look Inside thing there's no disclaimer saying you're looking at another book, and they've stated that they used facsimile reproduction technology (rather than OCR), it's usually a pretty safe bet. Conversely, if any of these are missing, you're taking a chance on the quality. I've bought a few based on my selection criteria above and they've been good quality. General Books LLC however, is a publisher to steer clear of at all costs.If you have been unfortunate enough to buy the General Books LLC version by mistake, you can return to Amazon for a full refund (but check Amazon's return policy and process first).All that said, I loved this book as a kid, still have my old illustrated copy that's almost in pieces, and it's a tragedy to see it being descecrated by a "Publisher" like General Books LLC. Basically, they're scamming people.And in response to the two Comments below criticising this review: Gentlemen, I suggest you check how Amazon publishes reviews and then READ MY REVIEW. Amazon does NOT allow you to publish a review for a book from a specific Publisher - Amazon groups a book with numerous different publishers together. This is why buyers get caught out by books published by General Books LLC - they rely on people inadvertantly buying from them for the bulk of their sales. Do a bit of checking for yourself before criticising.Please Note that I said:"Within Amazon, books are generally grouped by the same title regardless of whether there are multiple publishers - which there are for this book, as it's now copyright free. Consequently, when one of these books with multiple publishers is reviewed, you will see the reviews of other publishers versions associated with it. And as a result you need to be very careful to make sure you've bought a decent version." Lest you do not understand, let me reiterate in a more simplified version:(1) Amazon groups books by title. This means different versions from different publishers are grouped together. Review one, review 'em all. You CANNOT differentiate by Publisher(2)This is unfair to reputable publishers who do a good job. Which is why I explain this, something you seemed to miss. I'm not sure I can make it any more clear.(3) This review is by way of a warning. Use it or not, as you wish. Others have been caught out. Make sure you buy the version you want from a reputable publisher.That's it!

And I say "beware the General Books LLC reprint" because when you do the "Look Inside" thing, you'll read "Just so you know...This view is of the Paperback edition (2009) from WLC. The Paperback edition (2010) from General Books LLC that you originally viewed is the one you'll receive if you click the Add to Cart button at left.." And that's correct. The General Books LLC version is a completely different book. To wit....General Books LLC puts together books using an OCR automated scanning device which can miss complete pages. There are many many Typos and no table of contents. There books receive NO EDITING of any kind, also, the OCR scanning is done by a robot (which the publishers website outright says can miss pages). This is all stated on the publishers web site (google them and read for yourself to get all the details).Within Amazon, books are generally grouped by the same title regardless of whether there are multiple publishers - which there are for this book, as it's now copyright free. Consequently, when one of these books with multiple publishers is reviewed, you will see the reviews of other publishers versions associated with it. And as a result you need to be very careful to make sure you've bought a decent version. The version available from General Books LLC is NOT a decent version. To be quite frank, it's awful. Full of mistakes (OCR does that, when there's no actual editing to catch the software-generated mistakes), tiny font (verging on the unreadable), no table of contents, no index. By now you should get the idea.General Books LLC are flooding Amazon with these low quality publications (450,000+ listed so far) and, unfortunately, many of them have the reviews associated with the original or with better quality imprints associated with them. For the buyer that's not aware of this publisher this can result in a rather unfortunate purchasing decision.A good rule of thumb for these Print on Demand publishers is to take a look at the cover - if it's a good quality illustration that reflects the content, there's a table of contents, and when you do the Look Inside thing there's no disclaimer saying you're looking at another book, and they've stated that they used facsimile reproduction technology (rather than OCR), it's usually a pretty safe bet. Conversely, if any of these are missing, you're taking a chance on the quality. I've bought a few based on my selection criteria above and they've been good quality. General Books LLC however, is a publisher to steer clear of at all costs.If you have been unfortunate enough to buy the General Books LLC version by mistake, you can return to Amazon for a full refund (but check Amazon's return policy and process first).

Picked this up after reading a short story by Larry Correia on Baen's website. It was fun so I bought this one after taking a quick look at the Amazon Reviews. And all those reviewers who raved about this book were spot on. From the first chapter where Owen's boss gets a helping hand out of the building, thru to the last chapter, I literally didn't want to put this one down. Loved the guns and the gun descriptions - got to admire a writer who can throw a Finnish Lahti 20mm into a Novel and make it plausible (I assumme this is the one and only Antti Lahti designed L-39 "Norsutykki / Elephant Gun" - a good choice for monster hunting for sure given it was designed as an anti-tank rifle).Anyhow, aside from that level of accuracy on the firearms side of things, I really got into the monster-hunting / H P Lovecraft / vampires-are-evil stuff. And the action. Did I mention the action? It's all really well done. And there's even some fairly good characterisation. In fact I went and ordered every other book by Larry Correia before I even finished this one, including pre-orders for the ones in the publishing pipeline. That's how much I liked this one!!!And I do like the way Larry disses the Anne Rice school of vampire lovers. Hilarious. As someone who liked Anita Blake-Vampire Hunter before Laurell Hamilton went weird with her (the original Anita and Owen would have got on fairly well methinks, staking out vampires together and discussing the merits of different guns and ammuntion....) this book is a startlingly good entry into the genre.

Korsuarkkitehtuuri was a type of architecture exercised by Finnish troops during the trench warfare period of the Continuation War (WW2 to the rest of us). Use of only a few tools such as a knife and an axe is typical to the style. Scots Pine and Norway Spruce were the most used tree species.Published in 1983, Erkki Helamaa's book "40-luku" is perhaps the only book available on this subject, with some amazing photos.ThorBjorn - can't reply via comment as my commenting is still disabled by Amazon - but of you check my profile, as an Amazon "friend" you should be able to see my email address. Drop me a line and I'll email you a link to some photos from the book that have been posted online.Picked the reference to this book up from a discussion forum on Finnish military history, one of the posters gave me a link to a Finnish second hand bookseller site and hey presto - used Google Translate on the Finnish webpage and figured it all out (slowly). It's quite a stunning book photowise, although once you know what you're looking for you can find many of the photos online from Finnish Museum photograph collections - most of which are now online - with huge numbers of photos.If this obscure subject interests you, this book is well worth the trouble of tracking down. It also goes into the designs and building of post-WW2 log homes in Finland. There was a tremendous amount of post-war reconstruction and this book gets into this subject as well. All in Finnish, but if you're interested, you'll figure it out :)Cheers.......Kiwi

Most books on NZ in WW2 concentrate on the military and on the campaigns and units involved. This book, "Beyond the Battlefield" by Gerald Hensley is the dramatic unknown story of New Zealand's involvement in World War II told, pretty much for the first time, in an accessible, popular and enjoyable read. Savage, Nash, Fraser, Freyberg, Churchill, Roosevelt, Menzies, all great names from New Zealand and world history during the Second World War and all involved in the story of New Zealand's response to the global conflict and therefore the destiny of our nation.The book examines a key part of New Zealand's history during which time, under the immense pressure of fighting a war on both sides of the world, the country moved from being a quiet and faraway outpost in the Commonwealth to a strong, independent nation playing an influential role in the shaping of the United Nations. New Zealand's sometimes rocky relationships with its wartime allies Great Britain, Australia and the United States during a period of great world turmoil are all exposed and explained in an engaging and thoughtful lookinto the human side of diplomacy - highlighting the irritants, the cross comments, the subterfuge and intrigue that are the real drivers of history.The author, Gerald Hensley,  was trained as an historian before he joined the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. He served there for 20 years and was then appointed Permanent Head of the Prime Minister's Department. In that role he worked for Sir Robert Muldoon and David Lange before becoming Co-ordinator for Domestic and External Security and later Secretary of Defence.

"NZSAS: The First Fifty Years" is the first and only official history of New Zealand's elite Special Forces, the New Zealand Special Air Service (NZSAS). From their first ever engagements in the jungles of Malaya in 1956, through to the Vietnam War and on to modern conflicts in East Timor and Afghanistan, this book traces the history and development of 1 NZSAS Group.  Illustrated with maps and photographs, the book provides a rare NZSAS: The First Fifty Years is the first and only official history of New Zealand's elite Special Forces, the New Zealand Special Air Service (NZSAS). From their first ever engagements in the jungles of Malaya in 1956, through to the Vietnam War and on to modern conflicts in East Timor and Afghanistan, this book traces the history and development of 1 NZSAS Group.  Illustrated with maps and never-before-seen photographs, the book provides a rare and fascinating insight into the NZSAS.A quote from the Chief of the NZ Defence Force:"Like any family, 1 NZSAS Group's stories are part of the glue that binds them together. But for reasons of operational security, the activities and personalities of New Zealand's Special Forces have, until now, largely remained their own - shrouded in secrecy. This book has an essential role in informing anyone with an interest in how this Unit's special capabilities have been relied on in numerous deployments, over a range of environments, across the decades of its existence. Such unusual openness I believe cannot help but promote confidence, and ultimately improve the level of understanding of 1 NZSAS Group - whose history deserves the accolade it aspires to of being the elite Unit of the New Zealand Defence Force."Well worth reading if you have an interest in the SAS, and want to know more about the New Zealand SAS.

The story of a small force of Australian Special Forces commandos that launched relentless hit and run raids on far superior Japanese forces in East Timor for most of 1942. These Australians were the men of the 2/2nd Australian Independent Company - a special commando unit. Initially stranded without radio contact to Australia, the Japanese declared these beared warriors `outlaws' and warned they would be executed immediately if captured. The Australians drawn mainly from the bush, were chosen for their ability to operate independently and survive in hostile territory. As film-maker Damien Parer said after visiting in Timor in late 1942, `these men are writing an epic of guerrilla warfare'. Expertly researched by Paul Cleary, who is fluent in Tetum, the main language of the indigenous group of East Timor, it contains black and white photos.The author, Paul Cleary, is a senior writer with The Australian newspaper and a researcher in indigenous development at the Australian National University. In a career spanning 20 years he has reported on politics and economics in the Canberra press gallery, and has also worked as a correspondent in Southeast Asia and as a political adviser. Awarded a Chevening fellowship by the UK Foreign Office to study at SOAS, University of London, he became an adviser to government of newly-independent East Timor. His work on the Timor Sea resource negotiations led to his first non-fiction book, "Shakedown--Australia's grab for Timor oil". The Timor veterans whom he met while based in East Timor inspired this book. He speaks several languages, including Vietnamese and Tetum.By far more readable than earlier, rather dry, accounts.

The 1st Independent Company was formed in June 1941 and the following month, with the threat of war with Japan looming, it was sent to Kavieng, New Ireland. The company was based at Kavieng, where it was to protect the airfield, but sections were also sent to Namatanai in central New Ireland, Vila in the New Hebrides, Tulagi on Guadalcanal, Buka Passage in Bougainville, and Lorengau on Manus Island to act as observers. In the event of an invasion, the company's role, as understood by Major James Edmonds-Wilson, the officer commanding, was to resist the enemy long enough so that the airfield could be damaged and other military instillations, such as fuel dumps, could be destroyed. The company was to then withdrawal to bases further south where they could wage a guerrilla war. The company soon found itself at war.On 21 January about sixty Japanese aircraft, including bombers, dive bombers, and fighters, attacked Kavieng. The commandos' shot down a number of aircraft, but the schooner, the Induna Star, which was the company's only means of escape, had also been damaged. Despite this though, the schooner managed to sail to Kaut. Meanwhile, the commandos started to withdrawal over land to Sook. Later that day the Australians received a message that a Japanese naval force of an aircraft carrier and six cruisers was approaching New Britain. The Japanese landed in the early morning the next day. As the lead Japanese troops reached the airfield, there was some fighting as the Australians blew the airfield and supply dump. The Japanese landed between 3 000 and 4 000 troops, hopelessly outnumbered, those commandos still fighting around Kavieng fell back to Sook, but not all of them made it. Some were captured. On 28 January Wilson gather his men and moved to Kaut where they repaired the Induna Star. Wilson intended sailing down the coast at night and hoped to reach the east coast of New Britain. By 31 January they had reached Kalili Harbour, but by then, Wilson learnt that the fighting on New Britain was over and that the Japanese occupied Rabaul. Wilson decided to sail for Port Moresby, but on 2 February the schooner was sighted by a Japanese plane which strafed and bombed them - destroying the lifeboat and causing a number of casualties. The Induna Star was now taking on water and Wilson considered any further resistance useless.The Australians were instructed to sail to Rabaul, with the Induna Star being escorted by Japanese aircraft until it was met by a Japanese destroyer. Thereafter, the Australians were transferred to the destroyer and became prisoners of war. After a few months at Rabaul, the officers were separated from their NCOs and men, and the officers were taken to Japan where they remained in captivity for the rest of the war. The NCOs and men had a much sadder fate. At the end of June, these men, along with the 2/22nd Battalion and other members of Lark Force, how had been captured on New Britain, and about 200 civilians, boarded the Japanese passenger ship Montevideo Maru. There were between 1 050 and 1053 prisoners were aboard. Unescorted by other Japanese ships, the Montevideo Maru sailed from Rabaul on 22 June, but on 1 July the ship was sighted by an American submarine, the Sturgeon, off the coast of the Luzon, in the Philippines. Firing its torpedos, the Sturgeon sunk the Montevideo Maru. Only a handful of the Japan crew were rescued. None of the prisoners survived. All 133 men from the independent company who were aboard the Montevideo Maru were either killed or drowned.Those sections that had not been with the main group at Kavieng, those who had been sent to Vila, Tulagi, Buka, and Lorengau, faired better. Throughout 1942 these men worked with the coast watchers, reporting Japanese troop movements, until they were either evacuated or escaped from their various locations throughout 1942. Later during the year, one of these sections fought along side the 2/5th Independent Company as part of Kanga Force, in New Guinea. But the 1st Independent Company was not reformed and its survivors were subsequently transferred to other commando units.

The 2/5 Company served at Wau, Lae and Salamaua in 1942 when men such as these were the only force in action on the fringes of the defense line in north New Guinea. They dominated the hills above the Japanese base and carried out a dramatic attack on Salamaua, causing major casualties to the enemy. They ended their war with the invasion at Balikpapan in Borneo.This is an historical narrative of the 2/5th Independent Company, later known as the 2/5th Cavalry Commando Squadron 1942-1945. Includes rolls and photos of officers and men.Contents:History of Independent Companies1. Joining the AIF2. Volunteers Gather from other StatesAuthorForewordPreface and AcknowledgementsHonour Roll: Killed in ActionHonour Roll: Wounded in ActionDecorations and AwardsHistory of Independent Companies1. Joining the AIF2. Volunteers Gather from other States3. Guerilla Warfare School, Foster4. Formation of the 2/5th Independent Coy5. The Fifth Leave for the War Zone6. The War Becomes Real7. The Days that Made History8. The Fifth Fly to Win9. Bulolo10. Watut Valley11. Trek to the Markham Valley12. The Raid on Salamaua13. The Raid on Heath's Plantation14. Aftermath of the Raid on Heath's15. Bombing of Wau16. Japanese Attack Mubo17. Withdrawal from Mubo18. Burning of Wau and Bulldog Derby19. Reported Missing in Action20. Re-Establishment at Blake's and Skindewai21. Our First Raid on Mubo22. Markham Force, Until Christmas 194223. Skindewai and Observations of Mubo24. Missing Patrol Recuperates at Port Morseby and Returns to Unit25. Our Second Rain on Mubo26. Battle of Wau and Wandumi27. Wau Hospital during Battle28. Marhkam 194329. Reconnaissance Patrol, Wampit to Mapos30. Recuperation at Edie Creek31. The Fifth Return to Markham Before Going Home32. Home to Australia and Leave33. Canungra Capers34. Re-Forming on Atherton Tablelands35. Court Martial of Regimental Guard36. Unit's Sporting Activity37. Training for the Next Campaign38. Embarkation for Borneo39. Invasion of Balikpapan, Borneo40. Advance Inland from Beach at Balikpapan41. Advance to Milford Highway42. Japanese Make a Stand43. Cesstion of Hostilities44. 2/5th Cav Commando Squadron - Disband - and Return HomeRollsPhotos of Officers and MenBibliography
Published in 1997, another History of the No. 2 Independent Commando Company and 2/2 Commando Squadron.The author, Cyril Ayris, is an author and journalist from Western Australia.

Adam Smith's "The Wealth of Nations" is one those great Classics that almost everyone should read. But if you intend buying a copy, be very careful which version you buy. Why, you ask?It's out in the public domain and a plethora of reprints are available, a great many from Print on Demand Publishers and there are some truely awful reprints available. Amazon associates reviews of a book with many different versions of the same book from different publishers. Unfortunately for us customers, Amazon is seeing a growing plague of low-quality Print-On-Demand Publishers who are specialise in reprinting copyright-expired books. Such as "The Wealth of Nations." Some of these publishers produce quite good quality books, some do not. What you do need to do is check the publisher carefully for all these older "copyright expired" books.An outstanding example of "not good quality" is the version of "The Wealth of Nations" published by General Books LLC. This version is scanned in using OCR technology (and using pretty poor quality OCR scanning equipment and software from the look of their books), is overall of very poor print quality, uses automated reproduction with no index, no illustrations and an excessive number of typos.Lest you doubt, here's some word for word quotes from the publisher's own web site:"We created your book using OCR software that includes an automated spell check. Our OCR software is 99 percent accurate if the book is in good condition. However, with up to 3,500 characters per page, even one percent can be an annoying number of typos....""After we re-typeset and designed your book, the page numbers change so the old index and table of contents no longer work. Therefore, we usually remove them. Since many of our books only sell a couple of copies, manually creating a new index and table of contents could add more than a hundred dollars to the cover price....""Our OCR software can't distinguish between an illustration and a smudge or library stamp so it ignores everything except type. We would really like to manually scan and add the illustrations. But many of our books only sell a couple of copies....""We created your book using a robot who turned and photographed each page. Our robot is 99 percent accurate. But sometimes two pages stick together. And sometimes a page may even be missing from our copy of the book. We would really like to manually scan each page and buy multiple copies of each original. But many of our books only sell a couple of copies....."For the buyer that's not aware of this publisher this can result in a rather unfortunate purchasing decision as General Books LLC are all poor quality, tiny (almost unreadable) fonts and they don't bother to reproduce little things like Table of Contents or Indexes.A good rule of thumb for these Print on Demand publishers is to take a look at the cover - if it's a good quality illustration that reflects the content, there's a table of contents, and when you do the Look Inside thing there's no disclaimer saying you're looking at another version of the book, and they've stated that they used facsimile reproduction technology (rather than OCR), it's usually a pretty safe bet. Conversely, if any of these are missing, you're taking a chance on the quality. I've bought a few based on my selection criteria above and they've been good quality. General Books LLC however, is a publisher to steer clear of at all costs.If you have been unfortunate enough to buy the General Books LLC version by mistake, you can return to Amazon for a full refund (but check Amazon's return policy and process first).

5* for the Book, 1* for the version from General Books LLCLove H Rider Haggard's books, and Cleopatra has to be his best "little known" novel (as compared say to the better known ones such as "King Solomons Mines". Other reviewers have done a great job describing the novel, I'm not going to rehash, I agree.However, if you are interested in buying this, be aware that the book is now out in the public domain and a plethora of reprints are available, mostly from Print on Demand Publishers reprinting copyright-expired books. And, believe me, there's some truely awful reprints available. Some of these publishers produce quite good quality books, some do not. What you do need to do is check the publisher carefully for all these older "copyright expired" books. An outstanding example of "not good quality" is the reprint published by General Books LLC. This version is scanned in using OCR technology (and using pretty poor quality OCR scanning equipment and software from the look of their books), is overall of very poor print quality, uses automated reproduction with no index, no illustrations and an excessive number of typos.To quote some specifics from the publisher's own web site:"We created your book using OCR software that includes an automated spell check. Our OCR software is 99 percent accurate if the book is in good condition. However, with up to 3,500 characters per page, even one percent can be an annoying number of typos....""After we re-typeset and designed your book, the page numbers change so the old index and table of contents no longer work. Therefore, we usually remove them. Since many of our books only sell a couple of copies, manually creating a new index and table of contents could add more than a hundred dollars to the cover price....""Our OCR software can't distinguish between an illustration and a smudge or library stamp so it ignores everything except type. We would really like to manually scan and add the illustrations. But many of our books only sell a couple of copies....""We created your book using a robot who turned and photographed each page. Our robot is 99 percent accurate. But sometimes two pages stick together. And sometimes a page may even be missing from our copy of the book. We would really like to manually scan each page and buy multiple copies of each original. But many of our books only sell a couple of copies....."General Books LLC are flooding Amazon with these low quality publications (450,000+ listed so far) and, unfortunately, many of them have the reviews associated with the original or with better quality imprints associated with them. For the buyer that's not aware of this publisher this can result in a rather unfortunate purchasing decision.A good rule of thumb for these Print on Demand publishers is to take a look at the cover - if it's a good quality illustration that reflects the content, there's a table of contents, and when you do the Look Inside thing there's no disclaimer saying you're looking at another book, and they've stated that they used facsimile reproduction technology (rather than OCR), it's usually a pretty safe bet. Conversely, if any of these are missing, you're taking a chance on the quality. I've bought a few based on my selection criteria above and they've been good quality. General Books LLC however, is a publisher to steer clear of at all costs.If you have been unfortunate enough to buy the General Books LLC version by mistake, you can return to Amazon for a full refund (but check Amazon's return policy and process first).

Interesting little (192 pages) book that looks at the first steam-powered automobiles of the 1830's and their possibilities. These were interesting early attempts to move steam-power away from the limitations of railways and at the possibilities inherent in the technology of the time. It seems that the first attempts at steam lorries (France) and steam coaches (England) were halted by the commercial vindictiveness of the Railways (surprise ... seems similar to what happened to commuter tramlines in the 1930's and immediately post-WW2). If they had not been, MacAdam's and Telford's roads could have seen a massive growth in freight and passenger transport far earlier than actually occured.Circa 1828-33 the railway engineers (and their supporters) still considered the steam coach a threat to their efforts. Thus they were ready to fight against it in public and in Parliament. After the success of the L&M Railroad become evident, railways swallowed most of the capital that could have been used for the development of road vehicles. After this the premier steam coach builders crashed and burned by around 1840, and there was little faith in the technical and commercial feasibility of the steam carriage among those who mattered.In looking at the alternative, Beasley probably overestimates the possibilities. The technology of the time simply wasn't that mature - take a look at the Traction Engines used for agriculture as a successful commercial example - slow, large and heavy. For road-based steam-powered vehicles, there were constant problems with the steam engines (which had to be both light and powerful), the axles kept breaking, suspension was either nonexistent or inadequate, steering, brakes, etc. On the rails, all these problems were less of an issue, first of all the engine could be heavier (and thus overbuilt) and secondly one could avoid the jarring and bumps and need for quick changes in power that were pure hell for such machines like Gurney's, Maceroni's or even Hancock's on the common roads.The concept of steam carriages did arouse some discussion at the time: This is Benjamin Cheverton in the Mechanics' Magazine in October 1833:"As the public mind is now roused to a sense of the immense utility of railways, for all the grand communications between different parts of the kingdom, more especially those which radiate from the metropolis, it becomes a duty to arrest those attempts which are made to divert it from an object of such paramount importance, by representing the probability of steam carriages being so employed on common roads as to render railroads unnecessary. It is not denied that if these conveyances can be established - though the fact and not the probability should be allowed to have any influence - they will prove to be of considerable use: subsidiary to the railway train, they will on the various cross-roads and branches, act as feeders to, it but never as substitutes.It is not too much to hope, that communication on the main lines will become so active, that steam carriages and waggons, however improved, would never be equal to it on common roads; but the all-important point is, that this very activity has its origin in the improved ways: they are both the means towards an end and the cause of it. The steam conveyances may produce and be competent to a greatly increased intercourse between places, but they could never enlarge it beyond their own powers of achievement. Could the present communications between Manchester and Liverpool be carried on by steam coaches, and the transit of goods by steam waggons? Could any other roads than those of iron bear it? It will, indeed, be admitted that railways will answer only on the grand routes, and that steam carriages, and Mr Saxton's invention of the locomotive pully, in conjunction with a subordinate and less expensive kind of railroad, that may with the aid of this beautiful contrivance be made to accord with the undulation of the country, will sufficiently supply the demands of intercourse in every other place. Thus things will be in their right places, and a harmony of order and gradation be the result."And another interesting note: Hiram Maxim (inventor of the Maxim Gun - aka machinegun) attempted a steam powered aircraft back in 1894. Maxim invested 20,000 in building a huge, hundred-foot-wingspan, multi-winged machine, in England. It was powered by two lightweight 180-horsepower steam engines that he'd designed for it. Maxim began flight tests in 1894. On the third try the plane was powered up to forty miles per hour, left its track, flew two hundred feet, and crashed. After that, Maxim lost interest in flying. He went on to other inventions.It's certainly a good look at an interesting "might-have-been" - after all, back just after WW1 the Stanley Steam Car outperformed the Ford Model T and Steam Cars were a commercial success into the late 1920's. The books a bit short but nevertheless an interesting look at an alternative technological path that might have been followed.

The Author/Compiler's Note states "This is a first in a planned series of thematic collections of articles that appeared previously in classified editions of the Intelligence Community journal Studies in Intelligence, which is published at CIA. As part of its "openness" policy, CIA has declassified more than 1,200 articles from the first 40 years of Studies. We expect to compile and publish more collections of this type that address single intelligence-related themes or topics. We believe readers will find these articles interesting, informative, and colorful."You can also download the PDF's from the CIA's website if you're interested (that's where I read them). Table of Contents consists of the Foreword and a Preface "From Paris to Palo Alto" - which is an interesting little story of it's own how the files from the Paris Office of the Ohkrana made their way to the Hoover Institution on the campus of Stanford University.Other contents includeCIA Interest in the Okhrana FilesOrigins of the Okhrana and Its Paris OfficeForeign OperationsChange and ContinuityDramatisPersonaeConclusionsArticles by "Rita T. Kronenbitter"Paris Okhrana 1885-1905The Illustrious Career of Arkadiy HartingThe Sherlock Holmes of the RevolutionOkhrana Agent DolinThe Okhrana's Female Agents--Part I: Russian WomenThe Okhrana's Female Agents--Part II: Indigenous RecruitsReview of Edward Ellis Smith, The Young Stalin, by Harry GelmanCommentary by Rita T. KronenbitterAll in all, quite fascinating, entertaining and well-written. Whoever "Rita" was, he/she was a good writer and analyst and it makes for good entertaining reading as well as an interesting historical education.

LOC Kargil is an Indian War Movie about the Kargil War with Pakistan. Back in 2003, it was billed as the most expensive Hindi movie ever made. And as well as the budget, it had great locations (the Himalayas) and a good collection of Indian "name" actors to work with. Sadly and disappointedly, it's a flop. And that was also the reaction of the Indian viewing public at the time. It could have been India's "Saving Private Ryan" or "Black Hawk Down" but alas, it's downright boring.The basic storyline of this 4 hour film covers the Kargil sector near the LOC in 1999 when the Pakistani's crossed the LOC and penetrated deep into Indian territory (completely to the surprise of the Indian Govt and media at the time). It was an interesting and rather challenging war from the Indian perspective, especially given the logistics of fighting high in the Himalaya's, and one that the Indian Army responded to heroically. Pakistan initially denied any involvement, claiming the intruders were 'freedom fighters'. However it was very soon all to apparant that this was a lie and that the 'freedom fighters' were actually Pakistani Army soldiers that were deeply entrenched high up in the mountains on the Indian side of the demarcation line. I followed the war quite closely at the time and was interested in how this movie would portray it (obviously, I was hoping for an Indian version of "Saving Private Ryan" but alas.....). To read a bit of background on the war, I'd recommend starting with War at the Top of the World: The Struggle for Afghanistan, Kashmir and Tibet, Revised Edition for a general backgrounder, then diving in to Kargil 1999: Pakistan's Fourth War for Kashmir. Most of the other books available on the Kargil War are by Indian authors and strongly biased. These 2 are probably the best available for at least a general picture.What's obvious from the books on the Kargil War is that the Indian Army, operating under an enormous disadvantages, in incredibly hostile terrain and against fanatical fighters displayed a level of committment, bravery, technical expertise and professionalism that resulted in a crushing defeat for the Pakistanis. So much so as to lead to Pakistan actually considering escalating the local, low-level conflict into an all out nuclear confrontation. And Bill Clinton then saved their sorry asses. Anyhow, there was the basis for an incredible film here.So, there's the background. On to the Film. Overall, I think the main problem here is that while Bollywood is good at traditional Indian musicals, they just don't have any idea how to make a good war movie. I'd put it down to plain incompetence - after all, there's enough successful war movies out there that it should be possible for a professional director to figure it out.Cons:This is where we state, upfront, that the film sucks. The battle scenes are downright awful - corny, not just poorly done. There are long, pointless and (to the western ear anyhow) awful sounding songs. I know, I know, songs are traditional in Bollywood movies, but this is a WAR MOVIE. Do even Indian Soldiers do Bollywood musical routines in the middle of a war. I think Not! There's no apparant main storyline or even a good subplot or two that I could figure out (the subplots I could figure out were all cheesy romantic stuff) and the soldiers in the movie don't really achieve anything. For 4 hours, soldiers die over and over on the same mountain.Basic synopsis of Plot: (1). Gather the troops and discuss the attack plan, (2) Flashbacks to the men's wives (3) The approach - troops marching in a long line (4) Soldiers running up Mountain and shooting, usually the first getting shot in the head then 3 other men rescuing him. (5) Defeat of the enemy and calling to base to tell of success (6) Flashback to wives and the singing of 10 minute songs. Repeat 4 or 5 times.Apparantly the director worked without a script and it shows. There's no flow to the movie. There's no sense of progression from one battle to another. It's just one gunfight after the next with no connection to the overall scheme of the war. And the explanatory scenes are awful.Pros:There are LOTS of bullets and blood.Many of the props including the uniforms, badges, weapons, artillery, helicopters etc etc were all authentic Indian Army equipment.Thats about it for Pro's.All in all, I really wanted to enjoy this movie. It's not as if there weren't all the ingredients for a good, if not great movie. Sadly, it sucked.

It's been fashionable to knock the British Empire for a few decades now, and as the world becomes more literate and books become more international, events that received little or no attention both at the time and for decades afterwards start to move into the spotlight. The Bengal Famine of 1943 is just such an event and one that this book disects in some detail. There have been others - see for example The Great Famine and Genocide in Persia, 1917-1919 - another famine blamed on the British. The authors of both books, Majd and Mukherjee, have basically the same premise - in Majd's case that deliberate policy of genocide was practiced on the Persians, In Mukherjee's case, that Churchill in particular was waging a "secret war" on the Indian people, and Mukherjee does blames Mr Churchill's policies for being largely responsible for one of the worst famines in India's history.And it was a terrible famine - some three million Indians died as a result of the famine of 1943, with the majority of the deaths in Bengal. Mukherjee's book is a gripping and quite scholarly investigation into this event. Mukherjee's analysis is that the scarcity was caused by large-scale exports of food from India for use in the war theatres and consumption in Britain - India exported more than 70,000 tonnes of rice between January and July 1943, even as the famine set in. Churchill turned down pleas to export food to India citing a shortage of ships. As imports dropped, prices shot up and hoarders made a killing. Mr Churchill also pushed a scorched earth policy - which went by the sinister name of Denial Policy - in coastal Bengal where the British feared the Japanese would land. So authorities removed boats (the lifeline of the region) and the police destroyed and seized rice stocks.Mukherjee tracks down some of the survivors of the famine and paints a chilling tale of the effects of hunger and deprivation. Parents dumped their starving children into rivers and wells. Many took their lives by throwing themselves in front of trains. Starving people begged for the starchy water in which rice had been boiled. Children ate leaves and vines, yam stems and grass. People were too weak even to cremate their dead. Dogs and jackals feasted on piles of dead bodies in Bengal's villages. Survivors were men who migrated to Calcutta for jobs and women who turned to prostitution to feed their families. The famine ended at the end of the year when survivors harvested their rice crop. The first shipments of barley and wheat reached those in need only in November, by which time tens of thousands had already perished (but which does argue that attempts were being made to alleviate the effects of the famine).Mukherjee writes eloquently and passionately, as befits a local historian, stating that it was "not so much racism as the imbalance of power inherent in the social Darwinian pyramid that explains why famine could be tolerated in India while bread rationing was regarded as an intolerable deprivation in wartime Britain". Other reviewers have essentially supported Mukherjee's arguments and conclusions, understandably if you're Indian.While it's detailed recounting of the famine and it's effects and aftereffects, I'd have to diasgree with some (but not all) of the author's conclusion. Officials of the British Raj excepted, many of whom cared deeply for the people they ruled (read Plain Tales from the Raj for the views of the British), the British were focused on fighting and winning WW2 and a few million Bengali peasants were not important in the scheme of things. And yes, there was a certain element of racism involved - Bengalis were not particularly highly regarded and Bengali peasents even less so. As with Persia in WW1, it was not genocide, it was not particularly deliberate, just a focus of effort on the war and the ignoring of the fate of millions of civilians who were at best, irrelvant to the war effort. Tragic for the millions, but Churchill was a ruthless man who put Britain first and foremost, and as he himself once said "there is no-one as ruthless as an English Gentleman at bay". After all, this is a man who was willing to plunge Scandanavia into war just to open a second front against Germany, authorise the deliberate mass murder of German civilians thru the firebombing of the cities they lived in, and redrew Polands post WW2 borders with the stroke of a pen, resulting in the post war deaths of perhaps 2 million German civilians - how do a few million Bengali peasants possibly compare (looking at it from 1940 eyes rather than now). And in his eyes, he was justified in doing so. Churchill was a great man, but he was also a War Leader, and a ruthless one at that. And he put Britain first and foremost in everything.In this, Mukherjee's explanation of Social Darwinism is probably as accurate a conclusion as any. All in all, a well-detailed and well-written book about one of the little known side-shows of WW2 but with a lot of (understandable) emotional content. If those Bengali's were my ancestors, I'd be justifiably angry as well.Kinjal - re your comments. My apologies for responding within the review but Amazon removed my commenting privileges some time ago (I transgressed the guidelines somewhat inadvertantly) and haas never seen fit to restore them. Yes, I agree, Churchill was definitely racist in the modern sense of the term. He also wanted India to remain part of the British Empire - he was vehemently opposed to independance. And he was a great man, but as with all great men, he had flaws. As far as the Bengal Famine goes, other British politicians and military commanders disagreed with him, as Mukherjee points out. And yes, I can understand the outrage, especially if one is from Bengal (and having spent some considerable time in Dhaka and Calcutta myself back in the '80's, and having made good friends there, I can to a certain extent empathize). As I said, Churchill had his flaws - he abandoned Poland to the USSR after Britain went into WW2 using Poland as the reason, he was quite willing to throw Finland to the wolves, he was more than happy to draw Norway (and would have drawn Sweden) into the war if he could've. He did absolutely nothing for the European Jews. But also as I stated, he was Britain's war leader and he put Britain first and foremost at all times.Sue: well, I did get you riled up didnt I. And no, it was not genocide. Famine yes, millions of deaths, yes. But as for defending Churchill, no. No need. The man stands on his own merits as a great leader. And I would reiterate, one should see his acts in the context of the times. Simply, as with the Persian Famine at the end of WW1, the Bengali peasants were not a factor in the war - if they had been, something immediate would have been done. At the time, Britain was fighting for her survival, the Japanese were on the borders of India and it was the overall war that was important to Churchill and the British. Sad, yes. Tragic yes, but a deliberate act of genocide - No! Also, you have to keep in mind that at the time, in 1943, much of the countryside was in a state of endemic revolt against the British and the Indian National Army, made up largely of deserters and turncoats from the British Indian Army was fighting with the Japanese against the British. This made the population of Bengal very much a potential 5th column if the Japanese penetrated out of the hills and into Bengal itself. Despite this "state of endemic revolt," at one and the same time the famine also caused the British Army major logistical problems which were caused by massive gifts of food by the locally stationed British and Indian troops to the starving people - which threatened to stall the forthcoming offensive against the Japanese. As always, nothing is black and white.....However, that said, I think Mukherjee has done a magnificent job in documenting this little known and little-remember famine. I personally was aware of it, but had no idea of some of the details until I read this book.And as for my commenting privileges, sadly, Amazon removed them not for riling up the Sues of this world, but rather for posting a series of comments on scam books published a scam publisher called General Books LLC, whom I have been highly critical off. And they are a scam. As for reviews, well, I write what I think and Amazon users generally seem to like my reviews for whatever reason - if they arouse some discussion around the book or my omments, I am happy - and I sure do not mind people criticising my reviews or commenting on them - that usually brings a whole lot more interesting comments and views out. And I am not a sensitive soul :)

I've always been interested in the Hittites but really, there's very little available other than a very few textbooks on the subject. For those who know nothing about the Hittites, this is a really really really (you get the idea) good historical novel that manages to get you well and truely under the skin of Suppiluliumas ("Pure Spring"), King of Hatti and gives you a good in depth exposure to Hittite culture and the Hittite people while at the same time giving you a good history lesson. As the previous reviewer has noted, the book is liberally laced with quotes from Suppiluliumas' own Annals. Every character in the novel bar one is based on real people who are historically documented (there are a lot of Hittite clay tablets that have survived) - fascinating in itself, and the author includes a short bibilography at the end.In all honesty, this is one of the best historical novels I've read and I wish I'd come across it sooner, I'd rate it up there with Mary Renault's Alexander Trilogy (Fire from Heaven, The Persian Boy and Funeral Games), Wallace Breem's Eagle in the Snow or Rosemary Sutcliff's Sword at Sunset as far as historical novels go.For those more or less unaware of the Hittites, they were an Indo-Aryan people who set up a kingdom centered at Hattusa on the Central Anatolian plateau around the 18th century BC. The Hittite empire reached its height around the 14th century BC, encompassing a large part of Anatolia, north-western Syria about as far south as the mouth of the Litani River (a territory known as Amqu), and eastward into upper Mesopotamia. Under Suppiluliumas and his immediate successor, the Empire was extended to most of Anatolia and parts of Syria and Canaan, so that by 1300 BC the Hittites were bordering on the Egyptian sphere of influence. After approx. 1180 BC, the empire disintegrated into several independent "Neo-Hittite" city-states, some surviving until as late as the 8th century BC.Although established in the Bronze Age, the Hittites were forerunners of the Iron Age, developing the manufacture of iron artifacts from as early as the 14th century BC. Recent excavations have discovered evidence of iron tool production dating back at least as far as the 20th century BC. Hittite weapons were generally made from bronze though as iron was rare and precious. The Hittites were famous for their skill in building and using chariots, a skill which gave them a military advantage. In fact, the first battle recorded in any real detail is the great chariot battle of Kadesh (read (Qadesh 1300 BC: Clash of the Warrior Kings (Osprey Military Campaign Series)), fought between the Hittities (commanded by the grandson of the subject of this book, Suppiluliumas, and the Eqyptians in 1274 BC.For more light reading on this subject for the casual reader, I'd recommend the following:Hittite WarriorHittite Fortifications c.1650-700 BC (Fortress)Bronze Age War Chariots (New Vanguard)For other works of fiction set in Hatti, you might like to try the followingThe Hittite (the main character is a Hittite, but the real story is about the Fall of Troy using an outsider to give a different viewpoint)Hittite Must Die by Moshe ShamirHittite Warrior (Living History Library)The Hittite by Noel Gerson - An age of violent splendor... sensual paganism... barbaric cruelty...At the head of the onrushing Hittite legions was Lord Marduk. He was young, he had great wealth, high rank and his wife, Arinna was the most beautiful woman in the empire, but her warped passions drove him to seek another woman's arms... OK, you get the idea, and the cover picture looks more Roman than Hittite to me. It's trash, and quite laughable as far as historical accuracy goes.....Like I said, "I, the Sun" is the best fictional treatment of the Hittites you're going to find. Read and enjoy. Personally, I didn't put it down until I'd finished it. And then I reread it.

This is a very interesting look at one aspect of WW1 - the junior Officers in the British Army. You get passing mention of them in many books on WW1, but this is the first actual look at these junior officers that I've come across and it's quite fascinating, if sad at times, read.In general, British junior officers in the First World War had a life expectancy of six weeks, hence the title of the book. Most of them were fresh out of High School - usually the products of the British "Public School" system (that's private schools to the rest of them) where the upper class and upper middle class children went. And they went from High School to Officers Training Units and from there, more often than not, straight to the Western Front. And on the Western Front they died by the thousands, many of them leading their men from the front in a charge out of the trenches and across no-mans-land, knowing that the German machine guns were waiting and would be trained on the man at the front and knowing that many of their predecessors had fallen before them in identical attacks that more often than not had failed.The author really does focus on these often overlooked men (boys really) who were so crucial to Britain's war effort. He bases his book on a huge range of first person accounts that are available - many of these being letters and diaries sent home or back to their school. We can see from these what motivated these men, the kind of life they lived on the front and in the trenches, how they led and motivated their men, and how they tried to behave in the short time many of them had left before they died.WW1 was the death of the Edwardian era, and the junior officers that were slaughtered were the potential leaders of an entire generation. It's a well-written and poignant look at these boys, for that was what most of them were, and a tribute to them as well. Well worth the read for anyone interested in the history of WW1.

Definitely, this is a Creationist interpretation of Genesis that rather boggled my mind. I came across this in a (christian) friend's bookcase and browsed through it out of interest. Before I go any further, let me say that this book will only be of interest to those who believe in the Bible as, literally, the Word of God AND who are prepared to buy into Beechick's rather implausibly constructed little fantastical interpretations of "histpory". Anybody else, like me, will alternately giggle hysterically and beat their head on a brick wall out of despair. I know most buyer of this book will probably (a) be amused or (b) be offended or (c) start you praying for my soul, as my friends often do but hey, this book deserves a review from a non-religious, non-creationist perspective given that it is presented by the author as "history".So, as a non-believer (ahem) and the somewhat respectful son of a devoutly religious Methodist Minister (sadly, now passed away) who was also a very knowledgable scholar of Biblical Studies, who read and wrote Hebrew, Greek and Latin - and who had a library of some thousands or religiously-oriented books, many of which I have read over the years and which I have inherited and kept in my Dad's memory, I have to say this is a subject I have argued over many a time. And on past experience, I expect to convince no-one. However, it IS a subject I find quite fascinating - that, on the face of all the evidence, people still persist in trying to interpret the Old Testament books as the literal word of God.To quote from the book: "Read evidence here that the writings in Genesis are more ancient than historians admit. Moreover, the Sumerians and other early peoples left us documents that corroborate the Genesis history. So Noah was real, and Adam......" Interesting indeed. Seems not to have dawned on the author that, rather than corroborate, Genesis may actually have been based on these Sumerian texts. That's not corroboration by anyone's standards.Noah "was real" - well, the problem here is that flood myths exist in most cultures world wide, with certain variations which are largely based on what happened at the end of the last ice age some 8-10,000 years ago. There are very few flood myths in Africa (wasn't affected much by the end of the ice age and subsequent flooding). In North America, the indian flood myths relate to "Land Rising" - in all probability due to the collapse of the north american ice shield and the subsequent land rising as the ice and water drained off through Hudson Bay and (proven) raised world sea levels by 400 feet. Many other "flood myths" exist around the world, there's entire books on them and their linquistical variations which can be used to date them and source the origins. So was "Noah" real. In all probability, the Genesis account (which, plausibly, is descended from the Sumerian "Noah" myth) may well have been based on a real person, but the Sumerian myth is still just the Sumerian myth and all this proves is that Genesis in all likeliehood sourced this particular myth from Sumeria, along with the list of ancient kings (for more on this, read David Rohl's Legend: The Genesis of Civilisation. Very interesting study of Genesis as it relates to known events and archeology.Adam - lingusitically, the biblical name can be traced back to the Sumerian, original meaning "Red Earth Man" - neolithic burials more often that not had the bodies coated in red clay, the phrase seemingly relates back to these ancient burial practices.Eve - through Hebrew to Akkadian to Sumerian, the name Eve can linguistically be traced back to Innana / Ishtar, the Sumerian goddess.Yahweh - interestingly, God has many names in the old Hebrew texts. One of which has now been traced back via linguistics and archeology (including old Sumerian texts) to the High God of Ugarit, one of the old Sumerian cities. So in all likeliehood, the "Yahweh" of the Old Testament was one of the old Sumerian Gods adopted by the people of Israel and later turned by stages into a monotheistic God (there's a tremendous amount of material on early Judaism as a polytheistic religion and it's evolution into a monotheism - interesting stuff).So yes, one must agree with Beechicks initial statement that "the writings in Genesis are more ancient than historians admit" (except, unfortunately, that historians DO admit, it is indeed the standard theory). The point to this little ramble is that Beechick in this, as in her other books that interpret the Bible, takes a very basic premise that may well be accurate, and then twists, turns, manipulates and embellishes until it's a wildly implausible fantasy.IMHO, absolutely nothing wrong with a Creationist interpretation of history if thats what you personally want to believe. You've made a, presumably, informed decision or come to your faith in a way that's valid to you. However, inflicting this nonsense on gullible children as "education" is another story completely. This isn't the Bible taken as Faith, this is fantastical nonsense masquerading as history.I do respect Beechick's work in Homeschooling, altho she's now somewhat dated in her approach. But her Biblical-related books are pure nonsense and inflicting them on children as "history" is irresponsible. There's a distinction between Faith and Idiocy.Teaching3: I don't know that we know whether Jesus believed Noah was a real person or not but it seems somewhat irrelevant. We do know "Noah and the Flood" type myths exist worldwide and date to approximately the same period of time - linguistic analysis of oral versions can also tell you where these stories originated and roughly date them. The Biblical version was merely one of many and that it originated from the Sumerian version seems likely.Simple Bible Book Guy: Hmmm, definitely not ranting against Christianity per se. I send my 2 kids to a private religious (christian) school, having a strong belief that the education of the young should include a strong moral component. I would see my review as more of a rant against Beechicks rather unique interpretation of history. Its more than a little implausible IMHO to try and balance up a literal interpretation of the Bible against actual history. I did read almost all of the book in fact. It was a bit of an eye-opener at the time, hence the rant.Re the old myths being based on earlier oral stories passed down. For sure, I agree its far more than likely. One wonders how far back some of these core myths and legends actually go. The Adam vs Red Earth association for example - I recall an old neanderthal burial site somewhere where the bones had been coated with red clay. Quite intriguing. And then when one looks also at the linguistic studies in the origins of language and Nostratic - the identification of the first language - it gets even more interesting (if you are interested, take a look at The Origin of Language: Tracing the Evolution of the Mother Tongue - quite a fascinating account for the layman). Also, for a good archeological take on the first two books of the Bible, try David Rohls Legend: The Genesis of Civilisation.lovethelord - I prefer to think of it as a book review combined with a rant. The book as holes you can drive a truck through if you have any knowledge of ancient history. I find it tragic that something like this is passed off as "history".Anyhow, thx for all the comments and discussion. I know this is a subject some of us feel quite strongly about and I certainly appreciate and welcome the comments and feedback.

Just picked up an old version of this (how can you argue with a cost of 1 cent) and ended up reading it in an evening. It's a captivating short novel for children set in Canada's aptly named Barren lands - the huge area of Canada that stretches from the northern treeline north to the Arctic Ocean. The Barrens are a world of their own, beautiful and hostile, almost uninhabited and uninhabitable. Mowat's book takes us into the world of the Barrens through the adventures of two teenage boys, one white, one Indian. They accompany a hunting expedition north, go off on a side trip of their own, lose their canoe and from there, the adventure really begins.Lost, with no way to get back south, they must do their best to survived a winter in the Barrens. And they do, making mistakes but learning from them. They hunt (and there's no romanticisation of the hunting and killing), they build a shelter for the winter, the process of surviving a winter in the barrens is explained - the food available, the ability to live on a diet that's almost 100% meat (as long as there's sufficient fat available), the making of pemmican, how to dry meat and how to freeze food before the winter sets in, how to make clothes for the winter, how to build a fireplace within a hut without a chimney that won't smoke you out, eskers and how to use them to travel on (that was one bit that was completely new to me). The detail is both fascinating and woven in as an integral part of the story in a way that's entertaining.Written in the early 1950's, there's a lot that's now history - the use of birchbark canoes for example, as well as the hostility and fear that existed between the Indian tribes and the Indians and the Inuit. Also, the isolation of the Indian settlements in the North back then - the reason for the hunting trip in the first place was that the tribe was on the verge of starvation - something which wouldn't happen these days as the Fed would be airdropping supplies in! Makes for an interesting historical lesson though, particularly as, back in this period, entire settlements were occassionally wiped out due to starvation.All in all, a beautifully written childrens story with a lot of lessons on history and survival woven into it. A great read for any young child and a good intro to practical survival skills. Your kids going to want to go into the woods and try out some of this stuff after reading the book. You may too!

It can be used in the shower and is easy to clean, just pop off the top and rinse it out, then pop it back on.  The foil blade spins around without endangering one's skin but slices off unwanted hairs quickly and painlessly.  It's the only trimmer I'll put up my nose from now on.

I have a ten year old German Shepherd and a six month old mini-Doxie.  The puppy is not even close to being housebroken and frequently waits until she comes back inside the house to relieve herself.  After picking up poop or blotting up  urine, I spray some of this product onto the stained area, let it soak for a few minutes and then blot it up again.  I allow the area to completely dry and then vacuum over it.  People tell me that the stains are gone and there is no smell.  The puppy also does not seem to use that area as her personal dumping ground again.  Once a month or so, I use a carpet steamer to rinse out the ground in particles and that seems to reactivate the Nature's Miracle, a good thing.  No experience with large volumes or vomit but it does a great job on what I've  encountered so far.

This Bissell carpet cleaner is a very basic but functional machine.  If used correctly it will be better than some rental units and even poorly trained professional services.  The key is patience.  Assembling is simple.  Im blind and had this thing together in five minutes, it may take you longer if you try to read the directions.  Just close your eyes and do as I say:  First, unpack the box carefully.  I saved the Styrofoam in case I have to return the machine.  I took all the papers and threw them into the bottom of the box since I cant read them anyway and they mean nothing to me.  The top of the box held the small bottle of cleaning solution and the water tank.  The handle has two screws taped to it and you will need them to secure the handle to the main body.  At the bottom is the primary unit with the middle part.  That middle part slides and locks into the bottom part and is then secured by the two screws.  Make sure the two parts are flush before trying to install the screws.  The screws are similar to drywall screws, they are designed to bite into the plastic and are not meant to be removed repeatedly.  Once you have the two bottom pieces together, insert eh handle into the hole on top of the middle piece and just slide it in.  The handle can be collapsed for storage if you want by turning the tightening knob back and forth for tighten and loosen.  On the top of the handle is the sprayer trigger, just under the hand hold.  Also, there is a cord clip to hand the cord if you prefer.  The final part is the water bottle that installs with the plug side down into the main body of the unit.You put the hot tap water into this part.There are two pedals, the small one on the left releases the main body and handle to lay down flat to the floor so that you can remove the waste water tank, just like the average vacuum claner does.  The middle is the power switch.  There is a stiff brush that is deliberately mounted loosely designed to scrub the carpet and loosen ground in dirt and work the water and cleaning solution into the bottom of the carpet or rug.  It does not revolve and works just by moving the machine back and forth.In order to clean, you add a single capful of the solution  less is better!  and then add the hottest tap water you can get from your tap.  Be careful to know if your carpet is wool or some typethat can shrink with hot water.  I have cheap, polyester rugs so any hot water temp is OK.  Place the water bottle onto the unit and start on and end of the carpet where you will pull the machine, not push.  Use the solution sparingly, using too much solution will just make too much foam, leave your carpet sticky and make them get dirty much more quickly.  The key is to be patient and rinse well.  Start by turning the machine on and then slowly pull the machine while squeezing the trigger.  Do one good pass with the trigger spraying and then at least a couple slow passes withjust the vacuum.  Go slowly to suck up as much water as possible.  Pretend you are trying to walk in neck high water and you should have the right pace.This is a great little machine for smaller areas but if you are incredibly diligent and patient, you can do a large room, it will just take many fill-ups and waste tank emptying.  When the vacuum stops sucking up water, you should hear a change in the sound of the machine, this means that the tank is full and needs to be drained.  Step on the little lever, lay the handle flat on the floor, unlatch the two laches on the sides of the waste tank and  pull straight up to avoid spilling.  You will inevitably spill some so dont be upset with yourself.  Although fairly obvious, if the spray stops, you are probably out of water and need to refill the water tank.I highly advise doing a thorough job of dry vacuuming with your normal vacuum before you use this machine, it is designed to rinse dirt, not dry vacuum.  Allow the carpet a couple hours  at least  to dry before walking on it.Personally, I like to do a full rinse cycle with pure water and no cleaning solution.  I dont want unnecessary chemicals or solvents left behind.  If youre patient enough, its a good way to ensure all the solution is out of the carpet.After its totally dry, go over with a dry vacuum again to pick up dirt and hair that has wicked up to the surface.  Its a simple process but a time-consuming one.  In general, the slower you go, the better the results when it comes to vacuuming out the water.Analternative method would be to put the cleaning solution into a spray bottle and spray it onto the top of the carpet prior to the wet rinsing, that way only pure water is rinsing out the carpet.  It adds an extra stepbut may work better depending on your situation.If you have really ground in dirt or animal deposits, I suggest getting on your hands and knees with a scrub brush and cleaning solution prior to using the machine, then rinse the heck out of it for a very long time.
This amplifier helped bring in a couple of weaker signals but did not bring in any new channels.  If you have spotty reception, this may help but don't expect it to do any miracles.
Nice substitute for those times when a partener isn't available.

This is definitely a rugged and well protected external hard drive.  The USB is  the more common full sized and not a mini or printer type which makes it easier to connect with whatever cables I have laying around.  The transfer is very fast;  Being portable, there's no need for a power cord, it uses the power from the USB cable.  It's indeed small enough to fit into a shirt pocket if you're so inclined and the rugged rubberized case should protect it as advertised from a short drop, bounce or water splash.  It showed up right away in WIndows 8 and I was able to access it just like any other drive.

I ordered two bags of this seed last spring and had a decent beginning of a lawn a few months later.  I started with pretty much just dirt and a couple trees and ended up with a nice covering, certainly not a lush lawn but something that looks like a lawn from the street, mows easily and grows quickly.  I have an average sized front yard, about 60X30 and two bags of this seed did a good job.  I'll add more this spring.  What I especially liked about this particular seed is that it sprouted within a couple weeks and actually looked like grass within a month.  The birds didn't eat much - I did cover it withloose soil - and it grows very well in the shaded area of my Oak and  Sugar Maple.  I let the seed go almost two months before cutting the first time in order to grow some deep roots and keep the mower deck up about 3" with a weekly trim during the summer and fall.  We'll see how well it does after this Wisconsin winter it's first full year on the ground.

I'm a big guy, 46" waist and these are very comfortable, nicely fitting swim trunks.  They have a smooth feel to them, don't climb up my butt like some materials do and the string is long enough to get a nice bow tie know.  They dry very quickly when out of the water too.  Really pleased.

My TV reception went from two channels with the Amazon compact indoor 50 mile antenna to 12 channels with this small mast antenna.  It comes with the mounting bracket, not a small item, all hardware and instructions.  Be careful when unfolding the antenna to not bend or break off any of the parts.  This is a directional antenna but it picks up signals from all areas much better than the Amazon basic antenna did and for around the same cost.

My 10 year old German Shepherd can gnaw the small top off these Extreme Kongs in a day.  She adores the Kong and I continue to buy them for her but they tend to chunk out after a month and I have to throw them away.  She does much better with some monster size Elk antlers I found on an auction site but she loves to chew and chew this Kong.

I really like the large handle on this leash, I can get my hand inside and around to get a good grip, unlike the smaller versions of this leash.  The strap leash is strong although I am only using it for a 12 lb. mini-Doxie.  She likes the extra long distance she can travel with this leash, I like the bigger handle.  We're both happy.
