Effective and compelling. After a brief polyphonic "Intermezzo," the next major event of the sonata is the finale, a passacaglia that alternates between stern and lighter frenetic expression. Kletzki leans towards modernism with his use of ostinatos.The Piano Trio in D major (1926) is less successful and unworthy of detailed commentary. The outer movements, extroverted though they are, lack inspiration and arresting moments. However, the "Adagio" is a powerful jewel, notably serious and melancholy with rich arpeggiation and Slavic melodic lines bearing some resemblance to Rachmaninov.Bottom line: Collectors of offbeat chamber repertoire may like the Violin Sonata, but the Piano Trio is a dud, except for its captivating slow movement. Much better chamber works of the hyper-chromatic Szymanowski/early Schoenberg stripe are those of Roslavets, Lyatoshynsky, Catoire, and Bohnke.

Robert Volkmann (1815-1883) is regarded paradoxically as a conservative Romantic embraced by the New German School. Much of his music is no more chromatic or advanced than Mendelssohn, but there's rhythmic fire and intense gestures redolent of Liszt. His two piano trios are early works cast from a post-Beethoven mold with nods to Schubert, Schumann, and Mendelssohn.Beethoven is the temperamental and stylistic model for the Piano Trio in F major op. 3, a magnificent work chock full of energy, passion, memorable content. The first movement opens with a Beethovenian pensive introduction--captivating in its own right--before letting loose a spirited Sonata-Allegro. Volkmann's piano writing is heavy and more virtuosic than his conservative peers. There's constant arpeggiation and activity, sounding like Schumann's most intense solo piano music accompanied by strings. Beethoven is suggested again in the "Scherzo," which features a mesmerizing and wonderful trio section, notable for its dignity and pathos-laden melodic lines. Volkmann anticipates Brahms in the "Andante," an impassioned movement with reflective qualities. The "Finale" resembles the sheer wild energy and drama of Mendelssohn's stormy D minor trio. Here Volkmann offers the listener a buoyant catchy theme, lots of diminished chords and unstable arpeggios, sparkling flourishes, and toe-tapping momentum.Volkmann's Piano Trio in B flat minor op. 5 was embraced by Liszt and Hans von Bulow for its highly unorthodox form and hints at cyclical structure and thematic unity. There's nothing in its harmonic language or push towards chromaticism that approaches Liszt or even Reubke and Draeseke, but it is an engaging and eccentric work. The trio turns the standard fast-slow-fast structure on its head, starting with a long "Largo" that is in a state of palpable anxiety and melancholy, often reminiscent of Beethoven. Occasional turbulence breaks the stillness and then slow meditative passages continue. In the "Ritornell," the mood relaxes with tuneful and brighter ideas, although a sense of unease still lingers. Finally the work ends in a lengthy "Allegro con brio" notable for its free-form fantasy structure and recycling of themes from earlier movements. Beethoven and Schubert are still the foundation, albeit updated with early Romantic harmony and pianism. Volkmann is at his best when he aims to express intense passion, as is heard in the dramatic development section.Bottom line: I've enjoyed everything I've heard from Volkmann, which admittedly isn't much (his Piano Sonata and Fantasy and these trios). He is a melodist with a flair for youthful drama and virtuosic piano writing.

Robert Fuchs (1847-1927) taught such illustrious composers as Mahler, Sibelius, Korngold, and Wolf. After hearing these pedestrian chamber works, I think Fuchs should have stuck to his day job. There's not a single work or movement here that kept my interest for more than a few seconds. This music lacks drive, tension, and basic essentials of interesting melody, harmony, and expressive content. If one needed proof that academic composers can write musical vapor, look no further than Fuchs. Even Brilliant Classics was compelled to cite this funny anecdote: "Max Bruch showed Brahms some of Fuchs's music, to which Brahms simply replied, 'Where did you find such fine manuscript paper?'" The liner notes brushes this off as no slight on Fuchs's talent, but rather a typical instant of Brahms's misanthropy. On the contrary, I think his reaction has force and it's a response I can relate to. I'm tempted to follow suit and remark on the recording's fine Klimt album cover and leave it at that.What surprises me is that all three of these uninteresting works are in minor keys and stem from Fuchs's late period, yet there's nothing inventive, dramatic, evocative, or emotionally investing about them. The Piano Trio No. 3 in F-sharp minor (1926) is tired and forgettable, offering zero tension or memorable ideas. The opening movement is all warmth and contented relaxation with flat thematic material. In the "Andante grazioso," Fuchs seems to be writing an exercise in lyricism, in which he gives us a saccharine main theme and a slightly agitated central section. The "Allegretto scherzando" is the most distinctive movement of the trio, remarkably classical in aesthetic: bright Haydnesque phrases and a Mozartian tinkling piano part that flirts with Alberti bass figures. Nothing else stands out, although the sunny and rollicking trio is just OK. I cannot find anything positive to say about the finale, a duple meter folk dance with occasional canonic passages and sober expression.The Violin Sonata No. 3 in G minor (1915) is another late work devoid of quality. Despite its minor key, this is a bright and cheerful work. One indicator of how uninspired Fuchs was in this sonata is that the dynamics rarely change. Everything is uniform in mood. It's as if Fuchs is merely going through the motions of part-writing and academic harmonic progressions. The opening movement is warm and leisurely with not one storm cloud to be found, emphasizing a classical sensibility and safe interplay of instruments. I'll grant that the development section shows unexpected chromaticism, but much of it goes in one ear and out the other. Fuchs makes a terrible attempt at cantabile writing in the "Andante sostenuto" and the result is schmaltz and sentimentalism. The finale is of Dvorakian character, full of gaiety and energy and alternates minor and major key phrases; nothing special here.The Six Fantasy Pieces for Viola and Piano (1927) are more of the same, but Fuchs is consciously writing in a vein of nostalgia, as he looks back on the 19th century. Each piece is a stylized dance of melancholy character. Of course, "melancholy" to Fuchs means autumnal and restrained. The "Allegretto con delicatezza" is the only piece with an effective melody. High five to Fuchs. For once he manages to write a fetching theme with the lilt of Schumann and Mozart.Bottom line: Boring, dreadful, tedious. This is some of the worst chamber music I've heard in recent years. If you want strong Brahmsian piano trios and chamber sonatas, listen to Rntgen, Herzogenberg, or Gernsheim.

The music of Friedrich Gernsheim (1839-1916) might have survived had the composer not died during WWI. Many lesser conservative Romantics could not adjust to modernism or stay relevant after the Great War, but I think Gernsheim would have. He just never had the chance. Matters were much worse for his legacy because as a Jewish composer his music was willfully ignored and marginalized by the Third Reich. During his life, Gernsheim's reputation was that of a conductor, academic, and composer of a decidedly Brahmsian vein. Chamber music was his passion and these piano quintets reveal an accomplished master at work. The piano quintets have been recorded before on Toccata Classics, but I haven't heard the performances.Gernsheim is unabashedly Brahmsian in these quintets. No. 1 in D minor opens with what can only be called Brahmsian vigor and strength. Throughout the movement Gernsheim strikes a fine balance between dramatic and lyrical content in his thematic material. Wonderful things are achieved in the "Andante molto cantabile." Here Gernsheim is so evocative of Brahms in the way he writes for piano; comparisons with the "Adagio" from Brahms's First Piano Concerto are tempting. The result is a movement of slow passion, delicate beauty, and sublime turns of expressive harmony. In a startling twist of mood, the scherzo comes at the listener with the gruff violence of Beethoven. This is not a light Mendelssohn scherzo, but a toe-tapping highly active boisterous dance in the dark key of G minor. Gernsheim flexes his contrapuntal muscles in the lively finale, marked by classical phrasing and warm serenity.Gernsheim's chamber masterpiece is the Piano Quintet No. 2 in B minor. It reveals an upward curve of technical mastery and expressive force, most salient in the first two movements. Rich melodies and thick Brahmsian chords abound in the "Molto moderato," which is a stately affair featuring massive extroverted drama and a fine interplay of instruments. Gernsheim looks to Beethoven for expressive dynamic extremes; sudden loud climaxes erupt and then fade prematurely. In the "Adagio," Gernsheim lures us in with gentle lyrical A sections before unveiling his true purpose: a dark and turbulent central section, which is commanding in its power due to the excessive tremolos in the strings and dark-hued piano colors. I didn't find the short vivacious scherzo special; just a typical Mendelssohn clone. However, the "Allegro giocoso" finale is rousing and has astounding virtuosic passages on the piano fit for a concerto.Bottom line: Gernsheim is among the handful of first-class German composers who wrote chamber music in the wake of Brahms. His two quintets will delight Brahms lovers of all stripes: they're serious, memorable, and consistent in quality. Gernsheim's mastery of form, melodic invention, and his skillful writing for string ensemble and piano remind me of Rontgen and Herzogenberg.

There's a good chance of being misled by the title of this recording "Dutch Cello Sonatas," which is really the name of this series, now reaching six volumes. This particular volume might as well be called "Rontgen: Cello Sonatas" because over 60 minutes is devoted to his music. Even the performers admit that the three miniatures by Daniel van Goens (1858-1904) are essentially encores. It is hard to account for the complete neglect of German-Dutch composer Julius Rontgen (1855-1932) who stands apart from the legions of Brahms imitators and conservative late Romantics for one thing: melody. Whether it's the actual thematic material or voicings in his harmonic progressions, Rontgen is an outstanding melodist. Not even Herzogenberg and Gernsheim have such facility. It is no wonder then that he enjoyed a close friendship with another great melodist of his day, Edvard Grieg. Nothing of Rontgen's enormous output survives in the public consciousness, but what he offers in his chamber music is inspired and consistently high quality. He never phones it in.Having been blown away by Rontgens marvelous piano trios, I'm equally over-the-moon for these two cello sonatas, both serious and substantial minor-key works. The Cello Sonata No. 5 in B minor has the rich lyricism and intense beauty of the Brahms E minor sonata. The first movement is distinctly melancholy and tender in mood with gushing cello lines. Even more effective is the energetic second movement, which contains a rollicking toe-tapping theme. Rontgen demonstrates an inspiration for colorful and expressive harmony, yearning chromaticism, and dense piano writing.Yet even more exciting and intense, the Cello Sonata No. 2 in A minor looks to Beethoven, sometimes quite literally. Brahms hovers over the first movement, which is impassioned and turbulent with smoky dark colors and expressive cello lines. In the solemn and ruminating "Adagio," the piano drives the harmonic direction with its progression of chords while the cello supports with counter melodies. Where Rontgen literally borrows from Beethoven is in the spirited finale. The theme is lifted straight from the rondo of Beethoven's Tempest sonata. I have no complaints. Rontgen knows how to craft strong thematic material and he employs the arsenal of an expert melodist, using gorgeous sequences.An interesting inclusion on this program are the Cinq Morceaux, which reveals a programmatic side of Rontgen. Each of these pieces is a musical portrait of characters from Shakespeare's Tempest. Those familiar with the play won't be surprised by the moods he aims for in each piece. Prospero's spirit servant "Ariel" is conveyed with light and airy textures; Miranda is exemplified by sweet tenderness and passion; Rontgen goes for a comical and boisterous march to depict the villain Calibran. The miniatures by Daniel van Goens are unashamed trifles: "Scherzo" has the upbeat attitude of Rossini; "Invocation" is like a cello song without words, serious and nostalgic; "Menuet" is neo-Baroque and charming.Bottom line: These two cello sonatas by Rontgen are terrific discoveries, passionate and strong minor-key sonatas that will appeal to anyone who likes Brahms and Grieg.

It is hard to account for the complete neglect of Julius Rntgen (1855-1932) who stands apart from the legions of Brahms imitators and conservative late Romantics for one thing: melody. Whether it's the actual thematic material or voicings in his harmonic progressions, Rntgen is an outstanding melodist. Not even Herzogenberg and Gernsheim have such facility. It is no wonder then that he enjoyed a close friendship with another great melodist of his day, Edvard Grieg. Nothing of Rntgen's enormous output survives in the public consciousness, but what he offers in his chamber music is inspired and consistently high quality. He never phones it in.In his trio No. 2 in B major, Rntgen hadn't quite found the expressive powers that we'll see crop up later. It is tempting to assume that he is nodding to Brahms's Piano Trio op. 8 with his choice of key and four-movement structure. The work is certainly redolent of Brahms without being blatantly derivative. The first movement "Allegro molto ed energico" has an abundance of Beethovenian energy and robust Brahmsian gestures, in addition to attractive melodic material in both themes. "Un poco andante" is a noble and expressive cantilena of startling beauty. Although quite lengthy at 9 minutes, Mendelssohn is the obvious model for the whimsical and charming "Scherzo" with its nimble flights of piano figures. Rounding out the work is a passionate and triumphant finale heavily suggestive of Brahms.A much better trio is No. 4 in G minor "Entam." Here Rntgen raises the bar for himself, concentrating on motivic development and dramatic content. The opening "Allegro molto" has all the weight and urgency of middle Beethoven with memorable themes to boot. I must quote Jeff Joneikis of Records International, who compared the first theme to "a black rose blooming in the moonlight beneath the crumbling ramparts of a ruined castle wherein a white-robed figure with raven tresses is suddenly glimpsed out of the corner of one's eye." Take it from us, Rntgen knows how to craft powerful thematic material. Equally effective is the yearning "Andante tranquillo e cantabile," which features a ravishing lyrical violin melody and expressive arpeggiated piano writing. There's a degree of emotional depth here that presages Rntgen's later trios. In the final two movements, Rntgen develops melodic motifs from prior movements. The "Moderato" demonstrates to me just how fine a melodist Rntgen was. He knows how to write exciting and passionate music with almost neo-Baroque melodies relying on sequences for their impact. It works. His themes are striking even on a first hearing.Bottom line: Rntgen's piano trios are not merely mediocre items on par with say, Kiel, Fuchs, Reinecke, or Rheinberger. These are strong examples of serious Brahmsian chamber music, comparable in quality to that of Herzogenberg and Raff. All of his trios overflow with tuneful thematic material and expressive harmony. I think the fourth trio in G minor is the better work because of its dramatic activity and minor-key sobriety.

Elgar's great accomplishments in the realm of chamber music were all completed in the summer of 1917 during his stay at the secluded Brinkwells Cottage. There he penned the Piano Quintet, Violin Sonata, and String Quartet--all deeply personal minor-key works. The isolation of the cottage coupled with news of friends dying on the front colored the tone of these chamber works, which are serious, poignant, and introspective. Elgar's treatment of the instruments is surprisingly heavy and forceful, suggesting symphonic weight in sound that pushes the chamber texture to its sonic limits.The Violin Sonata in E minor, an exquisite work of its kind, is a full-blooded post-Brahmsian conception that attains orchestral sonorities. Elgar gives both parts equal significance, although frequently the piano takes on the drama, as evident in the first movement's coda, which unfurls as a rivulet of titanic chords. Apart from the gradually ascending climax, the second movement is quiet and contemplative, expressing tenderness and aching emotion through the violin lines. Brahms is evoked in the beautiful finale, rich with melody and sweltering passion. Overall, this is an excellent work, not quite at the level of Bridge's Violin Sonata, but certainly deserving of more attention.In the Piano Quintet, Elgar again strives for symphonic writing and gives the strings virtuosic and demanding parts that often carry the emotional gravity. Brahms is the major influence, which comes across most saliently in the first movement. Stentorian drama prevails in the first theme, but most remarkable is the powerful development section, a maelstrom of thick earth-shattering chords and cascading virtuosic writing for the strings. The Elgar who can move us to tears with Nimrod is also present in the slow movement, a heart-felt outpouring of pathos in which the strings carry the momentum.The Nash Ensemble has once again offered an astonishing performance with gripping urgency and immaculate dynamics. Ian Brown, the pianist, has recorded the Piano Quintet several times with other ensembles. His presence is commanding and matches the strings in all their vehemence and volume.Bottom line: The Piano Quintet is a significant work of dramatics and serious emotion that rewards repeated listenings. I would place it at the forefront of best English piano quintets in the literature, along with Bax, Bridge, and Vaughan Williams. The Violin Sonata probes similar emotional territory, although it doesn't have the lasting impression of the quintet.

Overall, this is an excellent work, not quite at the level of Bridge's Violin Sonata, but certainly deserving of more attention.In the Piano Quintet, Elgar again strives for symphonic writing and gives the strings virtuosic and demanding parts that often carry the emotional gravity. Brahms is the major influence, which comes across most saliently in the first movement. Stentorian drama prevails in the first theme, but most remarkable is the powerful development section, a maelstrom of thick earth-shattering chords and cascading virtuosic writing for the strings. The Elgar who can move us to tears with Nimrod is also present in the slow movement, a heart-felt outpouring of pathos in which the strings carry the momentum.The Nash Ensemble has once again offered an astonishing performance with gripping urgency and immaculate dynamics. Ian Brown, the pianist, has recorded the Piano Quintet several times with other ensembles. His presence is commanding and matches the strings in all their vehemence and volume.Bottom line: The Piano Quintet is a significant work of dramatics and serious emotion that rewards repeated listenings. I would place it at the forefront of best English piano quintets in the literature, along with Bax, Bridge, and Vaughan Williams. The Violin Sonata probes similar emotional territory, although it doesn't have the lasting impression of the quintet.

Alexander Tansman (1897-1986) assimilated many styles in vogue during the early 20th century: from late Romanticism and neo-classicism to French impressionism and modernism. I have found his music consistently uneven. Too much of it is derivative without offering fresh or memorable ideas. Tansman's expressive palette is elegant but emotionally detached and melody is not his strong suit. These works for violin and piano stretch across a wide period from 1918 to 1963. Virtually everything here is thoroughly shaded by the influence of Debussy, Ravel, and Stravinsky. "Romance" has a nostalgic air with ambiguous harmonies and cloudy impressionism, but Tansman doesn't have much melodic content to show. The Violin Sonata No. 2 begins with a schmaltzy and tepid opening movement that I have no desire to ever hear again. There's a Slavic Romantic flavor to the "Andante espressivo" and much more bite in the finale, which features thick chordal piano writing and Ravelian swirls of impressionist color. French modernism totally envelopes the "Sonata una quasi fantasia," replete with bitonal colors, parallel 4ths, and changing meters recalling Stravinsky. I liked the hazy bleak impressionist mood of "Andante", but the finale is quite grating from its simpering optimism. Similarly, both Sonatinas are suffused in brightness, naivety, and mirth. One exceptional movement is the "Andante cantabile" of the Second Sonatina. This desolate polytonal piece possesses a fine lonely violin soliloquy with brittle piano chords aromatic of Schoenberg's Pierrot Lunaire.To my mind, the greatest work on this recording is the late Fantaisie (1963). Here Tansman abandons his gleeful insouciance and aims for greater depth of expression. His harmonic language is even more advanced, often bordering on atonality. Stravinsky's influence is still present, particularly in the first movement with its frantic pizzicato, dissonant clusters, and asymmetrical meter. Tansman manages to produce a dizzying combination of violin sonic effects and spiky piano colors. At times Tansman brushes shoulders with the German expressionists. For example, the "Improvisazione" and "Finale" are dark and mysterious and reminiscent of Berg. The "Finale" is compelling. It opens with dark tolling bass chords and unleashes waves of frenetic and agitated violin writing, which often sound microtonal to me.Bottom line: A half-hearted recommendation for fans of French modernism  la Stravinsky, Debussy, and Ravel. Only the Fantaisie and a few movements from the Violin Sonatas and Sonatinas appealed to me. I think Tansman is more successful in his solo piano music, even though much of that is passable, as well.

Alexander Tansman (1897-1986) assimilated many styles in vogue during the early 20th century: from late Romanticism and neo-classicism to French impressionism and modernism. I have found his music consistently uneven. Too much of it is derivative without offering fresh or memorable ideas. His expressive palette is elegant but emotionally detached and melody is not his strong suit. I'm giving this particular volume the benefit of the doubt because I enjoyed these miniatures purely for their sonorities and mood, which are primarily quiet and impressionist or mysterious in a late Scriabin mode. The performances by Danny Zelibor are meticulously dynamic and detailed, proving that Tansman's music sounds better than it really is by virtue of a nuanced interpretation.As a composer for the piano, Tansman is a miniaturist. Most of these pieces are 1-3 minutes in length and reveal the direct influence of Stravinsky, Debussy, Ravel, and Scriabin. Although the Piano Sonata No. 1 does live up to its subtitle "Rustica" with droning accompaniment and pastoral charm, it also bears the stamp of Ravel. Bitonal clashes of chords and colors, super impressionist scales, and jazzy rhythms in the finale are a testament to that. Tansman offers some surprising depth in the second movement, a desolate and emotionally affective work with a wistful melody and chromatic dissonance.Ravel and Stravinsky loom large over the remaining pieces, which fit into two types: fragile and mysterious impressionism or Stravinskyan modernism. "Four Dance Miniatures" and Book 1 of the "Mazurkas" feature elements of both. Several of the mazurkas are remarkable and held my interest, such as the haunting "Moderato piu lento" and "Andante espressivo", which sound like Alfredo Casella with ambiguous harmonies, delicate chords, and eerie lyricism. As much as these mazurkas are dances with asymmetrical meter, many are quiet and dream-like  la Debussy. Exceptions to this norm include the "Etude Scherzo", a rapid concert piece that explores many colors in the space of a minute.The "7 Preludes" traverse similar impressionist ground without the dance rhythms. I hear Casella again in the first of these preludes: a dreamy and languidly chromatic piece. Late Scriabinesque mystery is evoked in several others. The "5 Impromptus" are mostly exercises in harmonic color, ostinatos, and changing meter.Bottom line: You have to really enjoy early 20th century modernism and miniatures in general to appreciate Tansman. If you don't like Debussy, Ravel or Stravinsky, move on. Most of these pieces blend into each other after repeated listenings because they sound so similar. Yet I found Zelibor's playing hypnotic, especially of the mysterious and becalmed miniatures that can be admired simply for their sonorities.

If you like that brand of warm, lively, and unimposing chamber music without much depth, these two works are awash in delights. I don't find them impressive enough to revisit, however. I was hoping Stanford would employ a bit more drama and expressive edge. For that, one has to turn to Elgar, Bridge, or Ireland. With some exceptions (his Piano Quintet and 2nd Piano Trio), Stanford's chamber music is Brahms-lite with a jovial spirit. Too much of that goes a long way and he lacks the melodic richness of his compatriots, let alone other more successful emulators of Brahms on the continent.The Piano Trio in G minor (1899) is the best of this chamber pairing. It is a mature work and gripping mainly because of the slow movement, which so adeptly channels the sublime sorrow of a Beethoven adagio. This is as dark and introspective as Stanford gets and I wish he allowed this emotional feeling to bleed over into the outer movements. Beethoven's ghost appears again in the Scherzo movement, a rhythmically engaging and energetic little essay. The finale begins promisingly dark and ominous, but perhaps again like Beethoven, Stanford teases the audience and instead unfurls a sprightly rondo, occasionally passionate, but thoroughly light-hearted.The Piano Quartet in F major (1879) is less remarkable than the trio and often superficial. For all its felicity and buoyancy, there is a dearth of memorable melodies and interesting turns of harmony. The outer movements are joyful and triumphant, but rather dull and unfulfilling. Stanford proves himself skillful at writing academically in a vein Reinecke would have appreciated. But without appealing ideas and tension, Stanford doesn't make much of an impact on me. Only the "Poco adagio" movement has notable qualities about it: expressive heights of passion, darker anguished sections, and strong lyricism in the cello lines.Bottom line: These two chamber works are just OK. The G minor Piano Trio is the winner, while the earlier Piano Quartet suffers from mediocrity. Both are decidedly Brahmsian in flavor, diverting and jubilant in mood, and each contain strong slow movements. I can't understand why there's so much inspiration in these adagios, while the outer movements leave much to be desired. Recommended for chamber or British music enthusiasts only.

The reputation of Alexander Grechaninov (1864-1956) firmly resides in the field of liturgical music. He may have excelled at writing vocal and stage works, but I find his chamber music devoid of quality. Stylistically, it draws upon Tchaikovsky and Glazunov, but there's nothing memorable or compelling to encourage repeated listenings. This isn't bad music if you like subdued and quiet chamber music without much drama.I agree with Scott Morrison's assessment of Grechaninov's trios: "neatly constructed, melodically undistinguished, and truthfully rather boring and complacent." The "Piano Trio in C minor" begins inauspiciously restrained and timid. It's a slow movement without much melodic hook or expressive ventilation. With the second movement, Grechaninov strikes interesting ground. After a dramatic declamatory opening, promising an onslaught of intensity, he gives us a deceptively light menuetto theme, which is catchy and tinged with melancholy. Darker-hued bass writing lends the movement some gravity. The finale is cool and detached, featuring a nice solo cello cadenza, but the music is so meandering and dull. Not much improves in the "Piano Trio in G major." Even the liner notes can't say much about it except to chart its key changes in a drearily academic way. It's an active, but jumbled mess of ideas and melodically deficient. Boring in other words. Likewise, the second movement is sunny and amiable, but forgettable. One starves for harmonic sequences or motivic writing. A mild spark of talent emerges in the finale with interesting toccata piano writing and pizzicato activity.Grechaninov's "Cello Sonata in E minor" is an overall stronger work than the trios, but not by much. For once the composer lets loose some emotion and inspired part-writing. The first movement has a passionately agonized primary theme, although the lyrical second theme is hollow. Moving lyricism continues in the second movement, although I found the passionate crescendos that start and stop in an abortive fashion rather irritating. The finale is energetic right out of the starting gate with surges of intensity that promised much, but never delivered.Bottom line: Makes for decent background music for reading, but otherwise Grechaninov's piano trios are misfires. If you want strong Russian chamber music off the beaten path, seek out Taneyev's Piano Quintet, Lyapunov's Piano Sextet, Catoire's Piano Trio, and Sabaneyev's Piano Trios. Even Anton Rubinstein's Piano Trios are better than this.

Mark Bebbington, a major proponent of British piano music, has unearthed two obscure piano sonatas, but only the Hurlstone is a gem. The death of William Hurlstone (1876-1906) may have robbed Britain of a promising young composer. It is difficult to gauge how much of an impact he would have made, but his Piano Concerto and chamber music reveal admirable qualities. I don't think he was quite the budding genius as suggested by Vaughan Williams and Stanford. The music world suffered a greater loss from the premature deaths of Stanchinsky, Lekeu, Reubke, and Tausig. However, the Hurlstone sonata is his best solo piano work; the Capriccio is another worthy piece which can be heard on Toccata Classics.Hurlstone's "Piano Sonata in F minor" is spawned from the mold of Schumann and Brahms. The first movement has all the requisite elements of a good Sonata-Allegro: well-wrought serious and lyrical themes with an engaging development and dramatic coda. It is the second movement, heavily steeped in Wagner and Brahms, that impressed me most. Hurlstone exhibits startling expressive depth and passion with a central section of real power and emotion. Had he continued writing like this, he would have made a great mark in the British music world. The robust finale features massive Brahmsian chords and Schumannesque kinetic energy. Note that Bebbington plays much slower than Kenji Fujimura on Toccata Classics. This really works well in the slow movement with its drooping chromaticism and profound Wagnerian lines. Bebbington takes his time with every delicate line and milks each note for expressive effect. Fujimura is faster and more devil-may-care with his bravura, which is a legitimate and exciting approach, too.Benjamin Dale (1885-1943), on the other hand, is a composer I could have happily remained ignorant. I agree with the other reviewer's astutely and succinctly phrased assessment of the Sonata as being "more perspiration than inspiration." I marvel at the attention and praise it got in the press and even in William Newman's Sonata Since Beethoven; Newman devotes a couple pages of analysis to it. What is interesting about Dale's 40-minute Sonata is that it's structurally unique. Three of the movements--the adagio, scherzo, and finale--are conceived at a macro level as a gigantic Theme and Variations. Beyond that, I don't see what's so original or gripping that York Bowen would show deference to it. This is syrupy salon Romantic music alright, but it's way too sprawling and vacuous, lacking depth and strong melodic content in equal measure. In the first movement, Dale is obnoxiously sentimental, piling loads of sugary schmaltz onto Rachmaninovian piano writing. Between the wistful second movement and incoherent scherzo, I noticed a scarcity of interesting ideas. Only in the Finale does Dale deliver some fresh moments of Lisztian bravura and incandescent pianism of enormous technical difficulty.Bottom line: Hurlstone's Piano Sonata is not ground-breaking, but it's a fine work of Brahmsian trappings; the slow movement is sumptuous. Bebbington's performance, while markedly slower, displays a degree of nuance not communicated by Fujimura. I can only look askance at the Dale Sonata, which for all its superficial bluster and gargantuan length, left me cold.

The death of William Hurlstone (1876-1906) may have robbed Britain of a promising young composer. His best compositions are the fine Piano Concerto, Piano Quartet, and Piano Trio. Hurlstone is not quite the budding genius as suggested by Vaughan Williams and Stanford. The music world suffered a greater loss from the premature deaths of Stanchinsky, Lekeu, Reubke, and Tausig. Hurlstone is not in their league. While this recording of his complete piano music is nice for completists, the quality is extremely uneven.As much as the liner notes wishes to convince us that these pieces are not mediocre juvenilia, many of them do betray a navet of youth. The Five Easy Waltzes, for example, were written when Hurlstone was just 9 and are curiosities at best. Compared to Korngold's preadolescent works, they are decidedly below the level of trifles. The Sketches are similarly innocuous, displaying Hurlstone's momentary fascination with all things classical in aesthetic. Indeed, most are cheerful Mozartian dances; cute and light-hearted. The "Hungarian Air with Variations" has Brahmsian vitality and gestures, but lacks expressive invention and variety. The "Demon's Dance" is more interesting, sounding like an Alkan esquisse with its quirky gurgling bass figure. Of the transcriptions, the Heller Tarantelle is the most striking. Confident and energetic, it has a memorable climbing melody and imaginative harmony. With the Five Miniatures, Hurlstone improves himself. These are all charming and possess fetching melodic ideas. 'La Simplicite' was a favorite of Hurlstone's to play in concert, but I liked the fifth 'Alla Mazurka' for its successful emulation of a Chopin waltz.Hurlstone's best solo piano works are the "Capriccio in B minor" and the "Piano Sonata in F minor." The Capriccio is an effective concert piece, brimming with full-blooded Brahmsian sonorities and rhythmic drive. The material alternates between lilting repose and extroverted drama; the last minute of the piece is a fiery cadenza of great bravura. Hurlstone manifestly poured his best ideas into the Piano Sonata, which is clothed in the accoutrements of Schumann and Brahms. The first movement has all the requisite elements of a good Sonata-Allegro: well-wrought serious and lyrical themes with an engaging development and dramatic coda. In the second movement, heavily steeped in Brahms, Hurlstone exhibits startling expressive depth and passion with a central section of real power and emotion. Had he continued writing like this, he would have made a great mark in the British music world. The finale is more in line with Schumann: fast, energetic, and urgent.Kenji Fujimura generates tremendous sonorities and plays the Sonata much faster than Mark Bebbington, who first recorded it. I don't know which is the more appropriate interpretation, but Fujimura's passion and momentum made a greater impression on me. If you're interested in Hurlstone's Piano Sonata, this is the better recording because Fujimura plays so well and I didn't find much value in Benjamin Dale's Sonata, which is coupled with Hurlstone's on the Bebbington recording.Bottom line: I have to be honest and say that most of these pieces are pleasant juvenilia without much substance. However, the Capriccio and Sonata are excellent specimens of British Romantic piano music influenced by Schumann and Brahms.

Judging by these piano works and some of his chamber music, Karl Weigl (1881-1949) is deservedly marginalized as a composer. What I've heard of his music--I can't speak for his orchestral output--sounds conservative, melodically stale, and lacking in creativity. Except for the "Isle of the Dead" and some of the Night Fantasies, these pieces are benign and forgettable. In a way, the opening Six Fantasies (1942) are a sad testament to a failed composer. They were written after Weigl fled Nazi-occupied Austria and emigrated to the United States. None of these amount to anything special or beyond the tonal territory of Schumann, Brahms, or Pfitzner. The third "Remembrance" has some melancholic depth and there's heightened chromaticism and passion in the "Capriccio." It is not surprising that Weigl couldn't make a name for himself in the States after publishing these trifles. Similarly, most of the Pictures and Tales (1909), an early set of miniatures, are buoyant but unremarkable. However, I liked "Once Upon a Time" for its lovely theme over a dreamy and magical accompaniment. This piece works, but my high hopes for the rest of the cycle were dashed. "Dance of the Furies" (1938) is disappointing, too. Despite the inventive rhythm and dissonant colors, it doesn't offer much drama or excitement.With the Night Fantasies (1911), Weigl shows some talent. I wish he had continued composing in this vein of serious nocturnal brooding and daring chromaticism. "Langsam" is quite good: anxious, dark, and stormy arpeggios underlining very expressive harmonic progressions. Likewise, "Unruhig, dransend" has the indelible stamp of late Liszt: dark rumbling bass sonorities, anxious chromaticism and palpable tension. "Zart bewegt" continues the severity of the previous pieces and has a Slavic temperament. Weigl's best work is the "Isle of the Dead" (1903). Like Rachmaninov, Weigl was inspired by one of Bocklin's paintings of the same name. Many qualities are revealed in this 13-minute work, although it's not as effective as Rachmaninov's. It opens quietly and in a fit of despondence with piano writing confined to the lower registers. This moody and somber piece doesn't evoke Charon's oars for me, unlike Rachmaninov's, but there is a haunted atmosphere to it with intense Wagnerian climaxes that I enjoyed.Unlike the other reviewer, I have no qualms with Joseph Banowetz's interpretations. The problem is the uninspired music, not the performer.Bottom line: I think my 3-star rating is fair because more than half of these piano pieces are unremarkable and I'll never listen to them again. Yet there are two very good works here: the "Isle of the Dead" and the "Night Fantasies." I recommend them to those who enjoy serious and chromatic music resembling late Liszt, Mahler, and early Schoenberg. Everything else is in a conservative Romantic style and has few redeeming features.

Afshin Jaberi (b. 1973) won't be familiar to many of us in the West. I don't know about his reputation elsewhere. What he offers through his compositions shows promise, but not the kind of substance and expressive ideas I'd revisit again. Stylistically, he strives for an East-meets-West aesthetic: a tonal framework of Chopin, Liszt, and Rachmaninov with Middle Eastern inflections and modal scales. There are some fine moments of rich sonorous piano writing and passion, but Jaberi's melodic and harmonic ideas are a little stale. Only a couple movements from his sonatas piqued my interest. I think the problem is Jaberi's insistence on safe and conventional Romanticism without much dissonant bite. I also wonder if he's all that capable of generating majestic or awe-inspiring music based on his Bah' faith. Even if that's where he gets his inspiration, it's not communicated very well. Liszt could produce a dramatic and profound portrait of St. Francis of Assisi through musical suggestion. Jan Niederle does it also with his stunning Piano Sonata based on St. Francis. But I had a flat reaction to Jaberi's evocations of The Bb, the founder of the Bah' religion.The First Sonata "The Seeker" is a good effort, passionately neo-Romantic with thick writing, but the melodic ideas are wanting. It's a little bit like watered-down Chopin and Rachmaninov. I'll grant the second movement has a lovely theme. In the third movement, there is also a fine amalgam of Middle Eastern colors and Lisztian arpeggiations and block chords. The Second Sonata "The Path to Peace" was a disappointment. Described as an expression of the horrors of war, the opening movement is not convincing. I expected something intense, dark, and powerful. Jaberi doesn't express anything remotely close to that. I suppose the rest of the sonata is a message of hope, but it is awfully maudlin and New Agey. The Third Sonata "The Bedouin" fares a little better but is mostly generic Romanticism by-the-numbers. Only the second movement shows some inspiration; it's darker, serious, and has appealing harmonic sequences. The final movement is strangely Bluesy and improvisatory.The Ballades are of lesser quality than the Sonatas, which doesn't bode well. Each has a dramatic subtitle that the music fails to evoke. These Ballades are quite improvisatory in nature, with chaotic ideas, rambling passages, and not much strength in melody or harmonic interest. The "Eroica" Ballade features lots of activity, stentorian chords, and impressionist whirls of notes, but little depth. Some odd choices of embellishment and passagework confused me, like the vapid simultaneous ascending and descending chromatic scale for no apparent reason.Bottom line: Fans of boisterous and sentimental neo-Romanticism may like this music. Jaberi occasionally stumbles onto charming and compelling ideas. I liked the First Sonata and the slow movement of the Third; I'll give him that. But his emotional sensibility is too histrionic and sanguine for me. His sense of pictorial narrative is not persuasive and neither are his melodic lines very special. There are so many better composers out there writing powerful and electrifying neo-Romantic piano music: Carl Vine, Heather Schmidt, Stephane Blet, Jan Niederle, John Pickard, and Lera Auerbach.

When asked to name the best pianists of his generation, Rachmaninov replied "Well, there's Hofmann and there's me." Though widely acknowledged as one of the greatest pianists of all time, few realize Josef Hofmann composed. He left behind a modest oeuvre of piano music extending roughly to opus 60. Artem Yasynskyy recorded a volume of Hofmann's piano music, which complements this one. A couple Hofmann pieces appeared on the great Kaleidoscope recording by Marc-Andre Hamelin, which I highly recommend. The trouble with Hofmann's piano music is that's so uneven, which is why it's usually scattered across recital programs or recordings of piano rolls.Quite surprising for a pianist of Godowskyan technique, many of Hofmann's early pieces sound conventionally Romantic and no more adventurous than Schumann and Liszt. "Ungarish" and "Polnisch" are of average salon stock written when Hofmann was very young. The "Impromptu" stands out for its rippling Schumanessque figurations and melodic dash. There is also a startling sequence of flurries that sound reminiscent of Alkan's "Scherzo diabolico." I had high hopes for Hofmann's preludes, but only a couple have merit, particularly the dramatic A minor and dark E minor, the latter being the best of the set; a memorable elegy of throbbing pathos and Lisztian gestures. As for the "Valse Caprice," it may be a mature work with a lovely Johann Straussian tune, but it is wholly innocuous salon material.Later on Hofmann's compositions would incorporate impressionist colors and display greater sophistication. The four "Character Sketches", for example, deserve revival in the concert hall. The opening 'Vision' has the flavor of Rachmaninov and early Scriabin. Suffused with rich and luminous washes of delicate arpeggiation, this is hyper-impressionism with remarkable depth. 'Nenien' is Slavic in character with a somber melody supported by a gentle arpeggiated accompaniment. 'Kaleidoscop' is a miniature masterpiece with astonishing piano writing and dazzling colors. Dedicated to Godowsky, the piece has all the technical demands and vigor of an etude. Busy and dramatic flurries of figurations surround a ravishing Lisztian theme. This is how you write an exciting concert piece. Biasini's performance is adequate, but not as satisfying as Yasynskyy's or Hamelin's. Her rhythm is rigid, mechanical, and her sonorities lack resonance. Hamelin's is the best performance, achieving a perfect tempo and grandeur that surpasses the others.The two "Impressions" are outstanding and need to be heard more often as encores. The first lives up to its subtitle "L'Orient et l'Occiden," featuring an exotic pentatonic melody and sonorous impressionism redolent of Debussy's Sunken Cathedral. More famous is the second Impression "The Sanctuary", a great piece of virtuosity and etude-like writing characterized by Ravelian figurations and a passionate Rachmaninovian melodic line. This is the kind of piece that can sound too "notey" in the wrong hands and it needs full-blooded passion. Biasini does her best, but her persistent staccato touch and stilted rhythm detract a little from the aural experience. I prefer Hofmann's own recording and piano roll, but we need someone like Hamelin to do this piece justice.Bottom line: Hofmann's "Character Pieces" are gems and should be encores in the standard repertoire. I prefer the more intense performances and fluid rhythms of Artem Yasynskyy. The two Impressions are Hofmann's finest jewels, but the interpretations are wanting. Hofmann's own playing of "The Sanctuary" is far superior to what Biasini does with it. The remaining content is nice to have, all world-premiere recordings, but much of it uneven. Therefore, this is a half-hearted recommendation for completists. Kaleidoscope and Yasynskyy's volume are the better alternatives.

When asked to name the best pianists of his generation, Rachmaninov replied "Well, there's Hofmann and there's me." Though widely acknowledged as one of the greatest pianists of all time, few realize Josef Hofmann composed. He left behind a modest oeuvre of piano music extending roughly to opus 60. Fabiana Biasini recorded a volume of Hofmann's piano music, which complements this one. A couple Hofmann pieces appeared on the great Kaleidoscope recording by Marc-Andre Hamelin, which I highly recommend. The trouble with Hofmann's piano music is that it's so uneven, which is why it's usually scattered across recital programs or recordings of piano rolls. Quite surprising for a pianist of Godowskyan technique, many of his early pieces sound conventionally Romantic and no more adventurous than Schumann and Liszt. Later on his compositions would incorporate impressionist colors and display greater sophistication.The four "Character Sketches" constitute Hofmann's best effort and deserve revival in the concert hall. The opening 'Vision' has the flavor of Rachmaninov and early Scriabin. Suffused with rich and luminous washes of delicate arpeggiation, this is hyper-impressionism with remarkable depth. 'Nenien' is Slavic in character with a somber melody supported by a gentle arpeggiated accompaniment. 'Kaleidoscop' is a miniature masterpiece with astonishing piano writing and dazzling colors. Dedicated to Godowsky, the piece has all the technical demands and vigor of an etude. Busy and dramatic flurries of figurations surround a ravishing Lisztian theme. This is how you write an exciting and melodic concert piece. Artem Yasynskyy gives a fine performance, more fluid and confident than Biasini's, but not up to par with Hamelin's, which is faster, effortless, and more powerful.The "Etude for Left Hand" is a stunning and effective concert piece, totally serious in mood and rhythmically thrilling. The lush arpeggios and dramatic arc bear kinship with Rachmaninov and especially Liszt. At times, the music so completely echoes Liszt that it sounds like it came from the Years of Pilgrimage. Hofmann's "Piano Sonata in F major" is an early work thoroughly tinged with the influence of Schumann. Its textures and structure are transparent and classical. Nothing too fascinating here, but the second movement is an enjoyable perpetuum mobile in which the styles of Beethoven and Schumann coalesce. The finale is lighthearted with rondo episodes having more in common with Liszt's bravura than Schumann.The "Theme with Variations & Fugue" is less impressive than I hoped, even though nothing about it suggests the authorship of a 16-year-old. Frankly, it is not that striking. Hofmann is restrained, quiet, and lyrical, but there's not much variation in the mood or texture. The fugue is extroverted and interesting, but far too short. Likewise, the three Chopinesque mazurkas are slight and forgettable, although the D minor has superior melodic ideas.Bottom line: Hofmann's "Character Pieces" are gems and should be encores in the standard repertoire. The Etude for Left Hand is also spectacular and highly effective. The rest is of lesser worth, although agreeable listening if you like Schumann and Liszt. If you haven't heard Hamelin's Kaleidoscope, listen to that first. If you like what you hear, seek out Hofmann playing his other wonderful piece "The Sanctuary." For those torn between Artem Yasynskyy and Fabiana Biasini, I'll just point out that Yasynskyy is more passionate and rhythmically fluid.

BIS has made it their quest to record the output of Finnish composer Kalevi Aho (b. 1949), who has garnered much acclaim in Europe. The bulk of his compositions are large-scale symphonies and concerti, so this present release of short piano pieces is a surprise. Unless the works list in New Grove's is incomplete, this recording contains all of Aho's solo piano works to date. A wide contrast of styles are on display here. The 19 Preludes are as tonal and gushingly Romantic as Schumann and Liszt while the atonal Solo II and Piano Sonata bear kinship with Sorabji and Corigliano. Quite a traversal of aesthetic growth.Aho's Nineteen Preludes (1965-68) are an impressive set of neo-Romantic miniatures. It is astounding to realize that these are student works, some written when he was just 16. Each are consistently imaginative and mature, exhibiting a variety of moods, textures, and technical difficulties. Some (1, 3, 14) dwell in a lovely realm of warmth and lyricism, redolent of Mendelssohn's Songs Without Words. Others (4, 7, 10) have the pianistic excitement and dramatic verve of Schumann and Liszt. Aho adopts Bachian counterpoint in nos. 13 and 16, the latter being conspicuously modeled on a Bach invention. Then there's a couple highly expressive preludes of a gloomy disposition. No. 5 marked "Grave" sounds like late Liszt, possessing a haunting oscillating chromatic figure, stern tritones, and menacing lower bass writing. No. 17 is special: modern, troubled, and frightening in its evocation of a nightmare. The labyrinthine chromaticism suggests a spiraling anxiety and feelings of being trapped; so effective and feverish, it reminds me of Feinberg's morbid Scriabinesque pieces.Although constituting less than four minutes of music altogether, the Three Small Piano Pieces (1971) are not trifles. They are atonal, severe, and expressionist. The 2-minute "Maestoso" piece packs a lot of punch with its booming bass sonorities and accumulation of drama. "Tranquillo" is a hypnotic Feldmanesque dreamworld, highly chromatic and mysterious; a perfect distillation of music in the space of a minute. How effective can a 33-second piece be? Aho demonstrates just how in the outer "Maestoso", a fast and violent volcanic outburst of expressionism, tritones, and chromatic intensity. "Wow" was my reaction after hearing it. The Sonatina (1993) is another disarmingly powerful work, fully atonal with tone clusters and shocks of dissonance. Rich sonorities and frenzied energy infuse the outer movements, the last of which has Bartokian rhythmic bite.I happen to think the Solo II (1985) is Aho's greatest piano work, although pianist Sonja Frki reserves that judgment for the Sonata. This is serious and tough music of fiendish difficulty, boasting some astonishing passages of evocative Romantic gestures and pianistic activity. Indeed, Aho ratchets up the piano writing with cascading swirls of notes and sonorous textures requiring a level of strength, stamina, and alacrity that would confound many concert pianists. If I had to make aesthetic comparisons, I hear Corigliano's Etude Fantasy, Ronald Stevenson, George Flynn, and towards the end Messiaen. The Sonata (1980) inhabits the same soundworld as Solo II, but this time incorporates Sorabjian arpeggios, glissandi, and violent tone clusters, all utilized in an aim for expression and not merely sonic effect. Messiaen is recalled again in the final movement, which slowly fades into mysterious higher registers and whispering trills.This is my first encounter with Sonja Frki, but she is one to watch: a virtuoso with a faultless technique and expressive range. She handles the variegated features of Aho's piano music with commanding facility, from the emotional and lyrical content of the preludes to the cerebral and technical complexity of the Piano Sonata. BIS sound engineering is always impeccable and some would argue the best around today.Bottom line: I can see why MusicWeb International made this their 'Recording of the Month.' I haven't even heard Aho's orchestral music, but I can tell from these piano works that he's a first-class composer. There's not a dull piece on here. The 19 Preludes will appeal to fans of neo-Romantic piano music in the tradition of Chopin, Schumann, and Liszt. Those who like Berg, Prokofiev, and Bartok will enjoy his Small Pieces and Sonatina. The Solo II and Piano Sonata are his best works: atonal but accessible, very intense, and arresting.

Adolf Jensen (1837-1879) had a glowing reputation for lyricism. Perhaps that was evident in his nearly 200 songs, but judging from these piano works, he had no better facility with lyricism than Raff, Scharwenka, or Anton Rubinstein. And they were better composers. For me, Jensen is on the lower end of mediocrity. His piano pieces are all innocuous and inhabit a pan-European Romantic soundworld that incorporates Schumann, Chopin, and Liszt. But they don't have any outstanding features or memorable content, aside from the Deutsche Suite, which I'll get to later. Most of this is ear popcorn: pleasant and occasionally enjoyable, but unfulfilling. This is the best summation of Jensen's worth I've read: "[He] was essentially a song-writer; his musical expression seldom reached great emotional heights, and yet there was so much charm and delicacy in his conceptions." (from the preface of a 1915 edition of Galatea)I like the idea of Erotikon, a suite of pieces based on erotic quotations from Greek mythology. However, the music is underwhelming and seems to have very little relation to the titles. "Elektra," for example, is baffling in its restraint and ordinary Romantic mood. No angst or turmoil to be found, whereas the symbolists always appropriated the darker themes of her tragedy. "Kassandra" and "Kypris" are rather muted in effect. I expected more passion and sensual abandon here. "Eros" is better because there's palpable drama and extroverted activity. "Die Zauberin" is the best of the lot for its effective fusion of Schumannesque poetry with a serious Lisztian attitude.The Deutsche Suite is a much more interesting work. Here Jensen shows talent for composing in an energetic and entirely neo-Baroque fashion. The "Courante" is brimming with fetching melodic content and vitality. The "Sarabande" is suffused with Bachian poignancy and noble expression; this is Jensen's best effort. There's also an admirable quality in the "Gigue" with fugal writing that sounds like Bach or Handel transcribed by a Romantic.Reger's arrangements of three songs didn't stand out for me enough to comment. I'm not sure what he saw in them. Only the first of the two Romanzes struck me as something special, revealing depth, inspired melody, and pianistic figurations redolent of Liszt and Thalberg.As always, Toccata Classics offers the most substantial liner notes after the Altarus label. This time, however, the notes are laden with academic music analysis that only readers with five semesters of music theory will understand.Bottom line: This isn't bad music; it's just not likely to encourage repeated listenings. Godowsky provided fingerings for an edition of Erotikon, so I'm sure pianists (and singers) have found value in some of Jensen's output, but as a listener, I'm unmoved. Only the neo-Baroque spirit of the Deutsche Suite grabbed my attention. A couple of the Erotikon pieces and the first Romanze also have merit. This recording is for collectors of third-tier piano literature. All others should first explore Raff, Rubinstein, Henselt, and Heller.

Here is an unusual and welcome program of music for violin and piano by two major figures of the Soviet avant-garde of the 1920s. Grigori Krein (1879-1955) is not as well-known as his brother, Alexander, but was a prominent member of the New Jewish School that emerged in Russia. Krein studied briefly under Reger, but found no inspiration from the German pedagogue; evidently, he often galled Reger during classes. Instead he found his path following the footsteps of Scriabin.Krein's 20-minute Violin Sonata (1913) is a rapturous and sublime specimen of Scriabinesque effusions and ecstatic harmonies. Both piano and violin are equally important; take one away and the music still works. The opening "Andante" is a slow burn of mystic tension and languid chromaticism, awash with a sultry decadent atmosphere reminiscent of Roslavets. The movement leads right into the second, a much faster and lengthier allegro. Tritones, flutters of trills, and lush swirls of colors suggest at times Vers la Flamme. There's a strong melodic drive and rhythmic interest, too, that makes this sonata worth revisiting. This is Scriabinesque chamber music done right. The Poeme (1921) is in the same lavish soundworld minus the dark intensity of the sonata. Here post-Romantic lyricism and lush violin writing prevails; it's similar in style to Szymanowski and Catoire. I won't say much about the two short Pieces on Yakutian Themes. These slight and rather pointless works are sad examples of how socialist realism can neuter a composer's creativity.Connoisseurs of Russian modernists should be familiar with the music of Samuil Feinberg (1890-1962), whose piano sonatas are just a peg below the quality of Scriabin's. Yet most pianophiles think of him solely as a pianist and transcriber. By the time he composed his Violin Sonata No. 2 (1955), he had already succumbed to the hammer blows of socialist realism. This recording does not acknowledge that Feinberg wrote an earlier violin sonata, which was published as an "Allegro and scherzo" (1922). I would much rather hear that, although to be fair, Feinberg was so talented that even his conservative works have glimmers of import. This violin sonata is like a 5-movement suite. It opens with a neo-Baroque "Prelude" with slow contrapuntal activity, which has flashes of brilliance and showcases Feinberg's penchant for density and nervous harmony. The "Intermezzo" is a delectable little piece of melancholy, featuring a lovely violin theme. Only in the fourth movement does Feinberg assert his old self. It is packed with melodic energy, dramatic piano writing, and gestures one can hear in his piano sonatas. Then in the final "Epilog", Feinberg gets weird on us with an incoherent mish-mash of ideas. It starts out in a mood of disquietude and then erupts into buoyant exuberance. Out of nowhere a simply gorgeous violin line breaks through, followed by a turbulent and agitated conclusion. A schizophrenic finale to say the least.I am always impressed by the performances of Michael Schafer and Ilona-Then Bergh, who are one of the finest violin and piano duos recording today. Each have a remarkable command of technique and expressive power. They also have an affinity for the Scriabinesque, which is demonstrated over and over. I must shamelessly promote their recording of Leonid Sabaneyev's piano trios, the last of which I believe ranks among the greatest piano trios of the 20th century.Bottom line: Krein's Violin Sonata is a significant work brimming with languorous and feverish sonorities; a rewarding discovery for fans of Scriabin, Roslavets, and Szymanowski. Feinberg's is also interesting but uneven and not likely to impress those already familiar with his piano music.

The great Violin Sonata and Piano Quintet notwithstanding, it is easy to forget that Cesar Franck wrote other exceptional pieces of chamber music. His piano trios as a whole have been relatively neglected and high-caliber performances of them are hard to come by. If you're interested in acquiring a single recording of Franck's piano trios, I recommend the Trio Novanta performance, which is more fiery and intense. However, this 2-volume Chandos series with the Bekova sisters is a close second.Coming off the heels of the highly dramatic and dark first piano trio, Franck's second Piano Trio in B-flat major (1841) is less interesting. Its major key and subtitle "Trio de salon" implies something more frivolous, but that's not altogether true; there's some depth and the occasional passionate climax. While the work is lighter and a little nave, there's nothing wrong with its warmth and elegance, especially when good melodies are on display. I particularly enjoyed the second movement, in which the cello and violin take turns carrying a strong lyrical line above a waltzing piano accompaniment. The Bekova sisters are masterful at shaping phrases and infuse the trio with infectious energy.With the Piano Trio No. 3 in B minor, Franck returns to the turbulent soundscape of his first trio. Passion and urgency reign supreme here. The opening movement is thoroughly riveting, containing a wealth of ideas and strong thematic material. Pronounced tension and rich sonorous piano writing add to the drama. The second movement features a stunningly beautiful theme marked by tenderness and a sad nostalgia, which is disrupted by a central section march of gleeful character; a very catchy little march, by the way. The finale possesses some remarkably thick piano writing and rhythmic drive, touching on a variety of moods, at first sober and meditative and ultimately triumphant and defiant.Franck's last Piano Trio, ostensibly No. 4 in B minor, was originally the finale of his third trio, which would have been colossal in scale as a result. At the behest of Liszt, who felt the 18-minute movement was too long, Franck published it as a separate piano trio in its own right. I disagree with this decision and like to think of it as the true finale to the third trio. At any rate, this single-movement trio is comprised of many sections of contrasting moods, from lyrical warmth and introspection to Alkan-like perpetuum mobile and tempestuous Lisztian passages. This is essentially a Beethovenian voyage from darkness to light.Bottom line: These are three engaging piano trios, barely known to even chamber enthusiasts. The minor-key trios are the most gripping, each having memorable content and exciting harmonic turns. The Bekova sisters are a formidable ensemble on par with and often surpassing the Trio Novanta's performances of Franck's trios.

The great Violin Sonata and Piano Quintet notwithstanding, it is easy to forget that Cesar Franck wrote other exceptional pieces of chamber music. His piano trios as a whole have been relatively neglected and high-caliber performances of them are hard to come by. If you're interested solely in acquiring a recording of Franck's piano trios, I recommend the Trio Novanta performance, which is overall superior. A close second would be the Bekova sisters on Chandos (Vol. 1, Vol. 2). With that said, this present recording is still enjoyable and offers two of Franck's early works for violin and piano, both of solid quality.Despite its relative obscurity, Franck's Piano Trio No. 1 in F-sharp minor should be in the standard repertoire. It easily outclasses the more famous trios of Smetana and Chausson. I can't understand why this trio has been recorded so infrequently. Take it from D'Indy: "With its budding genius, this trio marks an epoch in the history of musical evolution." Composed in 1841 when Franck was just 19, the trio is a weighty and passionate affair, exhibiting expressive momentum, stormy passages, and engaging thematic material. Quite remarkable for its date, the trio is cyclical at a time when cyclic form was only hinted at by Beethoven and not crystallized yet by Liszt in his B minor sonata. The trio opens rather ominously with a foreboding staccato motto theme, which should be as famous and recognizable as any classical tune. The first movement is an exercise in a slow boil of intensity that gradually builds until exploding with tempestuous outbursts and virtuosic piano writing. The second scherzo movement overflows with toe-tapping rhythms and engaging activity. In the final movement, Franck delivers a wallop of power and drive with a rolling piano accompaniment, soaring violin lines, chromatic octaves, and a forceful return of the motto theme. It is no wonder Liszt loved the work. Note that the performers take a slower pace and lack urgency and dynamic risk-taking. Trio Novanta plays with more fire and wild abandon, especially in the piano part.Coming off the heels of that first piano trio, Franck's second Piano Trio in B-flat major (1841) lacks potency. Its major key and subtitle "Trio de salon" and implies something more frivolous, but that's not altogether true. While the work is warm, elegant, and boasts good melodies, there are some degrees of depth and the occasional passionate climax. I particularly enjoyed the second movement, in which the cello and violin take turns carrying a strong lyrical line above a waltzing piano accompaniment. Here I think the performers do just fine, although Trio Novanta and the Bekova sisters are better-equipped at shaping phrases.The remaining pieces for violin and piano are delightful. The rarely-recorded "Grand Fantasy on themes from Dalayrac's Gulistan" is worth hearing if you like operatic fantasies. Franck selects a couple fetching themes from Gulistan, an 18th century opera by the totally obscure Nicolas Dalayrac (1753-1809). This 12-minute fantasy features lovely violin lines and an extroverted piano part with tremolos, arpeggios, and stern chords. The Andantino Quietoso (1843) is a major step-up in quality. Although an early work, it foreshadows Franck's later spiritual preoccupations. This tender and moving piece exhibits strong thematic material and a loftier degree of serious expression, with profound harmonies and a great agonized yearning in the violin line. This is just exquisite violin music.Bottom line: While Trio Novanta and the Bekova sisters offer better performances of the first Franck trio, the present recording is very satisfying. Of particular value are the two violin and piano works, especially the Andantino Quietoso.

Yevhen Stankovych (b. 1942) is a Ukrainian composer closely aligned with the Soviet avant-garde of the 1960s and 70s, which included Silvestrov, Schnittke, Gubaidulina, and Denisov. Judging from these three symphonies, Stankovych deserves to be listed with that group. His music is not as great as Schnittke's, but there's a similarity of expressive palette, consistently dark and serious, evoking a bleak and troubled world.The Symphony No. 1 'Sinfonia Larga' (1973) is scored for 15 string soloists and has all the aesthetic trappings of Ligeti and Penderecki: tone clusters, glissandi, polyphonic layers of humming and shrieking strings, and ethereal sonorities of sweltering colors. Although atonal, the music has a tragic, introspective, and horrified air about it, like Penderecki's Threnody for the Victims of Hiroshima. Yet it's not as discordant and harsh on the ears as this. Despite the clusters of sound, Stankovych creates a texture of neo-Baroque polyphony over a pedal point in which many shifts in harmony occur. The strings carry intense and haunting melodic lines that help make this powerful single-movement symphony rewarding on repeated listenings. Somewhat similar in idiom is the 26-minute Symphony No. 4 'Sinfonia Lirica' (1977), again scored for strings and composed as a single-movement work. Here Stankovych aims for a post-Bergian expressionist tonal soundworld, somewhat comparable to Schnittke; not quite astringently atonal, but certainly pushing the tonal boundaries to an extreme. Once again, Stankovych achieves his tremendous emotional tension and colors through layers of chromatic lines, pedal points, and clusters of chords. This is dark and uneasy music with broad melodic lines, painful and moving in their expressivity, which the liner notes compares to "Scriabin's mellow lyricism."Less compelling for my tastes, but not bad by any measure, is the Symphony No. 2 "Heroic", which diverges significantly from the others. Cast in three movements, it is scored for full orchestra, features a prominent percussion section with snare drums, and even a piano. The symphony was written as an anti-war protest and the opening movement has a more declamatory and extroverted character, although it is still disturbed and angst-ridden. The highlight of the symphony is the second movement, in my view. Conceived as a requiem for the war dead, it opens with actual tolling bells and sustains a creepy quietude, interrupted by lyrical woodwind and brass solos and sudden waves of grief in the strings. The terse 3-minute third movement provides an apocalyptic capstone to the whole work; surely this is a commentary on the nature of man and his doomed propensity for war.Bottom line: The First and Fourth Symphonies for strings are gripping and powerful pieces of music, full of anxiety, horror, and tension. If you like Ligeti and early Penderecki, you'll really enjoy them. Compared to these, the Second 'Heroic' Symphony is more dramatic and violent, although the profound central movement is a respite of quiet melancholy. Lovers of Penderecki or Soviet avant-garde orchestral music need not hesitate.

Mykola Lysenko (1842-1912) is said to be the father of Ukrainian classical music and a leading proponent of the instrumental dumka genre. I think Lysenko is more interesting from a musicological point of view. His achievements as an ethnographer and collector of Ukrainian folk song are profoundly important. Yet I struggle to hear any outstanding qualities in his music. Judging from this disc and the companion Toccata Classics release of piano music, Lysenko's output is uneven and mediocre. Most of it is sedate, limited in expressive range, and lacks melodic and harmonic interest. His style is heavily influenced by Chopin and Liszt, but comes off as generic Romanticism with a tinge of exotic color.These violin works are mostly in a Biedermeier salon style and quite forgettable. One problem I have with Lysenko's approach to this medium is that he gives the violin part too much prominence, reducing the piano accompaniment to an obbligato or continuo role. At first I thought this was because the piano was not adequately miked and thus Solomia Soroka drowns out her husband, Arthur Greene. I'm not sure how to account for this, whether Soroka is playing too forcefully, the mics are too close to the violin, or it's simply the nature of Lysenko's texture that the violin is always paramount and the accompaniment superfluous except when it underpins the harmony. All of this would be fine if Lysenko's violin writing was tuneful and had dramatic impetus.The "Rhapsody on Ukrainian Themes" has an enticing Ukrainian folk flavor, but the violin writing is underwhelming. The "Elegiac Capriccio" is more "capriccio" than elegiac. Even when Lysenko sets out to be serious in a minor key, he can't help sounding sunny and warm. A buoyant and energetic violin part saves the "Fantasy on 2 Ukrainian Themes," which is packed with more inspired ideas. The best piece, I think, is the little "Romance" because of its affecting and memorable melody, not to mention superior voice-leading. I have to question Lysenko's depth of sensibility in a piece like "A Moment of Despair." I heard not a whiff of despair in this miniature. It's stylized, more reflective than doleful, and too consonant to really suggest genuine sorrow.Bottom line: Half way through the second playing of the disc I got bored and antsy to listen to something more substantial. It's a shame because I really enjoy Soroka's tone and her passionate playing. Her interpretations of the Roslavets violin sonatas, for example, are masterful and authoritative. Fans of violin literature may like this recording, but I don't think Lysenko's music is rewarding.
