Use time in order to trickle in your investments.Trading Pocket helps to alleviate your brain's response to either panic when the market goes down, or become greedy when the market goes up. With this account, you can go ahead and make concentrated bets on stocks."Source: Information taken from "The Safe Investor" by Timothy F. McCarthy, published by Palgrave Macmillan, 2014.  * * *McCarthy believes that  understanding  how to create  a  truly globally  diverse portfolio while applying the magic of time will help all investors navigate risky markets. He writes that U.S. investors often neglect foreign investments out of fear and ignorance.McCarthy  also explores the fundamentals of picking and evaluating financial advisors for those who want to understand the principles of investing but not actually do the work themselves.McCarthy  helps guide the reader along a straightforward  path to investment  success by telling engaging and actual stories to illustrate each of his seven lessons of successful investing. "The Safe Investor" will help even those readers with little interest or aptitude for finance to be comfortable in knowing what to do to manage their life investment plan and how to manage their own advisors.To show the kind of humor McCarthy uses, take a look at his "Trickle In, Trickle Out" anecdote on Pages 106-7:"Some people will know at least the 'trickle in' part of the formula by its traditional name, 'Dollar Cost Averaging.' I used to use that phrase until an evening meeting years ago  when a well-dressed woman in her mid-60s said, 'Please  forgive me for being so upfront, but none of my friends understood what in God's name you mean by this 'dollar cost averaging' thing....After showing them on a sheet of paper how just putting in a little in every year really decreases your risk over time, one gentleman exclaimed, 'Oh, you just tinkle in a little money at a time!" His wife interrupted and said, 'George, I think you mean trickle, not tinkle. It's a bit more genteel.'With anecdotes like this, and with the puppy his mother promised him at the age of three -- an anecdote that really broke me up! -- I found "The Safe Investor" to be an exception to my "MEGO" rule.

I usually run the TLR-HL's on my long guns, but I was looking for a Laser for my new AR Pistol with only 7" of rail space,  so both space and weight were critical. Though I could buy a more compact laser only, my experience with the highly reliable and intuitive switches of the Streamlight TLR products kept me in the family. As much as I really would like a higher powered TLR2-HL version of the light/laser combo, at 3 times the price, weight and size, I can definitely live with the lower output light (the AR Pistol is a CQB/Home Defense weapon, so it's all within 20 yards for me).For either a home defense handgun, shotgun, or AR Pistol, nothing can currently touch the value of the TLR4 with Laser: just enough light, a good red laser, and Streamlight's great switches make this a great, compact, value priced deal.
Works great as a replacement for 8way pigtails that come with CCD systems.

When they work, they work okay, and at a great price. Problem is, they are really failure prone. I've ordered 4 of them in the last 6 months. One of them works great, one of them failed after 4 months, and two of them were defective upon arrival (clipping sound). If you don't mind returning them if they arrive faulty, all good. If you need a reliable solution, this isn't it.
The most reliable and easy to install switch for activating remote door locks. I have over two dozen of them installed in high volume shops all throughout SoCal and have yet to have one fail.

Far better than equivalent products at Fry's, Depot, Etc, and at about half the price. Easy to install, and it is truly fully articulating and easy to do so with it. This is definitely my new goto for mounting PC monitors for my Camera system installs.

I have been using the Hammerhead grips for almost 10 years on my featureless builds. It feels a lot like thin, traditional stock (think Keltec SU-16, Air Rifle, etc.) It also "looks normal", if you just swap out the grips and forgo installing your stock on this and padding your buffer tube.These are quick and easy to install (and uninstall), just like a normal AR Grip. It comes with a quality stainless steel bolt and washer, and is as solid as any other AR Grip. I have tried using the plastic cap accessories for the rear buffertube hole, but these seem to fall out after a few rounds; id suggest gluing it in place with your critical spare bolt parts and pins and leave it until you need it.If you are new to Featureless builds: Swap this grip with your traditional one, then swap your flash hider with a muzzle break, then pin your stock (assuming you have an length-adjustable, carbine stock) using a thick wire (a large paperclip works great!) though the small hole in the release piston (works for most magpul stocks; for those without a magpul stock, just drill a hole though the entire piston release area, and run a thin bolt though it, and locktite the nut on it). Go check out Calguns for all the details on staying legal with featureless builds and your legacy, pre-ban "standard capacity" magazines.Molon Labe !

This is a well finished, well balanced, reasonably light weight springer air rifle. Easy to cock. Reasonably accurate out of the box (I am shooting 2" groups at 15 yards, standing offhand. I'm sure I could shoot half that or better from a bench, but where is the fun in that!) So far with 100 pellets down range on day one, I am really liking this suppressed carbine.  As others have mentioned, the scope is too short in order to get to the eyebox comfortably, but it is reasonably bright, tracks well, and can adjust down to zero at 15 yards without shimming the rear mount; decent enough to get by with at 15+ yards during the break-in period, and would probably be survivable if you have long arms (otherwise, plan on upgrading the scope to a full sized Leapers or Centerpoint after break-in). Under 15 yards the scope is blurry, as the parallax is set at 30 yards, which is where the manual says to zero it at. So it is not a very good scope for close range shooting. I adjusted the trigger's second stage screw down to it's minimum setting, which seems to be pretty good...not exactly like my Geissele SSA-E trigger on my LR308 CSASS rifle, but certainly better than my stock Ruger 10/22 trigger! I think I can live with this for a while, though like many owners, I'll probably upgrade the trigger to a GRT-III after break-in.Noise-wise, it's quiet enough, even when still dieseling, to shoot in my urban backyard. If it get's even quieter after break-in, great! If not, it's plenty quiet to shoot in the city without a 911 call.I think this is a great all-arounder, and considering the price and it's low noise level, I give it 5 Stars.

This is why you should buy this scope for your air rifle:1) Price. It's about half the price of most other quality, air-rifle Mil-Dot, AO Scope, and comes with decent rings.2) You don't plan on shooting past 25 yards. 4x magnification with Mil-dot is just fine for shooting air rifle precision within 25 yards. If you plan on shooting past that on a regular basis, consider going to a 2x7, 3x9 or 3x12 scope (especially if you are target shooting at that distance and need to use your scope for spotting your hits)3) You want light weight! a 3x9 or 3x12 leapers will cost you an extra 5-6oz in weight. If you plan on sitting and shooting, the weight doesn't make that much difference, but if you plan on stalking game in the field, every ounce counts! (Especially when you get a bit older, or for younger or female shooters). There are a few lower weight variable options; see below.4) If you are left handed, you will want an Objective-based parallax adjustment ring like this one, NOT a side adjustment knob, as the side knob is on the left hand side, which is horrible for making regular adjustments for left handed shooters.5) You can live without an illuminated reticle. The only time you would use illumination is at dusk or night, but it is not nearly as important when using a 4x fixed power scope like this, as it is considerably more low-light capable than a high variable power scope (practically speaking, if you are shooting a variable power at dusk/night, you will likely drop the power all the way down to 3x in order to get the largest "aperture" you can, in order to get more light). The 4x fixed has better low light capability than a 3-Xx variable power set at 3x. All things considered, I choose a better low light scope like this, without illumination, as I can almost always make out my reticle in lower light anyway.6) You don't mind returning the scope to Amazon if you get a Dead on Arrival (DOA) scope: like some of the reviewers have mentioned, the quality control consistency appears to be lacking... some are good, some are not. Skilled budget shoppers can handle returning a dud or two on Amazon's dime. My first one was good to go.The closest size/weight/price capable Mil-Dot AO Air Rifle scope I have found to this scope is the CenterPoint/Crossman 3-9x32, which is 2oz lighter and illuminated. I have used both and find the overall quality of this scope (and included rings) to be better than the Centerpoint.Biggest downside to this scope is the very tight eye-box and no variable eye-relief distance. Most of my higher-end scopes for powder rifles (Burris, Primary Arms) have a much larger area in which your can see though this scope both front to back and side to side. Not so with this scope: it requires a very precise eye placement to get a proper view though the scope. As an experienced shooter, I have no problem aligning this scope quickly, but for newer shooters, this could be a problem, and is somewhat annoying to me, (- 1 Star)

Great switch for high volume uses (ours 24 installed RCI switches at 12 locations for remote door jams see 5000 presses a month, and all have lasted, good as new, for 6 to over 12 months! Well worth the money to prevent a warranty dispatch for a faulty switch, which we had seen all the time until we swapped them all out to these. highly recommended for high volume business use, and lower volume uses that need high reliability, such as life-safety.
perfect for my M500A 18" with breacher barrel. Solid, lots padding; not flimzy.

I have been using the non-mic version of these for a year, and they have held up well. I was getting tired of re-charging by bluetooth headset so I figured I'd try this one with the mic... it works great! It shipped directly from the factory in the midwest, which took a few more days than the non-mic version would have taken... no big deal. It came in a sealed plastic tear-open bag with two other ear-bud options aside from the big ones shown here; a small one, which I much prefer since they stay in my ears very well, and and oblong pair, which I didn't even bother to try. When I plug them in, they are immediately recognized by the 4.x Android OS of my phone as both a headset and mic... all good! Volume is good, quality of mic sound is good as per my GF, and very little problem with wind noise, which was a BIG problem with my bluetooth headsets...winner!For the price, I don't see how you can beat the JBuds with the Mic for smart-phone use. Sometimes simple and cheap is better... in this case, it is true!

I picked this up to use for my 2002 XT225. I was concerned with some of the other versions I saw for sale around, which showed up to year 2000 (since my was 2002). probably no big deal, but I ordered this one since the seller stated that it is the "latest version"... and it was... 2003!If you are going to buy one new, you might well buy the one that goes to 2003, right? Probably more importantly than the actual years listed, are the publisher revisions. Unfortunately, the publisher doesn't use traditional revision methodology, so to ID the latest version, you are looking for the one that is Copyrighted 2013 or search for  ISBN 1620920654Happy Trails!

I've been running these and the matching center mat for about a year now on my 2004 F150 XLT and they are showing no signs of wear. They are comfortable, look good, soak up big spills and quite down the road noise a bit as well. if they ever wear out, I'll be going right back to these for a replacement!

This worked great as a swap for my 1997 Jeep Wrangler TJ 4-Cyl, which was throwing an O2 sensor code. Cleared it right up! It comes with a small packet of anti-sieze compound in the box, so use it! Oh, you do not need to use a specialty tool to remove/install this (which the manual states)... an open end wrench, or even an adjustable wrench will do just fine.

My house chicken loves these! I think the high protein brought her back from a serious disease as well! Now my dog is interested in them... just great! I spent five minutes going through all the dried meal-worm options that were Prime-Shipping eligible and these were not only the best price per ounce, but the smallest quantity and best brand name available... go with these! I order them every few weeks and they are always a consistent quality. ~ House-Chicken Recommended!

This is a direct fit for the Yamaha XT225. it came well packed, in good shape, with a fresh build date. Comes with the mounting screws and nuts to attach to your cables. Due to a carb problem on my bike, I managed to drain this battery down in the first few days. I recharged it at 2 Amps as an AGM battery overnight and it came right back to where it should be... all good! Why spend twice as much for one more amp-hour, or three times as much for a Lithium Ion battery? Go cheap, charge it if you drain it down, swap them out every three years or so and you will be good to go! Happy Trails!

A great solution for when I am changing over muzzle devices and don't want to let a barrel thread "just sit there", risking possible damage. It would also work great as semi-permenent solution on a parc'd & threaded .22LR barrel that might use either a solvent trap adapter or perhaps even a legal NFA device.

I wear XL gloves and while this pen works great as a uniform/duty-shirt pen, it becomes painful to write with for any length of time due to it being very thin at the grip area. I have found the Zebra F-701 to be far more comfortable to actually write with for any length of time, which is a shame, since the Jotter is far more elegant and attractive. So... the Jotter says in my shirt, the Zebra stays on my clipboard; problem solved! Code4

JT doesn't list this on their website for fitment on the XT225. It does fit! It has the two holes to secure the threaded bolts on the XT225 and the offset is exactly the same as the stock 15T counter-sprocket: Perfect fit! It makes 1st & 2nd gear far more usable around town, and turns 6th gear into an "overdrive" on the Highway, assuming you are running flat or downhill, and your total rider weight is not near the 409# weight limit! ;-)

It seems like each newer version of the lower cost Jabra bluetooth heatsets work better than the previous version. With the STYLE, I think Jabra has finally reached a point where there is nothing lacking whatsoever with the headset:- Cristal clear reception- Plenty of volume available, even when in my truck with the window down- Plenty of distance available between the headset and my phone, and gives plenty of warning before disconnecting.- Long enough battery life-Quick enough to recharge-Comfortable ear piece, light enough overall to forget I'm wearing it.I took off one star for two minor reasons... the controls (on/off, sync) are non-intuitive... I still have a problem figuring out what control does what, and the ear piece will not stay in the ear for very long if you do not use the ear loop; even with just minor head movement. Hey, you can't have everything, and at this low price point, I'll be buying one of these again!Highly Recommended!

I love the Mark 2 knife, as well as larger variants, but there are a few things you should consider before going with a bigger Mark 2, whether that be this Ontario, or the KA-BAR versions:Weight: My standard Mark 2 by Ontario, with leather handle, weighs in at 9.6 oz... quite light for a 7" bladed utility/fighting knife, which makes for very quick snap cuts and fast and easy transitions from Tip-up to Tip-down grips and vis-versa. My 8106 FF weighs in at 13oz even. Though three ounces doesn't sound like much, it is significant additional weight, as it applies to speed and transitional grip control. Does it make a slightly better hacking tool or slashing weapon? Sure, a bit. But at the expense of speed and maneuverability. Depending upon your use model, this may or may not be a concern, but make sure and consider this issue. For self defense with a knife, speed and maneuverability are critical, which is why the USMC went with a 7" blade (they tested dozens of different knife blade lengths and shapes when designing the Mark 2 back in 1942... there are good reasons for settling on this final design!)Handle: bottom line, it's plastic. Sure it works, but I prefer leather washers on a Mark 2. And not just for historical reasons: I like to customize the handles of my Mark 2's to fit my own hand and enhance both a Fencing & Saber grip (I prefer a bit narrower "Commando-Style grip"). It's a very easy garage project to customize a leather handled Mark 2 with a Dremel tool, some sand paper and some leather dye; no so much with the plastic handled ones, which seem to always have air bubbles in the wrong spots, and cosmetically never seem to be color correct once sanded.Sheath: If you are buying a Mark 2 just to sit in it's box as a collection piece, this is not a concern. If you plan on carrying this in the field and around town, it is a significant issue to consider. Leather sheaths which come with factory knives are pretty thin and sometimes, not all that great of quality. At least this one comes with one of Ontario's "SP" nylon/leather sheaths, which are thick and stiff, but the attachment point (plastic belt loop) and security straps (plastic)  are nothing to write home about. Unlike a standard Mark 2, you can't just order up a Ka-Bar plastic sheath for $15 if you are looking for something lighter, or order up a Kydex sheath off of Ebay for it. No, you will be pretty much stuck with the factory sheath with this knife, unless you are willing to pay $65+ for a custom leather or Kydex sheath from Sky Storm... Ouch!In summary, if you want a Mark 2 that is slightly more biased toward being capable as a woods knife, and don't mind the weight, than this is a good choice. Otherwise, I suggest going with a USMC WWII tested and approved standard bladed Mark 2.

Wow... really... twice the price of their standard Mark 2 knife, and they couldn't bother to polish the blade? The price of brass must have skyrocketed since I last checked, as the ounce or so they used is the only upgrade over the standard models. If you want see what this knife should have looked like, check out the Ontario P3 Quatermaster... even the sheath is nice!

My "Go-To" fixed bladed defense knife, among dozens!With over 30 years of practical/tactical knife ownership, I have a pretty good collection of reasonably priced/good quality fixed bladed knives, including Becker, ESEE, Kershaw, Cold Steel, Boker, etc. Though I have plenty of prettier, pricier and more "tacti-cool" looking knives, I find myself strapping on my Ontario more than any other fixed bladed knife for potential self-defense/general utility use. Here is why:1. Grip. I grew up practicing with the 1st gen Gerber MKII dagger in Army Combatives training down at Ft. Benning, which requires significant grip changes during a fight; none of which can easily be accomplished with most of today's popular angled/finger grooved handles; I just cant live with a grip shaped for "hammer-grip-only" in a defensive knife. The WWII-proven grip style of the USMC Mark 2/Army M3 knives allows for quick grip transitions, which I believe are necessary for efficient CQB technique. The rounded pommel provides for a very quick and secure transition from tip-up to tip-down grips. The neutral center hump of the grip fills the hand well and works equally well in tip-up and tip-down grips. The leather handle version can easily be modified to be thinner/smaller/oblong via cutting or Dremeling, as well as to add some additional traction cuts; making it easy to create your own custom grip. I find the black paint on the handle to be a bit slick, so after custom cutting the handle for my preference, I sand the handle down then use my old Army boot polish kit to re-blacken the grip with dye then polish.2. Overall Knife Design. The USMC Mark-2 (1219C2 Combat knife) design was proven in WWII by the USMC to be both a good utility knife, and a good fighting knife. It can do both reasonably well, unlike the US Armys version, the M3, which only lasted a year before being canceled due to it being too fragile of a blade in a utility role, and a pretty poor slasher due to it's blade's short & wide belly and strait/bayonet blade. Very few knife designs can come close to the overall usefulness of the MK2s grip and blade combination. Speaking of the blade... very few blade designs allow for easy sharpening of the false edged clip; the MK2 design is great for that. If you prefer to have this knife to be more combat capable, and a bit less utility biased, a few hours of your time with a file, or a few minutes with a dremel or a bench grinder, will allow you to sharpen up the top 2.5" of the clip pretty easily (because of the clip's wider angle than the lower blade angle, plan on using a 25 degree edge on the clip, rather than the 20 degree edge of the blade).3. Cost/Value. I have a hard time taking my custom etched and scaled Becker (or any other knife that I have over $100 into) and hacking away with it on the trail or in the garage without care of damage.... not so with any Mark 2 variant (Ontario, Ka-Bar, Cold Steel). At +/- $50, I don't mind scraping it up, dulling the blade, or risking a chipped edge. The 1095 steel is a bit on the soft side, but that makes it easy to resharpen/re-shape, and easy to get it hair shaving sharp with just a minor effort (even though it's just a 20 degree edge, I swear this knife will take the sharpest edge of any knife I own!).Other notes:Sheath: It's a medium thickness with good stitching; it works okay, but it's no SkyStorm!. If you plan on using it for military use, or just want a friction retention fuction, I suggest purchasing a Ka-Bar plastic military sheath for around $15 (available in black, tan, and if you can find one, green); these function well as a low slung "semi-dangler" (a "dangler" allows for comfortable sitting due to the flexability at the belt... the extra long nylon-web belt loop on the Ka-Bar military sheath provides a semi-dangler function). Though not cheap, you can also find custom Kydex sheaths on Ebay that are great, or my preference, a Skystorm leather solution (though I find it tough to spend more on a sheath than I did on the knife it's holding, a good sheath is critical as part of the system... kind of like a sling on a rifle!)Brand: I own USMC Mark-2's by both Ontario and Ka-Bar. If you don't plan on moding your leather grip, and like the natural leather look, than the Ka-Bar might be a better choice (but note: the crossguard on the Ka-Bar is swept/curved back (the 2nd mod of the Mark-2), where as the Ontario keeps with the first version of the knife delivered by Camillius in 1943, which has a flat crossguard...which I much prefer).For the price, nothing beats Ontario's version of the USMC Mark-2 as a fighting/utility knife, even after 60+ years of production.

After using the Superfly for my Kahr PM9 for the last year, I decided to try one for my NAA .32 Guardian. Just as for the PM9, the Guardian version fits well in a Wrangler jeans pocket, as well as in the tighter pockets of my Wrangler Hiker shorts and Wrangler Cargo pants (My PM9 is pretty tight in those last two, so the Guardian is a great solution for tighter pockets!).The holster holds the handgun well, protects my factory custom-shop sandblast finish, stabilizes the pistol well, and provides a quick, reliable and repeatable "hook" draw from the pocket.I don't tend to use the flap on the Superfly's, as they add bulk and slow down the draw a bit... but... the flap does provide the benefit of providing a deeper level of concealment, when needed/prudent.No offense to the other few reviewers here, but I don't agree with the low ratings they posted; the Superfly is my goto for EDC pocket carry!Photos included for those NAA Guardian owners looking for a real product photo.

Combined with the matching front floor mats, this really "industrializes" the feel of the front cab of my 04 F150, which is wearing  carpet underneath. It has a nice rubbery, grippy feel, fits perfectly and really "locks-in" anything you sit there. If you are buying the front floor mats, and want to really protect and significantly enhance and accessorize your macho truck or SUV, add this to your cart; you'll be glad you did!

Fits my 2004 F150 SCAB XLT quite well overall. Looks great, wears great, perfect for wet and dirty people and dogs. Pretty easy to install, except for the rear upper; it's a PITA and has a poor design of the attachment solution... not a deal killer though. My friend rode in my truck and liked my seats so much, she ordered a full set for her Jeep Liberty and was able to install them herself... winner!Highly recommended!

As reference, I have been sharpening knives for 30 years and have a box full of sharpeners.Quick note: If you are only going with ONE double sided sharpener, I'd suggest going with the Red/Green version (Fine/Extra Fine), as it will quickly sharpen a duller knife with the Red Side, and then refine the edge to a good useable field edge with the Green Side.If however, you already have the equivalent of the "Red Side" (a medium grit), then I'd say go with this model here, as it not only provides a good field edge with the Green Side, but then provides a final, well honed edge with the Tan Side.I already have the Course (Blue) and Fine (Red) single sided DMT Diafolds, which do a great job for rough and dull sharpening needs. The EF and EEF grits on this model let me spend plenty of quality time with my knives in hand, sharpening to perfection!Unlike a few reviewers here, I find the EEF side to be quite useful for taking the final wire-edge off the bevel, which is more difficult with the lower grit (higher coarseness) of the EF.Stay sharp out there! ;-)

Some guys sweat more than others when working hard. For guys like me, who can soak a cotton baseball cap in about 15 minutes of work, the Superwide Halo is a godsend: it keeps the sweat off of my face and out of my eyes, keeps me much cooler than a hat, keeps me feeling much dryer than a cap, and dries itself out very well during use.I also own the original version of the Halo (which I originally purchased for mountain-biking), but found that after extended use (30+ minutes), it would get soaked and would start to drip... no big deal, as you can just wring it out and put it back on, but I decided to try the Superwide... I'm glad I did. the wider band really does a good job of drying itself out without having to wring it out.If you go with the Black one, it looks a lot less like you are trying to dress like a Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtle (my original Halo is Red and it seemed to elicit a lot more comments than this black one!)Buy one, you won't regret it!

I have been sharpening my large and ever expanding collection of knives for over 30 years. if you have the skills to maintain an angle by hand while sharpening (to insure that you do not bevel-out your edge) then this is a fantastic all around knife sharpener at a great price (The price is half that of a DMT dual sided diamond sharpener). It is my first choice to use as a quick "medium-ish" grit sharpener among over a dozen of portable knife sharpeners which I own.if you can't properly maintain an angle when sharpening (no shame, it's takes a lot of practice!), but still need a portable/field sharpener, a simple Smith or Lansky "keychain" solution (Smith 2-Step or Lansky Quick Fix) sharpeners will do you pretty well, so long as you are conservative with the Carbide use. If you have the skills to hand hone, but are looking to shave a few ounces over the DCS4, or need a courser or smoother combo option, then the DMT Dual sided are a nice way to go, if you can afford them. (though they don't feel quite as solid as the Smith DCS4 due to the Smith's larger diameter handle).Considering it's value, for the tool bag or bug-out bag, the DCS4 is a great "one sharpener" solution.

The original tinted flap lasted 18 months with 4 active dogs. Seems reasonable to me. The replacement flap was clear, not tinted as shown here. The original tinted flap prevented my indoor cat from going through the door... he went through the replacement clear flap in less than an hour! Aside from that unique cat management issue, I highly recommend this segmented door and replacement flap over the traditional soft plastic flap solution; the attachment system of this door/frame solution is much more durable and survivable over the long run than the soft flap systems.

I agree with those who tired of the math (endless "story problems - the sort that made me break out in hives i.e. a train leaves New York and another train leaves Chicago...  I reads like a movie (which it is becoming with Matt Damon in title role) But even for a non-science type like me it's still a compelling page-turner as we follow the hero's epic efforts to survive.  It also raises some moral issues (The value of one life), but it's a ripping tale well-worth the time and money.  My 5-rtar rating stands.
One of our favorite family Christmas movies.
These convenient pacs seem to work fine.  decent value.
Great U-trou.  Fit well all 'round and breathe easy.  Good value.  THBoxers are excellent, Too.
This book answered a question for me:  "No" doesn't really mean "no" if you're rich and handsome.  What an insult to women.
Dood, loose- fitting with drawstring and elastic.  OKbut not too warm.

A slow-moving thriller without much mystery but a fair amount of suspense.  Reminiscent of Hitchcock.  Nice turns by Mortensen Dunst, and Isaacs.  Great settings.  It's definitely noir and not the shoot-em-up, action flicks we've become accustomed to.

Not precisely certain why I liked "The Barkeep" so much, but I did.  It reminded me of "Gone Girl" which I read recently.  Lashner's writing is first rate - clear, precise - and his characters are first-rate - sketched out with a minimum of strokes, but I found them compelling.The whodunit is well-crafted and offers an intriguing twist at the end, but Lashner's description of family relations is terrific, and possibly that's where the feel of "Gone Girl" comes from.  You'll find yourself actually caring about the characters.Starts a bit slowly (first 25 pages had me wondering), but picks up speed and flows smoothly from there.Overall, and after the first 25 pages, for me, this was a great read.

Big Sandford fan - Lucas has become an acquaintance of sorts - in fact, I think I know more about him and his life than most of the folks I see every day.  And that's a good thing, but it also means that since I like him, I cannot be fair and even-handed in my review so my only advice to anyone reading this review who has never read a Lucas Davenport novel is to skip back to the beginning and read the first Davenport and move forward in order.  If you like the first one, you'll like this one.One thing that Sandford does well is to make the horrific seem "business as usual" for Lucas and his partners.  The contrast of the midwestern charm of Minnesota and the vile crimes is part of what makes these novels work - the "banality of evil" theme is ever-present.So if you are a long-time fan of Sandford, this one will work for you.  If you're new to his work, go back and read "Rules of Prey" and move on from there.  You'll be glad you did.

Arkady Renko is among my favorite characters in detective fiction so I am always predisposed to like any book by Smith that features Arkady.  If you read enough mysteries and thrillers, you develop an affection for certain authors and their characters, and you become "friends" with them.  And as with your friends, you accept the characters - faults, flaws, and all.So I am not unbiased here, but I will say that I thoroughly enjoyed this Renko adventure.  There is something about the setting - the "new" Russia - that is really appealing to me, and this particular Renko tale has added depth because the plot moves to Kaliningrad - a depressed and depressing vestige of the Cold War.Smith captures the paranoia that was necessary to survive in the USSR and now appears to be equally necessary in modern-day Russia.  Overall, it's a tightly woven and suspenseful addition to the Arkady Renko series.  If you've enjoyed the others, you'll enjoy this one.  If you have never read a Renko, start from the first and move forward chronologically.
Power cord broke and appears that it can't be fixed.  Big disappointment and soon off to the dump.

Been 3 years and this iron is still working like a charm.  Mostly used for household linens and the occasional shirt, it gets nice and hot and shoots a powerful and consistent stream of steam.  Have to refill a bit too often for my taste but overall, it's got a nice feel to it and does the job well.  Nice heft as well.

3 years out and it's working like a charm - that's everyday use.  Always like the handheld models - makes cleaning the tub/shower easier and this one functions well as a shower - perhaps even better than the wall-mounted ones.

Have had it for 3 years, and it works like a champ.  Love the picture and the access to Netflix and Amazon.  I am no techno so I probably don't have it dialed in right but the picture looks pretty darn good to me.  It's our main form of entertainment - we don't go to movie theaters and live in a rural area - so it's a real pleasure to have a good TV.  It's on for hours every day because I keep the music channels going all day while I work around the house so it's logged a bunch of hours of use with no signs of "wear."

I have to give it 5 stars even though it rotted out - but then I left it out well into two winters - one of those things I meant to do every time I drove out of the driveway...then promptly forgot on my way back in.  Comfy and cool.  Overall, a nice purchase.

Easy to assemble and lightweight but does the job.  Well-made for the price and the weight - durable extensions.  Have a one-story house and this thing works like a champ - cutting down through 20" or more of compacted snow (I always wait too long thinking it can't snow any more).

Used it for 3 years now and it's working just fine.  Provides nearly instantaneous reading in oven or on the grill - even use it to determine water temp in pan.  Neat, easy to read (but not in the dark for late season grilling outside).  Overall a good solid purchase that performs as advertised.

Bought them for my son who is tough on shoes.  He wrestles at 180 so he's no lightweight.  They lasted in good shape for two seasons - practice and matches.  They fit well out of the box and never seemed to give out or stretch too much for the two years he wore them.  As I wrote, he's very tough on shoes - his sneakers are usually shot within two or three months, but these stood the test of time.

Four years later and this drill (and light) still working like a champ.  It may nopt be the most powerful drill out there but it works fine for  average home maintenance tasks.  One battery always charging and the other seems to hold its charge for a while.  Really quite a good purchase - it's stood the test of time.

Ms. Flynn is a genius - she has a keen eye and ear and writes beautifully.  She captures the voices of her two characters perfectly, and while I usually do not care for books with alternating chapters for various characters to air perspectives, Ms. Flynn makes it work and if anything, her technique enhances the novel.She has extraordinary eye and ear for contemporary culture and captures the essence of male vs. female; Manhattan vs. Missouri; marriage vs. courtship; upper class vs. lower class; et al.She is neutrally critical as well - no NYC snobbery here - almost scientific in her perspective, she pins everyone down for close inspection by a critical eye - a social lepidopterist of the first order.And she manages to be wonderfully funny, witty, humorous.One of the best books I've read in a long time.
Nice chunks of hickory that really give off great smoke (soak 'em first) and lend a nice wood flavor to a propane grill.

Quick fix for rural areas with poor reception.  Don't give up on them.  I was bummed when they would not even pick up NPR from 15 miles away.  Started to repack it and send back then recalled a jury rig that we used to use to get signals on our radios back in boarding school out in the woods.  Grabbed a piece of aluminum foil and a twist tie.  Folded the foil so it was about 5" tall and then attached it to tip of antenna with the twist tie.  Picked up the signal and even a station farther away - one NPR, one classic rock!  Sweet.  OK...so I look like a UFO conspiracist, but I live in the woods so don't care if I look all dorky.  Hey, I listen to NPR.If you want, you can get all scientific - see below.Does a great job of reducing mower noise,  Sound is good.  Fairly easy to program IF you read the directions.  Decent sound.The MathTo build an antenna that centers on a specific station (such as a weak station you want to receive better), use the frequency of that station in the following formula. Otherwise, use the central frequency of the FM dial (98 Mhz) for the formula to get complete coverage. In Tampa, Mix 96 transmits at 95.7 Mhz (95.7 on your FM dial), 98 Rock uses 97.9 Mhz, 103.5 Thunder uses 103.5 Mhz, et cetera.Formula:300 / (frequency in Mhz) * (5/8) * (1/2) = length in meters of the ideal 5/8ths antenna using twinlead 300 Ohm wire.To simplify the formula:93.75 / Freq in Mhz = length in meters of the ideal 5/8th's antenna.So, to get the length of the ideal 5/8ths antenna for the full FM radio spectrum (centered on 98Mhz):93.75 / 98 = .95663265306 meters, or 95.66 centimeters(which converts to 37.66 inches).To build a stronger antenna, multiply that result by a whole number.Example:  0.9566 meters * 5 = 4.783 metersSo an antenna made of (5) 5/8ths wave sections for 98 Mhz would be 4.783 meters long (which is 15'  8 5/16 ")
Cool thing - not your typical bamboo backscratcher.  The extension works well and the claw provides good relief - not too sharp, not too dull. When you need it...

Quite nice - well-made and attractive i.e. they pretty much disappear.  Filled them with English ivy for a porch.  Tinkered with the hooks (easy-to-use clips) to make them hang evenly.  Water will drain right out so I lined them with a bit of plastic to hold some water so I don't have to water them every day.  Sturdy construction.

I quite liked the plot - the psychopathology here is well-described and pretty much believable.  Even the characters are pretty decent.But the novel needs an editor.  When I was in high school, my English teachers made much of correct use of tense and point of view (POV).  I never gave it much thought and generally regarded their instruction as fustian.This book is rendered nearly unreadable because the author does not adhere to common rules of grammar regarding the use of proper tense - it's all over the place.  Same for POV - the author never quite settles on where he's standing as he relates the tale.And here's why publishers hire editors - to make books readable.Overall, you can muddle through, but if you're like me, it's a tough slog.  Too bad.  It's a cool premise.

A serious issue treated to a full-on humorous, touching treatment by Frank Oz (Dirty Rotten Scoundrels, Bowfinger, the voice of Yoda), and Oz uses the film to take some shots at Hollywood celebrity, homophobia, the news media, public school administrators, et al. but surprisingly has a soft spot for small town folks who take people as they are, weighing and measuring them by what they have done or what is in their hearts.  A film about essential goodness.  And contains 4 of the funniest minutes ever on film.  All the actors are great but it's really Joan Cusack who makes this movie - she is the crazy glue that binds it together.  Like Glenne Headley in "Dirty Rotten Scoundrels."

The writing is first-rate - good, clear prose and fine dialogue.  Like the characters - they are well drawn and with commendable economy.  Ruminations of the main character are fairly compact and drive the plot along neatly.  The plot has just enough mystery to make it intriguing and reasonably realistic although the main character takes a few too many beatings for my taste - and certainly for his.Overall, quite a good read.

It's important for anyone who chooses to use impressionism that the dots or splotches make sense when you step back.  This collection of random, idle impressions, taken together, means not much and is just plain hard to wade through.  Hemingway managed to capture life in Europe in about 10% of the words.  Hemingway's female characters are forceful and independent.  Salter's are sad, vapid shadows.As to the writing, no thought goes unexplored.  No sight goes undescribed.  It's just mangled, disconnected, prurient gibberish masquerading as modernism.  To his credit, I suppose modern American fiction had to take this step, but I'll thank him for his pioneering effort and move on to David Foster Wallace or Jonathan Franzen who have the clarity and power of coherent prose working for them.Move on.  Nothing to see here.

OK, most of the 1- and 2-star reviews note leakage and lack of fizz and then finally, nothing.I think I may have found the solutions to many of the problems listed (and I am not a shill for iSi - just a guy who hates to give up on mechanical stuff that goes bad).1.  NEVER remove the plastic tube and fill the siphon only through the tiny hole in the top of that plastic tube.  You will have less water in the tank, but that's the way it's designed. (and which leads me to the 4-star review: not that much capacity for each CO2 cartridge which makes it less of a deal but probably still better than seltzer in bottles.  Whew.).2.  Since you can't over-fill if you leave the tube in the tank, there will be less leakage, but you do have to be very careful putting the top back on after filling since it has a tendency to cross-thread which means it's not a tight seal.  So, be sure you seat the top gently but start again if there's a ton of resistance as you screw it down.3.  We have hard water and after a while, the nozzle got clogged and simply didn't let the water spray out.  Soak the entire head in white vinegar which should get rid of the scale.Overall, it's a much better deal that it seemed, but you have to be pretty careful refilling it and give it a good vinegar soak every now and then.
Will have to report later on durability, but they look pretty sturdy.  Palms have nice padding.  Nice tight fit.  Decent materials.  For $12 they look like a deal, but we'll see how they wear.

Ridley Scott on meth.  A completely implausible piece of space junk.  How it got nominated for Best Pic is totally beyond me.  And I love a good sic-fi ripping tale.SPOILER ALERT: When the ghost of Clooney appears to Ryan as she's about to end it all (because of her dead 4-year old) and tells her to put her feet on the ground and start living for tomorrow, my gag reflex kicked in.

Always enjoy a ripping tale about Nazis - especially the post-war "what-if" plots that keep various Nazis war criminals alive and lurking about the globe trying to create the Fourth Reich.  This one is just plausible enough to be believable and entertaining.The characters in this book are pretty compelling, interesting constructs, but there are a few sentimental touches that strain credulity and dull the edge.  As well, the author needs a better editor - way too many notes, Mozart.At the end, during the exciting finish, Brown suffers a bad case of verbal diarrhea.  Every thought, every glance, every movement is recorded and even more annoying, each incident is described from the perspective of the different characters.  We get it - it's cold or difficult or painful or sad or...whatever.  Great writers assume the reader has an imagination and then they cultivate it with carefully chosen, tightly constructed images.

Great value BUT candy has a strong medicinal/industrial aroma and flavor - may be the plastic tub, but even without the plastic container, the candy still has a strong "produced along the Jersey Turnpike" flavor.  too bad because it is a bargain.  So many reviews mention how difficult they are to find on the East Coast.  Ever thought it's because Easterners think Re Vines taste terrible which they do.
Decent texture and freshness but there is a noticeably industrial taste and aroma.  Will not buy again - bargain or not.Returned them and bought Twizzlers which are reliably the better red licorice.

The author is an investment banker (which is like herpes so there's no such thing as a "former" investment banker - you always have "it") so I can understand how he can turn thieves into heroes.  Trouble is that investment bankers destroyed our economy - not making anything, not building anything, not hiring workers - just grabbing a couple of dimes on every dollar of any deal that they could devise.In this instance, Mickey is a convicted financier who's out and trying to recover some of his former fortune and avenge his wife's betrayal by generating a larcenous enterprise - teaming up with another convict who was part of a pump and dump penny-stock fraud - frauds that lost money for decent, trusting (but greedy) folks.  In other words, these two are scumbags of the first order.  Worse still, Mickey is not believable.  What corrupt financier (think Boesky or Milken) didn't hide a ton of dough, pay his fine, serve his time and get out with a still vast fortune?  And Mickey stole BILLIONS and comes home with a few grand in his pocket?  Lender can't have it both ways.  If you thought Tony Soprano was a swell guy and a good family man (and completely missed the irony), you'll be OK with this book.Lender is getting better - I'll give him that - but the fundamental flaws in his characters can't be avoided.Bit like his other book that built on the proposition that vaccines cause autism - a completely false and dangerous, unscientific theory.  Even that dope Jenny McCarthy gave that one up, but rich boneheads are still not vaccinating their children, exposing all of us to dreadful afflictions that were wiped out back in the 1950s.  Dose of polio, anyone?  This guy is dangerous - doing with a pen what he used to do with a computer.Certainly have to suspect some padded 5-star reviews as well.

Overmyer and Connelly - can't get much better writing than that (Overmyer worked on "The Wire," for example).  Although it's a bit overwrought at certain moments, overall, this production captures Bosch and his world perfectly.  So much better than either Cruise as Reacher or McConaughey as Haller.Hope Amazon keeps it going.  Please don't leave us hanging.

One of our three dogs seems to become incontinent occasionally, and her urine is very smelly.  We have a Hoover carpet cleaner and using this stuff have pretty much taken care of the odor and stains.  Is it a miracle product?  No, because we have to apply it ourselves (a miracle means we bring it into the house and leave it near the stains overnight and they vanish - now that's a miracle!).But it does seem to work better than any other product we have tried.  It does not repel the dog from peeing on the same spot, but at least we can reduce significantly the odor.  It's an oriental carpet so stains sort of disappear.Will definitely keep it on hand.

I read it.  I finished it.  I didn't dislike it.  I didn't like it.  For the price it provided decent entertainment, but I can't say that I feel compelled to return for more from this series.  The characters seemed cut from cardboard - not badly drawn, just not very imaginative.  The plot has some neat twists and the solutions don't strain credibility - once you've accepted the premise of the novel.  I wish I could summon up more enthusiasm, but I can't.

And I do love his books.  Handles the language so well, and has a real feel for putting folks in tense situations and having them work their way out - often with a good dose of necessary mayhem.  In this instance, an innocent couple casually become a pair of avenging angels.  They're thoughtful about it but as always, Block manages to make it all seem so simple and obvious - "Wouldn't you?"A good bargain for a decent Block novel.

...which would seem to be its primary purpose.  Can't say it's vastly superior to Orville's corn, but it does make a nice bowl of pop corn that, as I alway do, I smear with melted butter and a dose of sea salt - which as we all know, make anything taste pretty good.  The novelty of purple kernels turning into white pop corn is marginal.Overal, it's good pop corn.  Will I buy it again?  Maybe.

Jeepers. Ten year age difference is hardly a May/December, but when that ten years is the difference between you and your TEACHER? Holy moly. And this was BASED ON A TRUE STORY. Wowza!Mateo is demanding, sexy, and yet caring. He demonstrates it even while demanding some really hot sex from this young student of his.Shannon is having the worst kind of effed up life right now. Orphaned, older sister then dies after giving birth, she lives with her brother in law who is a total creeper and abusive, just a horrible way to turn 18.Shannon and Mateo are explosive and yet...at one point, I was pretty mad at him. The story keeps unfolding and I really enjoyed the ending and was glad ... well, I'll let you read it.

2.5 stars This was an amazon freebie and it's one of those books where...you keep reading even though you nearly DNF it several times. Something compels to you read on while at the same time you feel like you shouldn't. I couldn't like the main character. She just wasn't likable enough for me. I didn't like how she referred to her parents, I didn't like her actions and attitude, I didn't like her petulance, and I sure didn't like how she seems so obtuse when she's reading her birth mom's journal and it's spelled out for her: the guy you're hooking up with is a DARK ONE. Hello. Duh.Speaking of the dark one, Dorian is intriguing. But he's not quite alpha enough for me. There's a bit of the tortured soul thing, a bit of control, and then there's this vague hint that he's gonna be easily wrapped around her finger and end up meek instead of the strong type that I like. The sex goes from sweet to slightly violent to connection again. Dorian's nickname for her is "little girl" and boy is that fitting. So fitting.I'm torn. I'm torn about reading on because of how it ended and because I'm interested in Dorian Skotos, but I also didn't like the editing and thought this book could use a little more polish. Gabs gasps every few sentences at one point and it was annoying.But the story started to get good at the end and now I'm torn. Do I continue in this series? I don't know. A friend of mine is reading book 2 and I'll wait to see what she says before continuing on...we both felt similar about the book. LOL

I received an e-arc of this book in exchange for my honest opinion.Overall, this book was enjoyable. I think it took a little too long to get going and I found Riley frustrating. She keeps clamoring about being taken seriously, but she's twenty flipping two and acts like it. She acts like a the spoiled little rich girl that she is, with no clue as to how the rest of the world works. I didn't like her description of her friend, I didn't like her attitude, her actions, and had a hard time liking her.Brandon also acts way younger for someone who should be more mature based on his background. I found him difficult to like as well to begin with.The story did keep moving forward and I kept reading, but their actions and reactions often contradicted what they said they were trying to be, so this book fell short for me. However, by the end, I was definitely interested in reading more from Aubrey Parker and continuing in the Inferno Falls series. The author was successful in building a world and the start of characters that intrigue you enough to want to keep reading.

This is one of my favorite clean romance series - romantic, funny, with characters you easily get attached to, Ruth Hartman whisks you away in her regency novels and you get all caught up in each story. Percy has to be my favorite. And I cannot believe this whole box set is only 99c! I may own them all already, but I'm purchasing this box set to read them all at once :)

This is one heck of a debut romance novel! Witty, funny, and sexy as hell, I thoroughly enjoyed this read. The author knows how to write romance and leads you through great character development, wonderful convos, and an inner dialogue that resonates with me as a reader.I loved the characters and this is one I would reread when in the mood for a good, modern romance with a touch of naughty.

This was a wonderful story from HD Gordon that really puts into perspective the future of the Earth and what we can potentially screw it over to. It's a bit scary, has an overtone of self-fulfilling prophecy if we don't start giving a damn about what we are doing and how we're treating mother nature.The characters are dynamic and believable. You can easily hate the bad ones, love the good ones, and bite your nails at the possible outcome. The ending? Perfect.
Very cute post its. Love them, but the stickiness is not so good. It falls off easily from where I try to stick it, so I often add a little tape.
Grim here is my talisman to help fight my stage IV colon cancer. He keeps me ahead of the game!
Nice and thin, steady flow of ink, great vibrant colors.

I first started reading JA Huss when she did a blog tour for Tragic. I quickly was enraptured by her writing style and by the hint of more to come. And boy did it ever. And then I read her SciFi series, Junco. Oh. Em. Gee. Amazing.Julie Huss writes books with twists and turns and out of nowhere full on facial smacks. They're hot and sexy and dirty and twisty and mind blowing.This is not that kind of book. This is lighter than her usual fare without the psychological twists and turns, but still has her unique voice in telling the tale. And boy did I like this tale!Instead of the male being the richie, Tiffy Preston is the daughter of the billionaire. And Fletcher Novak is one of her employees, a stripper in the all male revue. And Fletcher singles her out in a crowd, not knowing who she is, and decides one thing: she. is. his.With an interesting proposal and a story that just flows, this was one enjoyable read, filled with sexy scenes, big mistakes, and a lovely outcome.Remember...Sexy is on the inside.

This was a really well-wrought tale of a gifted firestarter girl who runs away to the circus to belong. She's returning to her roots after the death of her family, but she soon learns that it's not all fun and games and the family she thinks it is. Lucy is the newbie and there isn't a level of instant acceptance she had expected. To top it off, there are two boys (or more) vying for her attentions and she soon discovers she has feelings for both. What tangled web...I really enjoyed reading GIFTED. While frustrating at times because I don't really get the teenage girl thing, the action and interactions of the characters sucked me in totally, so much so that I felt like I may be riding Lucy's coattails and am part of the circus myself.For those looking for a good read filled with action, friendships, coming into one's own, and a touch of mystery, this is an excellent book to while away a few hours!

A little larger near my calves than I expected for straight legs, but not boot cut. I probably should've ordered a size smaller as I think I've lost some weight and it's rather roomy at the waist, but hey...no muffin top then right?Looks and feels great, good construction, perfect.

I LOVE this dress and immediately hopped on over to Torrid to shop some more. Great material, great construction, fits the way I wanted it to fit (I purchased a larger size for comfort), and looks cute.

I bought this as a gift for my mom and she loves it. It's so nice to have your audiobooks, music, questions, jokes, immediately playing. The alarm feature is nice. I hope to get full use out of everything you can do with this, including working with house lighting, etc., eventually. As of right now, we all really like and appreciate Alexa!We're learning to ask her questions in a certain way so she will answer it instead of saying she doesn't understand. We find ourselves saying please and thank you and apologizing to her when we say her name but don't ask anything, etc. Dundundunnnnn AI. lol It's a fun and interesting product.

This was a fun contemporary romance that blends everything that is really hot and popular right now: Jamie Fraser, rich independent woman, and kilts!I had the chance to read this for free thanks to Entangled Publishing. IT does not disappoint. This was a fun, great read with likable characters that you root for getting together. The accent is adorable of course and I am really glad that Sloane warmed up to Molly. ;)While I found her friends obnoxious, they do prove true and you root for the HEA from the beginning of the book. Makes me want to head right back to Scotland myself and find MY Jamie Fraser!

I outright stole the reading order for you from Michelle New's review. So here it is. And yes, you need to read them.***Reading Order***Rook & Ronin:Tragic, Manic , Panic**we meet Ford and Spencer in this series.Ford:Slack, Taut**we meet Merc and Sasha in Slack *Syd is referenced*Spencer:Bomb, Guns**we meet James and Merc gets a mention or two.James & Harper:Come, Come Back, Coming For You**Sasha, Merc and the whole gang show up.**Jax appears in the epilogueThree, Two, One: Jax is introduced (Arks brother)Meet Me in The Dark: Merc & Syds story brings us back to Sasha.***********************Sasha Ashton, formerly known as Sasha Cherlin, is all grown up. And she's a successful post-grad student, living her life, her away from the Company life. But life isn't all sunshine and roses. She's harboring secrets from her adoptive parents, a secret that keeps her terrified, she harbors longing for Nick who abandoned her ten years ago, she harbors longing for life, true life.Jax Barlow is an Agent. And he's determined to use Sasha as means to an end. But he wasn't expecting who Sasha is and what that might mean for him.This book was one of those books where you snarl at anyone who dares interrupt the beauty of all that this is. The twisty little ties coming together to form a complicated, celtic knot of love, loyalty, deceit, murder, psychosis, friendship, and all the other ties that bind.And you know what? That's my review. I'm not saying a damn thing more. Read the series in order. Get a handle on what The Company is, what it means, look for all the subtle clues that have been woven throughout, and then get this book. This Sasha chapter. And then ask yourself: could you have survived?

A thoroughly enjoyable historical romance that embraces that American Dream/Horatio Alger Ragged Dick fantasy of rags to riches, although set across the pond in London. This isn't just a romance but a novel that tackles the idea of self-worth, both for females and males, and non-conformity.Lucy and Trevor were childhood friends, struggling to survive in the a corner of the poorest section of town. Trevor always looked out for Lucy and Lucy only trusted Trevor. Determined to save her, Trevor takes advantage of overhearing something and shoves Lucy out to be the one selected, thereby saving her from being sold as a sex worker at a very young age by her own mother. Trevor makes his own way out of the gutter, but neither has forgotten the other.I really enjoyed how this story was wrought: from interesting side characters, to multiple historical references, this was a romantic page turner that had many facets to enjoy.Thanks to Entangled Publishing and the author for the early read! This is available now and if you love historical romances, this would be a good pick for you!

I was very thankful to be so quickly approved for the amazon.com Prime Store Card. With online statements, email reminders, and the ability to pay online, it's easy to stay atop of my balance and pay it off, and then have fun ringing it up again. There are other benefits you can choose with the Prime Store Card. I chose the 5% back on every purchase which helps me pay my bill down!Hmmmm maybe next time I'll apply for the Chase Visa amazon.com card!

Bought it and then read it in the same day! I really enjoyed this romance from CD Reiss. From a glimpse inside the life of a paparazza (yes, a not i) to the gritty realistic background story of Laine and then Michael's own childhood background, it's a thorough, enjoyable read.I loved watching Laine and Michael come together, both knowing that they're basically committing career suicide if it continues, both reaching beyond themselves to think about the other. But I really enjoyed the friend characters as well. From the was-a-bitch Lucy to the foster brother Tom (how did she forgive him for that? I'd be SO mad, still! lol) to the celeb buddy with douchey friends, this whole book was like watching a romance movie in my head.I loved her S.O.S. books, but this one is my new fave CD Reiss book!

Bought for my mother and she loves it. The chain is VERY delicate, so you must be careful when wearing. She tugged at it in her sleep and needed to replace the chain until we get it fixed. But this is exactly what she wanted: dainty, shiny, and pretty. I will probably buy again and save it for my goddaughter.

This was one of my Kindle Scout books and I'm so glad it was published. Just like I thought, once I opened the page, I couldn't put it down. It's a coming of age suspense novel and kept me involved with what I was reading. Rather than feeling as if I'm being told a story, I felt like I was riding shotgun with the characters, a quiet passenger on this ride that was just so puzzling.I think I would've liked a little more interaction with her dad as I felt really bad for him. And she shows emotion there, so I was kinda wishing she did a little more throughout the book. But she had SO much going on, it's easy to see why she just didn't have time.The way it ends is satisfying while leaving the possibility for more in the future. I vote for more!

This review is long overdue. With medical crises and what is now my new life, my reading had been pushed to the wayside and I finally am picking up and getting my reviews out. My profuse apologies to Entangled Teen and the author for being so late when you so graciously granted me a review copy!With that being said, now to the review. This deserves every single gold star I can give it. Let's start with the cover. I'm not a complete cover junkie, but I have to admit that covers can lure me in. This cover is stunning in its simplicity and totally drew me in, making me want to read.But that cover is nothing to the story inside.Loosely, you can consider this a re-telling of Little Red Riding Hood. This is a fairy tale re-telling turned on its ear, made supernatural, and written in such a manner that you're gonna be guessing for most of the story.I don't want to give away a single thing, so I will leave this review by saying: Ms Harvey...I hope you write more in this world. This was my introduction to your work and now I have to go add more of your books to my TBR.

I quite enjoyed this fun contemporary romance. Cassia and Bram complement one another well and I enjoyed reading their story even as I wanted to smack Cassia and tell her to get over it.When these two first meet, chemistry is evident but Cassia is dating this schmuck, Spencer. Fast forward a little while later and Bram's & Cassia's path cross again and Bram finagles a way to see Cassia daily. Their chemistry is palpable, but a relationship is hampered by their own insecurities and issues.Karen Kincy has a gift for dialogue; I loved their conversations and innuendos and flirtations. They felt real and not just contrived for a story. I liked how the story developed and I read this all in one sitting! Instead of just kink and sex, this is a book that explores romance and flawed characters who need to learn to let go and embrace moving forward.

Ruth Hartman does it again! I adore this series and all of the characters in it. I love how they make cameo appearances in different books, and I love that each is a good, clean, fun romance!Maid for Romance is no different... Leah Hunter has feelings for Daniel Barlow who always makes her laugh. She longs for both love and a secure future like her friend has.Daniel makes her laugh but Felton Kensington can offer her the security she desires for her future. Will she choose money and companionship or true love and laughter for the rest of her days?As always, well written, well told, and includes the delightful Percy!

Let's start by saying this: THIS IS A STAND ALONE NOVEL. No, you do not need to read Rook & Ronin or the Rook&Ronin SpinOff series. Yes, Merc was a side character in those books, but THOSE stories are completely separate from this novel. STAND ALONE.Got that? :D Cool. I just don't want you panicking that you have to read a gazillion novels to catch up. And I don't want you avoiding this book because you think you need to read the others. You don't. This is stand alone, this is all by itself, and this is ... whoa.You should be warned: if you're looking for a romance with fluffy hearts, chaste kisses, Prince Charming, and Princess Honeypot, this is not the book for you.This book is gritty. It's suspenseful. It includes the horrors that humans are capable of inflicting on others. It touches bases on dubious consent. It contains violence. It's dark.Dark...yeah, okay, that's a start for this book. But then you kinda plummet into infinity and only little flickers of starlight to give you a little hope. Twisty? Uh, yeah. Messed up? Uh, YEAH.I've "met" Merc through the other books. He popped up quickly here and there within the other series. And he intrigues you greatly. You know he exudes danger, that he's a killer, that he's cold. But you also get the tiniest glimpses of some kind of honor code that is all his own. It may not be something you or I would define that way, but this man has rules.You're going to start reading this book and you're going to be hooked and not want to put it down and hiss at people who interrupt your reading. And while your'e reading, I guarantee you will go through some variation of the following inside your head as you're reading: "WTH! Did he SERIOUSLY just do that?! Wait, what is going on? OMG STOP DOING THAT. Oh, good. OMG that guy is a jerk! COME ON, WOMAN. STEP UP! ... holy moly!"This book runs the gamut. Violence, sex, mind-screws, emotion, vengeance, all peppered with tenderness, care, glimpses of sweetness, and then...that ending.Out. Of. The. Park.

Borrowed on KindleUnlimited. This was a very hot, erotic, quick read. I've not read many stepbrother fantasies or gynecologist fantasies (neither are on my radar as turn ons). This one could definitely change my mind on that: social taboos heighten the erotic sense of the forbidden.If you're looking for a sexy, quick read, pick this one up!

Disclaimer: I received an early copy of this book to read and review honestly. No other compensation was offered nor accepted.The Cabin Goddess introduced me to Kory M Shrum's DYING FOR A LIVING when the author was offering Read to Review copies. And, being the lover of Urban Fantasy that I am, I snapped it up. IT SO DID NOT DISAPPOINT. It was a five star read for me (and dudes...it's currently free to read over at amazon: http://amzn.to/1amuAwY) and so was the second book, DYING BY THE HOUR.It's not often that an author can keep the momentum going. But Kory M Shrum absolutely did with this third installment. This takes place along the same timeline as DYING BY THE HOUR, but told from Brinkley's point of view and with flashbacks that give you more to the story. It is seamless between flashbacks and the current timeline.What I loved about this book, as with the others in the series, is how the author brings her characters to life with emotion. Heart-wrenching, eviscerating emotion. From sympathizing with Brinkley to aching for his heartache, to all the feels for Jackson, Shrum takes you on another ride from the very first page to the very last.I will absolutely read on in this series. I cannot wait for the next installment!

Perfect. This was absolutely perfect for me because I seriously adore Percy and his eccentricities and I LOVE his match made in birdland, with his "Lady Peregrine", Georgianna. Of course, no story is complete without a little wrinkle in the fabric of a good story and that comes in the guise of the pickle Percy finds himself in when it comes to an in-law who has her claws set on having him.With hearts aflutter, some squawking from a nasty old hen, and cute scenes of complete awkwardness from eccentric ol' Percy, this was such a delight to read.A short, fun read that's free from author Ruth J Hartman? THANK YOU!

FABULOUS Stroller and exactly what I was looking for. And you really cannot beat the price of this stroller.I have stage IV cancer and need to make sure I keep up with some form of activity for my health. I wanted something to have company on my walks and since my little dog is getting older (She'll be 12 next month), her legs aren't up to walks anymore. I've been wanting a pet stroller, but couldn't justify the other prices I saw for them ($100 and up? Uhhhh maybe not). I also use this for my elderly cats so they can enjoy the fresh air while I take a walk.So for those who are curious...*this arrived much faster than intended (3 days earlier than thought!)*easy to put together - unfold it, snap on the wheels and wheel bar, and that was it.*easy to zip up the netting and unzip.*easy to plop the pet inside*Comes with two buckles you can attach to the pet's harness in case you do not want to use the netting*easy to steer, easy to put the brake on and off, at the perfect height for me (I'm 5'6") and yet comfortable for my mom to use when she's with me (she's 4'10")

Soft supple leather, the center zip pocket is anchored to the bottom (I really hate the free floating ones that are only tethered at the top, so I LOVE this one), and tons of room, I love this bag. The strap is comfy for my shoulder and easily adjustable to make it a cross body length on any body type (I'm a fat woman), and the handles are really well sewn and secure.This is seriously the perfect leather tote that I will use (and probably abuse) for years and years to come.

Disclaimer: I received a copy of this book in exchange for my honest review.I was so excited to have the chance to read this sequel to  Butterman Time Travel Inc as I really really enjoyed the first book. I thought it fresh and exciting and something different from my normal reading.We are back to Alaska and Tristan & Bianca in this sequel and Bee is learning to deal with Tristan's fame and all that comes associated with it. All of this media attention etc right on the verge of her Induction Day. And Agent Garth is back...to make things hell.I didn't enjoy this book as much as I did the previous one, but it's no fault of the book itself. Hrezo has written her characters so well that my dislike for them was so intense that it was hard for me to continue reading because I couldn't stand them. Bee's parents annoyed me, Tristan pissed me off, Agent Garth, of course, was her horrid self. And I wanted to smack Bee as well, especially in the beginning, for being such...a teenager. LOL But again, I must stress, that the book is well done; this is definitely one of those subjective things and I was not in the right frame of mind to be able to ignore my dislike!The twist at the end, what is revealed, was a surprise to me and not one that I had thought of before. I'm looking forward to the next book to see how the Garth v Butterman thing works out!

Although interesting, all of them, it could have gone into more depth. It could have elaborated the dark, and the creepy nature in all of them. Nearly believable, even.Still, I liked the rhythmic pace it is set. And because of that and no grammatical errors, or misspellings, or misuse of the words such as the "too" and the "to" (my personal peeve) - it was enjoyable to read. A quick read, for certain. I am not an expert at grammar, etc. Which is why I so admire well written works.Anyway, as far as who I will recommend it to? Easy. Anyone wanting a good, well written short eerie stories. Simple.It's a fun book. Enjoy it.By Kh ;)

It is not that I forgot to come and write this review; its that Ive been incredibly busy and, truth to be told, I have no idea how to write this review. Like all of my reviews, I shall fly by the seat of my pants. To sum up: this has to be one of the best sci fi fantasy series Ive ever read. It is brilliantly told, intricately woven, and man oh man am I glad I read it back to back. Junco is an amazing character who you both love and hate. Tier you want to love but youre unsure of what the hell is going on, and each character is like that: leaves you on a precipice.To begin, lets try a quote that basically sums up everything, in my opinion:"Lucan has placed us like actors on the stage. He's got us coming and going in so many different directions, it's impossible to figure out what's true and what's not."Oh, dear.This final book, RETURN, is told from multiple points of view: You hear from Junco, Tier, Lucan, Ashur, and Annun. It is brilliantly told and lets you know that each character doesnt have the full story, doesnt know exactly what is happening or what to expect, and that Lucan has kept everything very, very close to the vest, even from his most loved and trusted family members. And that even LUCAN, the orchestrator, the puppeteer so to speak, doesnt know how it will end because it all hinges on Juncos reaction. Can you imagine? Existence in its entirety hinges on the unstable JUNCOs reaction. Holy. Effing. Hell.If you think I had a white-knuckled grip on my kindle and was snarling at anyone interrupting my reading time, youd be right on the money. As each person is taking his/her place on the giant chess board (damn near literally speaking, here, t00), the tension from each character at the unknown pretty much reaches through the pages and strangles you.JA Huss is a very modern author whose contemporary romances are burning up the TBRs. Im sure by now youve heard of her Social Media series that she released in the course of 12 weeks, one book/novella (120 pages average) every 2 weeks. Many were enticed by the sex, which, dont get me wrong, was hot. But they were hooked on the story. So hooked that they didnt even notice that one book in the sexually charged series didnt even HAVE any sex! Huss knows how to write and does her job well.If there is one thing you take away from my reviews of her books, please let it be this: Keep reading. I dont care if you dont like the main character in the first book of the series. I dont care if you dont think the plot is good enough to hold your attention throughout the series. You dont know s***. Huss builds her worlds and weaves her plots so intricately that she doesnt give it away in the first book. Hell, shell keeping you guessing until the last book. And thats when you hear the darn near audible SNAPS and CLICKS as everything solidifies into place. There are hints dropped left and right that are so subtle, you dont see them til you reread. I dont care if youre reading her erotica romances or this NA scifi series; I guarantee youll make that face of utter consternation as you try to figure it out and see what you missed. And thats why Ill keep reading her books.

This book was totally written for people my age who adored the movies Labyrinth, The Princess Bride, The Never-ending Story, etc. Love, magic, fantasy, sexiness, romance, adventure, miracles,...Lol loved it

Disclaimer: Be jealous, bluebirds. I got one of the rare advanced reader copies! Don't worry; I also have this puppy on pre-order and will be happily devouring it again on November 5th!So, I think you all know that I'm not a fan of serials. I usually find them just not enough: not enough story, not enough background, not enough to keep me interested. And then I get annoyed with waiting. But with this series, I wanted more every single book. Huss had me hating her main character in the first book. So why would I want to read on? Because I'm a seasoned Huss-y. I know there's more than meets the eye. And you had all those hints about Grace and that there's something about her past.So I panted and waited, quite impatiently, for the release of each book every two weeks. Seriously...what serial do you know of that comes out every two weeks? And yet, I was STILL impatient. I didn't lose focus or interest because I HAD TO KNOW. And each book read like a full book: full of action and plot twists and characters you fell in love with. You had hot sex scenes in most of the books, sure, but the focus was on the development of this relationship, of two people overcoming their pasts, of two people becoming one and full partners.And I was not disappointed in this final installment, either. Wholly satisfying, the loose ends from the previous five books are all tied off and wounds are cauterized. And you get the deets that we were hoping to read. And, I admit it, I sighed. With contentment. And then I perked up...Will we get a Conner & Felicity story?!

What fun, and new perspective on vampires. And the intro of new specie, Enchantress, gives this novel a wonderful and imaginative take.I liked that there is the "true love" - that is pure, and in the making from afar, though neither had known it was possible for either of them. Oh, but when it did happen, talk about "falling hard" and fast! Delightful. One cannot help but to cheer when finally their love is made known to one another. Glad that Louis is a good guy, although can be lethal. Then Eva, too, is no push-over. A strong female character with her own powers, and isn't afraid to demonstrate it for all to see. Not to brag, but for a purpose.Only one or two items that bothered me. It was a little annoying that Eva dithered. For a strong woman, who is not afraid so much of anything, has a difficult time being forthright about telling Louis of her feelings for him?! I thought that the authors did not do her justice in that area. It just did not fit her personality. In fact, it was opposite to what they have portrayed her as.  Another issue I had with it; it had left a couple of mysteries unresolved. Definitely saving for the sequel I suppose. This trend, the "triquels" and whathaveyou, is very annoying. Obviously, some novels warrant one, or two additional books, because the fans do not want the story to end. However, I believe that the authors must wrap up the first part of the story, fully.
