I honestly wasn't bored for a second and I found myself laughing a bit too. Karina Halle does a great job with humor. I just wish there was more horror like Dead Morning Sky (book 3) where things were even scarier for me when some real life creepy things were happening while I was reading it.This book is an absolute must read if you're a fan of the series because things are never going to be the same from here on out. Halle has made it clear that she is not going to take the easy road for Dex and Perry, but that makes things all the more interesting.

Talk about an imagination!  I wasn't totally sure of what to expect going into this one.  I wasn't sure which book to choose for my monthly kindle prime freebie and time was running out.  It was a debut, and it was originally a Kindle serial series.  But all in all it turned out wonderfully.Though I've read other novels with a circus theme, this one certainly comes off as unique. Mab is a really cool leader.  There are a lot of questions but the story pulls you in so that you really want to read along to get them answered.  She can be generous but she absolutely has an agenda, so it keeps things interesting.I really enjoyed the evolving family dynamic.  Romance fans who prefer the slow build should appreciate this one, though it's not agonizingly slow progress either.  We are just scraping the surface for what the future will bring.I think A. R. Kahler keeping his name ambiguous was a good thing. I know that some people prefer female authors in this genre, especially when it's written in a female's perspective.  But A.R. handles it well and makes all gender appealing, especially the potential love interest.  Upon reading his bio I learned that he actually was a part of a circus troupe.  That's about the only way to explain why this book felt so authentic and legit (as far as the paranormal goes of course).The next one is due out soon and I'm getting it, Prime or no Prime! It's currently at $3.99 on the Kindle, but the pre-order for book 2 is $1.99.

More like 3.5 stars. I'd read the sequel.The premise starts out interesting enough. I  just would have liked more of an actual story as opposed to the large amount of sex. Basically, this would have worked better for me as an urban fantasy than a paranormal romance.  I don't mind British or other non-American authors, but I'd be lying if I didn't admit that the constant references to her "knickers" got annoying after a while. Blame it on my American ignorance (even though we use that term occasionally), but it just doesn't sound sexy.  Granted, neither do the words "panties" or "drawers" or "bloomers".  The point is that it was overused, though with how often those two went at it I wondered why she even wore them at all.In general I wasn't a huge fan of the dynamic either. I like for the heroines to have a bit more control and it was pretty clear that he was in the driver's seat.  Later in the book they develop the actual storyline a bit more, though it may be too little too late for some. I like the magic and the creatures, so I might keep up with this one for a book or two just to feel it out and see if this series is for me.  Like most serial PNR novels the next book focuses on another couple, but apparently the overarching storyline continues.Though it wasn't a personal fave of mine this year, I do see its appeal so I can recommend giving it a try.

I don't totally love these books but I like them enough to continue.  They are fun to read here and there between other books.  This one wasn't my favorite.  After four books in, I was hoping to be a bit more invested in the storyline and characters.  Cain is featured in this one.  He's an infamous throughout the course of fictional and biblical history, so it's a tall order to create a memorable version of him.  A number of authors do a fine job of taking old characters and making them their own (ie. Karen Chance with Mircea, Jeaniene Frost with Vlad ).  I didn't feel like this book accomplished that very well.  The characterization in general was sort of flat for not only him, but for Martha as well.  The constant comparisons to her dead husband didn't really enhance the story or character development.I am glad that this series goes the typical PNR route and focuses on a different hero and heroine because I wouldn't see myself continuing if it was focused just those two.  I have become somewhat invested in the world and the potential future of The Fallen and what appears to be the ultimate villain. The battles and politics actually keep me more interest than I though I'd be.  And I like the occasional focus on the stars of the prior books. I'll certain continue if only to see what happens on that front. I like that these books don't take the instalove route as well even though they do eventually end up together.  The author does a good job of making them take a pretty hard road so that you care a little bit more as a reader.  I just worry about her stretching things out so that it becomes long in the tooth.If you follow this series, I definitely don't recommend skipping this one. It has a lot going on.

Calli, a tattoo artist, lost her memory some time ago believing she was in a terrible car accident that left her scarred.  The memories start to return when Nycholas, a predatory, serpentine Vesper comes into her life to save her from a dangerous situation.  As it turns out, this stranger may not be a stranger at all and as things heat up between them, his brutal master is honing in with plans that put Nycholas, Calli, and her family at risk.I wasn't totally sure what to expect when I took a chance on this one, but it surely exceeded my expectations.  Novellas tend to be more miss than hit for me when it comes to a brand new story and new characters, but Sarina did an excellent job with the world building, character development, and the suspense. I've seen less in full novels which really speaks to her talents and skills.  The Vespers, while attractive, can also be super creepy.  I found their species quite refreshing in the urban fantasy genre.  They really stand out to me in times when vampires and other supernaturals have become a dime a dozen.The story is not for the faint of heart, but if you like series that are on the darker side, then I definitely recommend giving this one a try.  Considering how the novella ended, I am assuming this is the start of a whole new series. If it is, I can't wait to read it in its full on glory.*ARC provided by the author.

Unlikely best friends, Sophie and Agatha, test their level of friendship as they are whisked away to the School for Good and Evil, where failing your fairy tale is not an option.  Sophie, the embodiment of all things good, finds herself dumped in the School of Evil while Agatha, the dark and broody, is placed in the School for Good.  Clearly there's been a mistake, right?  But when the going gets tough, their journey exposes who they really are and all may not be what it seems.I could say this was one of my top 3 reads of the year thus far.  Though the story is categorized as middle grade, I thought it touched on a few mature themes here and there and could have been placed into the Young Adult category.  It's certainly impressive when that group is reading 500-page novels.  Though lengthy it's at least an easy read, which is to be expected, but it's still very engaging and well-written for the most part.  I think the youth and adults alike will thoroughly enjoy it.I loved how it took the lore and stereotypes of past fairy tales and pretty much turned everything on its head.  The book even includes some great underlying messages, so it's clear that the author did quite a bit of homework.  There is a lot of character development for both girls, and I appreciated the gradual process.  The POVs switched between the two throughout the novel.  I think I preferred Agatha's POV and thought process, but Sophie's POV served its purpose as well.I wasn't crazy about the ending.  That was probably the one area where I believe it deviated from the formula and not in a satisfying way (for me at least), but the rest of the book is very strong.Though I've only seen an episode of the show Once Upon a Time (I'll get around to more eventually), I feel like this type of book would appeal to those fans.  I highly recommend this entertaining and fresh take on what it means to be a fairy tale.  What most surprised me was how this appears to be Soman Chainani's debut novel.  This might be the beginnings of a new series, but the work as a whole could be a standalone.  If this is a sign of things to come, I will certainly make sure I follow this author's future works!*ARC Provided by the publisher.

I enjoyed the first Night Prince novel immensely. As I've said before, Vlad is easily my favorite character of the franchise, so I'm super happy that he gets three books.  He's a very frustrating character at times with  arrogance that knows no bounds, but Frost knows how to make the payoff worth it.  I found the glimpse into his ruthless nature and past to be a highlight of the story, though I feel as if we're still only scratching the surface.  Leila was pretty cool in this book.  I like that she's a capable heroine, though clearly her humanity hinders her abilities and that's a major focus of the novel.  I wish the villains were fleshed out a little more, but it looks like book 3 will round that all out.  I'm looking forward to it.  There's an excerpt of the next Cat & Bones book as well.  I do hope we see more of Vlad and Leila in that installment. I don't believe we saw him at all in the prior Cat and Bones novel and he was sorely missed.I think it goes without saying that this is a definite recommend for fans of the series.*Review copy provided by the publisher.

Mercy's adjusting to  lot of changes theses days; she's now Mrs. Hauptman, wife and mate to alpha werewolf, Adam, and stepmom to his daughter, Jesse.  This level of normalcy is refreshing compared to the usual whirlwind of her life.  But of course things can't remain peaceful forever.  While taking advantage of Black Friday, Mercy and Jesse are in a car accident and find that they can't reach Adam or anyone else in the pack. And it's not a coincidence.The pack has been abducted and may be in serious danger.  It's a delicate time for the werewolf race as they work to gain public acceptance.  Without her pack to turn to, Mercy will reach out to every ally possible to save them, including some new and unexpected faces.This was a really great read! I breezed through it in no time. I really missed Mercy and the gang. Maybe that's a sign that this series is inching its way into my favorites group. And that's a pretty exclusive club!  But after this book it's earned it. Adam is a true badass here, even tied to a chair!  I don't quote Paris Hilton often, but that "that's hott." Seriously, he's to die for here, especially since we get TWO chapters from his point of view!His relationship with Mercy really is refreshing.  Though they have some drama and angst, they are secure in their relationship and don't bother with mind games.  That's become an oddity with a number of series, even some of my favorites.The story combines events that occur in Patricia Brigg's Alpha & Omega series.  It definitely helps if you've read the A&O series. I haven't yet, but I was able to keep up with no trouble.  Though at first I wasn't really planning to read the series, but after Frost Burned I think I'll go ahead and add A&O to my TBR pile, though I likely won't get to them until next year, maybe around the time when Mercy 8 will be released.  Thankfully that won't be two years.This is one of my favorite Mercy novels, but I would have liked more Bran and Stefan (who I think deserves a spin-off of his own).  The book wasn't too short or long, but maybe if it were a little longer they could have had a little more presence.  I hope we'll see a good bit of them next time.  This book is definitely a must read for Mercy fans.

Sofia Claremont gets more than she bargained for on the evening of her seventeenth birthday after she is kidnapped to a mysterious island. While perpetually nighttime, it'd be easy to assume that she's been taken to Alaska during that time of year; but it turns out it's an uncharted location where vampires rule.  She soon learns that she's been abducted into slavery at the mercy of vampires that can be as cruel as they are beautiful.She may have a chance to fare better than most, as her master is the dark royal Prince himself, Derek Novak.  Though blood thirsty due to a 400 year stasis he may be her best chance at survival, meaning she'll do everything in her power to remain on his good side.  However, his more sinister Novak siblings may have other plans...I've been on somewhat of a YA kick lately, so this was a satisfying read for the time.  The writing and world-building were very good for a debut.  The characterization was adequate in that I found myself becoming invested in the cast. I liked who I was supposed to late and hated who I was supposed to hate.  I think Sofia makes a few silly choices, but that's pretty much the status quo for 99% of heroines out there.  Derek is a pretty good leading man, though I would like to see him more unhinged.  It would make him a little more interesting considering his age, though he looks eternally youthful.I enjoyed the premise but I read it almost directly after another novel with a similar idea, though this novel was published first. I plan to follow both, but I definitely want to stagger them so that I don't mix up plots.  Though only a novella, Bella Forest makes it count with a tight and suspenseful story.  I look forward to more, hopefully a full length novel at some point.*ARC provided by the author.

Overall the book was just an okay read for me. There were things I liked about it and things I didn't and so I guess 3 is a good average. It starts out fairly interesting, but then it drags quite a bit and I found myself speed reading as opposed to savoring the pages. I really am not interested in details about the shampoo she uses, and things of that nature which just filled the pages. The story picks up with a bit of force towards the middle but then there were still some slow parts.The writing felt more young-adult in quality, and it always weirds me out to combine that writing level with descriptive sex scenes.I wasn't a fan of the ending at all. It was completely rushed and I found myself really irritated. I was surprised by the twist but then predicted practically everything down to the letter that followed. Considering the "surprise" ending I kind of wonder if I could reread it and see his POV with new eyes, but I didn't like it that much to give it another go.To be honest I thought I could relate a little more to Camryn than I did. This summer was rough for me when my ex (who I was still very good friends with) died suddenly and then learned my grandmother was battling cancer for a second time (after 10 years of remission). But I never really felt a connection to the character. Not saying that it's a requirement for every book I read, but I thought it'd be inevitable here.Maybe I'm just not that moved by fictional characters. Usually nonfiction is what does me in, and in movie form. I'm not unfeeling. I cried during Stepmom (that was more realistic than this though) and Pursuit of Happyness (though that actually is based off nonfiction). I just didn't find myself all that emotionally invested here. But that's just me. *shrugs*It's a good book and I don't regret reading it. It only took two days (faster than average for me) and I did want to finish it. But it's not a read I'm personally reeling from and see myself thinking about a lot down the road.

I.S. cops Ivy Tamwood and Rachel Morgan were having a pretty good week, working their beat, busting brimstone street dealers left and right. That is until they realize someone may be gunning for them directly. That'll put a damper on anyone's week.  Fortunately dodging risky attempts on their lives, it's up to Ivy to figure out whose targeting them and why. Could it be Piscary? Does he want to eliminate Rachel to get Ivy back in his clutches faster? Or could it be a new big bad with something else in mind entirely?My favorite format of The Hollows will forever be in written novel form, but I'll take it any way I can get it.  Ivy fans will enjoy this book as much as the last, Blood Work. It's told from her POV even though Rachel maintains a consistent presence.  It's not a requirement, but it will help to have read the short story told from Ivy's POV, Undead in the Garden of Good and Evil, because certain characters and events become relevant again.Considering that this is a graphic novel, I'll start with the graphic part.  The cover is actually a bit disappointing.  The cover of Blood Work was one of my favorite parts about the novel. The colors and badassness really made it pop. This one? Not so much. It's dark and vaguely mysterious, but it's not interesting. I feel like the model should be wearing a more sinister expression.It's no secret that I'm not particularly fond of the artwork. Even though there's a new illustrator, they implemented the original artwork so the overall style is unchanged.  After reading this one, I'm still not a fan but it is definitely improved over the first one in a few areas. For one, the coloring is more professional. It's more vibrant and saturated, giving it an all around better look.  Interestingly enough, I think Ivy looks better in this one than in Blood Work. But on the other hand, I thought Rachel looked prettier in Blood Work than she does here.  Piscary looked pretty spot on to how I envisioned him in my head, and a new character, Celeste, actually had a pretty cool design.  The artist definitely does better work with her own original creations.The story itself was pretty good, if a bit short. It's natural to feel that way when a usual Hollows entry is over 400 pages. Though I'm pleased with the direction the later books have taken, I do miss the old I.S. runner days when they had to solve mysteries and tag bad guys.  This book brings a little bit of that back.  I liked how it continued the plot lines from Ivy's short story because it expands the vampire world just a bit more when it comes to their politics, connections, and the domino effect that comes with certain actions. There's a lot of inner turmoil with Ivy, fighting her attraction to Rachel, fighting her vampiric nature, fighting Piscary's mind games. That's pretty much all the poor girl does! Not to mention actually physically fighting the bad guys. Piscary was pretty scary at times, especially when pulling auras.  He's certainly one you love to hate.  Kisten's role is even smaller here than in Blood Work, but we do see enough to know how strong of a bond he and Ivy shared.  Rachel wasn't quite as funny as she was in the first novel, but she still felt like Rachel, kicking butt, taking names.  And seeing her cherry red splat gun in action again was pretty cool too.All in all, I don't think these are the best that The Hollows has to offer, but it is worth a read and fans will appreciate the story.*Review copy provided by the publisher

The Quiet King.  The blind and deaf ruler of vampires seemingly should be disadvantaged, harmless even.  But that's not quite the case here.  With a harem of human dominas acquired for the sole purpose of bearing his vampire children, he maintains an upper hand.  Brie, a domina for two years, is nearing her turn to begin procreating with the King. Unfortunately, his policy to slaughter babies who could challenge him is a pretty big turn off. Her only hope to escape lies with Samuel, a vampire known for leading slaves to freedom.Slaves are one thing; dominas are another, and they happen to be the one exception for Samuel as it's too risky, and not just the from the ramifications of the palace.  Brie lies about her identity, but her blood doesn't and the closer she gets to freedom, the closer she gets to Samuel as her blood becomes increasingly irresistible.For 127 pages, I was very enthralled. Usually it's hard to get into a novellas for me, especially for a new and unestablished series, but the world-building and characters were well done.  Brie's inner conflict as she fights the temptation of Samuel while trying to remain faithful to her husband and children to whom she desperately wants to return kept things pretty interesting.  I finished actually wishing this could have been a full length novel. I was definitely left wanting more.  There is a lot of romantic tension, but plenty of action as well, often times pretty gruesome.  There's certainly more to the story that can be told and I, for one, hope it is.  The Quiet King has potential to be a very good villain and we're only scratching the surface.There are illustrations provided sporadically which were a nice touch, though I think they could be colored and placed all together in a certain sections of the book.  At this point I don't think they add or detract from the story, but it did make me think that this could be a great graphic novel.*ARC Provided by the author

In the not too distant future, cancer and the common cold are things of the past.  But in the vain of "I Am Legend,"  the cure to one (or two in this case) leads to an even worse pandemic that will change the course of humanity as we know it.  Fast forward two decades and we see a new world where the infected roam, humans, while maintaining some sense of civilization, are as paranoid and as ever, and the country looks towards leadership to continue the fight to restore the "land of the free and home of the brave" to its former zombie-less glory.  But with power comes corruption, and the brother sister blogging team of Shaun and Georgia Mason are determined to expose this corruption in order to deliver the truth to the people, no matter the cost.This book was certainly one of the more unique takes on the genre that I've seen.  It gets very technical and scientific, but it also gets very political.  The thing is, if the second book is more of the same with practically 20 pages of zombie action among 550+ pages of just about everything else, I think I might pass on continuing down this road. In fact, I'm probably more likely to just read The Road.  I didn't see the need for 571 pages here and the next books are even longer.  I interrupted my progress more than once by reading other novels because this just wasn't keeping my interest as much as I would have hoped.  Since this is a favorite of many, I tried my best to muddle through it.  In the end, I need more tension and action in these kinds of stories.  Politics is fine and dandy, but I would have liked to have seen a better balance with actual zombie screen time.  The plot kind of shambled along, like the zombies this book is supposed to be about.  It became annoyingly repetitive at times, from the countless blood screenings to countless references to Georgia's eye condition.It did offer an extensive amount of world building that made scientific and technological references believable in the scope of the story.  It was occasionally thought-provoking and there were a few moments that had potential to get me hooked, but ultimately it never really took off.  However, the last 15% was boldy executed and if that intensity was maintained for a larger portion of the novel, I would read the rest of the series without a doubt. In fact, it gained one extra star for that alone.In the end, I wasn't scared, the zombies were more like a backdrop to drive the plot (so much so that they could have been arguably interchangeable with some other pandemic, but I doubt this book would have sold as well), and I was mildly intrigued at best for the majority of the book. If I continue it won't be anytime soon. I'm certainly in no rush.

3.5 stars may be a little harsh, but I had to rate it relative to how much I enjoyed the other novels and short stories of this series.Don't pick up these novels if you can't handle heavy and dark themes--often to the extreme. Some scenes are certainly not for the faint of heart, but if you've read the first two then you know what you're getting yourself into.Having practically inhaled this series reading everything back to back, this book definitely had a different feel to it than its predecessors. There was a lot of drama and angst that sort of came out of nowhere, particularly on Kingsley's part. Not saying he has to be "on" all of the time but I enjoyed his playfulness, confidence and allure in prior books (especially in his short story Submit to Desire), yet it was hardly anywhere to be found here as he spends the majority of this book being lovelorn and bitter. Though it wasn't unfounded, I just didn't enjoy it as much.I wasn't too surprised regarding Soren and Kingsley's past, but I wasn't expecting a third of the book to focus on it, and after a while the flashbacks felt a bit superfluous at times.I do root for Nora and Wesley to find happiness with each other, but in this book it felt a little drawn out. By the 60% point I felt like the bulk of what needed to be told was told. It picked up somewhat towards the end, but it made the read feel more disjointed to me because there was such a slow build to that point.There's a cliffhanger which will probably anger some readers. Usually I don't like them, but I honestly felt apathetic because I predicted the twist and knew that there wouldn't be enough page time to resolve it. It was a little too over-the-top and melodramatic for me.Overall I do enjoy Tiffany Reisz's writing. It's very cultured, thought-provoking, and it invokes a sense of horror which might add to the appeal since erotica is usually not my genre of choice. It still isn't' outside of this series. While there are some pretty graphic and explicit scenes, the series as a whole transcends that. I will keep reading due to the quality writing more so than the subject matter. I just wonder what Reisz could possibly have in store for us with the 4th book as this one could have served as a fine conclusion to the series with a few adjustments.*ARC provided by NetGalley

This is a novella from the Blud series. As a follow-up to Delilah Dawson's debut novel Wicked as They Come, to hold us over until the next book we get to revisit her alternative London and Criminy Stain's caravan. Instead of Criminy and Leticia (Tish) getting focus, we meet Madam Morpho, a new addition to the caravan with a unique ability to re-animate butterflies, and we meet Mr. Murdoch, the mysterious engineer behind the caravan's clockworks and staging. Morpho is running from her past, but is she valuable enough for the caravan and Mr. Murdoch to run with her?I love this series for a combination of reasons, from the quirky steampunk London makeover to the blud bunnies to enigmatic Criminy himself. The first two are there in spades which is great, but I've unfortunately caught a case of Criminy fever and found myself missing his presence immensely this time around, Tish as well. The world building remains impressive, with enough imagination to satisfy any urban fantasy/paranormal/steampunk fan, but the romance itself came up a bit short for me. Insta-love stories never really do it for me, namely because I just can't suspend my belief enough to completely buy it, and that's what we see here. Granted, Ms. Dawson is only working with 100 or so pages so she has to move quickly. It's just that it didn't resonate with me very much and if I was going to read this for the romance, I think it would have enjoyed it more if it was Criminy and Tish, an establish ship that readers are already invested in. Nevertheless, it's a solid read and I do recommend fans of the series give it a shot.

I do enjoy this series, but no installment has surpassed the first book as my favorite. Archangel's Storm doesn't do it either, but I would probably rate it top 3. Much like Archangel's Blade, Elena and Raphael take a back seat as the story gives Jason, one of Raphael's Seven, focus as he enters the rival territory of archangel Neha to solve the grisly murder of her consort.  Jason has his own demons to face from his past, and they do challenge him; however, he must put it aside to work with Princess Mahiya, daughter of the slain archangel, to find the murderer and return to Raphael.Jason isn't particularly one of my favorite side characters. In all honesty, I never really thought too much about his character at all so I wasn't really looking forward to this book.  I sooner expected angel Illium to get his own story or even my personal fave, the vampire Venom.  While Illium doesn't get much time at all here, Venom actually does get significant focus which was a pretty good consolation prize. As progeny of Neha, his presence helped to flesh out the story and character development, though I would have liked more.Both Jason and Mahiya have had pretty difficult upbringings, easily making them sympathetic characters. You root for them to find happiness, but it isn't the easiest love story and there is no insta-love, which is for the better in my opinion.  There is a lot more mystery and story than romance in this book which is personally how I like it, but it's hard to say if other readers will feel the same. I love the world building and the focus on angel politics, but I am sure there is a contingent that reads these more so for the romance aspect.It was a satisfying read, but I am still hoping Ms. Nalini Singh gifts us with a Venom-centric book at some point.  With the next book set to go back to Raphael and Elena, I am not sure how far off  that possibility is. Either way, I'll be reading all the same.

Betrayal and redemption are the primary themes in Love is Mortal, book 3 in the Valerie Dearborn series. It also completes the story arc of Valerie and Lucas. Stuck in the land of the Fey, Valerie is desperate to get out of Cerdwellyn's clutches. Her powers as an empath, while useful, are not enough and she'll have to work with Lucas if they have any hope of freedom. But can she trust him after his betrayal?I have enjoyed this series quite a bit so it was sad to see this come to the end, though this book was a fitting way to conclude their story. There's a lot of character development, particularly on Lucas's end. After the devastating revelations in Love is Fear, there was a lot of rebuilding to be done when it came to Lucas and Valerie's relationship and not a lot of time to do it. The work around was effective.There wasn't as much action this time around as Val and Lucas spend a great deal of time captive. It's more of a psychological game. The the start was a little on the slow side for me because of this, but it does hit its stride and doesn't really stop until it's over.Even though this doesn't leave on a cliffhanger, there are a lot of questions still left when it comes to the land of the Fey and Cerdwellyn's past and future, as well as Jack and Rachel, so thankfully we're not completely finished with Valerie Dearborn world. It's a fabulous series and I still want more.*ARC provided by the author.

This controversial spin-off of the Fever series switches from the point of view of MacKayla Lane's to her former sidekick, Dani "Mega" O'Malley.  After a tragic revelation, Dani goes from friend to foe.  On the run from Mac, Dani does what she does best-survive.  Of course her super powers make her a target for bigger and badder supernaturals, namely Ryodan, the immortal nightclub owner, and Christian, an Unseelie prince in the making after a shocking turn of events from the original novels.  Her abilities are particularly useful after certain parts of the already ravaged city turn up frozen, killing innocent people for no apparent rhyme or reason. To save her city, she begrudgingly joins forces with these guys, though her mere compliance may not be all they have in mind.To be honest, I wasn't really sure if I'd like this book.  Dani was fine for me as a supporting character, but I wasn't quite sure if she could be main character material.  After actually reading it I'm still not quite sure, but the final product turned out better than I thought.  Moning adopts a completely different voice for Dani and she is every bit the obnoxious teen that we've come to love or loath. I try to cut her some slack; she facing the most awkward time of her life with little to no support system, and she still wants to do good things and protect people.Moning can do the love triangle thing pretty well. Normally I don't like them, but the Barrons/V'Lane thing was an exception.  In this instance, it's got an extra little statutory dimension that's bound to ruffle a few feathers.  The book walks a fine line for me, but I can see how it could cross it for other readers.  I just keep in mind that these guys are immortal and they are enamored with the woman Dani will be, not the girl she is now. But again, it's a fine line. Her human buddy, Dancer, is also another good prospect (and probably the healthiest), but 3 potential love interests obviously makes things a bit crowded.  Someone's gotta go.The mystery wasn't that great to me. It was interesting the first couple of times, but it felt a little repetitive after a while as they stumbled upon scene upon scene.  However, a new recurring villain is introduced, and boy is she freaky! I loved reading those scenes and I felt genuinely scared!I wish there was more Mac and Barrons presence, but I wasn't expecting that so it wasn't too disappointing.  Cruce is also back, tormenting the Sidhe Seers in their dreams.  I don't know about anybody else, but I hope there is a more permanent solution to get rid of him for good.  Not a big fan of rapists and I don't care to read about them on an on-going basis if it doesn't include their deserved castration...A little much? Sorry...All in all, there were flashes of brilliance that reminded me why I love the original Fever novels (they're my #2 or #3 fave), but it wasn't quite as addictive for me.  I read all 5 Fever novels in 6 days.  This one took me a few days, but I will definitely continue reading.  This world is just too good to resist.

The trauma after the drama from the events of Third Grave Dead Ahead has left Charley in a bit of a rut.  Instead of solving cases, she's taken up a new hobby: sitting on her couch all day, acquiring a Home Shopping Network addiction in the process.  She finally finds a bit of motivation once a woman shows up who needs her help.  Someone is trying to kill her, but something is amiss when all of her loved ones believe she's paranoid.Meanwhile, Reyes Farrow, Son of Satan and her better half, has been released from prison, making ends meet by doing what he does best: fighting. He's been keeping his distance from Charley, but that doesn't last long (not surprisingly) as he becomes a person of interest in an arson case.I decided to shelf this series after the third book, but I agreed to an experiment for fellow blogger to go the audiobook route in order to determine if my reading experience could redeem the series for me.  I can say that this book was a bit more bearable.  I'm not sure if it's because I had a break from reading the books back to back or what.  There were a few moments when I got annoyed with Charley's punchlines and dialogue, but it wasn't so bad. I thought the narrator did a pretty good job, though she sounds slightly older than how I imagine Charley would sound.  I liked her voices for the supporting characters, particularly her aunt.My biggest gripe with this series is the lack of supernatural conflict in place of the regular old murder mysteries. While I felt her grim reaper issues actually were a little better in that respect, things need to come to a head already.  I recently saw that the books have been extended through Book 6.  At this point, because I've read this far I would be willing to continue the series in the event that things end at Book 6, but not much further beyond that.Either way, this was a good opportunity.  If I didn't routinely use text-to-speech I'd likely go the audiobook route much more often.

My daughter asked for this as she said it would help prep for med school tests.The book was highly recommended by several of her professors and the dean of her medical school. I thumbed thru it before I gave it to her and it is very detailed just as I expected. I wish when I was in pharmacy school 30 years ago there had been something like this as it would have been a big help.My daughter rated this a really good 8.75 to 9.s5 out of 10 - recommended for med students only,

This was a gift for my daughters 24th birthday and she loved it!She has told me it was great and the illustrations were really cool!. The book arrived in new condition at a price that was at least 10% below what I could find anywhere else. I thought the cover was pretty neat.She rated this a very high 9.26 to 9.75 out of 10 - highly recommended for Harry Potter fans!

Overall this was a very good set of Holmes stories. I don't care for The Strange Death of Sherlock Holmes - I thought it was crap but all the other stories were are least a 7.0 to 8.0 out of 10. In fact three of stories (The Mystery of the Red City, The Case of the Maltese Catacombs  & The Climbing Man) were top notch - 9 out of 10 stars!!The rest were 7 to 8 to out of 10 stars.I was a little disappointed that there weren't any really Egypt stories. But it was nice to have another visit with Sir Henry Baskerville even if he didn't seem like the same person in may ways.I would rate this book of short stories a really good 8.0 to 8.5 overall - recommended for Holmes lovers like me!

I've been going gray for about 5 years. My wife thought this would be a good idea so I ordered some.It worked really well and covered almost all of my gray hair in one application. It was not too difficult to use - even for a guy - and nearly matched the color of my 'normal' hair. But I now understand that they are discontinuing this for a similar product that according to the reviews doesn't work as well. The price on this has - as you imagine - at least doubled.  Since I figure that I will have to do this about every 6 to 8 weeks this will last me several months.I would rate this a really good 8.5 to 9.0 - recommended to least try!

This is a great multi-purpose grater!.This is very well built and easy to use. I thought the little ;box' that fits under the grater (WITH IT"S OWN LID) was a really great idea as well. You can grate enough cheese etc. for 2 or 3 days then store it in the little container - and do it all in one swipe!. This grater has 4 sides with different size holes. etc.It's easy to clean as well - we put it in our dishwasher and it came out perfect. My only real 'beef' is it's cost - regular retail is about $50 which is high for the average person. I was able to buy this at a huge discount in return for this review.I would rate this a very high 9.25 to 9.75 - it's nearly perfect for a multi-purpose grater!

Stated size was same as actual size - all printing sharp and clear - all images razor sharp - colors true but slightly muted.Price was under $10 including S/H!Very good poster for this classic musical that helped make Julie Andrews a big star. Or course most of you know this was based on a true story. However it varies quite a bit from the actual truth.I would rate this poster a very good 8.5 to 9.0 out of 10 - nice for Julie Andrews fans, Christopher Plummer fans or classic musical fans!

These are very nice colored metal stylists for under 90 cents each. Since I tend to lose them I thought I would buy a bunch and see if that helps any!.They are a nice, almost Tiffany Blue, and seem well made to me. My wife is also using one and told me she really likes it. I will also give my daughter one sometime this week after work.I would rate these a really good 8.5 to 9.0 out 10 NOT considering the price. Considering the price I would value them at lease 0.25 points higher! Recommended!

I've already hung this nice metal sign above our 75 inch TV in our basement theater!.Stated size was exactly the same as actual size. Printing is razor sharp and really pops on our gray walls. Price was $8.51 and that included S/H!This is a great, nicely sized metal sign for a home theater or any room that is movie themed.I would rate this sign a really good 8.75 to 8.25 our of 10 - you just can't beat this for the money!

I've compared this to an original large poster from this movie that I gave my daughter last Christmas. The colors match beautifully!The poster arrived quickly and in new condition. Price was very low (THINK UNDER $5.00!!!) and included S/H. All the printed words are razor sharp as are all of the images. Stated size was exactly the actual size.This is a great poster for this classic movie! Audrey Hepburn has always been of my favorite actresses'. And this movie along with My Fair Lady rank among her best IMHO.I would rate this poster a very high 9.25 to 9.75 - HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

This is a very nice poster - colors rich and true - images very sharp as was all the printing. The paper is fairly heavy.HOWEVER - it is both too long and two wide by a good half an inch. Since I am custom framing these that's not too bad a thing for me - plus we will probably have the framer trim some of the white off on all four sides. BUT if you were going to use a off-the-shelf standard 11x17 frame you will have a real problem. You will need to trim all four sides about 1/4 of a inch and cut it perfectly so you will have straight and true edges. That's going to be pretty difficult for the average person doing it at home.But otherwise this is a great poster. Since this is one of my favorite movies it will be hung inside our theater once it's framed.I would rate it a 8.0 to 8.5 out of 10 mostly for the size issue.

Another great poster for a great movie!I'm putting this in a white wood frame so it will pop downstairs on a medium gray wall. Since our downstairs home theater is done except for the white baseboard trim I will hang this when back from the framers this weekend.Actual size was identical to stated size. All print and images are very sharp. Price included S/H and was below $5!I would rate this poster a very high 9.0 to 9.5 out of 10 - highly recommended!

This is, quite simply, a great film!This has to be one of the best animated movies of at least the last 30 years. This plot is very good, the animation is superb and the voice actors are perfect - especially Robin Williams! His genie takes this from a top flight flick to a great one! We really enjoyed the extra bits of his genie character. He truly was one of the all-time greats and is sorely missed by all. His ability to improvise was unbelievable. But his ability to show how much he cared for Aladdin was off the charts.I was slightly disappointed they changed the lyrics to the opening song but it was only one line.Picture was perfect, colors were true and vibrant - sound was excellent. Price was very good and the Blu-ray arrived very quickly in new condition.I would rate this a 9.25 to 9.75 out of 10 - I deducted 0.25 points for them changing the lyrics to Arabian Nights but otherwise a perfect animated picture!

My wife and I love this series - it's a shame they didn't make anymore.The stories started out very true to the Stout books but just like Jeremy Britts Homes they started to deviate toward the end. The only thing I didn't like was re-using actors in different roles in different shows. But that was a minor personal opinion. The picture is great as is the sound. The DVDs arrived quickly in new condition.I would rate this series a very high 9.25 to 9.75 out of 10 - HIGHLY SATISFACTORY  as Wolfe would say!  Very highly recommended!

Very nice poster for this nearly 85 year old movie - this movie made Boris Karloff a huge horror star.This was released (on 11/21/31 - close to Thanksgiving!) about 9 months after Dracula (2/12/31 - Happy Valentines Day! - w/Bela Lugosi - who, apparently,  was offered this monster role - some say her turned it down & others say they changed their minds, etc). Thus 1931 was the start of the modern monster movies by Universal.The poster arrived very quickly in new condition. Stated size was the actual size. Colors slightly subdued. All images and printing were sharp. Price was very low and included S/H.I would rate this great poster a very high 8.75 to 9.25 out of 10 - recommended!

Poster arrived quickly and in new condition.Colors are true but slightly subdued. Images are sharp and clear - all printing is sharp as well. However, there is too much white on the sides IMHO. I plan on trimming the sides at my framers. In one sense this will be good as it will 'enhance'  Kong's height.I would rate this poster a lower due to all the white - 7.75 to 8.25 out of 10 - still recommended but there is too much border IMHO.

This is really cute!I bought this for my daughter for her 24th birthday next month. The price was under $10 including S/H. The lunchbox arrived very quickly and in perfect shape. All the images are sharp as all the printing. The pink color along with black is pretty neat as well.Since my daughter is a Audrey Hepburn freak I just know this will be a big hit!I would rate this a really good 8.75 to 9.25 out of 10 - IF it had a had a thermos w/Audrey's picture on from the movie it I would raise my rating to a perfect 10 out of 10!! It's that good!

This is a great product!.PQQ is a B vitamin like compound that - believe it or not - actually can increase both the efficiency AND number of Mitochondria in our cells - which are the little energy producers we all have. As a pharmacist I can tell you this is very important as we lose both the efficiency and number of mitochondria as we age. This is the main reason we get tired easier as we hit our 50's and beyond. There are few compounds that do this - another one is Metformin - a Rx only drug for diabetes.I had been buying this direct from Swanson but it's cheaper from Amazon and cheaper to boot!I would rate this unique compound a really good 8.75 to 9.25 out of 10 - well worth a try for nearly everyone looking for a little more energy!

I love this movie - poster is nearly perfect!.This was the first Sherlock Holmes movie with Basil Rathbone and Nigel Bruce. They made a total of 14 movies from 1939 to 1946. I felt each movie was a little sillier than the one before. But the first 3 or 4 were pretty good. And this was the best of the lot. Dr. Watson is played closer to the book in this one which is something I prefer.The poster arrived quickly and in new condition. The stated size was perfect with the actual size. The image is very sharp as is all the printing. Colors are intriguing and capture the mystery of the movie. I do wish the poster was about 1/2 a shade lighter but otherwise it's perfect!I would rate this poster a 8.5 to 9.0 out of 10!

This poster has a very nice, clear but slightly blurry image for this nearly 100 year old movie. This poster might have been better to be a little smaller and thus have a slightly sharper image - I would have preferred 18 by 24.This is a very creepy movie of the Dracula story. As many of you know it was thought 'lost' for quite awhile after they were sued for filming without approval from the Bram Stoker estate. All copies were to be destroyed but some managed  to survive. But all the copies I had seen until very recently were very dark, grainy and lacked a lot of detail. And now the film has been restored in Blu-ray format with much improved picture.The stated size was exactly the size I received. Image fairly sharp as are all printed words. The poster arrived fairly quickly in new condition.I would rate this poster a very high 8.75 to 9.25 out of 10 - it looks great framed!

This is a great poster for a truly great classic movie!I have seen this film at least a dozen times and every time I see some little detail that I had missed before. The on screen chemistry between Bogart and Bergman is very 'real'. And Claude Rains does his usual great job. And the ending is quite simply one of the best of all time - simply classic!I only have one very minor complaint - it looks to me like 1/8 of a inch got cropped during coping this poster as a little of the face of Paul Henreid has been cut. But otherwise this is super - the paper is very heavy - the size was perfect, the red is great and all the images are razor sharp. All of the printing is sharp as well. I am having trouble deciding what color the frame should be - I first thought a subdued red but am now leaning to a flat black or maybe a dark gray. I guess I will see what our framer recommends.I would rate this a 9.0 to 9.5 - if the entire image was there I would rate this a perfect 10 out of 10 - very highly recommended!

Since Wicked is one of my all-time favorites I think this is a pretty cool poster!We already have 2 of these framed - one of which is signed by the cast and hanging in our 'poster' hall. The other is at my daughters apartment but not yet on the wall. This one will be a gift for the daughter of a close friend for Christmas.The colors are perfect and the size was nearly perfect as well. It will go the framers we use this Sat or maybe Labor Day Weekeday as I don't believe on waiting to the last minute on Christmas presents.IF you love WICKED as we do or just Broadway musicals in general this is priced too low to pass up!! I would rate this poster a very high 9.25 to 9.75 - it just doesn't get much better than this!!!!!

Pretty good! I used this on some Omaha Steakburgers and they turned out really tasty.We visiting some friends last Saturday and cooked out using this to flavor all the meat. Everyone loved the taste and all the burgers were gobbled up fairly quickly. This is not something I would use every single time but it will be a major player in our flavoring rotation. Since we use our grill 3 or 4 times a week I imagine this will be lucky to last a month.The product came quickly arriving in perfect condition. The price was reasonable and the flavor, as I've already said, was really good. I would rate this a very good 8.5 to 9.0 out of 10 - certainly recommended for anyone who grills out often.

The first thing is this is very cute!I love Halloween so I bought this for my wife to make for me. She loved it and agreed it's cute.It arrived very quickly and in perfect shape. The price was good but S/H was a little high IMHO. I would rate this Halloween craft a very good 8.75 to 9.25 out of 10 - recommended for anyone who loves needle work or Halloween.

My daughter needs these for med school and since she double gloves most of the time I bought several boxes as this was available at a very good price.The boxes arrived looking like they had been dropped-kicked but that didn't harm the actual gloves so it ended up being ok.I would rate these a very good 8.5 to 9.0 out of 10.

Since I just love the classic Universal monsters these are great!!When they came out on Sept 30 1997 I bought a few of them and promptly LOST them. Life being what it is I didn't replace them and forgot all about them until running across these the other day. Since I'm in a lot better shape financially now I bought several sheets - some to frame for our basement theater and some just to keep because they're so cool.The price was reasonable and the stamps arrived in new perfect condition. The arrived very quickly. I did feel the S/H was on the high side but not high enough to keep me form making the purchase.Now if they would only have the Creature of the Black Lagoon, Bride of Frankenstein and the Invisible Man stamps I would be a very happy guy!!I would rate these a very high 9.0 to 9.5 out of 10 - perfect for Universal monster lovers, most Halloween fanatics and for those who collect stamps!

I've only used this twice but it went on smoothly. I wore while I worked out to test how it would stay on.  I walked/jogged a mile then lifted weights for about 50 minutes then rode the bike for 3 miles. Afterwards I sat on my deck for about an hour reading. Since I didn't even turn pink I think I can safely say that the product worked as advertised.As a pharmacist I feel the ingredients listed are both safe and effective.This sunscreen worked well and resisted wearing off very well.However (and it seems there is always a however) there is no way the average person would pay the $70 list price. Most people would not even pay the Amazon price of $40 as you can find good stuff for under $20. You might have to apply it more often than this product but so what? I have had skin cancer removed 3 times - the last time from my nose using the Mohr's procedure. I required some minor plastic surgery for that as well so I understand the importance of being protected. When I was a younger (and stupider) guy I, as most people, didn't think about this kind of thing - I was a both a roofer and framer in the construction industry for a little more than 3 years so I was in the sun 12 hours some days.And that my friends was not very smart!So in summary - a very good product that I felt was too high in price. I would rate the product a very high 9.0 to 9.5 without thinking about the price.For the average person the price will be almost as important as how the product performs however - taking in consideration the price I would have to lower my rating to 6.0 to 6.5. I would only use this if the price point was under $30.***************************In the spirit of full disclosure I bought this at about 99% off in return for a full and honest review.

This is - quite simply - GREAT!The size is perfect - the image is nice and sharp - colors are true and vibrant! The poster arrived quickly and in perfect shape. The price was very low (think under $10 including S/H!!!).  This is going in the Sci-Fi section in our basement theater that we hope to open by Labor Day weekend (might not be 100% done but should be functional!).This very old Sci-Fi poster is from one of my favorite old (1938) serials - Flash Gordon's trip to Mars'!I would rate this a very high 9.0 to 9.5 out of 10 - highly recommended for old time movie lovers, people who like old time serials,  Flash Gordon fans or even Buster Crabb geeks!

This was exactly what I was looking for!My credit union went from ONLY accepting loose change to ONLY accepting rolled coins. I don't understand that because they don't count them or even verify that that there are no Canadian coins now. They still have a loose coin counter but they charge you 10% to use it.Since interest rates are still below 1% they are making money off of your deposit big time. Nothing like CHARGING people to deposit money. What's next? Charging you to withdraw your own money?Since I bought some of the counter bottles I just wait until I get a certain amount then roll them up and deposit them in my daughters college account.It's a stupid way to handle it - I guess they just don't want to mess with change anymore.These were very cheap and arrived quickly in perfect shape. I would rate them a 8.75 to 9.25 out of 10.

This is a nice little project.I bought this for my wife as she really likes this kind of thing. However it arrived damaged as it was bent up a little. Thankfully my wife tells me it should turn out ok.This would make a nice pre-Christmas gift for someone who likes crafts - maybe around Thanksgiving to do after the big meal, etc.The price was reasonable but I felt that the S/H was little high especially considering there was some light damage. I would rate this a pretty good 8 to 8.5 due partly to that damage and the relatively high S/H cost.

For some reason the touring Broadway productions are no longer selling posters. I think that's stupid as that's just lost profit.I asked and was told that too many of the posters were be damaged when they moved from city to city. That's just dumb and easily avoided. We usually buy a poster and frame it when we see the show. Since we see 5 to 7 shows a year that I will now have to buy thru Amazon, etc usually for a lower price than the show charges the shows are losing a lot of revenue. The one guy I talked with said they usually sold around 150 posters a city. IF the average show did 15 cities a year that's 150x20x15 or $45,000 or so lost money.I don't understand why you would walk way from that much money.But anyway - the poster was dead on for the size. The image was sharp and the colors were perfect. The poster arrived in perfect shape. I've going to take it and a couple of others to be framed tomorrow as it's my day off this week.I would rate this iconic poster a 9 to 9.5 out of 10 - recommended for Broadway fans or anyone who like the show!

This was another gift for my wife who loved it!Of course this is image is a big hit with women of all ages. The price and shipping speed were great. The image is crystal clear and razor sharp. The colors were vibrant and beautiful. The size was right on.This will also go in our nearly finished basement home theater.  I would rate this a very good 9.5 to 10 out of 10 - nearly perfect in every way!!

I bought this for my wife as a gift as the animatied Disney version is one of her favorite movies of all time!This will go in our nearly finished home theater once it's framed. The image is very clear and sharp. The colors were very vibrant - in fact I felt the blue of her dress was gorgeous!! The stated size was right one as well. The price and shipping speed were great. And the poster arrived in perfect condition.I would rate this a very rare 10 out of 10 - it is truly that good!

Roger Miller was the bomb!!Ok - now that everyone has stopped laughing at me we will continue. This includes all of Millers big hits and several other interesting and intriguing songs. For a while in the mid 1960's he was hot as you could be. Then - for whatever reason (including his ETOH problem, splitting form his wife, partying in general, etc) he seemed to lose his way and started to record the songs of others which didn't seem to fit him as well as his own songs had.And that was a shame!.I've seen the musical he wrote all the music for (Big River - the book was kind of based on Huckleberry Finn) and it seemed - briefly - that he had found his muse once again. But then he died from lung cancer a few years later which ended everything.But his first songs, King of the Road, Dang Me, Do-Waka-Do, Engine, Engine #9 and England Swings - all in about  a 18 month period! - were was unforgetable as you could get!!!And then stuff happened and his career was in decline for quite a while.This CD has very good sound and arrived quickly in new conidition. The price was very reasonable.I would rate this a VERY high 9.25 to 9.75 - and yes it is that good! HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!

This is a nice overview of Sinatra's very long career. It includes all the big hits I remember and a few I had forgotten about as well.Of course even when you have a collection this big people will say why was this song included but not this other one. I didn't view this set in that light - if this was supposed to be ALL the songs he ever recorded that would be different. It is truly a career spanning collection however so it was nice to hear how his voice changed  - and the kind of songs he chose to record changed as well. Of course life changes a person and this is reflected in the songs he recorded.Sound quality is very good but the very old songs also reflect their age.I would like to see a series of collections that would in the end release EVERY SONG he ever recorded. That's probably not going to happen for many different reasons but I'm allowed to dream - aren't I?I would rate this a very high 9.25 to 9.75 out of 10 - VERY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

Since this was my daughters favorite book when she was just starting to read I bought this for her as her old book is missing it's cover, etc.The book was in almost new condition and was at a great price. It arrived very quickly and will be a surprise birthday gift for her in a few months. I remember reading  this to her almost countless times as she just loved the Duck and his many adventures.I would rate this children's book a very high 9.0 to 9.5 - it has been one of a child's most loved characters for many, many years!Very highly recommended!!!

We saw Bob Segar in concert about a month ago at Banker's Life Fieldhouse (home of the Indiana Pacers).He put on a extremely good show considering his age and recent shoulder problems. I had forgotten about some of his music - it's really pretty good! He did really good versions of Night Moves, Hollywood Nights, Mainstreet (reminded me of downtown Sheridan IN where I worked w/my dad at Biddle's Screw machine factory during summer break), Old Time Rock & Roll, Like a Rock, We've got Tonight, Against the Wind and Sill the Same!!I would rate this greatest hits package a very high 9.0 to 9.5 - recommended for anyone above the age of 40 or so!!

This was a home run for me! As my wife and I are both pharmacists plus considering my wife has started doing cross stitch again she loved it!This was a surprise gift for our 33rd anniversary and it scored me major points! This was very reasonably priced and arrived very quickly in new condition.I would rate this a very, very high 9.25 to 9.75 our of 10 - very highly recommended for any pharmacist, pharmacy tech or even many other medical professionals as a gift

Not as interesting or well done as I remembered but still worth watching. A bunch of us went to see this when it first came out at a small old theater in Carmel, Indiana. Most of the group had read the book and had discussed it into the ground. The ones who had read the book and were at least open to the concepts therein enjoyed it - the rest not so much - in fact most of them thought it was crap.An interesting aside - the ones of us who liked and thought the concepts thought provoking are much better off (economically speaking) than those who thought the whole idea sucked.  I'm not sure what the means but it is true.Anyway the music was intriguing as well. I almost wonder it this is not the whole and complete movie we saw as (and yes - I know that this was a long time ago) some of it seems missing, etc.So - if you find the whole ancient aliens thing at least pluasible you will at least enjoy seeing some of the footage. If not, then you will think it's pure crap. I would rate this as a decent 8.0 to 8.5 - interesting concept but the final product is lacking .

This book completes my James Bond Book collection. I now have a copy of every James Bond story every written irregardless of who wrote it or when it was written.Ths book it self was only fair to good as it only kind of follows the movie and has little in common with the Fleming story. There was more back story for the characters and the plot deviated a little from the movie making this book kind of a freak. However 'it is what it is' to misquote Yogi Bearra - a NY Yankee baseball great from the 1950s to 1960's.I would rate this very hard to find (and apparently fairly rare) book a 7.25 to 7.75 out of 10 - recommend if you want to complete your collection otherwise it's skipable IMHO.

I first purchased these at a Amish store about 45 minutes from where I live in central Indiana.It was a 1 pound bag for $7.50 plus tax. Since I only use them 2 or 3 days a week they have lasted me almost 6 months. However finding myself out of them plus my wife is now using them some I was looking for them on Amazon and found this 3 pound bag at a much cheaper price per pound.I'm not sure what the people who said there is not a liquid center thought this would be but there is most definitely a liquid center. However, since it's honey and that is a very thick liquid maybe that confused them.I would rtate this a high 8.75 to 9.25 out of 10 - recommended for honey lovers of nearly all ages (Maybe not for very young children due to possible choking problems!).
Using one in a 13 amp load 120VAC scenario and it works great, lights up and I have lots of spares now just in case :)
Very nice quality transformer for the money.

I'm using this for an odd specialty application to control the voltage input to a 24VAC transformer that then goes through a full wave bridge to produce DC output to run a motor.  I was very happy to find that the knobs have an internal plastic "boss" protrusion in them that I was able to use to prevent it turning off completely so that it is on at start up. (This isn't one you can turn on and off by pushing in on the knob.  It has a detent for "off" when you turn it all the way back.
Just as presented. Works great

Love this.  Heavy duty.  Love the ON - OFF label.  When you throw this toggle switch, you know it means business :)  I'm using it as the main power switch for an application that involves operation of a 1550 watt heating coil and a DC motor run from a full wave bridge in the circuit.  This switch is hefty and well made.

I took a chance on this for an application using an SCR to control a 1500 watt heater.  It says 100 - 300VAC, but turning u the SCR slowly with load, it comes on at 20VAC.  Not sure if it's true RMS voltage or not because all I need is repeatability. I was hoping it would work with an SCR and I'm so glad it does, although I would have been able to use the current value alone for my control purposes (which I am taking from the power input to the SCR).  Nice that it can read voltages so low after it kicks on although I'll be using it mainly for the range of 80 - 130 VAC.  Hard to believe the low price.  Hope it lasts a while !!  Thanks to all the reviewers who led me to buy this.
This is a very nice, fairly thick gauge box.  I like the elevations that fit the holes so you don't need to screw it together right away.
This was a great and inexpensive solution to managing wires in an application I'm working on.  Will definitely use again in the future.
Nice bright red display.  Inexpensive and easy to install.  Just what I needed for my DC voltage application.  I am operating it with a regulated 12VDC power input.

Definitely five stars.  I'd give it six if I could.  Love the small form factor on this device, the attention to detail in design and construction -- like the numbered dial.  I'm using this to control a 120VAC heating coil that is around 9.4 ohms.  I decided to put an 80 mm computer cooling fan over it to aid its generous heat sink. I'm running the heater at about 1500 watts.  Will update this review after I'm sure it lasts a while, but I'm very happy thus far.

We are glad we got Alexa!  Just as a voice recognition music speaker alone this was worth our purchase price of around $120.  Alexa will find and play any artist or song from all the ripped CD's we've ever purchased through Amazon via The Cloud, Amazon Prime music, much of which can be added to our music library for free, Pandora, iHeart, TuneIn, Audible, and whatever content we have on our cell phones via Bluetooth, or she will randomly mix a selection of music we may specify.  Naturally, we are finding ourselves listening to a lot more music than we every did before because it is now so easy.  And the sound is quite good and fills our living room and kitchen area very acceptably.We absolutely love the shopping list function that works in conjunction with our smart phone Echo app.  It is so easy to just tell Alexa what to add to our shopping list and then check items off the list as we pick them up at the stores.It's also fun to fool around with Alexa and sometimes get surprised.  The other day, just goofing around I said, "Alexa, open the pod bay doors." , and she replied, "I'm sorry, Dave, I can't do that."  My wife and I were almost literally rolling on the floor laughing.  There are all these little surprises that continue to delight us. And Amazon is planning to evolve this platform by adding new capabilities.  We're looking forward to seeing what happens.If you have read Ray Kurzweil's book The Singularity is Near, you will recognize Echo as being on the leading edge of a technological advance that has been and will continue to grow at an increasingly exponential rate.  When I was a kid, we had to go to the library to look things up in the encyclopedia.  More recently, all we had to do was type our questions into a search engine like Google.  Now we can just ask Google, or Siri or Alexa as technology continues to augment human intelligence.This is not to say that the current iteration of Echo is equivalent to Siri, for example, in terms of information; it's definitely not.  But it is very good at finding and playing music, podcasts, spelling words, getting simple facts from Wikipedia, etc., and occasionally wowing us with the unexpected response like "Sorry, Dave, I can't do that."  But we feel like this isn't just about it as it is at this moment but rather about the process it is part of and where that process will take us.So I think if you look at it in those terms, you will have fun and enjoy it; not focusing upon what it currently is not, but rather upon what it is, and more importantly what it will be.My wife's comment on the review is (1) I forgot to mention the "Alexa: set timer" function which she and I now rely upon when cooking, and (2) that she considers this among the best purchases we've made since we got our turbo hot air Oyama oven.  What can I say; she's always right:)

I'm using this in a converted Presto PopLite popcorn popper that I now use for coffee roasting.  The temperature range and build quality of this device are just what I needed!!  It is a bit slower in response than our other, similar device, but I think that is due to the sturdier probe.
We installed this easily to replace our older Broan unit.  Inexpensive, attractive, and performs well.

This is just what we were looking for to switch between our Amazon Fire Stick and our DVD player which we are operating on the same HDMI input to our Sony Audio/Video Receiver.  Simple and works great.  We don't have to swap cables anymore

I had an older keyboard style Kindle for years and it came up missing.  We looked everywhere for it and figured I'd lost in while traveling.  So I finally decided to pick up this new Kindle.  I really like its size and light weight, and I think the screen has higher contrast and is easier for me to read.  So about a week after receiving it, guess what?  I found the older Kindle in the zippered pocket in a bag, right where I'd put it.  So now I have two.  I have a case for the older one with a light, so I use that at home in bed.  I'll be taking the newer one with me when I travel for its form factor.  I love how all my content is linked together so I can read on my cell phone, computer, or either Kindle.  (PS.... we LOVE our Echo too, Alexa is becoming a member of the family.
Odorless and works well on my wife's hair which is otherwise frizzy.

We placed these in halls, bedrooms and kitchen.  They illuminate a good size area when your eyes adjust to the dark, turn on and off automatically depending upon ambient light levels, and the direction of light can be changed in 360 degrees by swiveling so that the light doesn't shine directly into your eyes (which would perhaps reduce your overall night vision)  The LED should require minimal electricity, generate very little heat, and last a long time.  If you wanted one to operate continuously, you could put a piece of tape over the small optical sensor window.  We will probably pick up another pack.  Sure beats stumbling into things if you have to get up during the night and also turning on harsh lighting after your eyes are adjusted to the dark.  If you are one of those people who needs the bedroom to be totally dark, you wouldn't want one of these there.

Note the size before you buy to see if these are right for your intended use.  That said, I used them in an indoor range at 25 feet with a .38 and had no difficulty in spotting locations of hits.  If you were shooting long range handgun with a bench-rest, I think these would also be of use in combination with a spotting scope.  They also make a nice record for future reference.

I have several 3.7VDC Li-ion, and AA and AAA Ni-MH to recharge.  Now I can mix and match any combo with the smart cell sensing capability of this unit.  Only restrictions: Above two, Ni-Cd, and IMR ONLY; don't charge a single AAA or 10440 all by itself; and if you are only doing two cells, use ports 1,3 or 2,4, not adjacent ports.  Built in overcharge protection and automatically knows when to stop, trickle, etc.
Our favorite album of theirs and was automatically added to my Amazon music account so we can request any or all from Alexa on Amazon Echo.

Forgot my Fluke VOM was in amp mode and "checked the voltage" across a 120VAC receptacle. Local hardware stores only had slow acting fuses, and I opted for this because if I made this mistake once, it could happen again and the meter is expensive.  Exact duplicate for what was in there.

Works just as I'd hoped.  I fill it with 16 oz of black coffee heated to around 185F at around 6 am each morning and it stays hot throughout the morning hours. Seems to be well constructed, the cap seals well and with one turn counter-clockwise makes a good pour spout, following the pour lines on the top, into the insulated cap.  Perfect size for me since 16 oz each morning is my limit.
works great. great price for 2 pair. fits over my glasses.

It was free, and I guess you get what you pay for. But I feel this brochure could have been written by someone with no direct experience with the Echo.  It was quite honestly a waste of time, sorry to say; but that's my honest view.

The film was thought provoking in that we must be vigilant these days regarding ulterior motives in the "health" professions, sickness professions according to the perspective of the film makers.  As someone who suffered a ruptured disk at the hands of a chiropractor, though, (requiring painful surgery to avoid permanent nerve damage), chiropractic isn't a perfect alternative.  The best alternative, perhaps, is to find a physician you can establish a trustful relationship with, one who you feel is your advocate, and one who is not too fanatic when it comes to at least considering alternatives with an open mind.  So, in conclusion, I think the movie serves to disrupt the mindless trust and confidence many have in doctors and the pharmaceutical industry these days and at least get us to think a bit for ourselves instead of just (literally) swallowing whatever we're told blindly.
Like many series for TV, this one went off the deep end, just much more quickly than most.  Not sufficient to snag me into watching more than the first few episodes.
I've used this for the last 30 years and I'm glad to see it's still available.  Best preservative for storage there is, as far as I am concerned.
This works as expected although the tube holds less than our last birdfeeder.  It's very well made of excellent materials.
A little goes a long way!  I use this for firearms and it is slick!
Very easy replacement, great video guide by the supplier (totally unexpected), worked like a charm!  We are totally satisfied.

The belt fits my extended waste line requirements, the compartments slide along the belt to position as needed, the bottom is coated with water-resistant rubber and the whole design is ideal for holding shot shells for trap shooting which is why I bought it.  However, I also discovered that it is quite useful in my hobby of photography as well to hold and allow quick access to various gear when I am doing nature photography with one camera body; much more better in that regard than a dedicated camera bag.

We use this lid on a number of 9" diameter cake pans in our Oyama convection oven.  The convection oven tends to dry things out and this lid enables us to keep that from happening and at the same time keep an eye on the progress of roasting things like carrots, onions, chicken etc.

Used this to shoot trap with my 12 gauge Mav 88 this past week and barely noticed the recoil; I mean I had to actually try to recall it later.  I will never be without one of these again.  Glad I paid attention to the reviews.

I would rate this eight stars if I could.  We got it a few days ago, connected it to the open BluerayDisk HDMI port on our Sony AV Receiver (works perfectly on Video 2 on the TV directly too), and we now have access to Amazon Prime videos, our Netflix subscription, Pandora and a whole lot more, and since it's on our receiver, it all goes through the 7 speaker surround sound as well.We downloaded the free app to our android smart phones and can now access control from the phones as well as from the wireless remote included.  Plus, from the phones we can pull down and say a word or phrase and the system recognizes that and present us with a menu of choices based upon what we say.We have a simple dsl internet connection, relatively slow speed, and we have watched a number of movies and internet TV programs with no delays whatsoever, and we've been listening to Pandora music on the surround sound system much of this afternoon without any problems.  I was concerned that our internet wouldn't be fast enough, but no problem; system works great!This device has already truly transformed our use of the TV / Home theater system; we are finding that we are using the Fire TV Stick 2 - 3 times as much as we are other options such as Direct TV programs and media options, DVD's, etc.  For both music and video entertainment, this device provides such a wide array of options it's hard to beat, and I think we haven't even scratched the surface of its capabilities.If you get one and have an android phone, definitely get the Fire TV app download.Just another step on the path on the road to singularity :)  Thanks, Amazon !!!

In combination with a Kuissential burr grinder (reviewed separately by me on Amazon), this Bodum press makes the perfect cup of coffee every time. It makes two regular cups; one for me and one for my wife; and we enjoy the process of making it and the time we sit together and talk each morning while making and enjoying it.  We are also now exploring various offerings from a local coffee roaster in Geneva, IL. Freshgroundroast dot com.  Great stuff!The purchase of these two items; the Bodum Chambord 17 oz maker, and the Kuissential burr grinder (operated with a cordless screwdriver as explained in my separate review of that item), has made a big change in our time together each morning and a our start of each day.  You'd be surprised how great a basic coffee like Eight O-clock Original beans can taste when freshly ground and brewed with this system.We were concerned about clean-up, but it's so easy. After the four minute extraction time, before plunging, I remove the floating grounds with a couple of table spoons into a paper towel in a small stainless bowl.  Then we press the coffee, pour it off and enjoy.  Later, after removing the plunger and pushing the few grinds on it into the paper towel, I use the plastic spoon to help dump the grounds in the beaker bottom out into it as well.  I just gather up the paper towel, put it in the kitchen trash can, and rinse off the plunger, the beaker, and the spoons in the sink. Done. Much easier than cleaning the Mr. Coffee 4 cup drip coffee maker which is now history.

We received our Kuissential mill yesterday and also an e-mail from the company with some helpful instructions.  Most importantly for us, they explain how to achieve the best settings of grind for your application.  You tighten the slotted wheel to draw the bottom, conical ceramic fully in contact with the fixed upper ceramic.
